fields.headline: Greta Gynt
fields.standfirst: Norwegian siren who brought glamour to postwar British films
fields.trailText: Greta Gynt, who has died aged 83, appeared regularly as a femme fatale, British style, in a number of mostly forgotten programme fillers of the postwar years - although she herself is remembered.
fields.body:
It was said that nobody deliberately went to see British B-films in the 1940s and 1950s, because they formed part of a double feature at the local cinema, where audiences had paid to see the latest Hollywood movie. However, while waiting for the main picture, filmgoers were often distracted by a comely, blue-eyed and blonde actress attempting to bring some sex and glamour into unsexy unglamorous films.

Greta Gynt, who has died aged 83, appeared regularly as a femme fatale, British style, in a number of mostly forgotten programme fillers of the postwar years - although she herself is remembered.

In 1951, for instance, she made an off-screen splash on two occasions. The first was at the 8th Army Alamein reunion at the Royal Albert Hall, when she put her arms around Field Marshal Montgomery and gave him a big kiss; the photograph went round the world. The following month, her picture was widely seen when she turned up to meet the Queen, at the royal command film performance, wearing a silver lamé strapless gown, with silver hair, silver osprey feathers and a silver fox coat.

Gynt was born Margrethe Woxholt in Oslo, and first came to Britain at the age of three with her engineer father, who worked for Vickers Armstrong. Her mother, a costume designer, encouraged her daughter to become an actress (Greta herself sometimes made her own costumes for films). Educated at a convent in Norway, she and her mother returned to England in 1936, where, having changed her name to Gynt after Ibsen's Peer Gynt, she got a few small stage parts. Then J Arthur Rank put her under contract, with the vain idea of making her into a British Jean Harlow.

One of her first screen appearances was (briefly) in a Hollywood movie, The Road Back (1937), James Whale's so-so sequel to All Quiet On The Western Front. However, she was first noticed in The Arsenal Stadium Mystery (1939), in which she played the mistress - and chief suspect - of a murdered footballer. In the same year, she was one of evil doctor Bela Lugosi's victims in The Human Monster, based on an Edgar Wallace story. She would later appear in two more films adapted from Wallace, The Calendar (1948) and The Ringer (1952).

In the wartime propaganda picture Tomorrow We Live (1942), Gynt played a French patriot who risks her life by becoming the mistress of a German commander to get information about U-boats, and in Mr Emmanuel (1945), she portrayed a German cabaret singer. She was often seen singing (with her own voice) in nightclubs, as, for instance, in Easy Money (1948).

Gynt was the cause of smoothie Dennis Price's death in Dear Murderer (1947), when her husband (Eric Portman) killed Price in order to pin the murder on another of her lovers, and in Mr Perrin And Mr Traill (1948), she played a school matron with whom two rival teachers (David Farrar and Marius Goring) were in love.

As a contrast to such melodramas, she was amusing as Penelope Toop, the former actress who had become a vicar's wife, in See How They Run (1955), based on the popular farce by Philip King. Now nearing 40, she might have found a new vocation in comedy had she pursued this vein of pictures. But it was not to be: "I'm utterly bored with this femme fatale business," she announced, before retiring to become a housewife.

Gynt was married four times, her last husband being Frederick Moore, a plastic surgeon, who died in 1983. For the last decade of her life, she lived in a beautifully- furnished Mayfair flat as Mrs Moore, although she was once pointed out to me as the former film star Greta Gynt.

A few years ago, I was taken to lunch by an Argentinian film director at the Connaught hotel. When an elegant and handsome elderly woman settled at the next table, I told my host who she was. He got extremely excited, and went up and kissed her hands, saying that she was still very popular in Argentina, where minor British films, considered exotic, had become something of a cult. She was absolutely delighted, and invited us to join her for lunch. She seemed to glow more brightly than she was allowed in any of her films.

She is survived by a son from her third marriage. Greta Gynt (Margrethe Woxholt), actress, born November 15 1916; died April 2 2000

fields.headline: The best outback scene
fields.standfirst: Holy Smoke
fields.trailText: Holy Smoke.
fields.body:
Australia. Cult deprogrammer PJ Waters (Harvey Keitel) deposits Ruth (Kate Winslet) outside the shack where, for the next week, he will attempt to convince her to return to her family.

"This is a complete waste of time," Ruth grimaces. "You're never going to break me."

"That's fine", Waters smiles. "I didn't expect it to be easy. You're an intelligent lady with strong convictions. It would be a little disappointing if it were too quick."

"There's no way I can even listen to someone like you, who dyes their hair. I've made up my mind."

"So, you've made up your mind."

"That's right."

"And how, may I ask, did that happen?"

Ruth begins to twist her prayer beads.

"What?"

"How did you do it? Did you make your mind solid like a brick? Always the same, rain or shine, nothing gets through? If I were to say to you 'Don't think of pink butterflies', you don't, right? Or do you?"

Ruth snorts derisively.

"I'm not thinking about pink butterflies."

"You just mentioned them. You see, the mind is a riddle. It's not a servant. I'm not the one who will bring you truth, your own mind will. It will seek the truth. 'And the truth will set you free' - John 9, 32."

Ruth scowls at her captor.

"I've already heard the truth."

See also: Walkabout, Mad Max, Picnic At Hanging Rock

Don't see also: Razorback

Pointless trivia: Between 1982 and 1993, Harvey Keitel was married to actress Lorraine Bracco, who can now be seen as Dr Melfi in The Sopranos

fields.headline: Chelsea  3 - 1 Barcelona
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Chelsea: De Goey, Ferrer, Desailly, Thome, Babayaro, Petrescu, Wise, Deschamps, Morris, Flo, Zola. Subs: Cudicini, Hogh, Poyet, Sutton, Di Matteo, Lambourde, Harley.

Barcelona: Hesp, Puyol, Abelardo, F. De Boer, Bogarde, Gabri, Xavi, Cocu, Figo, Kluivert, Rivaldo. Subs: Arnau, Reiziger, Dehu, Guardiola, Litmanen, Dani, Simao. Referee: Markus Merk (Germany)

This match represents the most important fixture ever staged at Stamford Bridge as Chelsea face Barcelona, the team widely regarded as favourites to win the Champions League. Luis van Gaal's side ooze class, as well as ex-patriot Dutchmen, and Chelsea will do well to deny them a valuable away goal.

1 Barcelona kick off and both teams immediately indulge in some close tackling in an attempt to assert some early authority.
2 Chelsea concede a free-kick after Babayaro nicks the heels of Figo but Barcelona are unable to capitlise.
3 Ferrer, Babayaro and Flo work the ball around in midfield but the move breaks down as Barcelona get back in numbers.
5 The early minutes have shown Barcelona seeking to attack on the break while Chelsea attempt to build from midfield. On balance, Barcelona are seeing more of the ball.
7 Chelsea's chance to threaten as Wise gets involved for the first time when he releases Babayaro deep on the left. Two Chelsea throws later, Wise puts in a probing cross but Barcelona clear.
9 Wise and Gabri become entangled in the centre circle and for half a second the referee thinks about reaching for a card, when he could have let play continue.
10 A lot of to-and-fro in midfield as both teams seek to establish a rhythm and cut down on the scrappy early tackling.
13 Reports that Barcelona's back line may be their weak spot appear to be unfounded as Puyol, Abelardo and F De Boer nip keep things tight.
15 The game coms alive. Barcelona win a free-kick just over 20 yards out after Deschamps is harshly adjudged to have brought down Figo. Rivaldo takes and blasts through the wall to force a flying save from De Goey. The loose ball is fired back into the six-yard box by Rivaldo but Kluivert is somehow unable to get a touch. Gabri behind him makes the most of his unlikely chance and forces a fine save from De Goey at the near post.
16 Chelsea counter with Zola breaking down the right. Barcelona are caught exposed as he centres for Morris but the latter cannot get in a clean shot and the ball bobbles towards Barcelona 'keeper Hesp.
20 Chance get another whiff of a chance as Flo finds Zola through the middle. Zola shimmies a little before shooting wide of the left-hand upright.
22 Intense action in the Chelsea penalty area as a sustained bout of head tennis keeps De Goey dancing on the spot.
23 Chelsea win a free-kick to the right of the Barcelona area. Zola takes but the ball drifts over everyone. The return by Thome wins a corner from which Desailly almost scores with a lunging header in the six-yard box. Hesp keeps out with a fine reaction save. Great chance for the home side.
27 Figo makes good ground on the right and gets the best of Desailly, but his cross is poor.
30 Goal: Chelsea 1 - 0 Barcelona Babayaro wins a corner on the left. Wise takes and in the process of clearing the ball, Figo handles just outside of the area, is duely booked, and concedes a free-kick in dangerous territory. Flo takes and curls the ball past the ball and in to the top left corner of the net.
32 De Goey is almost caught out when a speculative long-distance shot by Rivaldo arrives like a cross and only just clears the far post.
34 Goal: Chelsea 2 - 0 Barcelona Chelsea win a corner. Wise takes but the ball is cleared. Thome drills the ball back in from 30 yards towards Zola running into the area. Zola looks up and lays the ball off for Flo to tap in from close range. Stamford Bridge rubs its eyes in disbelief.
37 Barcelona win a free-kick 30 yards out after Deschamps brings down Figo. Rivaldo's blistering effort beats the wall and clears the bar by inches.
38 Goal: Chelsea 3 - 0 Barcelona What is going on? Deschamps immediately redeems himself with a hoof into the air from deep in the Chelsea half. He finds Flo in space up front and the Norwegian lobs Hesp from just outside the Barcelona area. Vialli, restrained until now, goes bananas on the bench.
43 Barcelona's eagerness to aquit themselves on English soil appears undiminished after their 10-minute hammering. The Spanish side will be acutely aware that an away goal would give them every chance of overturning the deficit at home.
45 Rivaldo, tucked in just over half-way line, continues to take on the Chelsea defence and feed balls into the area, but nothing goes. Half-time.

46 Substitution Litmanen on for Puyol. Chelsea show no signs of letting up on the tempo of the first half.
47 Booking Zola, for diving over the legs of De Boer in the Barcelona area.
50 Booking Cocu, for clattering into the face of Morris. No clear chances for either side so far. Chelsea, not surprisingly, decide to sit back for a few minutes and soak up the pressure.
53 Barcelona keen to spread the ball wide for Figo on the right rather than rely so heavily on Rivaldo going through the middle.
54 Wise gets away from Figo and releases Zola on the left. The Italian is tackled just outside the area but wisely refuses to go down for what looked like a foul.
55 Figo continuing to probe ever wider on the right in his search for space and the perfect crossing position.
61 Kluivert gets away from Desailly just outside the Chelsea area as Rivaldo attempts to play him in from the left, but Desailly recovers to clear.
63 Barcelona win a corner on the left and Kluivert gets up well on the edge of the six-yard box but his header fails to find the net.
64 Goal: Chelsea 3 - 1 Barcelona Barcelona get the vital away goal. Figo drops back into midfield and with a short pass finds Rivaldo, who in turn spreads the ball wide to Cocu. Figo, continuing his run, picks up the return almost immediately and slots the ball past De Goey at the far post with apparent ease. Some whimpers of applause from the crowd.
68 Chelsea starting to look at little ragged as Barcelona take control with some neat passing.
70 Dodgy moment for Chelsea as Rivaldo and Figo combine again to release Kluivert on the right edge of the area - his shot is wide.
71 A Rivaldo rocket shot from all of 30 yards has De Goey fumbling on the ground, but Thome is on hand to clear.
72 Substitutions Di Matteo on for Petrescu, Dani on for Kluivert.
74 Flo, on a hat-trick, gets away on the right and beats Abelardo with ease, but the Norwegian loses fluffs it and skews his shot yards wide of the far post.
76 Figo moves out to the right again and fires in a cross to Dani, alone in the six-yard box bar three Chelsea defenders. Dani beaten by shear numbers.
78 Chelsea win a corner. Wise takes from the left and plays it short to Zola. He gets away to the byline but his cross fails to find anyone.
82 Zola takes a free-kick from wide on the left, but the ball falls into what must have been the only space in the six-yard box and Barcelona clear. Barcelona immediately counter with a break. Figo charges off through the middle, passes to Gabri on the overlap, picks up the return and then makes a complete mess of his shot by spooning the ball into the crowd.
87 Substitution Sutton on for Flo.
88 Wise concedes a free-kick 40 yards out; Rivaldo takes, but drills it against the wall.
89 Some sharp one-touch passing by Di Matteo, Sutton and Morris in midfield ends with Zola running into space on the right near the byline, but he is unable to get in a shot and puts behind.
90 Three minutes of extra time to play. The game finally appears to have hit a low point as the Stamford Bridge faithful warm up for a celebration. The last chance falls to Barcelona when Rivaldo whips in a cross to Dani, but his effort fails to test De Goey. Full-time. Chelsea 3 - 1 Barcelona. Top result for Chelsea, but Barcelona will fancy themselves to get the required result in two weeks' time.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sharon Campbell, 28 IT consultant
fields.body:
Sharon Campbell, 28 IT consultant

I travelled around Australia for 18 months and learned a lot that I applied to work. When you're hitching a lift with dubious characters in the Outback, you learn how to handle people. You learn patience and the fact that you can have bad days even when you are doing exactly what you want. When I had my first interview for a career job after travelling, I was asked if I would go away again and said yes. I got the job because my boss thought I could achieve in six months what would take other people years. Everyone else had asked about the perks, while I asked about the potentials of the business. I had a fresh approach and a questioning mind that came about through travelling.

Bob Alagh, 26 communications officer

I went to Thailand for two years. I had planned just to travel but ended up teaching English in a refugee camp for eight months. When I came back, I did voluntary work to get back into the swing of things. When I finally went for an interview for a career job, I made sure that the panel knew what kind of travelling I had done. I pointed out that I had worked, that I had gone for a "life experience" and that I had thrown myself into the country's culture. The person who interviewed me had never travelled, and he could easily have presumed that I'd just been dossing around for a year. A lot of people go away just to get smashed every night, so it was important that I pointed out I hadn't just been a backpacker.

Caroline Larsson, 38 solicitor

Travelling literally changes your life and you've got to assess before you leave how it will affect your career. I gave up my job in the City as a solicitor with no illusions that I was closing a few doors, but when I came back I was still surprised by snooty attitudes. Several city agencies said they couldn't help me because I'd taken time out and that travelling was "unacceptable". I did a management course for graduates which got my feet back on the ground and used my contacts in law. I thought about what I really wanted to do, decided on Legal Aid work and got a job through a friend after five months. I get a lot more job satisfaction now and don't regret a thing.

Anthony Jeffries, 36 production manager

When I started work I applied to large organisations as I wanted to travel. I've been away three times and when I came back the third time I saw my last job advertised, applied and got it. If you are enthusiastic and good at your job, and if you give your bosses plenty of notice before you leave, they are more likely to offer you a position when you come back. You can't work your way up a firm as quickly, but the alternative is lying on your CV, which is never a good idea.

Jenny Adams, 29 PR consultant

I've gone travelling twice, and the first time I came back I took a high-powered job which I hated. I was working with people who had never travelled and seemed small-minded, and after six months I went away again. When I came back the second time I thought really hard about my mindset. I felt creative and inspired so applied for a job in arts PR. I didn't have much experience but got the job. Much later, I asked my boss why she'd employed me. She said it was because I'd typed my CV on yellow paper and wore a bright-coloured shirt! I suppose I was enthusiastic and willing to stick my neck out. I love my job, and think that risk-taking mindset you get when you come back from travelling is worth exploiting.

I pointed out that I had worked, that I had gone for a "life experience" and that I had thrown myself into the country's culture. The person who interviewed me had never travelled, and he could easily have presumed that I'd just been dossing around for a year. A lot of people go away just to get smashed every night, so it was important that I pointed out I hadn't just been a backpacker. Caroline Larsson, 38 solicitor Travelling literally changes your life and you've got to assess before you leave how it will affect your career. I gave up my job in the City as a solicitor with no illusions that I was closing a few doors, but when I came back I was still surprised by snooty attitudes. Several city agencies said they couldn't help me because I'd taken time out and that travelling was "unacceptable". I did a management course for graduates which got my feet back on the ground and used my contacts in law. I thought about what I really wanted to do, decided on Legal Aid work and got a job through a friend after five months. I get a lot more job satisfaction now and don't regret a thing. Anthony Jeffries, 36 production manager When I started work I applied to large organisations as I wanted to travel. I've been away three times and when I came back the third time I saw my last job advertised, applied and got it. If you are enthusiastic and good at your job, and if you give your bosses plenty of notice before you leave, they are more likely to offer you a position when you come back. You can't work your way up a firm as quickly, but the alternative is lying on your CV, which is never a good idea. Jenny Adams, 29 PR consultant I've gone travelling twice, and the first time I came back I took a high-powered job which I hated. I was working with people who had never travelled and seemed small-minded, and after six months I went away again. When I came back the second time I thought really hard about my mindset. I felt creative and inspired so applied for a job in arts PR. I didn't have much experience but got the job. Much later, I asked my boss why she'd employed me. She said it was because I'd typed my CV on yellow paper and wore a bright-coloured shirt! I suppose I was enthusiastic and willing to stick my neck out. I love my job, and think that risk-taking mindset you get when you come back from travelling is worth exploiting.

fields.headline: Driving ambition
fields.standfirst:
So Greg Dyke has decided to ditch the BBC chauffeurs. Esther Addley asks how the ultimate status symbol became a bit of an embarrassment
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: So Greg Dyke has decided to ditch the BBC chauffeurs. Esther Addley asks how the ultimate status symbol became a bit of an embarrassment.
fields.body:
Pity the poor fat cats at the BBC. While most of the embattled corporation's 22,000 workers have greeted the arrival of new director general Greg Dyke like a long lost son, the 11 members of the Beeb's executive committee may be feeling less enthusiastic. This week, they learned that their entitlement to a chauffeur-driven car to work is to end. (They may be allowed to keep the additional company car they are given for personal use, but only "on basis of need".) It's all very well giving extra money for new programmes, but how's a chap to get in from Banbury in the mornings?

Dyke may be directing millions at programme-making and slashing the Beeb's notoriously bloated strategy department, but it is the top brass losing their chauffeurs that has cornered the headlines. There is something in the image of a fat cat brought low - preferably reduced to strap-hanging on the Victoria line - to raise a cheer from anyone whose daily journey is spent with their face in someone else's armpit. New boy Dyke, nothing if not a populist, wants to give us what we like. "It won't save much money in the scheme of things," he conceded, "but it is an important issue in terms of the way it looks." Whether the DG's concern for appearances extends to sacrificing his own chauffeur-driven Jaguar remains to be seen.

It is perhaps surprising that Dyke's predecessor John Birt (chauffeur-driven Rover, wife behind the wheel of a BBC-funded 4x4) didn't recognise his vulnerability to unfavourable press in failing to display similar restraint. It's all very well for top dogs at billion-pound operations in the City to demand chauffeurs as part of their package. "Everyone from chairmen and vice presidents to bankers, lawyers and investors," does it, according to international chauffeuring firm Brunel Carriages. But public servants can't very well be seen to be ferrying their staff around in Rollers with uniformed lackeys scuttling to open doors and doff caps at every turn. Just ask John Prescott. It doesn't matter how good you may be at your work - or indeed whether your job is the second most important in the country - how many vehicles you need to get there is crucial if you want to at least appear to be in touch with your roots.

Enter Ken Livingstone, official Man of the People. Despite recently being outed as a man of substantial means thanks to his extra-curricular speaking engagements, Livingstone insists on taking the Tube at every opportunity, preferably with a photographer in tow. If he is elected mayor, he says, neither he nor any GLA members will have access to chauffeur-driven vehicles or even a pool of cars. "Nobody in London would pay any attention to the Mayor droning on about using public transport if they are being swished around in a chauffeur-driven car," he has said.

Similarly, we don't any longer hear Steven Norris talking about the "dreadful human beings" he has to sit beside on trains, as he did to the commons select committee on the environment, now he is himself seeking election. Public transport is now, if not to be embraced, at least to be supported publicly at every opportunity, even if that means having to use it from time to time. Martin McGuinness made a point of declining the chauffeur-driven car to which he was entitled while (briefly) minister for education in the Northern Irish assembly. And first for the chop under Neil Kinnock's reforms of the "gravy train" European parliament? Free travel and chauffeur-driven cars.

It's a tough job driving toffs around when they decide they want to show restraint. Being a chauffeur is a profession akin to sword swallowing at a time of corporate cutbacks - the smallest movement from above is likely to mean the chop. "Chauffeurs are always the first people to be made redundant when a company decides to slim down," says Katherine Shields, manager of Staff of Distinction, an international domestic staff agency specialising in chauffeurs. She currently has 500 chauffeurs on her books looking for positions with a corporate or private client. And the number of employers currently seeking drivers? "Um, around five."

The number of chauffeurs kicking their heels while waiting for work may be a surprise, since it is not a job many would envy. "You need to have an understanding wife," concedes Shields. "I'm never interested in candidates who say they are not prepared to be flexible." Her definition of flexibility? "You might pick up a company chairman from an address in Buckinghamshire or Hertfordshire at 5.30am, drive the directors to meetings or lunch appointments during the day, and then drive the chairman home again in the evening. There can be a lot of hanging around, which many people wouldn't like. You can drop your client off to a business meeting or a business lunch and then have to wait two, three, four hours."

The company also supplies "handymen-chauffeurs" to private clients, who may be called on to do odd jobs around the house during the day. "They would maybe run the wife to Peter Jones and take the kids to school and pick them up again." A posh version of the school run, in other words, but in a peaked cap.

Despite the long hours and silly threads, however, there is no shortage of those wanting to sign up for the job. Rolls Royce/Bentley has run a chauffeur instruction school for half a century, and there is currently a five-month waiting list for the £1,000 course. "There is certainly still a need for them," says Steve Tomlinson, the course trainer. "The main reason nowadays that people have chauffeurs is so they can conduct their business on the way to work. I would guess 60% of the work done by some people in London is done in the back of a car on the way to meetings. Rolls Royce cars are almost like mini-offices, you can hold meetings in the back of our cars."

Which almost makes a fat cat's chauffeur, if not his best friend, perhaps his PA. "It's crucial you get on," says Shields. "You spend a lot of time with this person. One candidate became so close to his employer, he was given his Mercedes when his boss was relocated to the US. They have to have a special relationship." Very generous, although it pales compared to the gesture of Steven Norris, who valued his government chauffeur so much he hired him when he lost his post in 1997 and put him in charge of the company fleet in his new role at the Road Haulage Association. More recently he has described his former chauffeur as his "right-hand man" in his campaign to be mayor.

So pity the poor fat cats of the BBC. Not only reduced to scanning the timetables of Thames Trains, but suddenly bereft of their most reliable, deferential and discreet companions. No doubt the remaining 22,000 at the Beeb, not to mention the nation's licence-payers, will weep for them.

webTitle: IBM and KPN Qwest build cybercentre net

fields.headline: IBM and KPN Qwest build cybercentre net
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: IBM and KPN Qwest intend to open a network of 18 cybercentres in Europe in order to tap into the e-business services market, which is expected to worth almost £33bn by 2003.
fields.body:
IBM and KPN Qwest intend to open a network of 18 cybercentres in Europe in order to tap into the e-business services market, which is expected to worth almost £33bn by 2003.

KPN Qwest and IBM are aiming to capture just under 10% of the e-business services market in the next few years, building up a client base in the "tens of thousands".

KPN Qwest's fibre-optic network will provide the spine for the cybercentres while IBM will deliver the information technology and sales force to meet client needs.

Internet service providers and companies of all sizes will be targeted as users of the cybercentres which will act like telephone "call centres".

The services will range from managing and operating customer computer servers in the cybercentres, to hosting complex websites and building new network-based applications for larger customers.

An initial six centres are expected to be completed by the end of this year, located in Frankfurt, Paris, Munich, Stockholm, Milan, and London. It follows a similar deal between IBM and Qwest in the United States, Mexico and Canada, where both companies also intend to develop a network of cybercentres.

Jack McMaster, KPN Qwest's chief executive, said: "This initiative demonstrates that the predicted convergence of next generation network and information technology services is happening in Europe.

"The combination of IBM's industry-leading information technology services and KPN Qwest's modern fibre-optic network and cybercentres will accelerate the ability for Europe's businesses to offer improved services and e-commerce solutions."

IBM will become the anchor tenant, taking 25% of the space in each of the centres. KPN Qwest will also pay IBM £600m to build the centres.

Frank Kern, general manager of professional services for IBM Global Services, said: "The e-business hosting and business to business network services market in Europe is exploding, and is expected to be worth €55bn by 2003."

fields.headline: Death is not academic
fields.standfirst:
Wit
Vaudeville Theatre, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Wit
Vaudeville Theatre, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
A year ago Margaret Edson's Wit struck me as one of the few substantial American plays in New York. And even if, on a second viewing, a few caveats creep in, it is a provocative and eloquent play. It boasts a superlative performance from Kathleen Chalfant as an American academic in a cherry-red cap confronting death with whatever stoicism she can muster.

Dr Bearing is a formidable Donne scholar diagnosed as having metastatic ovarian cancer. Subjected to a rigorous, eight-month treatment that will advance cancer research, she finds roles reversed - from being the teacher, she becomes the taught; where once she anatomised poetic language, she finds her body is the subject of endless tests, probes and analyses. As an expert on Donne's Holy Sonnets confronted by mortality, she finds that simplicity and kindness are of more value than scholarly cerebration.

At the play's heart lies a witty metaphysical conceit: the notion of a parallel between textual criticism and medical science, in which the demands of research take precedence over human considerations.

It is an idea which Edson pursues unflinchingly, so that the young doctor attending the heroine is as heedless of her final requests as she was of undergraduate needs.

While the parallel is seductive, it is also suspect. Edson is forced to show Dr Bearing as a friendless solitary - as if academic brilliance precluded human contact. And having shown a Stoppard-like delight in the excitement of practical criticism, the play ends up adopting a faintly anti-intellectual stance in which brains and niceness are mutually exclusive.

However, Chalfant's magnetic performance transcends any qualms about the thesis. She makes you believe in the heroine's beaky toughness in the lecture hall, as she also captures, with beautiful precision, an increasing realisation that death is a reality rather than a literary concept.

It is a compassionate and moving performance reminding us of the hollow defences we erect against mortality.

Leigh Silverman's production and Myung Hee Cho's design, with its sleekly sliding white curtains, is a model of efficiency, while Malcolm Tierney as a god-like consultant and Jaye Griffiths as a kindly nurse lend dignity to a play that asks us to confront matters of life and death.

 Until June 25. Box office 0171 836 9987

fields.headline: Men of few words
fields.standfirst:
Godspeed You Black Emperor!
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Godspeed You Black Emperor!
Royal Festival Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
No one could have predicted it, but after decades of being derided, political music has become fashionable again. Released within weeks of each other, Primal Scream's ferocious Exterminator and Asian Dub Foundation's equally furious Community Music have proved that music can be innovative, energetic and exciting while talking passionately, if sometimes somewhat over-emphatically or incoherently, about politics.

Canadian ensemble Godspeed You Black Emperor! are also a deeply political band, but their work almost erases a vital component of political music: words. The band numbers three guitarists, two bassists, two drummers, a violinist and a cellist but no singer; they rarely agree to be interviewed; the vinyl copy of their debut album, f#a# (infinity), offers no song titles.

When words do appear they tend to belong to others: BBF3, from last year's Slow Riot for New Zero Kanada EP, set visceral music to a recording of a man Godspeed met on the street in Rhode Island, ranting about how "America is a third world country".

Carefully applied, these few words can carry more weight then an album full of vitriol ever could. When Godspeed play BBF3 to close their set, it is quite frightening: the sound crashes down like thunderbolts while the man enumerates the guns in his arsenal. Another scratchy tape unravels a sermon about giving yourself up to God.

Godspeed themselves are more fragile and ingenuous than these extremist sentiments suggest. They begin with drummer Dave, in a rare verbose moment, dedicating the evening to "quiet refusals... to imminent market collapse... to secretaries, alcoholics and schizophrenics". Projected onto the wall, the word "Hope" flickers. It returns at the end, accompanied by the phrase "Freedom can be achieved".

In between, the music is exhilarating, churning with paranoia, reeling with ideals, while jittery films of council estates, desolate landscapes, barbed wire and police cars flash past.

The crescendos are breathtaking but there is subtlety too: poor sound renders the violin a reedy scrape, but the guitars are stunning, falling from the cacophony into simple, sighing chords.

Stand away from it all and you might fall into cynicism. Godspeed know that, but counter it with a disarming lightness. Another film features a smiling dog sniffing the camera.

Heavily delayed on their route in to London from Dublin, Godspeed arrived at the Festival Hall about 20 minutes before their set was supposed to finish. They appeared more flustered by the appearance of the building than their lateness: "A sort of culture can be built here," Dave said, before looking around him. "Well, maybe not in this building."

 Godspeed You Black Emperor! play Planet K, Manchester (0161-832 1111), tonight, then tour

fields.headline: Eddie George 'powerless to help' manufacturers
fields.standfirst: Bank of England offers little hope on exchange rate
fields.trailText: Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, yesterday acknowledged that the strong pound was putting manufacturers under "unmanageable and excessive" pressure but said he was powerless to help.
fields.body:
Eddie George, governor of the Bank of England, yesterday acknowledged that the strong pound was putting manufacturers under "unmanageable and excessive" pressure but said he was powerless to help.

In a robust defence of the Bank's interest rate policy, Mr George said there were some firms that could do more to help themselves by improving productivity - but added this was not true of all businesses.

"I think the pressures they are bearing currently with the strength of the exchange rate goes beyond manageable pressure in a general sense. There are some sectors which are experiencing what I regard as excessive pressure," the governor told business people.

"The question for me, sympathise as I do, is what the hell can we do about it, and I'm afraid the hard-hearted answer is not an awful lot."

The governor was addressing delegates at the annual conference of the British Chambers of Commerce in London on the eve of the Bank's monthly interest rate meeting, which ends at lunchtime on Thursday.

Mr George's views were echoed by Gordon Brown who told the Treasury select committee that any action to depress the level of the pound against the euro would run the risk of blowing the economy off course.

"I appreciate the concerns of exporters, but they themselves would say that the last thing they want the government to do would be to put at risk the stability of the economy by pushing us back to boom bust. That's not something we are going to do."

Mr Brown, who praised manufacturers for increasing productivity by 0.5 per cent last year, said the stop-go policies of the past had destroyed more than two million jobs in manufacturing, compared to the 150,000 or so lost in the last few years. Although most economists expect the strength of sterling, at present worth more than DM3.20 to persuade the monetory policy committee to leave borrowing costs on hold at 6%, some believe accelerating earnings growth and the extra public spending announced in the Budget may trigger another quarter-point increase.

Mr George also pointed out that the strong pound was the flip side of having a weak euro. "I don't think one can realistically argue that we should consciously put the economy as a whole at risk of excess demand pressure and accelerating inflation in order to try to bring about a weakening of sterling against the euro."

Absolving the European Central Bank of any blame for the euro's weakness, Mr George said it was due to exaggerated perceptions in financial markets of euroland's structural weaknesses.

The governor was addressing delegates at the annual conference of the British Chambers of Commerce in London on the eve of the Bank's monthly interest rate meeting, which ends at lunchtime on Thursday. Mr George's views were echoed by Gordon Brown who told the Treasury select committee that any action to depress the level of the pound against the euro would run the risk of blowing the economy off course. "I appreciate the concerns of exporters, but they themselves would say that the last thing they want the government to do would be to put at risk the stability of the economy by pushing us back to boom bust. That's not something we are going to do." Mr Brown, who praised manufacturers for increasing productivity by 0.5 per cent last year, said the stop-go policies of the past had destroyed more than two million jobs in manufacturing, compared to the 150,000 or so lost in the last few years. Although most economists expect the strength of sterling, at present worth more than DM3.20 to persuade the monetory policy committee to leave borrowing costs on hold at 6%, some believe accelerating earnings growth and the extra public spending announced in the Budget may trigger another quarter-point increase. Mr George also pointed out that the strong pound was the flip side of having a weak euro. "I don't think one can realistically argue that we should consciously put the economy as a whole at risk of excess demand pressure and accelerating inflation in order to try to bring about a weakening of sterling against the euro." Absolving the European Central Bank of any blame for the euro's weakness, Mr George said it was due to exaggerated perceptions in financial markets of euroland's structural weaknesses.

fields.headline: Gates appeals to common sense
fields.standfirst: Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft's founder, Bill Gates, who led the company's efforts to reach a settlement with the government in its anti-monopolies trial, returned to the attack yesterday.
fields.body:
Microsoft's founder, Bill Gates, who led the company's efforts to reach a settlement with the government in its anti-monopolies trial, returned to the attack yesterday.

In comments made after Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled that the world's largest software company had broken anti-monopolies laws, Mr Gates said that the ruling would not lead to a break-up of the company.

"I don't think any kind of extreme remedy such as a break-up is at all consistent with what the court put forward," he said. "Common sense stands on our side."

Mr Gates, who stood down from the day-to-day running of the business in January, has made few forthright comments on the case since the judge delivered his first negative ruling in November. But since settlement talks broke down over the weekend and the judge delivered his almost entirely negative verdict on Monday, Mr Gates has turned to criticising the government's position.

"The principle at the centre of this case is very important for the economy. The lack of [government] regulation of the software industry has been key to its success to date," he said.

This argument flies in the face of the verdict handed out by Judge Jackson. In his historic decision, the judge found that Microsoft violated the law by using anti-competitive means to maintain its stranglehold on the personal computer industry and to prevent competition in the fledgling internet browser market.

The European commission has stepped up its own investigation into Microsoft and the ruling has given sustenance to more than 100 private lawsuits already filed against the company in the US.

Wall Street analysts, most of whom are still supportive of Microsoft, yesterday suggested that the uncertainty would continue to hit the group's share price.

After falling 15% on Monday, the company's shares were down a further $2 yesterday at about $88 as the technology sector continued to be hit by falling confidence. The Seattle-based company has already said that it will appeal against the eventual remedy decreed by Judge Jackson.

Even the expedited appeal asked for by the company is likely to take six to 12 months. During such time, the company expects the software market to change even more significantly.

Brad Smith, a senior lawyer for the company, said after the ruling: "At bottom, this is a case about our decision to integrate the internet into Windows."

He indicated that all software would soon include an ability to link to the internet.

Andrew Roskill, industry analyst at Warburg Dillon Read, the investment bank, agrees with Microsoft. "The whole case has been ridiculously moot," he said. "The entire market has already changed."

But the judge has ruled that Microsoft's bundling of its browser with Windows, which is used on more than 90% of the world's personal computers, broke laws designed to curb monopolistic power.

In spite of this week's bravado, Microsoft executives do admit to having made mistakes. Mr Smith said on Monday night: "We have already learned a lot - about our responsibility as a corporate citizen, about our responsibility as a business partner."

fields.headline: Idlewild
fields.standfirst:
**
Leeds Metropolitan University
fields.trailText:
**
Leeds Metropolitan University
fields.body:
Somewhere there must be a factory churning out bands for the sole use of student unions. Like Ned's, the Wonder Stuff and the Frank & Walters before them, Idlewild's tunes reek of cider and green-laced Dr Martens. The snogging, though, is a new thing. Where middle-aged ladies throw their knickers at Tom Jones, Idlewild's barely post-pubescent audience indulge in an orgy of slurping that could cripple the National Health. One couple in particular are so thoroughly lost in French kiss-induced stupefaction that I spend the entire gig worrying whether a slip of the tongue will land awkwardly on my ear. Hasn't anyone taught them about germs?

The snogging abates when Idlewild come on and people start pogoing, but then the pogoers start snogging in mid-air and I'm even more terrified. I long to escape by losing myself in the music, but trying to achieve reverie in this cider rock is like trying to waltz through a brick wall. At their worst (which is most of the time), these scrubbed-up boys produce an Identikit indie gruel, the great Nirvana via the awful Bush.

And yet, somewhere there is hope. The group are already straining to escape the brief shelf-life of the "student band". Their intense eyes betray ambition, and occasionally their tunes match it with a stirring resonance reminiscent of Murmur-era REM, the Undertones and That Petrol Emotion. It may be their third album before they deliver anything approaching a masterpiece, but a few years back, the definitive snoggers' band was Simply Red. This, people, is progress.

 At Wulfren Hall, Wolverhampton (01902 552121), tonight, then touring.

webTitle: Near panic as investors rush to sell dot.coms

fields.headline: Near panic as investors rush to sell dot.coms
fields.standfirst:
Pursuit of Microsoft not the cause, says White House

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The rush by hordes of private investors to reduce their exposure to over-inflated internet and technology companies threatened to turn into a stampede yesterday, triggering a slump of more than 12% at one stage on the Nasdaq index in New York and a fall of almost 9% on London's Techmark index of growth companies.
fields.byline: Paul Murphy  and  Jane Martinson  in New York
fields.body:
The rush by hordes of private investors to reduce their exposure to over-inflated internet and technology companies threatened to turn into a stampede yesterday, triggering a slump of more than 12% at one stage on the Nasdaq index in New York and a fall of almost 9% on London's Techmark index of growth companies.

Stockbrokers reported near panic among clients, with many unable to deal as share prices gyrated wildly and computer systems threatened to collapse. Having soared by almost a quarter over the past three months, America's technology-heavy Nasdaq index was trading back below the 4000 level at which it began the year, while the Techmark has fallen by a third from its peak two weeks ago, prompting claims that the public's five-month love affair with stock market speculation, fuelled by the growth of online share trading in Britain, is coming to a sticky end.

In an acceleration of the trend that has developed over the past two weeks, investors were shifting funds out of the technology, media and telecoms sectors back into "old economy" companies such as retailers and drinks companies. "People are watching their paper wealth disappear," said the head of dealing at one private client stockbroker. "They are trying to lock in what profits they still have and in the process the market mechanism is threatening to break down. It has been very ugly today."

Investors' nerves began to crack two weeks ago when Barron's, the respected US financial newspaper, published a detailed analysis questioning whether many new dot.com companies, spending heavily on advertising in order to establish new brands, would soon run out of cash. The air of nervousness in the markets was reinforced last week when Abbey Cohen, the top equity strategist at American investment bank Goldman Sachs, declared that share valuations had become over-stretched and investors should reduce their exposure to equities.

This week the atmosphere among investors was one of crisis, triggered by the declaration that Microsoft has been unlawfully maintaining its monopoly by "anti-competitive means".

In a marked departure from earlier "corrections" in internet-related share prices, private investors have avoided rushing in to buy shares which have fallen, a phenomenon know as "buying on the dips".

Justin Urquhart Stewart, director at Barclays Stockbrokers, said: "There aren't people coming in. There aren't bottom fishers. It is alarming."

He pointed out that ordinary market players would be feeling most of the pain because institutional investors had largely avoided heavy exposure to tech stocks. However, while there were no signs yet of buying at the lower levels, the "rush for the door" was not pronounced. "It's knocked the top off the market," he added.

On Wall Street, fears were growing last night that the extent of the sell-off had been exacerbated by private speculators who had borrowed heavily to bet on the direction of the market and were now scrambling to unwind their positions.

Andrew Roskill, e-commerce analyst at Warburg Dillon Read, said: "What worries me more than anything else is that this market has been driven by individual traders over the last six months, with a lot of them doing things on margin."

The White House warned against predictions of an economic plunge and dismissed charges the administration's pursuit of the Microsoft anti-trust case was to blame. "I do not think that one should judge the strength of the fundamentals of our economy based on the movement of the market over a one-day or even a one-month period," said White House economic adviser Gene Sperling.

fields.headline: No time like the present
fields.standfirst:
Moment
Dundee Contemporary Arts
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Moment
Dundee Contemporary Arts
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Time is not an easy theme for an exhibition. It impinges on a daily, hourly, basis on all our lives, yet the narrative or artistic reflections it inspires can be dry, dusty, dull. But not in this smart and assured show, which explores time as a fluid, almost fantastical space - a moment out of life that can last as long as you want it to.

A film projection by Marijke van Warmerdam exemplifies this indulgent, endearing mood. Five jets pass overhead, leaving streams of energy and lines of smoke against dreamily blue skies, and it's like a moment recalled from childhood in its beauty and simplicity. As film it's clunky, deliberately amateurish stuff, all whirring equipment. But the whirring works as an imaginary echo of the planes soaring above - one looks into the film as if into a deep and lovely pool and, crucially, loses all track of time.

The same is true of Igor and Svetlana Kopystiansky's film Incidents, which is, knowingly, a load of rubbish. Following various bits of trash along New York's streets, it has an illogical loveliness (a pipe is entangled with the tape from a cassette; a broken umbrella flaps in the wind). Its tone is quite sarcastic too, as it follows its starlets - a carrier bag, a takeaway carton. They open up their secret selves to us and we begin the chase, discovering along the way that some discarded objects make better performers than others.

Graham Gussin's video projection Remembering and Forgetting at the Same Time captures some social performers (people leaving a cinema) unawares. This is the stuff of mundane moments, shown in footage played back and forwards, with much checking of watches, doing up of coats, glancing about. It's dreary and captivating at the same time, an all too familiar ennui suddenly making compulsive viewing.

Moment plays with that oscillation - between boredom and fascination - throughout, as in Emese Benczur's daily embroidery of clothing tape with the same phrase. It's about the future (there are new reels of tape and cotton stacked up) and about the accumulation of what has been and what may be. But ultimately, like the rest of the exhibition, it's about the depth and resonance, the possibilities of this moment, now.

 Until 20 May. Details: 01382 432000

fields.headline: Desk therapist
fields.standfirst:
We showed psychologist Donna Dawson the desk of popular philosopher Alain de Botton
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: We showed psychologist Donna Dawson the desk of popular philosopher Alain de Botton.
fields.body:
This desk conveys an impression of nervous energy: the computer screen, keyboard and telephone are pushed to one side, to make room for a creative space in which to write. This person hovers over the desk - not just because the chair is pushed so far back, but because of the Post-It notes taped to the wall (you have to stand to read them!).

Everything on this desk is slightly off-centre, which suggests a person who is quite independent, a person who doesn't take advice easily.

The overall colour scheme (black with splashes of red) and the startling flexi-lamp suggest a person who appears serious and self-contained, but who also has a wacky side.

This is a person who likes to surprise others, who won't be pigeonholed. I guess that this desk owner is a man. He likes to think of himself as stylish, although at times he can be quite unaware of how he comes across socially. In fact, he's not really bothered about what others think of him, and he enjoys his own company. However, the Post-It notes used as wall decoration are telling: quirky, slightly rebellious, and a bit self-absorbed.

Did our expert get it right?

Alain de Botton responds:

The analysis is spookily accurate. I am definitely self-contained outside, more unconventional inside. I do enjoy my own company. The only quibble is that I never hover.

 Alain de Botton's The Consolations of Philosophy is published by Hamish Hamilton

webTitle: Labour accused in rural banks row

fields.headline: Labour accused in rural banks row
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report
Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The row over rural banks intensified last night as the government's strategy to save rural communities from mass closures was heavily criticised in an internal Post Office paper that accused ministers of using bogus figures to justify closing down smaller post offices.
fields.body:
The row over rural banks intensified last night as the government's strategy to save rural communities from mass closures was heavily criticised in an internal Post Office paper that accused ministers of using bogus figures to justify closing down smaller post offices.

Meanwhile, Barclays Bank hit back at the environment minister Chris Mullin for his "irresponsible" behaviour in advocating a boycott in protest at its plans to close 172 rural outlets.

Ministerial colleagues moved quickly to distance themselves from Mr Mullin's remarks, revealed in yesterday's Guardian. A spokeswoman for Barclays said it was "extremely disappointing" for a member of the government to have made such comments.

But Mr Mullin won backing last night from his ministerial colleague Lord Whitty, who told the House of Lords: "It is of course open to customers of Barclays who are disgruntled by what seems to be a bit of a cavalier disregard of rural interests to change their bankers."

The Conservative leader, William Hague, aware that bank and post office closures are a huge political issue in the countryside, condemned the Barclays plan as outrageous - but he also criticised Mr Mullin for urging a boycott, saying that it was a futile call since millions of customers would ignore it.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, refused to condemn Mr Mullin's comments, made to MPs on two separate occasions last month. The junior minister had told MPs that the most effective way for customers to stop the closures was to vote with their feet and leave Barclays.

Mr Byers told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "Chris has made his own personal view very clear and it is only right that he is able to do that, but the government's view is that it is for individuals to make these decisions themselves." A spokeswoman for Barclays said: "We are extremely disappointed at Chris Mullin's irresponsible remarks. Customers are changing the way they bank and we need to respond quickly in a competitive world."

The row came as an internal Post Office paper expressed "deep disappointment" at the government's refusal to give financial support for the Post Office's bid to run key government services. The memo reveals that the Post Office is privately pressing the government to delay the introduction of automated benefit payments into bank accounts, a move estimated to deprive some local post offices of more than 50% of their income.

The memo, dated March 3 and written for Stuart Sweetman, the Post Office's group managing director for customer and banking services, challenges the government's presentation of the savings to be made by moving to automated credit transfer (ACT). Ministers, including Tony Blair, have claimed that introducing ACT will save £400m, since it costs taxpayers only 1p per transaction.

But the Post Office paper says the 1p figure ignores other costs, including "the cost of physically getting £50bn in cash to the banks and post offices which will in due course pay benefits in cash via bank accounts, the cost of setting up bank accounts for benefit claimants, the cost of running bank accounts which are used to pay benefits".

Alan Johnson, the industry minister, hit back. He told the Guardian: "We are pursuing a big idea. We think the post offices can also take on the people the banks don't want - the socially disadvantaged, pensioners who don't trust banks or cash machines."

He accepted that poor people were not attractive or profitable customers to the high street banks, but claimed that a new computerised post office counter network, if it worked, "would tackle the problem of social exclusion, allow the government to meet its commitment to continue to pay pensioners in cash and provide new areas of work for the Post Office".

webTitle: Bradford & Bingley chief's pay rises by half to £654,000

fields.headline: Bradford & Bingley chief's pay rises by half to £654,000
fields.trailText: The chief executive of the Bradford & Bingley building society saw his pay leap 48% last year - provoking criticism that directors were giving themselves bank-style salaries before members had given their verdict on plans to demutualise later this year.
fields.body:
The chief executive of the Bradford & Bingley building society saw his pay leap 48% last year - provoking criticism that directors were giving themselves bank-style salaries before members had given their verdict on plans to demutualise later this year.

Christopher Rodrigues picked up £654,048 in 1999, up from £441,743 in the previous year, according to the annual report and accounts for the country's second largest building society.

The revelation is certain to raise eyebrows among some of the members voting on whether he should be re-elected to the board.

It comes days after it was revealed that Barclays' chairman, Sir Peter Middleton, received a four-fold increase in pay last year while its new chief executive, Matt Barrett, picked up £1.3m for three months' work.

Mr Rodrigues' 1999 pay package includes a total of £266,667 in "short and medium term performance remuneration" on top of his £360,000 salary.

A society spokesman defended the increase, saying his pay was "commensurate with running a £24bn business," and adding that because it was not a PLC, Mr Rodrigues does not get any share options. "We are a major organisation and not just a small mutual building society."

News of the sharp increase comes less than two weeks before Bradford & Bingley's annual general meeting in Bradford on April 18, at which there are six candidates standing in the directors' election to fill the five vacancies on the board.

Mr Rodrigues is one of five official candidates seeking re-election, but he could face a challenge from Philip Crozier, a 45-year-old accountant hoping to win a seat. Mr Crozier, who was nominated by 50 members to stand in the election, said it was an ideal time for an "ordinary member" to be elected. Members are currently voting by post, and all votes must be returned to the scrutineers by April 14.

Bob Goodall, co-ordinator of the Save Our Building Societies campaign group, which opposes Bradford & Bingley's planned flotation, said: "It appears that Christopher Rodrigues has already awarded himself a PLC-level salary before the members of B&B have had a chance to vote on whether to convert to a bank."

A special general meeting to vote on conversion is expected to take place in July and, provided the go-ahead is given, the society is set to float on the stock market in December.

Bradford & Bingley has announced a "flat" share distribution scheme which means that most members will receive the same size windfall, regardless of the size of their investment. Payouts were initially estimated at £1,000 but some analysts say the figure is more likely to be £600-£800.

fields.headline: Ferguson prepares to counter
fields.standfirst: Giggs the only doubt as United plan to catch Real on the break
fields.trailText: Ryan Giggs is the only doubt as United aim to teach Real, the original masters of Europe, how to win the Champions League. As David Lacey reports, current form suggests there can be only one winner.
fields.body:
As a youngster with Queen's Park Alex Ferguson was one of 127,000 spellbound spectators at Hampden in the spring of 1960 when Real Madrid beat Eintracht Frankfurt 7-3 in a European Cup final widely regarded as the best football match ever played.

"After that game," Ferguson recalled yesterday, "Scottish football changed its attitudes towards football management. Scott Symon was running Rangers with just a secretary for assistance. From then on there was a greater emphasis on tracksuit managers." Not before time, it would appear, seeing that Eintracht had reached that final by scoring a dozen times against Rangers.

Yet within seven years Jock Stein's Celtic had become the first British club to win the European Cup, followed by Manchester United the next season after they had overcome Real Madrid in the semi-finals.

Now United are in the Spanish capital with much of football believing that they are about to teach Real, the original masters of Europe, how to succeed in the Champions League. As the teams prepare to meet at the Bernabeu this evening in the opening leg of their quarter-final it is a tempting proposition.

Consider the facts. United are 10 points clear at the top of the Premiership, in a race involving one thoroughbred horse. Real Madrid, by contrast, are riderless mounts in the Spanish league, eight points off the lead and struggling to fill one of the top three places to give themselves even a chance of returning to this competition next season.

On Saturday United beat West Ham 7-1 but Real struggled to draw 1-1 with faltering Sociedad and would have lost but for seven exceptional saves by their 19-year-old goalkeeper Iker Casillas.

For United, therefore, the situation seems sublime. Yet this is Real Madrid we are talking about and a team, moreover, which tonight will be able to call on the combined talents of Raul, Fernando Morientes, now recovered from injury, Fernando Redondo, Roberto Carlos and, yes, Steve McManaman as they attempt to set United a stiff task in the second leg.

If Ferguson's players reproduce a performance to compare with their airy dismissal of Fiorentina at Old Trafford three weeks ago, United should achieve the sort of result they need but Real's coach Vicente del Bosque is convinced that United, on their recent away form in Europe, are beatable.

"I watched United lose 2-0 to Fiorentina in Florence and they didn't play well," he said. "I saw them draw in Valencia and win in Bordeaux but still they didn't play well. I expect United to play the way they normally play. There will be nothing new. We have to go forward and put them under as much pressure as we can."

Such an approach would suit United, whose game is based on swift counter-attacks. Ryan Giggs, said by Ferguson to be doubtful because of a recurring hamstring problem, is nevertheless expected to play provided there is no reaction to last night's training session.

"We want to make sure our midfield is very tight so as not to give Real space," Ferguson explained. "We will use this as a base to catch them on the counter-attack. We hope our present form will be the deciding factor for us. Paul Scholes is having a great season and the two strikers [Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole] have found their best form at the right time."

Tonight's referee, the Frenchman Gilles Veissière, refused Inter at least one obvious penalty when United played at the San Siro last season. Given the form of David Beckham and Scholes, the authority of Roy Keane and the scoring potential of Cole and Yorke, Real and their leaky defence may need better luck with such decisions if the European champions are to lose.

Real Madrid (probable, 4-4-2): Casillas; Salgado, Ivan Campo, Karanka, Roberto Carlos; McManaman, Redondo, Helguera, Savio; Raul, Morientes.

Manchester United (probable, 4-4-2): Bosnich; G Neville, Berg, Stam, Irwin; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Cole, Yorke.

Referee: G Veissière (France).

webTitle: Bunglers enter the hall of fame

fields.headline: Bunglers enter the hall of fame
fields.trailText: Dean Holdsworth's consolation prize for his FA Cup semi-final howler will be to join a select band who have achieved immortlity through their errors.
fields.body:
Poor Dean Holdsworth. One has to feel sorry for the man. Ever since the Bolton striker left Griffin Park embarrassment has followed doggedly in his footsteps like a wolf trailing a wounded caribou.

Kiss-and-tell revelations in the tabloids, his wife Samantha singing You're So Vain on television and now that Wembley miss.There is a grain of comfort for Holdsworth, however. Fame is said to be a fickle mistress which perhaps explains why she sometimes tells the victor she has a headache and invites the defeated into her boudoir instead.

Sunday's high-profile mistake could see the unhappy Wanderer getting just such an unexpected call and joining that select band of sportsmen and women who have achieved immortality through error.

People such as Scott Norwood of the Buffalo Bills whose last-second field goal attempt in the 1991 Super Bowl drifted wide, ensuring that his name would live on long after those of many of the winning New York Giants have faded from memory, or the French golfer Jan van de Velde whose camel-like instinct for finding water during last year's British Open raised his public profile more dramatically than any amount of solid performances on the European circuit.

As he leafs through the match analysis of Sunday's game the former Wimbledon forward's consolation must be that, while practically everyone in Britain has heard of Devon Loch, only a few can remember the name of the horse that beat him.

Not that any old case of abject bungling is enough to bring sporting renown. If it was, the pantheon of immortals would be as chock-full of names as Mike Reed's notebook.

Milan's Daniele Massaro, for example, conclusively proved the importance of supply and demand in the equation with his performance against Marseille in the 1993 European Cup final. Paying the price for wearing silly-coloured boots, the Italian striker produced a cluster of the worst misses seen in one place since the closure of St Trinian's. Anyone of them might have had Massaro spoken of in the same hushed tones as Geoff Thomas. Their ubiquity, however, left them tragically devalued.

As Holdsworth relives the moment when his stiff-legged swish sent the ball arcing over the Aston Villa bar, he should occasionally mutter the name "Gordon Smith" to himself. Smith, as hardly anybody will need reminding, was the Brighton forward whose botching of an easy chance in the last minute of extra-time in the 1983 FA Cup final cost the Seagulls victory over Manchester United. That the Scotsman had put his side ahead in the first half of the match, played in six cup finals with Rangers and scored the winner for them against Celtic in the Scottish League Cup final of 1978 are high points overshadowed by that monumental miss.

He might think too of Wakefield Trinity's goal-kicking prop Don Fox. The 1968 rugby league Challenge Cup final between Trinity and Leeds took place on a Wembley pitch that so resembled a paddy field the two teams played in constant fear of slips and handling errors.

In the dying moments, with Leeds leading 11-7, Ken Hirst touched down for Wakefield to bring it back to 11-10 and give Fox the glory of winning the game with his conversion. The kick from straight in front of the posts looked simple but Fox sliced it. "He must wish the ground would swallow him up," Eddie Waring intoned after watching the kicker fall flat on his face with a splash afterwards. Instead time has raised Fox on to a pedestal. Sometimes in sport nothing succeeds like a mess.

fields.headline: Ricard gives Boro fizz
fields.trailText: George Graham has spent much of this season complaining that a shortage of strikers has held back his progress. The Spurs manager ought to take a close look at his defence after this disjointed performance. "We want our Tottenham back," chanted the fans.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin  at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
George Graham has spent much of this season complaining that a shortage of strikers has held back his progress. The Spurs manager ought to take a close look at his defence after this disjointed performance. "We want our Tottenham back," chanted the fans.

After going ahead through Chris Armstrong, three errors at the back enabled Middlesbrough to snatch an unexpected win. After Stephen Carr's own-goal, Hamilton Ricard scored twice. David Ginola's late strike provoked the expected pressure but no breakthrough.

George Graham must have had high hopes. Whereas Boro came into this game with nothing but pride to play for, Spurs are still thinking of Europe in terms of football rather than beaches and pina coladas. Sixth place could yet gain them entry to the Uefa Cup.

A repeat of their 7-2 victory over Southampton in their previous game here seemed unlikely, particularly as Boro arrived unbeaten in six matches. But it will not have escaped Graham's attention that Bryan Robson's side had not won away since October, and that at Vicarage Road.

With Juninho dropped to the bench, Robson opted for an adventurous 4-3-3 formation, playing Andy Campbell and Brian Deane either side of Hamilton Ricard.

Boro's approach ensured a quick, open start in which they created the best chances. Ricard turned and shot wide from a Campbell cross. Minutes later Mark Summerbell failed to make the most of a Ricard centre.

Tottenham's passing was far from its best and hard as David Ginola and Willem Korsten tried to make ground down the flanks, there were few dangerous crosses and little end product.

Gradually, though, Spurs improved and when finally they managed a move of genuine quality and pace on the half-hour, they took the lead through Chris Armstrong.

Armstrong began the attack near the halfway line, chesting the ball down and flicking a neat pass to Darren Anderton. And when Anderton's cross was headed down by Steffen Iversen, the striker poked the ball past Mark Schwarzer. So often the target of abuse from Spurs fans in the past, he has now scored six goals in as many matches.

With Anderton a growing influence, that should have been he signal for Spurs to dominate. But within 10 minutes Boro got the equaliser courtesy of an own-goal by Carr. Ricard may have fouled Chris Perry in the build-up but when Deane helped the ball on, Carr diverted it past Ian Walker.

Anderton went close to restoring Tottenham's lead in first-half injury-time but his swerving long-range shot beat Schwarzer only to bounce wide off a post.

After the break it was Boro who surged forward in the driving rain, passing neatly, and Walker was forced low to his left to save a long-range shot from Paul Ince. That, though, seemed to prompt Ginola into action. The Frenchman cut in from the right and curled an excellent left-foot shot towards the far post which Schwarzer stopped at full stretch.

But still Spurs could not manage sustained fluency and pressure and they paid the price when Ricard scored Boro's second in the 64th minute.

Walker was partly at fault, failing to collect Christian Ziege's corner cleanly, and the Colombian pounced on the loose ball to sent a powerful shot through a gaggle of bodies and into the net.

Ginola hit a post, but Boro added a third one minute later, Ricard rising unmarked to head in Ziege's free-kick. When Ginola finally found the net from long range it was too late.

webTitle: Owls may turn to Lord for salvation

fields.headline: Owls may turn to Lord for salvation
fields.trailText: Lord Hattersley said yesterday he would consider offering his services to Sheffield Wednesday if the club's rebel shareholders succeed in their attempt to dislodge the chairman Howard Culley.
fields.body:
Lord Hattersley said yesterday he would consider offering his services to Sheffield Wednesday if the club's rebel shareholders succeed in their attempt to dislodge the chairman Howard Culley.

Only five weeks after replacing Dave Richards, Culley's future at Hillsborough is in doubt with the Owls next to bottom of the Premiership and £12m in debt. The former Labour MP for Birmingham Sparkbrook has emerged as his potential successor.

"I was contacted by Dave Richards once before Christmas and once just after and my attitude is the same now as it was then. He asked me whether I was prepared to consider it and I told him I was," said Hattersley.

"I am not looking for a job but, as a Wednesday-ite for more than 50 years, I would do anything I can to help in this desperate situation."

The Sheffield Wednesday Shareholders' Association are on course to secure the 3.1m voting shares needed to force an extraordinary general meeting of the club at which they would call a vote of no confidence in Culley and the finance director Bob Grierson. Should that happen, Hattersley's supporters will urge him to stand for the chairmanship.

Stan Collymore was making good progress last night after a 48-minute operation at a private hospital in Leicester to insert a plate and eight screws into his left fibula. The Leicester striker suffered a spiral fracture after falling awkwardly during the 3-0 defeat at Derby on Sunday but he expects to make a full recovery by the start of next season.

"It's a nice fracture, if you can call a fracture nice," said the Leicester physio Alan Smith. "He's still in a lot of pain but we expect him to fight his way back to full fitness. He says that he wants to come in as soon as possible to work out a rehabilitation programme."

webTitle: Money talks as Accies make a visit to the bank and call off their strike

fields.headline: Money talks as Accies make a visit to the bank and call off their strike
fields.trailText: The players at Hamilton Academical called off their strike yesterday, allowing tonight's Scottish Second Division match at Alloa Athletic to go ahead.
fields.body:
The players at Hamilton Academical called off their strike yesterday, allowing tonight's Scottish Second Division match at Alloa Athletic to go ahead.

The decision was reached after a three-hour meeting convened with the club apparently on the verge of extinction. The talks came to a bizarre conclusion with the club's secretary Scott Struthers accompanying the players to a local bank where their cheques were cashed.

"I watched the players being paid," he said. "The cheques have been cashed and the match will go ahead."

The Accies' opponents in Saturday's postponed fixture, Stenhousemuir, have called for Hamilton to be relegated. "They have brought the game into disrepute and must be held responsible," said the chairman, Terry Bulloch.

The Germany coach Erich Ribbeck has threatened to drop Jens Jeremies after the Bayern Munich midfielder described the state of the national team as "miserable".

Jeremies, who was expected to feature against England at both Euro 2000 and in qualiciation for the World Cup, said it was "very unlikely" that the holders would retain their title this summer. "Nothing has changed nor improved since the World Cup," he said. "You have to ask yourself why things are not moving."

"If he's got a problem with the state of the team, I will decide whether I should not free him from that problem," added Ribbeck. "We need players who look forward to playing in the national side."
