webTitle: McManaman in mood to jog memories

fields.headline: McManaman in mood to jog memories
fields.standfirst: Real Madrid's former Liverpool forward is looking to kick-start his continental career
fields.trailText: Real Madrid's former Liverpool forward is looking to kick-start his continental career and impress Kevin Keegan when Real meet United tonight.
fields.body:
For Steve McManaman tonight's visit of Manchester United is a chance finally to announce himself to the Real Madrid crowd, even if he would struggle to do so in Spanish.

In the nine months since the former Liverpool forward arrived in the capital he has been fluent neither on nor off the pitch. His grasp of the language has been described as "somewhere between appalling and very bad" and a niggling thigh injury has reduced him to three early league games, cameo appearances in the world club championship and Real's last three matches.

Worse still, he also slipped out of the England reckoning as Real struggled to rectify their worst start to a season for almost three decades.

In the 1-1 draw with lowly Real Sociedad on Saturday Real struggled and, but for their 18-year-old goalkeeper Iker Casillas, would have lost heavily. McManaman was pulled off in the 75th minute with a minor knee problem but is looking forward to playing tonight.

"Sooner or later you're going to have to play the better teams and we're happy to play them now," he said. "Since the turn of the year we've done exceptionally well. We're still in three competitions and that's all you can ask for at this stage."

The 28-year-old lives with his long-standing girlfriend, Victoria, in La Moraleja, a fashionable complex of bungalows and chalets outside the capital and popular with footballers and the jet-set. His widower father and other friends from Liverpool are regular visitors.

Now and again McManaman's picture appears in the papers, usually with friends in the plusher restaurants and nightspots, and he has confessed to a soft spot for jamon serrano , a cured ham. He has also integrated well with team-mates and is on particularly good terms with the France midfielder Christian Karembeu, whose language skills effectively make him the liaison officer for Real's multi-national squad.

Since the 1998 Champions League winners were drawn against the holders, however, the press has beaten a path to the Bootle boy's door and he has gone from being virtually unknown to a valued commentator. In yesterday's edition of the national sports daily Marca he was variously pictured in a policeman's helmet and a bowler hat, opining: "United are more successful because of their qualities as a team rather than as individual players. They are clearly in good form but are not unbeatable ... they allow you to play your own game."

It is also an opportunity to impress the England manager Kevin Keegan, who last picked him in September, the more so as McManaman has tentatively ruled himself out of May's Brazil match as it clashes with the Copa del Rey final. Should Real win their semi-final, that would leave only the Ukraine match later that month to get back for Euro 2000.

"I just have to keep on playing well and hoping I get noticed but Kevin Keegan has not been in touch," he said. "I want to play for my country and I have not given up hope. But at this moment I'm just aiming to do well for Real Madrid and that's what I care about."

He also makes an effort to get on with the right people and is on good terms with the coach Vicente del Bosque at a club he joined on a Bosman at a rate of £54,000 a week but who, he knows, may cash in on their windfall at any moment.

Jose Felix Diaz of Marca sees it thus. "More was expected of him when he was signed and he took a long time to appear because of the injury. But he's gradually finding his way. If he picks up a bit, he should be around for a while more.

"The problem is that Madrid have had such a difficult season that, unless they win the Champions League, they will be looking for scapegoats."

webTitle: Kanu gets the green light to take on Lens

fields.headline: Kanu gets the green light to take on Lens
fields.trailText: Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu has been cleared by Nigeria to play for the Gunners in Thursday's Uefa Cup semi-final first leg against Lens at Highbury.
fields.body:
Arsenal's Nwankwo Kanu has been cleared by Nigeria to play for the Gunners in Thursday's Uefa Cup semi-final first leg against Lens at Highbury.

But mysteriously Chelsea were last night still waiting for a similar green light for their left-back Celestine Babayaro to face Barcelona in the Champions League quarter-final against Barcelona 24 hours earlier.

Both players have been called up by their country for a World Cup qualifier in Eritrea next Sunday and the two clubs feared Nigeria would enforce Fifa's rule which gives countries the right to call up players five clear days before a competitive international match.

Arsenal and Chelsea were at loggerheads with the Nigerian Football Association before and after the African Nations Cup finals in January when Kanu and Babayaro were fined for arriving back late.

But Arsenal confirmed yesterday they have had a fax from the Nigerian FA allowing Kanu to face Lens on Thursday before linking up with his national squad the next day.

It is a relief for the manager Arsène Wenger, who is without his top scorer Thierry Henry for the first-leg after he was sent off in the quarter-finals against Werder Bremen.

Chelsea are apparently still in the dark about Babayaro, who last month was excused duty from an Under-23 international match after the club had consulted Nigeria's sporting envoy John Fashanu, the former Wimbledon, Aston Villa and England striker.

Chelsea's assistant manager Gwyn Williams said last night: "We are still hoping Baba will be free to play against Barcelona but we have heard nothing from Nigeria yet.

"It seems strange because our game is 24 hours earlier than Arsenal's match and we know they have been given the go-ahead to play Kanu." Babayaro looks certain to miss Sunday's FA Cup semi-final against Newcastle.

Meanwhile, Arsenal's Ukrainian defender Oleg Luzhny looks set to escape with a one-match ban for his sending off against Wimbledon on Saturday.

Wimbledon say they have been told that Jason Euell, sent off for a similar offence in the same match, had been reported for denying the opposition a clear goalscoring opportunity, which carries a one-match ban, rather than violent conduct, which would mean missing three matches.

Wenger had been ready to appeal against Luzhny's dismissal which he called "harsh" but an FA spokeswoman said: "Clubs can only appeal against a red card if the offence, as stipulated by the referee, carries an automatic three-match suspension."

webTitle: Mobile firms reject headset cancer claims

fields.headline: Mobile firms reject headset cancer claims
fields.trailText: Mobile phone manufacturers today rejected claims that hands-free headsets channel three times as much radiation into the heads of phone users.
fields.body:
Mobile phone manufacturers today rejected claims that hands-free headsets channel three times as much radiation into the heads of phone users.

The industry expressed surprise at the findings of research commissioned by the Consumers' Association and questioned the test methods. "Tests made by FEI [Federation of the Electronics Industry] members and also at an independent laboratory have without exception shown that the absorption levels produced when using a headset are significantly less than those produced without a headset," said a spokesman for the FEI.

"All mobile phones on the market meet all relevant safety standards and recommendations, with or without an approved headset."

The federation was reacting to reports by Which?, the trading arm of the Consumers' Association, that the earpieces acted like aerials, directing up to three times as much microwave radiation into the brain as a phone held next to the head. The new research also raised fresh doubts on the effectiveness of radiation shields.

The results came from tests on hands-free kits for a Philips Savvy phone sold by BT Cellnet and for an Ericsson A1018S sold at Carphone Warehouse. While the watchdog did not have time to test other kits, it said it believed the results would be similar.

Graeme Jacobs, editor of Which? magazine said: "If you're worried about levels of radiation from your mobile phone, you shouldn't rely on a hands-free set. The two models we tested triple the radiation to your brain, though we still don't know for certain whether that radiation is harmful." Which? also tested phone shields and attachments that claimed to block radiation, but tests revealed they offered limited, if any protection.

Mr Jacobs said there was currently no conclusive evidence that mobile phone radiation caused health problems, including cancer or gene damage, but neither had the fears been discounted.

He added: "International research is ongoing, but until conclusive evidence is available, users could limit their phone use if they are concerned about radiation." The tests also found that older analogue phones tended to emit a higher level of radiation than digital models.

Scientific tests were ordered after medical studies in Britain and overseas suggested that mobile phone radiation is linked to brain tumours, genetic damage and a range of illnesses, including Alzheimer's.

The industry has consistently denied that there is any proof of danger, but many companies and individual users have bought hands-free kits to cut exposure to radiation.

Some 24 million Britons, including 300,000 schoolchildren, now use a mobile phone.

webTitle: Standards inquiry takes on Lords conduct

fields.headline: Standards inquiry takes on Lords conduct
fields.trailText: April 4 2000: Members of the House of Lords may soon be forced to register their business interests, following an inquiry into the conduct of peers that began today.
fields.body:
Members of the House of Lords may soon be forced to register their business interests, following an inquiry into the conduct of peers that began today.

Lord Neill, chairman of the committee on standards in public life, identified the register of members' interests and the code of conduct as the two key areas for scrutiny in a consultation paper published today. He insisted he had "no preconceptions" about what action would be required, but hinted at major change.

"We are an open-minded committee that takes evidence and we form our opinions when we have heard the evidence, but where radicalism is required we are ready to administer it," Lord Neill said.

Lord Neill said his inquiry was vital, because of the Lords' growing role in lawmaking. "The House of Lords now occupies a very important part in the legislative machine," he said. "On at least 10 occasions in the last year, the House of Lords has refused to go along with propositions coming from the Commons - trial by jury is one example."

The Neill inquiry follows last year's removal of 600 hereditary peers from the House of Lords, leaving 92 hereditary peers, 548 life peers and 26 bishops and archbishops. The House of Lords escaped thorough reform after the 1994 "cash for questions " scandals which led to Lord Neill's predecessor, Lord Nolan, proposing strict rules and penalties for MPs who failed to declare their interests.

The Lords at the time set up a mainly voluntary register, only requiring declarations where peers represented lobbying firms or were ministers in the government. Peers also agreed that "Lords should always act on their personal honour and never accept any financial inducement as an incentive or reward for exercising parliamentary influence".

The House of Lords is increasingly dominated by appointed life peers, who have become much more active in overturning controversial government legislation such as the move to scrap section 28, which bans schools from promoting homosexuality. This more active approach by peers is leading to demands for greater scrutiny of their outside interests.

The government's decision to start Lords reform, the appointment last week of a new batch of working peers - including the contentious appointment of Conservative treasurer Michael Ashcroft - and the removal of 600 hereditary peers, have fuelled calls for a fresh look at a code of conduct for the second chamber. Although the government has not announced what it plans to do next, a blueprint for the Lords was unveiled in January by the Royal Commission chaired by former Conservative cabinet minister Lord Wakeham.

Lord Neill said the present transitional period between the abolition of hereditary peers and the establishment of a new reformed second chamber was a good time to look at the rules. He added: "The House is in an interim stage and I think that is a rather good time to have a look at what the rules of conduct should be before a new system of election or appointment is finally established."

fields.headline: Me and Frank
fields.standfirst:
The Guardian's Diarist explains how he fell out with Labour's candidate for Mayor

'Oooh, you amaze me': see the video
fields.trailText: Tuesday, 10.45: Guardian Diarist, Matthew Norman, explains how he fell out with Labour's candidate for Mayor
fields.body:
The story of how Frank Dobson was transformed almost overnight, after decades of useful and well-meaning public service, into British politics' most hilarious clown is a tragic one, and soon after the election on May 4, when the poor old sap is heading disconsolately for the Lords or the chairmanship of a quango, someone must write the article marking it as such. Someone, but not me. There are peaks of hypocrisy which even the newspaper columnist must not attempt to scale.

Since the beginning of his mayoral campaign last autumn, the Guardian Diary has teased Dobbo (or tormented him, as he might put it) with all the lack of mercy due a placeman of Tony Blair's in a rampantly rigged election. It has not, in all truth, been a difficult job, the tone of buffoonery being set from the very start, with Dobbo announcing his entry into the race three weeks after stating on record that he would never run for mayor.

From that moment forth, thanks entirely to its readers' fervour in reporting these things and not one iota to journalistic skill, the Diary led the way on such memorable early cock-ups as the failure to get permission to use the membership lists - "You amaze me!", said Dobbo, when Panorama's John Ware told him the Data Protection Registrar had received no application from him - and the sending of identical "Dear Friend, Vote Dobbo" letters by a dozen London MPs.

When news emerged that Frank was a little down, we inaugurated the Cheer Up Dobbo! campaign, first with a series of vulgar jokes ("Frank's Chuckle") of the kind he is so fond of; and then, more dramatically, with a circus-style show involving jugglers, stilt-walkers and fire-throwers outside his HQ in Camden. A day after this event, a letter of rebuke marked "for publication" arrived from the campaign, pointing out that Frank missed the performance because he was visiting a sick child at the nearby Great Ormond Street hospital ... an ill-judged attempt to make political capital out of human suffering which, like so much else, swiftly backfired. A call to the hospital elicited amazement from a press officer, who had thought that the visit was strictly private, and had received no request to make it public.

Nothing inflames a politician's self-righteous wrath like being caught red-handed in an act of gross political cyncism, and when recently a friend bumped into Dobbo in the green room of a television station, the official Labour candidate for Mayor of London referred to the Guardian Diarist as "that c*** who's trying to ruin my campaign". He's not the first Labour figure to use that word about me (it has long been a favourite of Alastair Campbell's), and I doubt he'll be the last, so I cannot claim that this amazed me.

Even so, flattering as it is, ruining his campaign is something with which Frank Dobson has needed little help. What the Diary has done, perhaps, partly by launching that much-loved catchphrase, is bring an enduring comic character into sharper focus. But as for highlighting the tragedy of Frank Dobson, this, as I say, we must leave to someone else.

fields.headline: Mobile miscommunication
fields.standfirst:
Science correspondent James Meek on the latest phone panic

Mobile firms reject headset cancer claims
fields.trailText: There is no doubt that hands-free kits for mobile phones represent a major  breakthrough in something, but it may not be technology. It used to be that when  you saw someone talking to themselves as they walked down the street you thought  to yourself: "Mm, care in the community, a well-intentioned if poorly  implemented policy." Now any pedestrian muttering to him or herself is assumed  to be juggling an active social life and a successful career.
fields.body:
There is no doubt that hands-free kits for mobile phones represent a major breakthrough in something, but it may not be technology. It used to be that when you saw someone talking to themselves as they walked down the street you thought to yourself: "Mm, care in the community, a well-intentioned if poorly implemented policy." Now any pedestrian muttering to him or herself is assumed to be juggling an active social life and a successful career.

Other than a mask for those who like to hold loud conversations with themselves, however, the hands-free device has always seemed of limited utility - that awkward bobble microphone stotting against your chin, those wires snaking into your jacket. Now the Consumer Association reports that the only other remaining reason to acquire one, to protect your head from the microwave radiation emitted by phones, is invalid.

"Radiation" is a scary word. It conjures up images of Hiroshima and Chernobyl.

But there are many kinds of radiation. Sunlight is radiation, for instance. Just as the lightning dose of radiation you get from an x-ray machine won't do you the same damage as standing close to the site of a nuclear explosion, so there is a world of difference between the potentially cancer-causing effect of tanning in intense sunshine for months on end and a few hours on the beach for a few days a year.

So it is with mobiles. The tiny pulses of microwaves emitted by mobile phones are of the same genre as the radiation used in microwave ovens to heat your frozen meals. It does heat your brain slightly, but if you tried to use your mobile to warm your cup of coffee, you'd be disappointed. There's just not enough power there, and the rise of temperature in the brain is less than you would get from using a hairdryer or, again, sunbathing.

Does that mean using mobiles is harmless? Not necessarily. Despite centuries of research, the human brain is still a little understood, inaccessible organ. There is no firm evidence, of the standards of proof that scientists demand, that mobiles do damage the brain. Yet the mysterious, intricate and delicate workings of our brain cells could be altered in ways we do not yet understand by radiation which is presently considered harmless.

If the uncertainty worries you, try thinking about other ways in which you harm your brain. Alcohol, for instance, is known to damage it. There seems little point in panicking about an occasional imperceptible buzz of microwaves if you are subjecting your brain to regular pickling.

There is another, simpler solution for people concerned about the dangers of mobile phones: stop using them. Heresy? Well, there is a persuasive school of thought among some senior managers in the US that people who use mobile phones are simply failing to manage their time properly. Ten years ago, we did without them. Perhaps we could again.

fields.headline: Hands-free mobiles 'increase radiation risk'
fields.trailText: Hands-free kits for mobile phones do not protect your brain from radiation - on the contrary, they channel three times the dose into the skull that you receive by holding the phone next to your ear, according to the Consumers' Association.
fields.body:
Hands-free kits for mobile phones do not protect your brain from radiation - on the contrary, they channel three times the dose into the skull that you receive by holding the phone next to your ear, according to the Consumers' Association.

A report in this week's Which? magazine will upset those who rushed to buy the devices out of fears for their health. Two of the most popular kits were tested - one from Carphone Warehouse and the other from BT Cellnet. The researchers found the wires leading from the phone into the ear acted like an aerial, conveying a more concentrated dose of radio waves than usual.

Which? acknowledges that nobody knows for certain whether the form of radiation emitted by mobile phones - radio waves which are non-ionising radiation - is harmful to the brain. Exposure to this type of radiation can cause a rise in temperature - although not as much as sunbathing in a Mediterranean summer - which makes your heart work harder and can lead to headaches, sickness and dizziness. Some claim the phones can cause more serious problems, such as tumours, headaches and memory loss. The Department of Health has asked a panel of scientists, the Stuart Commission, to investigate. The Consumers' Association has submitted its findings to the commission.

The national radiological protection board, which sets limits on the amount of radiation mobile phones are permitted to emit, says they do not have enough energy to damage genetic material such as DNA and therefore could not cause cancer. But it sets limits on the grounds that the heating effect of the phones could potentially be a problem.

The Consumers' Association says the findings on the hands-free kits were a surprise. "If you're worried about levels of radiation from your mobile phone, you shouldn't rely on a hands-free set," said Graeme Jacobs, editor of Which? Phone shields, marketed with the express purpose of reducing radiation to the brain, did not work either, he said.

Antonia Chitty, one of the authors of the report, said there was a mismatch between the reasons the companies design hands-free kits and the reasons many people buy them. "Consumers are buying them because they want the protection. Our impression is that companies are developing them to be handy and convenient," she said.

BT Cellnet makes no safety claims about its hands-free kit, says Which? but Carphone Warehouse said that if the user was worried about radiation, an earpiece attachment meant the phone will not be adjacent to your head.

When Carphone Warehouse was confronted about the findings, "the response was pretty disingenuous", says Which? The company said its fact-sheets "simply state the facts - it is a fact that earpieces remove the phone away from the user's head". The company said its revised fact sheet would include the Which? findings.

webTitle: Sanctions teach nothing to Iraqi children

fields.headline: Sanctions teach nothing to Iraqi children
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Going to school in Iraq can be hazardous to your health: exposed cables, broken window panes, unsafe drinking water and no sanitation. Unicef estimates that no more than 45% of schools have even the basic infrastructure needed for teaching to take place. The rest, according to Anupama Rao Singh, the country director for Unicef, "are in appalling physical condition. Some run two or three shifts a day to cope".
fields.body:
Going to school in Iraq can be hazardous to your health: exposed cables, broken window panes, unsafe drinking water and no sanitation. Unicef estimates that no more than 45% of schools have even the basic infrastructure needed for teaching to take place. The rest, according to Anupama Rao Singh, the country director for Unicef, "are in appalling physical condition. Some run two or three shifts a day to cope".

Teachers from the American Friends Service Committee (AFSC) visited al Bakr boys school in Nasriya in April last year. They found 45 students crammed to a classroom, many sitting on the floor and sharing a single textbook. A battered tin can under a dripping tap was the only source of drinking water.

In 1990, says the principal of the neighbouring Jaffa elementary school for girls, each student at al Bakr had a desk and his own textbooks. The classrooms had stoves and fans. All the children received a simple but nutritious meal each day - milk, biscuits, hummus and fresh fruit.

But after 10 years of the sanctions imposed by the UN after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, schools are able neither to renew their physical infrastructure nor to invest in students' health or teachers' well-being.

"We met the al Bakr school head in the afternoon," recalls Peter Lems, an AFSC programme assistant. "He had been out selling cigarettes in the morning because his salary isn't enough".

In 1990 teachers earned around $450 (£281) a month; now they earn as little as $2-$5. Before 1990 Iraq invested heavily in education. According to the UN Development Programme's 1991 human development report, Iraq's combined primary and secondary enrollment ratio for 1989 stood at 75% - higher than the 70% average for all developing countries.

Education was free to university level, and thousands travelled, at state expense, to earn postgraduate degrees in the United States and Europe. Education was perhaps even taken too seriously: during an early literacy campaign, men and women could choose to attend classes or go to jail.

Now, fewer people see the point. "When doctors sell ice cream and teachers drive taxis, people feel education doesn't get you far in the present situation," says Ms Rao Singh.

Children are dropping out in droves to earn money for the family - or to beg. There are higher drop-out rates for girls, who see marriage as offering greater security in a country where once women had begun to achieve parity with men.

In 1988 around 6% of Iraq's budget - $230m - went on education. "Your first impression on visiting Iraq," says Peter Buckland, a Unicef education expert,"is that this sophisticated system was designed on the assumption that plentiful resources were available, and that it has been devastated by the collapse of resources."

By contrast, under the UN oil for food programme established in 1995 to mitigate the impact of sanctions, just $23m has been earmarked for education, and it must all be spent on goods. It is a major constraint and, says Ms Rao Singh, cash is needed for teacher training and physical rehabilitation.

Unicef is using its own money for these purposes. "We've rehabilitated more than 300 schools since 1997, with another 100 planned for this year," Ms Rao Singh says.

"The impact on morale is amazing. Parents start sending their children back to school."

There is a "tremendous sense of guilt" among the professional class, she adds. "They are not able to provide their children with the kind of education they had, and feel helpless to do anything about it."

Today, life-long education is needed to keep abreast of changes in science and technology, and the sanctions have had a devastating effect on fields such as medical science. An AFSC medical delegation which visited Iraq in May last year reported: "Iraqi doctors got their first taste of the intellectual boycott when delivery of their own medical journals and those in their hospital libraries abruptly stopped at the time of the Gulf war."

The US post office manual states: "Due to United States government sanctions, mail pieces sent to Iraq may contain only personal communications". But it is hard to see what threatening military use could be made of some of the categories which have been suspended, such as sheet music.

AFSC applied to the UN last summer for permission to send medical journals to Iraq. The request was routed first to the US treasury and then the state department, and AFSC has only just received the green light. It has now launched a campaign against the "intellectual embargo" of Iraq, seeking funds to send the 15 subscriptions to Iraq's 10 medical schools via Jordan.

Ms Rao Singh says: "Iraq can still manage because it has extremely qualified professionals, but most are in their mid-30s and above. So where are the human resources going to come from in 10 years time?"

webTitle: Never too late in principle, if you can find the cash

fields.headline: Never too late in principle, if you can find the cash
fields.standfirst:
South Africa Literacy groups at odds about value of adult learning

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: There is one thing on which just about everyone involved in adult education in South Africa agrees - as things stand, it is almost a waste of time.
fields.body:
There is one thing on which just about everyone involved in adult education in South Africa agrees - as things stand, it is almost a waste of time.

Some say there is no point in pouring resources into teaching grown men and women to read or pass secondary school exams when the schools are churning out another generation of young people who can barely spell their names.

Others argue that there is some merit in helping adults help themselves, but that in South Africa today the few resources available are being wasted on paying teachers who, when they turn up, are lecturing to virtually empty classes.

"In apartheid days you had 'black night schools' for adults," said Richard McGillvray of Project Literacy, the country's oldest and biggest adult education organisation. "The government has changed the name but they're still around. There are so many 'ghost teachers' on the payroll and many of the real ones don't turn up. Some adult education classes don't even have any pupils. It's pretty laughable."

About a third of black adults in South Africa are functionally illiterate. The government has launched an education initiative called Tirisano (Sotho for "let's work together"), which is strong on combating the problem. The programme has met with a mixed response but even those who praise it say that without resources it is worthless.

"The government has successfully established a good, workable policy but there is the problem of cash. There's a huge gulf between policy and delivery and its name is money," Mr McGillvray said.

Until now, the Catch 22 of adult education in South Africa has been that just about the only way to afford the cost of classes is to have a job, but to get a job you usually have to be literate.

This is particularly true of what is known as the "lost generation", those black people who, as children, failed to attend school after the launch of the schools boycott in 1976 in protest at apartheid education and the use of Afrikaans in the classroom.

To many, they are the true heroes of the struggle against racial oppression for setting in motion the popular unrest which helped force the white government from power. But they have generally benefited least from South Africa's transition to democracy. Only a minority have been able to get jobs, because they lack the formal education and qualifications to compete with school leavers.

Those who do have jobs are anything but secure. "Those people in the struggle generation who did get jobs are fac ing wholesale retrenchment. Those who didn't get jobs aren't going to get them now, because of the glut of school leavers out there," said Mr McGillvray.

Until recently many of South Africa's big companies paid for their less educated workers to attend literacy and secondary school exam classes. Project Literacy ran courses for hundreds of people at a time at state-owned companies such as the phone company, Telkom, and the power company, Eskom.

But with many state enterprises going for wholesale dismissals before privatisation, the classes have been mostly scrapped.

"Last year we had about 60 classes running at Telkom. This year it is just four. The companies are pulling the plug on funding. They don't think it's worth it any more," Mr McGillvray said.

"Our organisation is on the brink. Our adult education centres are funded privately and that cash is drying up. We are facing the choice between cutting back on classes or dismissing valuable staff."

With resources so scarce, organisations promoting literacy are at odds about how the money available should be spent. One of the biggest, Read Educational Trust, argues that it is futile to put cash into adult education when 80% of secondary schools are bereft of books.

"The education minister's thing is adult literacy, sadly," says Cynthia Hugo, Read's director. "The government hasn't thought it through. In a good world, we should not deny anybody the chance to become literate. But if you want to have the most impact then you have to stop illiteracy at the school level otherwise you'll always have an adult literacy problem and will never be able to do more than a patch-up job."

Mr McGillvray agrees up to a point. "Literacy in itself is a waste of money but development education, such as learning about subsistence farming, is invaluable.

"But if you can't read you can't learn about farming, unless you are going to send teachers out to every little community, and the country can't afford that.

"Also, functionally illiterate parents very often have difficulty ensuring their children learn to read. Aids is a huge problem. How do you combat HIV if people can't read the pamphlets? So where do you draw the line? When is someone a has-been, not worth educating, and when is someone a 'developable' person?"

fields.headline: Building tomorrow from today's rubble
fields.standfirst:
Angola War has displaced millions and all but destroyed schooling

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: At the back of the classroom a tiny child, under two, squatted in the dust next to his 10-year-old brother, who was bent over a slate.
fields.body:
At the back of the classroom a tiny child, under two, squatted in the dust next to his 10-year-old brother, who was bent over a slate.

They were taking part in an emergency programme for Angolan children who have missed out on school.

In the camp for displaced people in the coastal town of Benguela there are three such emergency classes in a highly organised programme leading to basic literacy.

The programme is financed by Unicef and the Norwegian government, and classes are limited to 25 children. Teachers across the country follow the same course and are provided with the same materials.

The camp itself is a scene of horror: flies buzz over puddles of foetid black water; women, babies and a few crippled men lie in rubbish or sit hunched over a cooking pot on a smoking bundles of twigs.

The three classes of ragged children, one under a tree, another in the shade of a wall, the third inside, are small oases of order. Each has a young, smartly dressed teacher in front of a blackboard.

The children are refugees from the interior, the central highlands of Huambo and Bie, where last year Unita rebels made yet another attempt to seize control.

Some of the children arrived in Benguela last year. Others fled an earlier wave of fighting in 1993, when - after a UN-monitored election failed - the Unita rebels captured the city of Huambo before being driven out by government forces.

Others arrived in the 1980s when Unita, then backed by the United States and apartheid South Africa, destroyed the rich agriculture of the central highlands, burning villages, laying mines and blowing up bridges.

Three million people, about a quarter of Angola's population, are displaced. Many have been displaced several times, and will never return to the ruined towns and villages of the interior which were once their homes.

"A lost generation has grown up since 1992 - kids who have never been to school, kids who have been only sporadically in school. There is a huge education backlog which needs an emergency plan," said Allan Cain of Development Workshop, a Canadian organisation which has been working in the slums of the capital, Luanda, for nearly 20 years.

War has laid the country to waste in the 25 years since independence in 1975. At that time education was still a priority: the president was a poet, writers and intellectuals dominated the government, and the country was inundated with teachers from Cuba, Vietnam and eastern Europe.

The system began to buckle under the impact of the opening to the market in the late 1980s, when teachers' salaries became worthless. The near collapse came with the new war after 1992 when Unita took over half the country, destroying the infrastructure and forcing the population on to the move

In the past 10 years alone Luanda has grown about two and half times and an estimated 100,000 school-age children have come to the capital. Often separated from their immediate families, they live with extended families who are strained to breaking point by the ruined economy. Thousands live on the streets in gangs, surviving by begging and stealing.

More than half the children of primary school age are not in school; the number of children in school has dropped by about 100,000 since 1990 despite the population increase of 2.9% a year; net enrollment is projected to go down to 40% by 2015; a shortage of classrooms mean that schools are used for three shifts of teaching; the majority of schools are in poor shape, with leaking roofs, no water or sanitation and often no desks or chairs; a shortage of teachers means that class sizes of 80 are normal; less than half the teachers are adequately trained; the failure rate at the national exam after four years of school is over 30%; the poorest children are effectively barred from school registration by fees for chalk, exams, books, uniforms and other costs.

The chronic disorganisation in Angola makes all statistics of doubtful value, but the education crisis is visible on every street and in every school. The state system has been utterly overwhelmed in the past decade.

But the well turned out girls teaching the refugee children in Benguela are symbols of a refusal to be defeated - as is the 20-year-old smiling student teaching in a remote desert village where people's only livelihood comes from making charcoal.

Many of the teachers have lost all their material possessions and many relatives. Their $10 monthly salary does not even cover their transport to work, much less their textbooks, but they are still there, smiling, singing, and repeating numbers in front of a class.

Another group of heroic teachers is at the centre of a quiet revolution emerging in parts of Angola. Adra is a local organisation of former teachers who are horrified by education's loss of prestige since the early years after independence.

"When a soba (chief) explains that people do not want to send their children to school because they see that those who go become politicians or businessmen and are thieves and liars, you know you have got a really fundamental need for change in style, in content and in perception of education," said a leader of Adra.

The scale of the changes needed would deter most people, but Adra's leaders have come through the tradition of struggle of the ruling Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA), and are used to working long term in rural communities for apparently modest gains.

The organisation's president is Fernando Pacheco, an agricultural economist and former MPLA official. One of the group's founders was Lopo de Nascimento, a former prime minister, then secretary-general of the MPLA.

In one of the world's most rigid government systems, such high profile political backing was essential to starting what has become an unofficial support system for government education and an example of what can be changed.

Adra works in three autonomous groups in Benguela, parts of Luanda, and Malange, a city in the north which held out against Unita sieges for months, helping local communities to be self-sufficient with civic education and seminars on rights and justice.

The groups help communities - most often of displaced people - to organise agricultural projects, run seminars for teachers, organise the community, build new classrooms or upgrade old ones, and give land to the teachers to grow food to supplement their wages.

A displaced community outside the coastal town of Catumbela provides an illustration of what can be achieved.

A disused sugar plantation is now the site of thriving communal maize plots. A $2,000 maize-grinding mill started with micro-credit from Adra was so successful that the money was repaid within 18 months. Women and children laugh as they swim in the irrigation canal.

Two schools, the Patrice Lumumba primary school and the People's United school in the centre of Catumbela, have the typical atmosphere of Adra-supported schools. The classrooms are freshly painted and a new health post has been built by parents.

More importantly, every teacher talks about how Adra's monthly seminars with teachers, parents and government officials have meant an end to the feeling of being isolated in an underpaid job, with no real interest from parents or teachers.

"We are in a network now and I believe we can do anything in this school and all our children have a different chance now," said one young teacher.

Adra's communities have stopped waiting for help from anyone else. Instead, they have begun building their own democracy where it matters to them most - with their children. In the slums of Luanda hundreds of local schools have sprung up in churches, or in modest classrooms built by parents.

The teachers, paid by the displaced parents, are usually refugees themselves.

"I will never return to Huambo," said one. "I don't want to see my destroyed house and street, which no one will help me to rebuild. Here is where I have to make a life."

fields.headline: Female trouble
fields.standfirst:
Proof that women academics are paid less than men, especially in areas such as nursing, has forced universities to take action
Natfhe
fields.trailText: Proof that women academics are paid less than men, especially in areas such as nursing, has forced universities to take action
fields.body:
Universities are to set up a special equal opportunities directorate in an effort to crack down on longstanding discrimination against women lecturers and professors.

The move follows the clearest evidence yet that higher education institutions are breaking the law - paying women up to £8,000 less than men for doing the same jobs in the same subjects. The lecturers' union, Natfhe, which today published detailed figures, has threatened legal action.

Even in nursing and paramedical studies - the subject most dominated by women, where 70% of lecturers are female - male lecturers earn £1,558 more on average, and senior male nursing lecturers earn £1,061 more than women in the equivalent posts.

University and college heads hope to set up the proposed equal opportunities office this month and recruit staff in the summer. Ten universities are piloting an advisory service to improve policies and procedures and the sector was serious about taking action, said Howard Newby, president of the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals. "There are historical and structural reasons for the current situation, but this is no excuse and institutional practices must be examined in a serious and committed effort to tackle discrimination."

The 59 women professors of nursing are unique in British higher education in being paid more on average than their male counterparts. A big pay gaps exists in almost all subjects, and at every grade for lecturers and researchers.

Topping the list is anatomy and physiology, with an £8,000 difference in male and female professors' pay, closely followed by veterinary science with a £7,000 gap.

Ministers have been alerted to what the union regards as shocking figures, and next week it will present them to a joint working party of university employers and unions. "The discrimination is even more widespread and deep-rooted than we thought," said Tom Wilson, head of the union's universities department.

Years of discussion and agonising over the issue between staff unions and the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals have failed to make any progress, and in November David Blunkett, the education secretary, expressed his impatience by spelling out in his annual funding letter the need for universities and colleges to tackle discrimination.

Calling for the universities to negotiate national agreements to tackle the issue of equal pay for work of equal value, Wilson said: "Either they get dragged in front of tribunals, or they take action before they are forced to do so by the courts. We are happy to negotiate decent agreements through the national working party to make sure the gap is closed. The evidence is now incontrovertible - they might as well come out with their hands up."

Natfhe's research showed how class-ridden and ossified British higher education remained, said Wilson, who warned that figures on staff from ethnic minorities would show a similarly disturbing pattern. A recent survey of academic economists featured in the Guardian showed black and Asian lecturers were paid less well than their white counterparts.

The latest research, commissioned by the union from the independent Higher Education Statistical Agency, showed that agriculture and forestry heads the lecturers pay-gap table, with a £4,950 difference between women lecturers' pay of £21,742 and male lecturers' pay of £26,692. Yet 20% of agriculture lecturers are women.

There were no significant differences because of age - so the gap was not because men were older and further up the pay scales, said Wilson. "Natfhe's research destroys the myth that unequal pay can be somehow explained away. These figures prove beyond doubt that women are paid less than men they work alongside. The government, funding councils and higher-education employers must urgently act to ensure there is top-level commitment and resources to tackle the problem."

Other women-friendly disciplines still pay men more. The proportion of women staff does not seem to affect the size of the pay gap. For example, subjects with the biggest pay gap, at all grades, are the clinical and veterinary sciences (with more than 20% women) and physics, chemistry and engineering (with around 10% women). But women-friendly subjects pay least.

The research also revealed that, among permanent staff, there are no women professors anywhere in the UK in civil engineering, "other technologies" or central computing, and less than five in the entire country in almost half the other subjects listed - including even such comparatively "women-friendly" subjects as catering, librarianship, and continuing education.

 Natfhe commissioned the research from the independent official Higher Education Statistics Agency (Hesa). All figures relate to 1997/8, the latest data available, and cover all academic staff in the UK. All figures relate to permanent full-time staff. Hesa warns that universities and HE colleges sometimes vary in their classification of staff by grade and subject when making their annual statistical return to Hesa. Natfhe has 66,000 members and is the biggest trade union and professional association for academic staff working in UK universities and colleges.

fields.headline: One false move
fields.standfirst: Pick the wrong university and you can say goodbye to that dream job.  Cliff Pettifor on a new survey that highlights employer prejudice
fields.trailText: Pick the wrong university and you can say goodbye to that dream job. Cliff Pettifor on a new survey that highlights employer prejudice
fields.body:
Ever wondered why Karen, with first-class honours, didn't get that job? Puzzled why that brilliant student you wrote a sparkling reference for wasn't recruited? Couldn't work out why David didn't even get an interview, despite a perfect match for the job description? You might be right to put it down to prejudice, but not right if you're thinking of sexism, racism or ageism. It's likely to be a more insidious form of prejudice, beyond laws and exhortations.

The most recent set of employers' outspoken preferences show that if Karen, the "brilliant student", or David, all business and management graduates, had gone to Manchester instead of "X", had chosen Warwick rather than "Y", or studied at Bath rather than "Z", the jobs could have been theirs. Had they sought careers in electronics, London Imperial, UMIST or Brunel might have done the trick; in social science and economics it could have been Bristol, Oxford or Cambridge.

The 1999/2000 Graduate Recruiters' Surveys confirm that most recruiters act on preferences in the recruitment process. Whether based on sound evidence or ill-founded preconceptions, they matter, and not just in a few cases. Less than one recruiter in five says their rating of a university has "no influence at all" on choice of graduates. University applicants, who hope they will meet one of the 19.8% who don't care which university they go to, do so at their peril.

Sadly, no single league table identifies the "good" universities. Each subject has its own hierarchy. Loughborough heads the table for civil engineering and construction but lies 15th in computing and information technology. Conversely, Cambridge ranks second for computing but 15th equal for civil engineering.

Of course, choice of university depends on more than a simple ranking of employers' votes. It is heavily influenced by other aspirations and abilities, but incurring debts as an undergraduate is no less a concern for most students whose applications are severely constrained by their A-level achievements.

Oxbridge and other institutions with prestigious reputations might be options for "high-flyers", if not for "mere mortals". However, survey results show that from around 18 down to as low as 12 A-level points might still open up opportunities to study most subjects at a university that participating recruiters cite as "above average". For example, four "new universities", De Montfort, Brighton, Leeds Metropolitan and Bournemouth are awarded several commendations for graduate employability in business and management, earning them a place in the top 30. Many universities enjoying more traditional assumptions of "quality" might envy that status.

Restrictions aside, the popularity of these universities in business and management is underlined when considering that the bottom 10, not listed here outside the context of the full report, would record nett totals of from -2 to -4.

When recruiters explain the origins of their university ratings, certain factors emerge. Clearly, "previous recruits" are ambassadors for their university. Usually this works to the benefit of subsequent graduates but not every time. There is always the anecdotal opposite.

One employer's negative attitude to electronics courses at one university was based on the "slightly unfortunate experience of one of their graduates". And the generalisation that students at a renowned university had a "massively over-inflated sense of worth" was a burden that all its future graduates would bear with another company.

A substantial recruiter in engineering shunned one "new" university because "they were still advertising for students when the term had started". A significant hurdle stood between one set of students and careers with a company expressing reservations about all of the university's graduates because of "very low entry requirements". And a household name in finance avoided some prestigious courses for "producing very clever people with no common sense".

Academics and careers advisers, too, generate positive or negative responses to their own institution, which may not help their students. In many cases, the employer's opinion might be based on personal and individual experiences. The description of a business studies course tutor as a "very difficult character to deal with" or of a careers adviser as "more interested in what we could do for him than what he could do for us", were perceptions that would limit the chances of all graduates from these universities with those employers at least - hardly the students' fault.

Similarly, the careers service which "does everything its way, and is unwilling to tailor service to what the employer - ie the customer - wants" is the frame of mind in which one major recruiter in the computing industry makes his decisions about recruits. It might not be typical of all recruiters, but his judgment clearly torpedoes applications from that university's students with that company. Maybe that's what spiked the chances of your "brilliant student".

Even during a degree course at a less favoured institution, most companies can be persuaded by a graduate's individual qualities. After having committed themselves to the "wrong" university, there is no reason why Karen, David or their colleagues shouldn't develop the right skills to make them more employable. Employers emphasise that there are many important influences on their choice of recruits, but once again the combination of abilities they seek is unique to their subject area.

In business and management, over 85% of survey participants identify A levels, business awareness and work experience as critical. In engineering, three different attributes - enthusiasm, degree classification and oral communication skills - are cited by over 80%. Again, the subject-specific nature of employers' preferences is clear. In law, both written and oral communication skills are significant to over 90% of recruiters; for computing and information technology, enthusiasm is a leading attribute.

Perceptions about the validity of degrees vary, too. In business and management, 41% of recruiters think standards are falling - and that perception applies equally in general engineering. For civil engineering and construction, 55% think standards are falling.

These perceptions, too, have a direct influence on career opportunities. So pity the graduate from university P, applying to the large, public sector recruiter who considers university P as "far too generous with degree class awards". Maybe if Karen, with first-class honours, "that brilliant student" and Michael had all graduated at P, then it was prejudice of a kind.

Maybe only second-class honours, less "brilliance", and a less than perfect match for the job description, but an award from A, B, C or any other of the employers' favourite departments, would have opened more doors for the students.

Not all recruiters admit to favouritism. Not all universities enjoy hearing about it, but it doesn't take a genius to guess which ones do, at least in their specialist subject(s). For many graduates it might be prejudice beyond their control, at least once they've made their choice of university. My advice to future Karens and Davids is to think sooner rather than later about A, B or C; leave X, Y or Z till last.

 The combined preferences expressed by employers over 11 subjects in the Performance Indicator Project's 1999 and 2000 Graduate Recruiters' Surveys are published as Signposts to Employability (for professionals' desks) and Choose-a-Uni (for students' shelves). Both are priced at £24, with extra copies for £4.50 (either version). Orders and inquiries, in writing only, to Performance Indicator Project, c/o Harlaxton College, Grantham, Lincs NG32 1AG; or by e-mail to: cpettifor@ueharlax.ac.uk

Maybe only second-class honours, less "brilliance", and a less than perfect match for the job description, but an award from A, B, C or any other of the employers' favourite departments, would have opened more doors for the students. Not all recruiters admit to favouritism. Not all universities enjoy hearing about it, but it doesn't take a genius to guess which ones do, at least in their specialist subject(s). For many graduates it might be prejudice beyond their control, at least once they've made their choice of university. fields.headline: The pursuit of happiness
fields.standfirst: British doctors are carrying out a ground-breaking study into anhedonia, a common yet mysterious aspect of depression and other mental illnesses.  Lizzie Gardiner, left, on the condition that 'sucks the joy' out of her life
fields.trailText: British doctors are carrying out a ground-breaking study into anhedonia, a common yet mysterious aspect of depression and other mental illnesses. Lizzie Gardiner, left, on the condition that 'sucks the joy' out of her life
fields.body:
I suffer from clinical depression and have done on and off since my teens. The current episode has lasted more than five years and it looks quite likely that I shall always have a predisposition for the big gloom. I am one of the 20% of the UK population who live with this invisible illness and whose core symptoms include anhedonia.

This is a little-studied area of depression. It was first observed by the Victorians, but has prompted little investigation since. Someone suffering from it has little or no ability to feel pleasure from normally pleasurable experiences. Basically, it sucks the joy out of most things that make life worth living - food, sex, relationships and achievements. They no longer make sense as something which would prompt an emotional response. It's emotional dyslexia, if you like. You know what the occasion is; you just can't rise to it.

My own depression came with a variety of symptoms, few of which could be measured effectively and most of which have shifted and changed as the condition has become chronic. It's an illness which other people can't see, and unless they've experienced it first hand they sometimes view a sufferer as not helping themselves, as becoming a "victim of their own misery" and basically not even trying. Plenty of well-meaning people have said this to me in so many words and I can remember, to my shame, that I once said it myself to a depressed friend.

At the time I couldn't understand why she wouldn't just drop it; if she couldn't get a life at least she could try a hobby to help her get a grip. Now I know - when I am at my lowest, I couldn't "drop" my depression if the pope asked nicely, and I could no sooner get a grip than fly.

Depression can be triggered by specific life events, a physical illness, or a chemical imbalance in the brain. It seems likely that my present onset was prompted by a series of common disasters mugging me. My depression can be devastating. It can take every ounce of energy I have just to sit still; it requires every bit of spirit I possess to do anything. Anhedonia leaves me impassive and joyless. My responses become shallow and mechanical and I'm left feeling completely isolated and adrift from the world.

Even now that I'm better able to manage my symptoms, I still have to listen to other people's reactions to my achievements before my autopilot kicks in and I can at least appear more convincingly pleased.

There are people who just don't believe in depression. It's a subjective issue, of course, and with no visual aids and only the word of sufferers, it's hardly surprising.

There is hope, however. Dr Tonmay Sharma, a consultant psychiatrist at the Institute of Psychiatry in London, heads a team presently investigating the organic nature of depressive illness by conducting a study into anhedonia and depression through brain imaging. Functional magnetic resonance imaging - fMRI - has given researchers the opportunity to visualise the effects of depression on the brain.

His findings suggest that a tangible change occurs in the hippo- campus (an area of the brain which deals with emotion): it's often smaller in people with depression and anhedonia. Lesions and changes in brain metabolism have also been noted.

Dr Sharma's study has shown that the network which modulates mood in the brain of an anhedonia sufferer shows no activity when presented with pleasing or positive images, whereas in the brain of a person with no anhedonic symptoms such stimulation causes the network to light up.

"This is a crucial juncture in research into depression. The emergence of new technology is allowing us to map the brain," says Sharma. "We can now work together with patients to learn more about the condition and find appropriate psychological or pharmacological treatments."

The team is hoping that being able to show physical evidence in the brain will also encourage depression and anhedonia sufferers to obtain treatment earlier. He points out that if someone breaks an arm they will generally go straight to casualty, whereas someone with anhedonia might well delay asking for help in the hope that their symptoms will go away on their own.

Anhedonia responds well to treatment in most patients - whether it's drugs or therapy - and it's thought a delay of this sort can cause further dynamic changes in the brain, making the condition more difficult to treat. Sharma and his team also hope to investigate how treating anhedonia affects the make-up of the brain, again using fMRI. Sharma sees this study as an important part of the campaign against stigma being waged by the Institute of Psychiatry, as well as an exciting breakthrough in understanding the illness.

Enjoyment is a basic requirement for a full and happy life. We know that happy people live longer, and they generally cope better with illness and pressure along the way. The loss of this function can be truly crushing. Rats placed under unpredictable mild stress exhibit signs of anhedonia by a reduction in their response to reward.

Laughter and pleasurable experiences in humans are known to decrease levels of the stress hormone cortisol and help fight off respiratory complaints by increasing the level of immunoglobulin in our system. People find their larger pleasures in myriad ways but anhedonics lose a sense of joy in even the most basic of everyday comforts. A really excellent bacon sandwich, a glass of wine or a loving hug no longer provide sufficient inducement or reward to keep them fully functioning.

Learning to live with anhedonia is a strange and tedious business. I hadn't imagined for a moment that I might have to relearn one of the most basic of human experiences and it's a great deal harder than you might imagine. I've had to learn actively to take pleasure in the small things of life: clean cotton sheets; Ella Fitzgerald beginning to see the light with The Ink Spots; or chatting to the cat.

I'm moving on to achievements next and will slowly work my way up to blowing my own trumpet. Or polishing it at the very least. I'm learning to look for enjoyment in my day. I practise and reward myself by working towards small goals with the incentives that work for me - I do the Hoovering and win Desert Island Discs, a cup of tea and a fig roll, for instance.

Next week is national depression week. I hope it generates more talk and more research. The more study into the symptoms of depression the better the likelihood of effective treatments being found. The better the public awareness and understanding of this condition, the more likely it is that depression will finally be seen as an organic illness equal in validity to diabetes or epilepsy.

And people might finally stop trying to get us to join a club and just enjoy life.

fields.headline: Living with Lucy
fields.standfirst: They were told she had only three  months to live, but with loving care she  survived 10 years. By the time she died,  she had become a central part of their  family. Now Carol and Neil Wilkinson  tell Claire Wallerstein why they're  adopting another 'life-limited' child
fields.trailText: They were told she had only three months to live, but with loving care she survived 10 years. By the time she died, she had become a central part of their family. Now Carol and Neil Wilkinson tell Claire Wallerstein why they're adopting another 'life-limited' child
fields.body:
Like most parents, Carol and Neil Wilkinson cannot imagine any greater anguish than the death of a child. More than three years after the death of their adopted daughter, Lucy, ripples of pain still lie just below the surface.

After the bleak days of grief, guilt, and severe marital strain, Carol and Neil might now be expected to try to put the past behind them. Instead, having survived every parent's worst nightmare, they have chosen to plunge themselves into it again - by fostering a one-year-old boy who stands only a slim chance of surviving to adulthood.

"A lot of people probably think we're mad, and I can understand that," says Carol. "But there are terminally-ill children spending the whole of their lives in institutions because their families can't cope with the strain. After all we learned with Lucy, it would seem a waste not to help make another short life a happier one." The Wilkinsons, both 49, show no sign of masochism, missionary zeal, or obsession with glory - they seem quite simply besotted with children. They have four of their own, an adopted daughter, and have fostered more than 100 others since 1976.

The motivation to foster initially came from Neil. Now a principal engineer at Jaguar, he was put into care twice as a child - less-than-happy experiences which left him determined to provide a better environment for children in similar situations.

The couple had no experience of dealing with so-called "life-limited children" until 13 years ago, when Coventry social services asked them to foster a baby called Lucy, then only 12 weeks old, who was expected to die within three months. In the end, Lucy defeated this prognosis and many more. She survived for a decade, becoming emotionally and legally - through adoption - a central part of the Wilkinson family.

She had been healthy at birth, but a day later "died" a cot death. She was revived, but left with severe cerebral palsy, epilepsy, asthma and, says Carol, "virtually everything else in the book".

"We had no real experience of dealing with serious sickness, and at the start we were only told that she had difficulty feeding," says Carol. "If we'd known then how long she would live, and how badly disabled she was, we probably wouldn't have accepted her."

The memories of caring for such a deeply damaged child are still vivid. "At first, Lucy was in constant pain and screamed 24 hours a day. It wasn't the cry of a normal baby, but this kind of high-pitched whine, which was awful to listen to. She would fit so violently that she would go into a banana shape with her head touching her toes, so you couldn't even cuddle her to comfort her. She couldn't suck, so it was almost impossible to feed her. She ended up being fed through a tube in her nose, and later by a tube directly into her stomach."

Lucy's pain and epilepsy management improved after the first year - by which time she was being given 26 tablets and several medicines each day - but she never had any kind of normal mental development, and all her movements were involuntary. In the last year of her life, she was on constant morphine and oxygen, and was suffering from degeneration of the heart. She died in Carol's arms while Neil was away on holiday with the other children.

Can Carol really justify the couple's emotional investment in Lucy, or believe that such a sick child had any true quality of life? "I would be devastated if I thought Lucy's life had been unhappy and that we had kept her alive for no reason. That little girl had an incredibly strong personality - I'm sure that's why she refused to die for so long. She would respond to music and to all the members of our family, and for the first few years she could smile - she had an amazing ability to make everyone around her smile too.

"She also adored her visits to the Acorns Children's Hospice in Birmingham, which were great for us as well. Those times were the only respite we had, and as her condition deteriorated we literally lived from one visit there to the next. It had a wonderful warm atmosphere, and we knew she was in safe hands.

"Our other kids had a wonderful relationship with Lucy - they used to love helping with her physiotherapy massage, and she taught them a lot about tolerance, and how to relate to people with disabilities."

Carol doesn't believe they resented the almost constant attention she devoted to their sick sister, or that living with a terminally ill child placed them under unnecessary emotional strain. "She was so helpless, and her needs were so different from theirs, that jealousy didn't come into it," she says. "Of course, her death was traumatic for them. Even now they are still deeply affected by it. But in some ways I think it has made them more mature. Children today might hear about a grandparent or neighbour dying, but they don't experience it first hand - whereas 100 years ago nearly every family would have had a child that died, and it was just a fact of life."

It was Carol and Neil who suffered most, however. "As a parent it was almost impossible to accept that she really was going to die, no matter how much love and care we gave her. "For at least a year afterwards I had terrible black days, and could tell you the exact number of months, weeks and hours since she died. Neil and I went through a very rocky patch, because his response to her death was denial. He bottled everything up and wouldn't talk about her - I thought it was because he didn't care."

After more than two decades of non-stop childcare, three of the Wilkinson's own children have now flown the nest, leaving "only" four youngsters at home. The smell of baking still fills the couple's five-bedroom house, and regimented lines of shoes and coats still line the hall, but until the recent arrival, Carol says it "felt a bit empty".

Although taking on another terminally ill child had been discussed before Lucy died, Neil clearly feels a certain amount of trepidation. "I'll probably go off the deep end again," he jokes - and sometimes still seems lost for words when he talks about Lucy. "My problem was that I never really believed she was going to die, because there had been so many times when family life came to a virtual standstill while we waited for her to die - and she never did.

"In the end we decided that life had to go on around her, because marking time like this was having a negative effect on us all. That's why I wasn't there when she died - I'd taken the other children on holiday while she was having one of her bad turns. I felt terrible guilt, and it took me a long time to come to terms with it."

Neil isn't alone in having some misgivings about the new baby. Carol says: "Two of our children still aren't at all happy about us taking him on, and our eldest son was initially against it too, because he felt we would be forgetting about Lucy. But the younger ones are really excited, probably because they dealt with Lucy's death in a different way - they just think she's happy in heaven now."

On the brink of stepping back into the maelstrom, Neil makes a last effort to explain a decision which, he admits, almost defies explanation. "It's not the losing or the dying that's important - it's the life that comes before. Living with Lucy was sometimes very difficult, but it was also an incredibly enriching experience. If we can give another child the stability, love and happiness of a home environment, then it balances everything else out."

webTitle: Eat your greens, blues, yellows, pinks and reds

fields.headline: Eat your greens, blues, yellows, pinks and reds
fields.standfirst: There is now an easy way to check if you have a healthy, balanced diet - and it's all about colour.  Sonia Purnell investigates
fields.trailText: There is now an easy way to check if you have a healthy, balanced diet - and it's all about colour. Sonia Purnell investigates
fields.body:
The barrage of information on links between diet and disease has left most people feeling they need a PhD in biochemistry to understand it, let alone know how to interpret it on the dinner plate. But now one woman has come up with a beautifully simple healthy-eating code based on the colour of food.

Jane Sen, dietary adviser and head chef at the Bristol Cancer Help Centre, who won a BBC healthy cooking award yesterday, says that nature has done all the hard work for us. Antioxidants, those valiant nutrients which combat cancer cells, are also very often what gives a fruit or vegetable its colour. Based on research from around the world as well as advice from specialist doctors, Sen has come up with a simple rule: we should all make sure we are eating as many colours as possible every day.

"If there's a colour missing, very likely it's an antioxidant. You actually need all the antioxidants all the time, so the simple solution is to make sure your fruit bowl and vegetable basket have all the colours in them: orange, red, purple, bright green, curly green and yellow. This is not just for when you are ill, but also to protect against ageing, promote fitness and guard against illness."

She warns against simply consuming vast quantities of whatever happens to be the week's wonder fruit. "People get an idea that because they've had betacarotene in carrots that's OK. But that's only one of 40 carotenoids, and you need all of them. I've been thinking about making a full list of which foods contain which antioxidants, but I'm trying to keep this about food, not research chemistry. You need antioxidants all the time and they need each other to work properly. Research shows that when they are in the body, they can be dangerous unless they continue to work with other antioxidants.

"Following the colour key stops this becoming a scientific minefield and vastly improves your diet. Eating as many raw fruits and vegetables as possible - preferably scrubbed rather than peeled - also helps enormously as you then get the full hit of antioxidants." That said, if someone is either suffering from cancer or is known to be predisposed to the disease, it is worth knowing which foods have particularly useful antioxidants in them. Lycopene - shown by research to be good at the prevention of and recovery from prostate, bladder, cervical and pancreatic cancer - can, for example be found in various pinky-red foods such as pink grapefruit, crab shell, watermelon and tomatoes.

Sen's work in Bristol, which revolves round a vegan, low-fat, salt and sugar diet based on the colour theory, has been recognised by heart disease charities for its contribution to healthy eating and has inspired many cancer patients who have visited the centre. She believes it can help all aspects of health, even conception.

Sen has not always been in healthcare, having worked as a chef for many years for various royals as well as healthy-eating rock stars such as Peter Gabriel. "I wanted to feed people who were hungry at a different level, so I studied nutrition and now scour science journals and the internet for the latest research to use at Bristol.

"I aim to provide a bridge between all that information and the dinner table by making the research accessible and explaining how to turn it into delicious food. Healthy food can be a delight to eat and doesn't have to taste like a cardboard box. Hippocrates' famous statement about 'food being medicine' is inspiring only when everything to do with it doesn't feel or taste like medicine."

fields.bodyText: The barrage of information on links between diet and disease has left most people feeling they need a PhD in biochemistry to understand it, let alone know how to interpret it on the dinner plate. But now one woman has come up with a beautifully simple healthy-eating code based on the colour of food. Jane Sen, dietary adviser and head chef at the Bristol Cancer Help Centre, who won a BBC healthy cooking award yesterday, says that nature has done all the hard work for us. Antioxidants, those valiant nutrients which combat cancer cells, are also very often what gives a fruit or vegetable its colour. Based on research from around the world as well as advice from specialist doctors, Sen has come up with a simple rule: we should all make sure we are eating as many colours as possible every day. "If there's a colour missing, very likely it's an antioxidant. You actually need all the antioxidants all the time, so the simple solution is to make sure your fruit bowl and vegetable basket have all the colours in them: orange, red, purple, bright green, curly green and yellow. This is not just for when you are ill, but also to protect against ageing, promote fitness and guard against illness." She warns against simply consuming vast quantities of whatever happens to be the week's wonder fruit. "People get an idea that because they've had betacarotene in carrots that's OK. But that's only one of 40 carotenoids, and you need all of them. I've been thinking about making a full list of which foods contain which antioxidants, but I'm trying to keep this about food, not research chemistry. You need antioxidants all the time and they need each other to work properly. Research shows that when they are in the body, they can be dangerous unless they continue to work with other antioxidants. "Following the colour key stops this becoming a scientific minefield and vastly improves your diet. Eating as many raw fruits and vegetables as possible - preferably scrubbed rather than peeled - also helps enormously as you then get the full hit of antioxidants." That said, if someone is either suffering from cancer or is known to be predisposed to the disease, it is worth knowing which foods have particularly useful antioxidants in them. Lycopene - shown by research to be good at the prevention of and recovery from prostate, bladder, cervical and pancreatic cancer - can, for example be found in various pinky-red foods such as pink grapefruit, crab shell, watermelon and tomatoes. Sen's work in Bristol, which revolves round a vegan, low-fat, salt and sugar diet based on the colour theory, has been recognised by heart disease charities for its contribution to healthy eating and has inspired many cancer patients who have visited the centre. She believes it can help all aspects of health, even conception. Sen has not always been in healthcare, having worked as a chef for many years for various royals as well as healthy-eating rock stars such as Peter Gabriel. "I wanted to feed people who were hungry at a different level, so I studied nutrition and now scour science journals and the internet for the latest research to use at Bristol. "I aim to provide a bridge between all that information and the dinner table by making the research accessible and explaining how to turn it into delicious food.
