fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.trailText: Sense of smell | Warts and all
fields.body:
Sense and non-sense
Q: My sense of smell has completely diminished over the past few years. I've been to the doctor and he can't find a blockage so it's not a sinus/nasal problem. I haven't got around to going to a specialist yet. I'm 27, a non-smoker, vegetarian and am careful about eating a balanced diet. I've tried researching the problem but can't seem to find much info on the subject. The only thing I could come up with is maybe a zinc deficiency. Could this be the case?

A: Loss of smell (anosmia) is usually temporary and caused by a cold or sinusitis. If it persists, you certainly need to see an ear, nose and throat specialist. The usual causes are nasal polyps, allergies or dental problems. Rare causes are side-effects of medicines, insecticide poisoning, radiation treatment for cancers of the head and neck or brain tumours. Deficiencies of copper, zinc or other trace metals have all been touted as causes but are hard to prove. Often, no cause is found and the sense of smell returns as mysteriously as it disappeared.

Wart worry
Q: My children (four and six) are plagued by warts. Our GP says it's a virus called molluscum contagiosum and other than lancing them and dabbing them with iodine (which sounds brutal), there is nothing you can do. Is there anything you could recommend? Are there any homeopathic remedies that might help?

A: Molluscum have joined headlice, threadworm and verrucas as a rite of passage through nurseries and primary schools. You can leave them alone; the body eventually fights off the virus that causes verrucas and warts and they drop off. But children prone to eczema may get irritating patches of eczema round their molluscum, they can become infected, and they spread easily to others.

Dr Richard Aron, consultant dermatologist at the Garden Hospital in North London, says there's no single anti-molluscum drug that works. He applies a cream called EMLA under clingfilm or similar dressing for an hour to numb the skin and then scoops out the moluscum (curettage). He's also investigating whether Aldara cream, used to treat genital and anal warts, works against molluscum. Homeopaths say sucking one thuja tablet a day for a week helps and is safe for all ages. Thuja is widely available in pharmacies and health food shops. See www.homeopathydr.com.

Spot of bother
Q: I'm 27 and have suffered from spots for the past 10 years. I've tried many products, none of which have worked. I keep my skin clean, eat plenty of fruit and vegetables and avoid caffeine and excessive amounts of alcohol, but my skin is constantly spotty. I very rarely have periods, which suggests a hormonal link, but when I tried the contraceptive pill, Dianette, it made me depressed, so I stopped taking it. My ovaries have been checked and appear to be fine so there is no obvious reason why I don't have periods.

A: I'm not advocating it, but you could live on chocolate, coffee and alcohol and find that your skin was no worse than if you ate an impeccable diet. Dianette's good for acne because it counteracts the hormone testosterone that contributes to greasy skin and spots. But if Dianette makes you more depressed than the acne, there's no point taking it.

Dab-on tropical antibiotics such as Stiemycin or oral antibiotics such as Minocin may work. But if your acne is severe or persistent, I'd ask for a referral to a dermatologist to get Roaccutane. This drug gets a bad press because it causes cracked lips and dry, peeling skin which can feel like you've been sandblasted. You can't get pregnant while on it or for a month after finishing the course, but it works better than anything else.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor and seeking medical help. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

fields.headline: Peer pressures
fields.standfirst:
Joining the Upper House is easy - the difficult bit is choosing your title. Just ask the would-be Baron Ashcroft of Belize. By Emma Brockes
Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: April 4 2000: Joining the Upper House is easy - the difficult bit is choosing your title. Just ask the would-be Baron Ashcroft of Belize. By Emma Brockes
fields.body:
It is safe to assume that a statement requiring the suffix "just my little joke" has failed in its aim to amuse. Thus it was when Michael Ashcroft floated the idea of calling himself Baron Ashcroft of Belize last week, as the title for his new appointment to the House of Lords. William Hague's keen ear instantly divined that people were not laughing with Ashcroft on the matter and swiftly claimed on GMTV that it was just the billionaire financier's "little joke" - not to be confused with an April Fool, of course, which would have been silly.

For once, however, Ashcroft's faux pas was at least partly understandable. The free hand given to new peers when choosing their titles is too great a temptation for those whose idea of "naughty behaviour" was firmly set in public school. And it is the new peer's chief dilemma - which bit of geography to honour by attaching it to his name? Insalubrious birthplace or swanky new locality? A glance down the list of current Lords members suggests that there are some peculiar factors influencing the process.

First, there is the bathos of titles that sit uncomfortably with the po-faced tenor of the Upper House. Lord Baker of Dorking is a good one, but only because it has the word "dork" in it. Lord Archer of Western-super-Mare is, for reasons other than the risible nature of its holder, an intrinsically funny title because there is something about the camp, shabby seaside town that really suits the House of Lords.

Then there are the titles that leave one unsure of their holders' meaning. Are they intended as little jokes, or are they the inevitable home goals scored by people whose sense of irony went out in the 1600s, along with their family's last injection of fresh genes? Is Lord Brabazon of Tara really a fan of Gone with the Wind? Is Lord MacLaurin of Knebworth paying sly tribute to stadium rock? Lord Jauncey of Tullichettle has to be having a laugh, and as for Baroness Young of Old Scone - Old Scone?

There are, of course, rules governing the naming process, but in keeping with the House of Lords they follow a pretty random logic. "You are not allowed a road and there are certain villages that are too obscure to qualify," says Lord (David) Lipsey, who became a member of the House six months ago.

Lord Lipsey, as the first person in his family tree to enter the peerage, is not officially known by his full title. He was nonetheless required to choose one. A practical man, he looked no further than his home address - a controversial move when you live in Tooting Bec. "The authorities said, 'Tooting Bec! That doesn't sound quite appropriate for a peer of the realm.' I said, 'It is Tooting Bec or nothing.'"

A quick poll of obscurely titled peers suggests that the biggest influence over their choice of titles is not perversity, but nostalgia. Baroness Symons of Vernham Dean named her title after the small village south of Hungerford that she used to visit as a child. Jeffrey Archer grew up in Western-super-Mare and Old Scone is a real place, outside Perth, and home of the Baroness. Lord Harris of Peckham, tired I'm sure of Delboy jokes, went to school in Streatham and rose to become the head of a carpet-making empire, Carpetright plc, before bringing titular fame to his South London roots.

Unsurprisingly, the act of choosing a name is riven with politics and subject to the sort of abstract snobbery the House excels in. One of its members, preferring to remain nameless, recalls the distress caused by the late Lord Montague of Oxford, who several of the grander peers considered presumptuous in his choice of moniker (he went to a grammar school). "It is thought not quite right to choose a big city unless you can live up to it," he says.

Baroness James of Holland Park, more commonly known as the crime writer PD James, has moved about so much in her life that when she was created a peer in 1991, she was stuck for an obvious title. Eventually, she too settled on Oxford, but knew not to claim the whole city for herself. "I thought it would be rather nice to have the name of the parish where I was born," she says, "but there was huge confusion about the parish boundaries. The King of Arms phoned up Oxford, but they couldn't be sure what parish 127 Walton Street had been in, so I was left high and dry." She settled on Holland Park in the end, as the place where her most successful book to date, A Taste for Death, had been set. Another little joke?

fields.headline: Marianne
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about France's national figure on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about France's national figure on the net
fields.body:
1. Marianne is the essence of France. Her origins are shrouded in history, but around 1789 she came to embody the Revolution. Next to the "tricolor", she is the nation's most potent symbol.

2. Painted and sculpted by generations of French artists, Marianne is variously represented as fierce, calm, war-like and earth-motherly. Her bust is displayed in every mairie in France. Indeed, Marianne very likely has more busts of her than any other woman, real or imaginary. She often appears on postage stamps too.

3. More recently, Marianne has become a living person. Every few years, French mayors elect a young woman to represent La Belle France.

4. Previous winners include Brigitte Bardot and Catherine Deneuve.

5. Last autumn, there was an almighty stink when the accolade went to Laetitia Casta, actress and supermodel, and the youngest contender for the title at 21. Among the beaten icons were singer Patricia Kaas and windsurfer-turned-TV host Nathalie Simon.

6. Ms Casta is described on her snazzy website as "the world's hottest woman" (it sounds nicer in French). In her virtual village, you can find out all about her and her business deals.

7. You can even pitch a business proposition to Laetitia online, though it must remain tasteful, like the work she has done for US undie mart, Victoria's Secret.

8. The official site is coy about the traffic it gets, but not so the unofficial fan site, Laetitia's Secret Garden.

9. Interest may pick up now that Laetitia's big secret is out: she lives in London where, rather surprisingly, she says she is less pestered than she is in Paris. The French political establishment is outraged.

10. The British tabloids are as pleased as punch: the Sun uses the obligatory Sacre Bleu! intro, while the Star detects a diplomatic storm.

webTitle: £1.1bn introduces Admiral chiefs to office cleaning

fields.headline: £1.1bn introduces Admiral chiefs to office cleaning
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
CMG
fields.trailText: The Anglo-Dutch computer consultancy CMG declared that "big is best" yesterday as it snapped up rival group Admiral for £1.1bn.
fields.body:
The Anglo-Dutch computer consultancy CMG declared that "big is best" yesterday as it snapped up rival group Admiral for £1.1bn.

The agreed deal creates one of Europe's largest software and computer services companies, with more than 11,000 staff and sales of £780m.

CMG's chairman, Cor Stutterheim, said: "We're building a combined force, which will be able to serve international clients much better.

"The technological revolution is only just beginning and we'll be ideally placed to be a major force."

However, the stock market reacted badly: CMG's shares fell £10.52 to £43.33. Some analysts said they thought CMG had overpaid for Admiral, which issued two profit warnings in the past year.

James Heal of Commerzbank Securities said: "There's an element of surprise at the size of the deal. CMG's strategy over the last five years has been for small, bolt-on acquisitions. These are market conditions where any change of strategy causes a jolt."

Admiral shareholders will get 0.39 CMG shares for each share they hold. There is a limited cash alternative, worth up to £175m.

The deal means the 9% stake held by Admiral's chairman, Clay Brendish, is worth £103m. He will join the combined company as executive deputy chairman.

Mr Brendish co-founded Admiral 21 years ago in a room above a newsagent in Frimley, Surrey. He said: "I will stay as long as I can contribute something."

Admiral had a difficult 1999: the company recruited too many staff ahead of the mil lennium. Many customers then delayed their orders, to see if any problems arose.

Mr Stutterheim insisted this was a temporary setback: "We are confident the fly in the soup has been removed."

The two companies expect no job cuts. They said the deal was intended to create critical mass rather than savings.

However, Admiral staff are likely to experience some cultural changes. CMG was set up under loosely socialist principles, with all employees considered equal and all salaries made public.

CMG's chief executive, Tom Rusting, said senior Admiral executives would have to get used to "cleaning up after meetings just like everyone else". In time, Admiral employees will undergo pay and performance assessments, with the full results placed on view for all staff.

CMG also encourages broad employee share ownership: 20% of the company is owned by the workforce. Admiral has similar policies to encourage stakeholding

The takeover gives CMG a much bigger position in the UK market and the combined group more firepower to develop telecoms products

webTitle: Restless workers double job site hits

fields.headline: Restless workers double job site hits
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Top Jobs
Jobsite
Monster
fields.trailText: The internet is swiftly becoming an alternative to the classified pages for restless employees, with record numbers of job-seekers logging on to career sites in February.
fields.body:
The internet is swiftly becoming an alternative to the classified pages for restless employees, with record numbers of job-seekers logging on to career sites in February.

The number of people accessing online employment advertisements was 521,000, more than double the figure in January, according to internet audience measurement firm MMXI Europe.

The most popular site was Stepstone.co.uk, visited by 3% of all who logged on to the net. Also heavily used were Topjobs.co.uk, Jobsite.co.uk and Monster.co.uk.

Lucy Green, MMXI's marketing director, put the boom down to advertising: "There's been a general raising of awareness. Stepstone have been using billboards and there's been quite a lot of promotional activity generally."

Job-seeking on the net is popular because it can be done outside working hours. "It's quite difficult to job-hunt in the office. You can get on the phone to a headhunter but everyone in the room will suspect you're doing it. With the internet, you can look for a job any time of the day or night, completely privately."

Many of the openings advertised are in the computer industry or clerical roles. However, MMXI expects to see an increase in employment sites catering for specific industries over the coming months.

Mr Green said job seeking was going online in the same way as buying books or booking holidays: "In general, people understand it's a way of saving time and doing something more conveniently."

Stepstone, the most successful jobs site, floated last month with a valuation of £480m. The site is run by Giles Clarke, who made a fortune from the retail chains Majestic Wine and Pet City.

webTitle: Microsoft puts on a brave face

fields.headline: Microsoft puts on a brave face
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
Microsoft
fields.trailText: William Neukom, the head of Microsoft's legal team, put a brave face on the company's court-room woes yesterday. "This is an especially busy, especially stimulating time for us on the campus," he said. "These couldn't be more exciting times in terms of development."
fields.body:
William Neukom, the head of Microsoft's legal team, put a brave face on the company's court-room woes yesterday. "This is an especially busy, especially stimulating time for us on the campus," he said. "These couldn't be more exciting times in terms of development."

In calls to analysts and journalists, senior executives stressed that yesterday's judgment was just one more step in a long and painful legal road while the rest of the business was on the fast track to success. Company president Bill Gates urged investors to look to the spring conference in which the world's biggest software company intends to announce a new five-year plan to bring Windows, its dominant software programme, closer to the internet. "For us, the big thing is going to be Forum 2000," he said. By looking to the future, however, the company confirmed the impression that the next few months will not be very exciting at all.

Investors were more than conscious of the fact that by the time Forum 2000 opens, possibly at the end of May, the company may be facing a legal decision that it should be broken up, on top of private lawsuits threatening to cost hundreds of billions dollars.

Microsoft believes that the future shape of the software industry will make the bundling of its internet browser to Win dows look like old hat. Most of the excitement seen among campus techies by Mr Neukom is partly generated by them trying to add more services and functions to Windows, the software used on more than 90% of the world's computers.

Government forces saw the use of the "software is different" argument as just an updated way for a company to abuse its stranglehold over a market. They see Microsoft's threats to computer manufacturers and rivals alike as the same as any other traditional company breaking anti-monopolies laws designed to protect consumers.

In spite of this gulf between the two sides, they had worked on about 20 drafts of a possible consent decree. Yet they failed to agree on an effective remedy notwithstanding signs that the government was willing to accept something short of a break-up of the company.

Microsoft blamed divisions between the justice department and the 19 US states party to the anti-Microsoft action for the failure to bring about an agreement. The states are widely believed to have pushed for a break-up.

Mr Neukom said yesterday that such a remedy "makes no sense whatsoever as a way of dealing with the harm, even if you find that there is such a harm".

Government lawyers are understood to have wanted an effective ban on tying new products as well as uniform pricing for Windows. They did not trust Micro soft, which has previously broken consent decrees. Richard Blumenthal, one of the most vociferous attorneys general on the states' side, said yesterday that the government forces were united and that they would use yesterday's conclusions of law to guide their calls for an effective remedy.

"We have always said that remedies have to be fundamental and far-reaching in order to prevent this kind of behaviour happening again," he said.

Joel Klein, head of the justice department's anti-trust division, has said that the courts rather than government agencies should define the law on monopolies.

Such definitions take time, however. Yesterday's ruling will be followed by a decision on an effective punishment in the next couple of months, An appeal could take nine to 12 months, according to Mr Neukom. The company is to rest part of its case on an earlier court of appeals decision which upheld its ability to tie its internet browser to Windows 95. It is to criticise Judge Jackson's handling of the case and use of inadmissible evidence, a position which has won the support of few legal experts.

Several analysts, worried about the effect on share prices of continued legal shenanigans, yesterday followed Microsoft in advising investors to look to the future yesterday. Andrew Roskill, industry analyst at Warburg Dillon Read, believes that the changing nature of the software sector, with everyone supplying internet-dependent products, will make today's arguments about remedies look obsolete. "In another year, this whole case will seem even more ridiculously moot," he said.

Analyst Henry Blodget, of Merill Lynch, said that a break-up would make the company more effective. He believes that Microsoft's consumer-oriented internet services should be separated from its corporate software group. A web-focused division could then merge with a pure internet company to create a competitor to America Online Time Warner. "They are fighting a war on two fronts," he said.

1993 Justice Department begins anti-trust inquiry into whether Windows has monopoly in PC market.

1994 Microsoft agrees to stop punishing PC makers using rival software. 1997 Microsoft launches Internet Explorer to compete with rivals such as Netscape . It is sued for allegedly violating 1994 agreement by forcing manufacturers to promote Explorer. Judge Jackson issues preliminary injunction to stop bundling of Explorer with Windows. Overruled on appeal.

1998 Department of Justice and 20 US states sue for breach of anti-trust law. Texas later drops out. Trial begins on October 19. In November America Online buys Netscape for $10bn.

1999 Judge Jackson's findings of fact are sharply critical of Microsoft. He appoints an independent mediator.

2000 Settlement talks fail on April 1.

webTitle: ITC may bend rules for Carlton

fields.headline: ITC may bend rules for Carlton
fields.standfirst: Carlton
fields.trailText: The Independent Television Commission yesterday admitted that consolidation among the remaining ITV companies was inevitable and hinted it may bend the rules for the proposed merger of Carlton Communications and United News & Media.
fields.body:
The Independent Television Commission yesterday admitted that consolidation among the remaining ITV companies was inevitable and hinted it may bend the rules for the proposed merger of Carlton Communications and United News & Media.

In a submission to the competition commission, the ITC conceded that "sooner or later there will be greater concentration of ownership" among the three large ITV companies. Granada, stung by the putative £8bn merger, has also made its intention to bid for either United or Carlton and the matter is now in the hands of the Commission.

The ITC noted that the proposed merger would not be allowed under existing rules but signalled that the key obstacle may be surmountable. No company can account for more than 25% of the total TV advertising market but a combined Carlton/United would have 35%. The ITC submission said it would be reluctant to al low a single firm to go as high as 40% but added: "We are not opposed to some increase."

The ITC has no direct say in the merger which will be judged by trade secretary Stephen Byers but its views will be influential.

Colin Tennant, media analyst at Warburg Dillon Read, described the ITC submission as "broadly supportive" and said the merger has a 70% chance of going through.

Carlton and United have already made it clear that they would be prepared to sell down their stakes in Channel 5 and GMTV to keep their audience share under the 15% limit, the other stumbling block.

Carlton and United welcomed the comments in a joint statement. "We are particularly encouraged that the ITC is open to an increase in the maximum shares of advertising revenue that can be sold by one company, which is necessary for our merger to go ahead," they said. The commission will report to the DTI in May. Shares in Carlton fell 46p to 705p and United was 47.5p lower at 777p.

fields.headline: Don't believe the hyperbole
fields.standfirst: Why all the furore about pay-per-view, asks Sean Ingle, when the ordinary fan will benefit as much as the big clubs?
fields.trailText: Judging from the predictable out-pouring of hysteria and hyperbole from today's press, the Premier League's decision to introduce pay-per-view is another kick in the teeth for the ordinary fan.
fields.body:
Judging from the predictable out-pouring of hysteria and hyperbole from today's press, the Premier League's decision to introduce pay-per-view is another kick in the teeth for the ordinary fan.

"You will have to pay for 40 top TV games," thunders the Sun, no doubt worried that Murdoch's monopoly on live Premiership coverage might be coming to an end. "Fans face £6-a-game shock" screams the Star. Even the Guardian worries about a "radical shake-up of televised football".

No-one makes the case that pay-per-view football is probably a good thing. Strange really, considering it will give fans a greater choice, clubs more revenue - and certainly won't have the nightmarish consequences that many pundits predict.

Let's look at the nitty-gritty. One of the main attacks against pay-per-view is that it is wrong for the ordinary fan to have to fork out more for live Premiership football. These arguments forget that subscribers to Sky Sports have already being paying for football since 1993. Sky may argue otherwise, but the £30-a-month subscribers pay to watch their sports channels certainly isn't down to the endless repeats of Futbol Mondial.

In fact the introduction of pay-per-view is great for Joe Average, because it will allow him and his family of four to watch his team for just £6 a match. That's 90 minutes of action for about £1.50 each; better value than the local multiplex, and certainly better value than splashing out £100-plus to get the family through the turnstiles - if he can get a ticket in the first place, of course.

Another phantom fear is that pay-per-view will snatch all the juiciest matches - the Liverpool v Manchester Uniteds and Arsenal v Chelseas - leaving the main broadcasters to show the rubbish that nobody wants. But again, a close reading of the Premier League's announcement yesterday shows that the reverse is true.

Each club must be shown at least once but no more than six times on pay-per-view each season. That means the big clubs won't be on pay-per-view every week. Furthermore, the first and second choice of live games will go to the main-deal broadcaster (i.e. Sky) as part of their 66-game package. Whoever wins the pay-per-view contract will be left with the third pick.

This means that they will get the scraps - particularly when the likes of Manchester United, Chelsea and Arsenal are playing on Saturday because of a European match in mid-week.

And as the pay-per-view matches will start on 2pm Sunday, if you're unwilling to splash out £6 to watch Coventry - Derby, you can always switch to Channel 4 to watch live coverage of Lazio - Roma.

Anyway, if you're still desperate to catch the live pay-per-view match, you can always do what every football fan without Sky has done since 1993 - go down the pub, and watch it there.

webTitle: HSBC sets pace with French connection

fields.headline: HSBC sets pace with French connection
fields.standfirst:
Bank steals march on rivals
HSBC
Barclays
Natwest
fields.trailText: The surprise news over the weekend that HSBC is to acquire Crédit Commerciale de France provides, for once, a rare opportunity for a story about a "British" bank taking the initiative and gobbling up a foreign rival rather than being the prey itself.
fields.body:
The surprise news over the weekend that HSBC is to acquire Crédit Commerciale de France provides, for once, a rare opportunity for a story about a "British" bank taking the initiative and gobbling up a foreign rival rather than being the prey itself.

While it is a bold move by the multi-faceted owner of what was once Midland bank, the deal met with some criticism in the City yesterday for the hefty price HSBC is paying. The €11bn price tag is reckoned to be at least €1bn over the top, and this showed through in the price of HSBC stock which fell 5% yesterday. But then the purchase had to be made in the face of some pretty stiff competition from ING, the Dutch bank which had been courting CCF for months.

The fact is HSBC has bought a top quality French institution which fits well with its existing mix of businesses. Despite its size - it is one of the top three banks in the world - the deal also demonstrated HSBC's agility and ability to take the initiative in a new territory. This contrasts with Lloyds TSB and Barclays which seem to have been procrastinating about the continent for years, while HSBC has been busy doing deals all over the globe.

Something of a gap is rapidly opening up between HSBC and the other traditional UK clearing banks. To be fair, what used to be called the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation was never a simple clearing bank in the first place, having built up operations in just about every quarter of the world; in fact, it wasn't very British at all until the bank's registration was moved from Hong Kong in the face of the Chinese takeover of the colony. But whatever the history, the fact is, in an era of accelerating globalisation, HSBC is now the only UK bank able to claim a truly global presence.

There are differing views now on whether the CCF deal heaps further pressure on Peter Ellwood, the chief executive of Lloyds TSB, who has been banging on about his plans to take his acquisition train to Europe for at least a year. It has been argued that CCF is not a typical French bank, in that ownership was already widely spread, and that its acquisition says little about the ability of British banks to break into the market there. But at the same time it shows that deals are there to be done, so long as the acquirer looks hard enough and acts fast enough. European banking is consolidating. The short-term expectation is that most of this will continue to be done on the continent, amongst continental players. But it is only a matter of time before Europe is considered to include Britain when it comes to this particular sector.

D-day is here

We have had e-commerce, which was always pretty straightforward since the "e" stood for electronic. Then, soon enough, along came m-commerce, just about wearable since the "m" was about the mobile internet and the wireless applications protocol.

The patience was then tested somewhat with p-commerce, the "p" allegedly defining bespoke applications for Psions and Palms and other palmtops. But now we have d-commerce, as in D for digital, referring to those goods, such as music and video and even newspapers, which can be sold and delivered over the internet.

Yesterday, one self-declared specialist in d-stuff, Magex, announced an $80m private equity funding yesterday, handled by Goldman Sachs - seemingly one of the largest such cash raisings in Europe's portion of the new economy to date.

The company promises a payment infrastructure for the delivery of digital content over the internet, while at the same time protecting against unauthorised copying. Using a type of tamper-proof cyber-wrapper called a "digibox," Magex even reckons it can stop people downloading music or a video and then e-mailing it to friends. This is exciting stuff, potentially, helping to develop a market in which to date there has been lots of talk and little action.

But one thing that catches the eye is the origins of the Magex system - namely, the card payments division of NatWest bank. The British clearer developed the technology, formed Magex in 1998 and will retain a minority holding after the latest funding round.

NatWest clearly has some talent in the world of e-m-p-d. A couple of months ago it popped up with a 13% stake in WorldPay, one of its software suppliers based in the Channel Islands which has developed a genuine plug-n-play internet payment system for small and medium sized businesses.

It promises all NatWest's business clients quick and easy online access to the banks' payment systems.

The thought occurs that if NatWest had started shouting about these tech-laboratory developments back in the autumn it might not now be a subsidiary of the Royal Bank of Scotland.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Euro weakness alarms IMF
fields.body:
Euro weakness alarms IMF

The weakness of the euro is making imbalances in the global economy worse, the International Monetary Fund said yesterday. In its annual health check on the eurozone economy, the fund said the single currency was undervalued by as much as 30%. The report said this could "exacerbate existing patterns of trade imbalances and heighten the risks of abrupt exchange rate reversals and of protectionist pressures".

Overall, the fund's assessment of the eurozone was upbeat. Jacques Artus, deputy director of the IMF's European department, said the region had the best chance in 30 years for lengthy economic expansion.

Vodafone seals US alliance

US local telephone company Bell Atlantic and Britain's Vodafone AirTouch said yesterday they combined their US wireless and paging operations to become the country's biggest wireless carrier.

The new firm, reportedly to be named Verison, will top such carriers as AT&T and Sprint, and set a new national pricing structure.

An initial public offering of a tracking stock is reportedly under consideration. Verison will have more than 23m wireless customers.

EMI may open archive to net

Live concerts involving EMI artists might be streamed over the internet and archived concerts made available online under a deal announced yesterday between the British music group and On-Line Entertainment Network, a subsidiary of GlobalNet Systems.

The non-exclusive agreement covers provision of on-demand, pay-to-use content.

Mattel to dump Learning Co

Mattel, maker of Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels cars, said yesterday it plans to sell its troubled Learning Co unit in a transaction that could fetch far less than the $3.5bn it paid for the software business last May. Mattel said it had hired Credit Suisse First Boston to handle the sale of the business, which has racked up big losses and led to the resignation of Jill Barad as chairwoman and chief executive

P&O floats freight unit

P&O is to take advantage of an upsurge in ocean freight rates to float its Associated Bulk Carriers subsidiary on the Oslo stock exchange.

The move follows a seriesof property sales and a recent decision to demerge its successful cruise ship division in order to streamline the company.

Chairman Lord Sterling has bought out ABC's Chinese joint venture partner, Shougang Holdings, but will sell off the majority of its ABC holding with an initial public offering later this year.

ABC operates a fleet of 22 dry bulk carriers with an asset value of around £300m. Freight rates have doubled to $20,000 (£12,000) a day recently

An initial public offering of a tracking stock is reportedly under consideration. Verison will have more than 23m wireless customers. EMI may open archive to net Live concerts involving EMI artists might be streamed over the internet and archived concerts made available online under a deal announced yesterday between the British music group and On-Line Entertainment Network, a subsidiary of GlobalNet Systems. The non-exclusive agreement covers provision of on-demand, pay-to-use content. Mattel to dump Learning Co Mattel, maker of Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels cars, said yesterday it plans to sell its troubled Learning Co unit in a transaction that could fetch far less than the $3.5bn it paid for the software business last May. webTitle: Rexam's £1.3bn US deal is a canny move

fields.headline: Rexam's £1.3bn US deal is a canny move
fields.standfirst: Coca Cola
fields.trailText: Rexam yesterday became the biggest supplier of cans to Coca-Cola and one of the world's top consumer packaging groups, following a £1.3bn foray into the US, writes Terry Macalister.
fields.body:
Rexam yesterday became the biggest supplier of cans to Coca-Cola and one of the world's top consumer packaging groups, following a £1.3bn foray into the US, writes Terry Macalister.

Its shares soared nearly 7.5% as the market welcomed the move to buy American National Can Group (ANC) for $18 per share cash offer plus £615m for debt.

The transaction, which still needs regulatory approval, will be financed mainly by bank loans and sell-offs. It has already hived off its windows and bulk packaging business and is poised to sell its printing operations for £100m. The building engineering and coated films activities should go within 12 months and raise up to £700m.

Chief executive Rolf Borjesson said the ANC deal would enhance earnings by 20% in the first year and give the combined group overall sales of £2.8bn.

He added:"This is the final step in transforming the group and makes us number five in the world for consumer packaging. It strongly increases our presence in the US which is the number one market." If the deal is waived through, Rexam will employ 27,000 worldwide with 5,000 based in Britain. Rexam shares ended the day up13p at 227p but this is still less than half their 1995 peak of 517p.

webTitle: Brink regrets World Online sale uproar

fields.headline: Brink regrets World Online sale uproar
fields.standfirst: World Online
fields.trailText: In an attempt to defuse investors' mounting criticism, World Online, the pan-European internet service provider, yesterday released details of the controversial sale by chairwoman Nina Brink of more than 6% of the company's shares ahead of the flotation.
fields.body:
In an attempt to defuse investors' mounting criticism, World Online, the pan-European internet service provider, yesterday released details of the controversial sale by chairwoman Nina Brink of more than 6% of the company's shares ahead of the flotation.

In a statement yesterday Ms Brink said: "I would like to express my profound regret about the commotion in the market. My sale was made for entirely personal reasons to secure the financial future of my family."

Ms Brink said she would make no further statements, but the Amsterdam bourse and bourse watchdog are investigating the IPO after heavy pressure from investors.

World Online shares have lost around half their value since their March 17 listing amid controversy over sales by Ms Brink of some 15 million shares (6.35% of the firm) in late December.

Ten million were sold to Baystar, a private US investment fund in which Ms Brink is an investor.

The shares were sold at $6.04 (£3.78) apiece, World Online said.

But investors in the Dutch-based internet service provider drew little reassurance from the statement, sending the shares down €4.10 (£2.46) to €19.25.

SNS Securities analyst Bert Siebrand said: "The sheer stupidity of the whole thing is absolutely amazing. I can understand that back in August (when the sale was first agreed), we were facing a different market.

"I can understand that she wanted to cash in some shares. But she should have told us," Siebrand said

He added that even the draft prospectus, which included fewer details on the share sale, was not widely available.

"Nobody saw it. Nobody got it."

Responding to widespread allegations of a close relationship to Baystar, Ms Brink said yesterday she was a "passive investor" in the investment fund and that she had not become entitled to any profit-sharing proceeds from any World Online shares it sold.

webTitle: BT told it is taking wrong ADSL line

fields.headline: BT told it is taking wrong ADSL line
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
BT
fields.trailText: Yes Television, the video-on-demand company gearing up for a £600m flotation, yesterday threatened to abandon its partnership with British Telecom unless the former state-owned monopoly changed the technology being deployed to upgrade its network.
fields.body:
Yes Television, the video-on-demand company gearing up for a £600m flotation, yesterday threatened to abandon its partnership with British Telecom unless the former state-owned monopoly changed the technology being deployed to upgrade its network.

The comments from Yes TV were made as BT was forced to defend itself against criticism that it had been dragging its feet over the introduction of its broadband network.

BT said its roll-out was on target with 25% of the population connected to asymmetric digital subscriber lines, which turn an ordinary telephone copper wire into a high-speed connection for internet, broadcasting or video-on-demand services. BT expects its coverage to grow to 33% of the population by June, which would account for 50% of the UK's internet users.

Yes TV was critical of the technology being deployed and said it was lobbying senior BT executives to introduce a different form of ADSL.

BT has allied with Yes TV to pilot a scheme over the next three months in 440 homes. The equipment supplied by Fujitsu and Alcatel for the service does not have a multi-channel TV facility, leaving only internet access and the ability to download specific films or TV programmes.

"Our endgame is to use ADSL that supports multi-channel TV and if BT does not go down that route then we will find another telecoms partner," said Yes technical director Huw Price-Stephens. "But we are confident BT will listen because they understand that is a threat to their business."

Both sides later tried to play down any suggestion of a rift. BT's director of broadband, Chris Gibbs, said upgrading the ADSL network would be a simple matter. "We have been working on the strategy of building out high-speed internet access so far but are looking very closely at the needs of the broadcasters." He noted that the ban on broadcasting over BT's network would not be lifted until January 2001.

Yes TV provides a video-on-demand service in the joint venture between Kingston Communications and BSkyB using ADSL in Hull.

Kingston began its service in January over its local network carrying 60 TV channels, internet access and video on demand, using technology supplied by Newbridge Networks, recently bought by Alcatel.

Paul Reynolds, BT's managing director of network and information services, estimated BT had spent "a couple of billion pounds" in the past two years upgrading its network to broadband. "There will be more of it in the coming year and I don't see it slackening."

"What we have not done is take a catastrophic lurch into this. It's the fastest roll-out of DSL we've seen in the world."

Yes TV yesterday published details of its flotation and set a price range of 225p-275p.

fields.headline: Microsoft: what the papers say
fields.standfirst: What the US papers are saying about the Microsoft case
fields.trailText: The Boston Globe
fields.body:
The Boston Globe

"The right to innovate on behalf of customers, no matter how badly it hurts Microsoft's competitors, has been the company's battle cry throughout this antitrust case. Yesterday, Microsoft made it clear it will continue to make that argument all the way to the US Supreme Court. And some industry experts say that the company's chances aren't as bleak as they might at first appear."

Chicago Tribune

"High-tech companies had complained for years about Microsoft tactics they considered ruthless and unfair. But because of the software Goliath's stranglehold in the high-tech field, they believed they could do little to counter the company. Many feared Microsoft would exact revenge if they complained too loudly."

Los Angeles Times

"Even after the long-awaited judgment that Microsoft Corp. has violated antitrust laws, only one outcome seems certain: The legal battle will rage for years to come."

Miami Herald

"Microsoft has 'a strong case on appeal,' co-founder and Chairman Bill Gates told reporters and employees. Those appeals, sure to be time-consuming, undercut Attorney General Janet Reno's assertion that Jackson's 43-page decision meant 'consumers who have been harmed can now look forward to benefits'."

New York Times

"In failing to reach a settlement over the weekend, Microsoft is wagering that either it will once again find a more sympathetic appeals court bench or that advances in technology will make the case moot. Indeed, if the case still takes several years to reach a conclusion, any remedy short of a breakup of the company could prove largely irrelevant. The company may also benefit from a change in the White House since Governor George W. Bush, the expected Republican candidate for president, has suggested that antitrust enforcement should be confined mainly to price-fixing cases."

Washington Post

"Microsoft's biggest enemies cheered Monday's ruling that the software giant broke federal antitrust laws, but the only immediate impact on the industry may be emboldened sales pitches from rivals. Observers on all sides of the debate agreed that U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's decision still doesn't resolve the uncertainty over how Microsoft might be punished or whether its dominant Windows operating systems might lose market share any time soon."

fields.headline: Giant cut down by law
fields.standfirst: Mark Tran, who covered the Microsoft antitrust trial for the Guardian, assesses the economic implications of the ruling
fields.trailText: The court ruling in the Microsoft antitrust case sends out an important message to America's corporate titans: no matter how big or important you are to the US economy, you are not above the law.
fields.body:
The court ruling in the Microsoft antitrust case sends out an important message to America's corporate titans: no matter how big or important you are to the US economy, you are not above the law.

Microsoft contributed enormously to the popular acceptance of computers. Apple may have been the pioneer of the computer revolution with its Macintoshes, but it was Microsoft that brought computing to the masses through the Windows operating system. Microsoft's clout in the US economy can be gauged by the impact of judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's decision on the market. The Nasdaq, the market where many technology companies are listed, slumped 349 points, its fifth biggest percentage loss ever, as investors fretted about further lawsuits that will dog Microsoft.

Bill Gates, the world's richest man, now faces the prospect that his mighty company will be broken up and consumers may have to deal with the devil they don't know instead of Windows, the devil they had come to accept grudgingly. But there is something admirable in the ruthlessness of the US economic system, where even a company as important as Microsoft can be taken down.

Innovation and competition lie at the heart of America's economic success. They override the importance of consumer convenience, which was one of Microsoft's arguments. If convenience was the dominant factor, the US government would never have broken up AT&T, the phone monopoly, in 1984. Customers grumbled at having to deal with the plethora of companies that resulted from Ma Bell's break-up. But AT&T's dismemberment had important economic consequences.

It allowed new companies such as MCI, the long distance phone company, to flourish. Phone charges in the US are among the lowest in the world because consumers can pick and choose from a sometimes bewildering array of telecommunications and cable companies. It may be inconvenient, but few Americans want a return to the monopolistic ways of Ma Bell and high phone charges.

It will be argued that the US government is always a step or two behind in the fast-moving world of technology. Netscape, the pioneering internet browser company, which was at the heart of the Microsoft antitrust case, no longer exists, having been absorbed by America Online, the world's leading internet service provider. As Judge Jackson said in his historic ruling, Microsoft succeeded in preventing - for several years, and perhaps permanently - Netscape Navigator and Java, a programming language, from fulfilling their potential to open the market for PC operating systems to competition.

Microsoft may have served consumers with a de facto standard for operating systems, although that is debatable. But Judge Jackson faulted Microsoft on two important counts: it did have monopoly power through its control of 95% of the market in operating systems and it abused that monopoly power by trying to stifle competition, not just from Netscape, but from Apple, Intel, RealNetworks and IBM. For an economic system whose lifeblood is innovation, Microsoft's tactics were unacceptable and detrimental to the US economy.

The US government may have missed the boat in the browser market - Microsoft's Internet Explorer has won that battle - but its victory, subject to appeal, is an important reminder to US companies that they cannot flout America's antitrust laws with impunity. Consumers may be inconvenienced in the short-term, but they will ultimately benefit as new innovative companies flourish. If Microsoft is broken up, these "baby Microsofts" could also be beneficiaries from this landmark case.

fields.headline: The Journals of Sylvia Plath
fields.standfirst:
Stephen Moss assesses the critical response to the publication of The Journals of Sylvia Plath
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: The publication of The Journals of Sylvia Plath (Faber, £30) was, as Jacqueline Rose noted in the Observer, "heralded as an event of some literary significance". Ms Rose, an authority on Plath, was given a good deal of space to expound on that significance, but didn't quite manage it. Her conclusion - "No potential writer trying to haul themselves from bed, drudgery or distraction into writing should miss them" - made it sound more like a creative writing textbook than a new account of a life that has proved captivating and hugely controversial since Plath's suicide in 1963.
fields.body:
The publication of The Journals of Sylvia Plath (Faber, £30) was, as Jacqueline Rose noted in the Observer, "heralded as an event of some literary significance". Ms Rose, an authority on Plath, was given a good deal of space to expound on that significance, but didn't quite manage it. Her conclusion - "No potential writer trying to haul themselves from bed, drudgery or distraction into writing should miss them" - made it sound more like a creative writing textbook than a new account of a life that has proved captivating and hugely controversial since Plath's suicide in 1963.

Rose, in fact, was unwilling to read too much into Plath's outpourings, and argued that publication of the journals (minus the two that Plath's former husband, Ted Hughes, lost or destroyed) resolved nothing. "It is a mistake to see these journals as giving us access to some new or previously hidden 'truth' about Plath," she said. "If the journals are cause for celebration [strange word, surely], it might be, bizarrely, because evidence can be found within them to support every single theory that has ever been produced about Sylvia Plath - the never recovered child of the dead father, the woman oppressed by the small, suffering psychic landscape of her mother, the woman trapped in a domestic life unredeemed by a feminism which arrived too late on the scene, the woman nursed by her husband out of pain into burgeoning creativity, the woman betrayed. They are all here. With each one so vividly and insistently present, and each one just as immediately countered by the energetic presence of another, it becomes clear that none of them, that is, none of them on their own, will, in fact, do."

Other critics were more willing to base their readings of Plath's life on her words, and two - John Carey in the Sunday Times and David Sexton in the London Evening Standard - thought the journals established once and for all that she was unbalanced, impossible, perhaps doomed. The corollary of their analysis was that Hughes did not deserve the opprobrium heaped on him for more than three decades by feminists who blamed him for Plath's death.

"This is a portrait of the artist as a sick colossus," wrote Carey. "Plath's giant ego teetered on the flimsiest of stilts. Ambition goaded her. She craved the world's applause, money and love. But behind the eager mask howled a vortex of self-doubt ... Her elevation into a feminist icon seems curious, given the view of womanhood the journals express. Without a man, woman is incomplete. Single women have 'wry sour lemon acid' in their veins, and give off a 'sterile forced pathetic smell'. Only through childbirth can a woman achieve true fulfilment ... Plath emerges from her account as an invalid. This is recognisably the same disturbed woman that we have met in Hughes's Birthday Letters. In that respect his account is vindicated, if it needed to be."

Sexton's review trod strikingly similar territory: "Plath's best poetry is tremendously accomplished but repulsive, indeed near to evil. Larkin put it best: 'As poems, they are to the highest degree original and scarcely less effective. How valuable they are depends on how highly we rank the expression of experience with which we can in no sense identify, and from which we can only turn with shock and sorrow.' She is a horror poet. This is all the more true of her journals. They are little less than the proof of psychosis. This new edition, 730 pages long, carefully transcribed from the originals, adds an enormous amount of material to the previous one, published only in the States, including two entirely new volumes, from the years 1957-1959, one of which contains raw and bloody material from her private therapy sessions. These expanded journals make Plath more than ever terrifying: self-obsessive, raging, living at an unendurable pitch of intensity. They go far to confirm Hughes's helpless version of events ... It is unfortunate that such pain and hatred, such deadliness, should have been thought a model for anyone, particularly for women, particularly for schoolchildren. The gradual absorption of these journals will at least make that mistake more difficult."

The Carey-Sexton axis, the view that Plath was basically bonkers, had no gainsayers. Where were all the feminists who used to traduce Hughes? Has publication of Birthday Letters in 1998 put them all to flight?

Allison Pearson, in the Daily Telegraph, offered a more sympathetic view of Plath, but she too subscribed to the doomed poet view. "The journals are full of portents and prefigurings - at times so self-conscious they almost stiffen into plans. The book reads like the longest suicide note ever written. Death appears to have taken out a lease on Plath's imagination at the age of eight, when her father Otto died, and never moved out." Pearson examined Plath's obsessive pursuit of a husband and her physical and psychological dependence on Hughes. "There is something almost unhinged in a phenomenally well read woman congratulating herself on having bagged the kind of Heathcliff rampant who straddles the pages of Mills & Boon," she wrote. "But this is fifties America, and there is much to the modern eye that looks not just doolally but diseased in the relations between the sexes."

So there we have it - society was to blame, not Hughes. How the picture has changed since the 70s. But is that really the end of the story?

Larkin put it best: 'As poems, they are to the highest degree original and scarcely less effective. How valuable they are depends on how highly we rank the expression of experience with which we can in no sense identify, and from which we can only turn with shock and sorrow.' She is a horror poet. This is all the more true of her journals. They are little less than the proof of psychosis. This new edition, 730 pages long, carefully transcribed from the originals, adds an enormous amount of material to the previous one, published only in the States, including two entirely new volumes, from the years 1957-1959, one of which contains raw and bloody material from her private therapy sessions. These expanded journals make Plath more than ever terrifying: self-obsessive, raging, living at an unendurable pitch of intensity. They go far to confirm Hughes's helpless version of events ... It is unfortunate that such pain and hatred, such deadliness, should have been thought a model for anyone, particularly for women, particularly for schoolchildren. The gradual absorption of these journals will at least make that mistake more difficult." The Carey-Sexton axis, the view that Plath was basically bonkers, had no gainsayers. Where were all the feminists who used to traduce Hughes? Has publication of Birthday Letters in 1998 put them all to flight? Allison Pearson, in the Daily Telegraph, offered a more sympathetic view of Plath, but she too subscribed to the doomed poet view. "The journals are full of portents and prefigurings - at times so self-conscious they almost stiffen into plans. The book reads like the longest suicide note ever written. Death appears to have taken out a lease on Plath's imagination at the age of eight, when her father Otto died, and never moved out." Pearson examined Plath's obsessive pursuit of a husband and her physical and psychological dependence on Hughes. "There is something almost unhinged in a phenomenally well read woman congratulating herself on having bagged the kind of Heathcliff rampant who straddles the pages of Mills & Boon," she wrote. "But this is fifties America, and there is much to the modern eye that looks not just doolally but diseased in the relations between the sexes." So there we have it - society was to blame, not Hughes. How the picture has changed since the 70s. But is that really the end of the story?

fields.headline: Premiership votes for pay-per-view revolution
fields.standfirst: How the proposal is made up
fields.trailText: The Premier League last night approved a radical shake-up of televised football which may generate untold riches through the introduction of pay-per-view games and giving clubs limited rights to broadcast their own games.
fields.body:
The Premier League last night approved a radical shake-up of televised football which may generate untold riches through the introduction of pay-per-view games and giving clubs limited rights to broadcast their own games.

The 20 chairmen voted to accept a revolutionary tender document which will now be sent to all broadcasters interested in showing football.

Under the terms of the proposals they will be able to bid for different packages, including two highlights programmes and a limited number of pay-per-view games.

For the first time clubs will be given rights to show matches on their own channels less than 24 hours after games have taken place; they will also be able to broadcast them on the internet.

Use of new technology and the decision to end exclusivity in the broadcasting of games mean that more football will be shown on television than ever before.

The deal is for three years and starts at the beginning of the 2001-2002 season. It could lead to as many as three live games being broadcast on Sunday afternoons.

Broadcasters have until May 10 to submit initial bids; the Premier League is expected to make its final decision by July. The deal may be worth as much as £2bn as all the major players, satellite and terrestrial, are expected to bid for packages.

The tender document was finally approved late yesterday afternoon, when a two-thirds majority was reached by the chairmen. A number of small clubs opposed the structure of the deal, claiming it would increase the gap between rich and poor.

The tender document divides up the broadcasting of football into seven packages.

At the core of the deal will be the 66-live-games-per-season package, with matches to be broadcast on Sundays or Mondays. The winning broadcaster will have the first choice of the live games but all Premiership clubs will have to appear a minimum three times.

At the moment 60 live games are shown each season by Sky. That deal between the broadcaster and the Premier League expires at the end of next season.

The new one will also lead to first-class domestic football being screened on a pay-per-view basis for the first time.

Under the proposals 40 such matches will be shown each season, each kicking-off at 2pm on a Sunday.

The broadcaster who wins the bid will be allowed to feature the same club on a maximum of six occasions a season, and all Premiership teams will have to be shown on pay per view at least once during that time.

There will also be two highlights programmes featured on British terrestrial television each weekend.

The terms of the Saturday evening highlights package - currently owned by the BBC - will contractually oblige the broadcaster to show them at a fixed, unalterable time.

Another package of highlights to be broadcast on Sun days from 9pm is also to be made available. It will feature highlights of Saturday games and any Sunday afternoon matches.

Both packages will be available only to free-to-air broadcasters.

Richard Scudamore, the chief executive of the Premier League, said: "We feel that this is a very balanced document. It allows consumers more choice and gives clubs greater flexibility.

"I have to emphasise that the deal has not been done but it is a pointer towards what the future deal will look like."

The most revolutionary aspects of the deal are the concessions made to the country's larger clubs, who will thus be able to cash in further on their popularity.

For the first time clubs will have the rights to broadcast matches they are involved in on their own channels. This could generate millions in extra revenue for the likes of Manchester United and Liverpool, who already have their own channels.

Under the new proposals clubs will also have the right to broadcast their Saturday afternoon matches from Sunday midnight onwards.

Sunday afternoon matches can be shown from 10pm on Mondays and games played on Monday evenings can be shown from midnight onwards.

Clubs will also have the rights to show matches on their own websites once the weekend is over. Scudamore said: "This allows for clubs to provide a proper service to their fans worldwide."

A sub-licence is also to be put up for tender allowing broadcasters to experiment with mobile phone technology, so that matches or highlights can be broadcast on the screens of handsets.

Seven ways to sell football

 The main deal Sixty-six live games played at 4pm on Sundays and at 8pm on Mondays, with the right to show highlights programme on Sunday mornings.

 Pay-per-view Forty live games to be shown on pay-per-view basis. There could be up to three Sunday games but first and second choice will go to 'main deal' broadcaster. BSkyB, NTL and Ondigital likely to bid. Cost of games to be carefully examined, says the Premier League chief executive Richard Scudamore, right.

 Saturday highlights Reserved for terrestrial channels; BBC likely to face competition from ITV and possibly Channel 5.

 Sunday highlights A reintroduction. Reserved for free-to-air TV.

 Clubs' channels Currently use only archive material but in-house channels such as MUTV will now show their own matches on a delayed basis.

 Internet Clubs can show their own Saturday, Sunday and Monday games on their websites after midnight on Monday.

 Sub-licences To be awarded on experimental basis for 'video on demand' and mobile phones. Overseas and radio rights yet to be dealt with.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: The most expensive film ever begins shooting in Hawaii, Travolta's a dad for the second time, and Thora Birch and Jim Caviezel take up the casting couch
fields.body:
 History's most expensive production finally went before the cameras on Sunday, as exterior location shots for Disney's Peal Harbor began filming in Hawaii. The second world war spectacular is produced by Jerry Bruckheimer, directed by Michael Bay and stars Ben Affleck, Cuba Gooding Jr and Kate Beckinsale. The budget is set at a whopping $135m.

 John Travolta is a father for the second time round. His wife, sometime actress Kelly Preston, has given birth to the couple's second child - a 9lb girl named Ella Bleu. Travolta and Preston's son Jett is eight this month.

Casting couch

 American Beauty star Thora Birch has signed to star in The Hole, a teen thriller to be directed by Nick Hamm (Talk of Angels). The picture tells the tale of a quartet of adolescents who explores a mysterious underground maze they unearth beneath their school. Production begins in June and the film will shoot in England. The 18-year-old actress (who played Kevin Spacey's daughter in American Beauty) has clearly hit the big time: her fee is a reported seven-figure sum. Birch has recently completed work on Ghost World, the feature debut from maverick documentary-maker Terry (Crumb) Zwigoff.

 Jim Caviezel will take the lead role in The Count of Monte Cristo, the umpteenth adaptation of Alexander Dumas's swashbuckling tale of revenge. The picture begins shooting in Ireland this July, although a director has yet to be dragooned on board. The skinny, intense Caviezel cropped up most memorably in Terrence Malick's The Thin Red Line and is currently completing work on the Mimi Rogers comedy-drama Play it Forward, starring Oscar winners Helen Hunt and Kevin Spacey.

fields.headline: Aventis Science Prize for Children
fields.trailText: All of the shortlisted books try to present scientific information in an accessible way without being patronising, but the different styles reflect very different solutions.
fields.body:
Helping children to understand science is the aim of the Aventis Science Prize for Children, run jointly by the Science Museum and Copus (the Committee on Public Understanding of Science of the Royal Society). The prize, for which a shortlist of six books has been selected by a panel of adults chaired by conservationist David Bellamy, is judged by pupils from 31 schools who will pick the book they feel does its job the best.

The problems of presenting scientific information in an accessible but non-patronising way, all the while keeping it simple yet not over-simplified, are legion, and the diverse approaches and styles of the shortlisted titles reflect very different solutions.

Richard Robinson's Brainwaves in the Bedroom (OUP, £3.99) is one of a series of indoor tricks for the different rooms of the house. The combination of simple scientific principles - like the optical illusion that makes us think a vertical line is longer than a horizontal one because of our natural fear of falling - with paper and pencil tricks which can be simply played on friends and family, teaches effortlessly. The fun factor far outweighs any sense of instruction.

Phil Gates's Evolve or Die (Scholastic, £3.99) is one of the Horrible Science series that uses the successful approach of Horrible Histories. Again, the emphasis is on fun and the attractive way the story is told, helped by cartoon illustrations, will be the initial lure. But the science is sound, too, exploring the issues around evolution including a long account of Darwin's views and their implications.

The Usborne First Encyclopedia of our World (Usborne, £8.99) has a more traditional, textbook feel. Split into double-page spreads, it covers the key topics in physical geography from the formation of the world to pollution today. Well-labelled illustrations help to explain the scientific facts, making it an easy but absorbing introduction to science.

Martin Redfern's The Kingfisher Book of Planet Earth (Kingfisher, £14.99) examines how the planet was formed by looking at the forces of nature. The text reflects the excitement - and violence - of the earth's ever-changing make-up.

Read all about it - hot headlines flag up new developments in space discovery in Michael Johnstone's The History News (Walker, £10.99). Eye-catching newspaper spreads chart observations of space from Ptolemy to Hubble with suitable illustrations for each period.

It is the astonishing quality and detail of the photographs in Peter Bond's DK Guide to Space (Dorling Kindersley, £12.99) that make it so irresistible. It includes the latest images from the Hubble telescope revealing every blemish on the planets and capturing the amazing moments of the birth and death of a star.

The winning book will receive the £10,000 prize at a ceremony at the Science Museum on May 23.

Lyn Garner's selection of the best books for kids is on Books Unlimited's children's library special report.

fields.headline: Témoin
fields.standfirst: Capt. Comte, fire chief, looks back on the day a fire killed 39 in the Mont Blanc tunnel
fields.trailText: Capt. Comte, fire chief, looks back on the day a fire killed 39 in the Mont Blanc tunnel
fields.body:
Le jour même, on m'a dit qu'il y avait un problème dans le tunnel du Mont Blanc et que nos premiers secours étaient partis. Je suis allé les rejoindre.

Sur le moment, on n'avait pas d'informations précises - on ne savait pas ce qui brûlait, ni à quel endroit, s'il y avait du monde à l'intérieur ou pas. Mes gars étaient partis parce qu'ils pensaient qu'il y avait du monde et ils voulaient les sauver.

J'ai appris peu de temps après mon arrivée qu'ils étaient coincés dans le tunnel - et qu'ils n'avaient pas d'air. J'ai envoyé un véhicule de pompiers avec des bouteilles d'air pour aller les chercher. Mais il y avait énormément de fumée et le véhicule s'est trouvé bloqué pratiquement dès son entrée dans le tunnel. La fumée était tellement dense qu'on ne voyait pas à un mètre.

On n'a jamais atteint les accidentés - mes gars sont restés coincés dans la fumée. C'était de la folie - on respirait deux bouffées de cette fumée et on se retrouvait à genoux, tellement elle était toxique.

On a attendu encore un peu et mes collègues qui étaient restés à l'extérieur nous ont envoyé des secours - une ambulance et puis des bouteilles d'air de rechange pour qu'on puisse rentrer avec les véhicules qu'on avait. Là, on est sortis. Il devait être quatre heures et demie, alors qu'on était rentrés à onze heures.

C'était l'enfer - mes garçons ne s'en sont pas remis, psychologiquement ils sont très atteints. Moi aussi. Mais je pense que dans la même situation, mes hommes y retourneraient, parce qu'ils sont pompiers. Ils sont là pour sauver la vie.

Glossaire/Glossary

une bouffée d'air a big gulp of air
coincé stuck
de la folie madness
du monde a lot of people
énormément a lot
mes gars (coll.) my guys
à genoux on one's knees
peu de temps après a little later, a short while after (my arrival)
sur le moment at the time

 Captain Comte, chief of firemen in Chamonix at the time of the disaster just over a year ago, was speaking to Zo Eisenstein.

fields.headline: Hadde 'nen Piep?
fields.standfirst: For the second year, Germany's Eurovision song contest entry is sending up the event.  Nicole Prestle finds out if young people agree
fields.trailText: For the second year, Germany's Eurovision song contest entry is sending up the event. Nicole Prestle finds out if young people agree
fields.body:
Hadde mal 'n Moment Zeit? Klar doch. Für 'ne Reise nach Stockholm immer. Stefan Raab wird sie sich gerne nehmen. Am 5. Mai vertritt er beim Grand Prix d'Eurovison de la Chanson seine Heimat Deutschland - im sexy glitzernden Anzug, in Plateauschuhen und mit langhaarigen Blondinen im Hintergrund-Chor.

Sein Lied? Ach ja, den Titel kann man sich ganz leicht merken, aussprechen dagegen schon weniger: "Wadde hadde dudde da" heißt er. Was auf Deutsch soviel bedeutet wie: "Was hast du denn da?" Entschuldigung - der Text ist natürlich deutsch. Nur, dass man ihn nicht so recht versteht, wenn man nicht den gleichen Dialekt spricht.

Schon Guildo Horns Auftritt im vergangenen Jahr hat in der deutschen Schlagerszene niemand so richtig ernst genommen. "Piep, piep, piep" lautete der vielsagende Titel seines Liedes und so manch einer hat sich schmunzelnd gefragt, ob's bei Horn vielleicht wirklich piept.

Doch heuer ist den meisten altgedienten Song-Schreibern das Lachen gehörig vergangen. Traut sich doch schon wieder einer, das ehrenwerte Festival auf die Schippe zu nehmen. Einige Komponisten haben nun resigniert ihren Rückzug aus dem Geschäft angekündigt. Sie wollen keine Lieder mehr für die Vorentscheidung schreiben, "es gewinnen doch ohnehin nur die Irren".

Ist Stefan Raabs Auftritt wirklich so peinlich für Deutschland? Wir haben Jugendliche befragt.

Was haltet Ihr von Stefan Raabs Auftritt und von seinem Lied?

Marion (17): Ich habe die Vorentscheidung gesehen und ich muß zugeben: Ich fand das alles ziemlich witzig. Vor allem die dummen Tussen im Hintergrund.

Michael (22): Ich kenne nur das Lied, aber das reicht mir schon. Ich finde es richtig kacke. Stefan Raab hat eine arrogante Art, und das mag ich nicht an ihm.

Christian (17): Normal ist der Grand Prix doch ein richtiges Spießertreffen. Dann kommt auf einmal jemand wie Gildo Horn oder Stefan Raab, verarscht die ganze Sache und gewinnt auch noch. Ich finde das gut.

Die meisten Länder schicken bekannte Sänger zum Songfestival, Lieder und Texte sind oft anspruchsvoll. Wie wird der deutsche Beitrag eurer Meinung nach auf die Jury wirken?

Christian: Viele denken über Deutschland ja in Klischees. Lederhosen, Dirndl. Da kann Raab einmal aufräumen. Wenn die Jury Humor hat, wird sie das auch würdigen.

Marion: Der Grand Prix sollte ja auch was für jüngere Leute sein, und die hören bestimmt nicht zu, wenn es immer nur so anspruchsvolle Lieder gibt. Raab bringt den Song gut rüber, auch wenn er vielleicht keinen so großen Sinn ergibt. Das Zuhören macht Spaß, und das ist doch die Hauptsache, oder?

Marion: Naja, den letzten Platz wird er hoffentlich nicht machen. Ich glaube aber ehrlich gesagt auch nicht an einen ersten. Er wird wahrscheinlich im Mittelfeld landen, aber das ist ja ok.

Michael: Raab hat die Leute mit diesem Schmarren total auf seine Seite gezogen. Weil seine Fans für ihn gestimmt haben, hat er auch die Vorentscheidung gewonnen. Ob er das in Schweden auch schafft, wage ich zu bezweifeln.

1999 Guildo Horn, 2000 Stefan Raab. Wie wird es mit dem Grand Prix weitergehen?

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Today's paper prattle picked apart
fields.trailText: The Sun Michel Platini flew into London yesterday and met Mohamed Al-Fayed for lunch to discuss taking over Fulham's vacant managerial post. Platini is currently a senior figure within Fifa as well as the head of the French Federation's Organising Committee. But Fayed looks set to tempt the former European Footballer of the Year with a contract worth £2m-a-year.
fields.body:
The Sun Michel Platini flew into London yesterday and met Mohamed Al-Fayed for lunch to discuss taking over Fulham's vacant managerial post. Platini is currently a senior figure within Fifa as well as the head of the French Federation's Organising Committee. But Fayed looks set to tempt the former European Footballer of the Year with a contract worth £2m-a-year.

Daily Star Rivaldo will not be joining Manchester United. "I have always believed the best league competitions in the world are Spain's Primera Liga and Italy's Serie A," he said. "My opinion hasn't changed."

The Mirror Arsenal are ready to sign a striker who has never played professional football before. Frenchman Claudio Samer was spotted by Arsene Wenger performing ball tricks on late night TV. Samer was invited over to London by Wenger for a trial, and scored for the reserves with a mis-hit shot.

Planet Football Sebastien Frey is the latest goalkeeper to be linked with a move to Old Trafford. The French Under-21 keeper, currently the property of Internazionale but on loan at Verona, is a former teammate of United's Mickael Silvestre. Inter coach Marcello Lippi does not want to sell Frey, but may have no choice as Italian international Angelo Peruzzi remains his first choice keeper.

fields.headline: Tarantino on the war path
fields.trailText: Those fearing for Quentin Tarantino's sanity may well be turning still more uneasy today. The Reservoir Dogs director is hard at work on a script which contains a tailor-made role for gurning American comic Adam Sandler.
fields.body:
Those fearing for Quentin Tarantino's sanity may well be turning still more uneasy today. The Reservoir Dogs director is hard at work on a script which contains a tailor-made role for gurning American comic Adam Sandler.

Discussing the project at a Miramax Oscar party with a journalist from the Daily Mail, the Reservoir Dogs director described the film as a gung-ho second world war movie in the style of The Dirty Dozen. "I've got a bunch of guys fighting the Nazis, and there's a part for Adam Sandler, and I hope he'll be crazy enough to do it."

If and when the script is completed, the film will be Tarantino's first since Jackie Brown in 1997 and only his second in the last seven years. But while Tarantino's star has effectively dropped out of sight, Sandler's has risen at an alarming rate. A breakthrough role in The Wedding Singer led to last year's hit comedy Big Daddy and to the stand-up comic currently commanding an alleged fee of $20m per picture.

In addition to toiling on his war movie script, Tarantino has filled his days with some other writing work. He has written the liner notes for one section of Columbia's forthcoming Johnny Cash box-set Love, God and Murder. While he wrote for the Murder section, U2 frontman Bono tackled God and Cash's wife Jane Carter penned the Love notes.
