fields.headline: Film confronts Spain's last taboo
fields.standfirst: Terrorism is tackled at last in a biopic of an ETA leader
fields.trailText: The murder of Yoyes, one of the most senior women in the Basque separatist group ETA, at the hands of a former comrade, shook Spanish society. Now, 14 years later, a film about her life threatens to reopen old wounds.
fields.body:
The murder of Yoyes, one of the most senior women in the Basque separatist group ETA, at the hands of a former comrade, shook Spanish society. Now, 14 years later, a film about her life threatens to reopen old wounds.

Yoyes was released in cinemas throughout Spain, including the Basque country, at the weekend. The film breaks a taboo on using the terrorist group, which has killed some 800 people in its 30-year campaign for an independent Basque state, as subject matter for the cinema.

"Compared to the American cinema, or the British, which has touched on the most painful aspects of its history, and made many films on Northern Ireland, the Spanish cinema has tiptoed around subjects like ETA terrorism despite their decisive influence on the country," said Guillermo Altares, film critic of the daily El Pais.

The film traces the life of Dolores Gonzalez Catarain - known by the codename Yoyes - from her early involvement with ETA in the Basque country and France, through her exile in Mexico from Paris and her eventual return to Spain.

It shows her going in 1973 to France, where most of the leadership were based, and taking over responsibility for ETA's political wing.

Yoyes is seen wielding a gun in target practice but not carrying out a terrorist attack.

The film includes real footage of the prime minister at the time announcing to a roomful of cheering Eta mem bers that Franco had died.

It then follows Yoyes's gradual disillusionment, after a particularly bloody bomb attack on a Madrid cafeteria, and her decision to break with the group and seek exile in Mexico.

"I have tried to tell the truth," said Helena Taberna, the director, whose treatment of Yoyes is broadly sympathetic.

The film focuses on Yoyes's love affairs and marriage to a philosophy professor, the birth of her son, and her agonising over whether to return to Spain in the early 80s when the country had become a democracy after Franco's death and former terrorists were offered an amnesty.

"Neither one side or the other will let me live in peace," Yoyes says in the film, which ends with her son witnessing her death in 1986 in a crowded market place, where she was shot at point-blank range by a member of ETA who considered her a traitor.

"This is one woman's story, based on her right to change and on the times she lived in," said Ms Taberna, who acknowledged that at first it was difficult to get funding for the film, an Italian, French and Spanish co-production, which received 20m pesetas (about £72,000) in subsidies from the Basque regional government run by the Basque Nationalist party.

"People haven't made films on ETA because they were scared," said Andres Vicente Gomez, a producer.

Yoyes was filmed last spring, virtually under cover, on location in the Spanish Basque country and in France during the truce declared by ETA when it looked as if peace might be possible.

Its release coincides with renewed conflict after ETA's decision to end the ceasefire in December.

So far this year there have been three deaths; threats against politicians, businessmen and journalists, one of whom received a bomb in a cigar box last week which failed to go off; and a sense that peace is further away than ever. At the weekend there was widespread street violence in the Basque country.

Ms Taberna has been praised for her courage in tackling the subject, but criticised for equating ETA with the self-proclaimed Anti-Liberation Groups, known as Gal, which waged a bungled dirty war against the terrorist group in the early 1980s.

Gal's links to the governments in Madrid at the time are still under investigation.

A minister shown in the film bears a strong resemblance to a minister who is currently on trial together with a top paramilitary civil guard general. They are accused of involve ment in the deaths of two ETA members.

"Of course the Gal should not have happened, but it [the dirty war] went on for only three years, not 30," said one Basque MP.

"We're starting to break the taboo," said Borja Hermoso of the daily El Mundo. "But there is still a sense that the subject needs to be handled carefully."

"It's still very much alive. I'm not surprised people don't dare tackle it," said Jose Sacristan, an actor involved in another film on ETA.

"Those who have done have been quite rigorous. It is better to have fewer films and that they should maintain that rigour."

fields.headline: Hanks flick avoids Beach-style controversy
fields.trailText: Fox appear to have learned a long, hard lesson from the controversy surrounding The Beach. The studio's latest production - a desert-island drama starring Tom Hanks - appears to be bending over backwards to reassure watchful environmentalists.
fields.body:
Fox appear to have learned a long, hard lesson from the controversy surrounding The Beach. The studio's latest production - a desert-island drama starring Tom Hanks - appears to be bending over backwards to reassure watchful environmentalists.

Co-funded by Fox and DreamWorks, Cast Away has been filming on the idyllic Fijian island of Monuriki. While the World Wildlife Fund (WWF) was concerned over the possible damage caused by an invading army of some 100 crew members, WWF representatives visiting the shoot found their fears put to bed.

The film-makers, they conclude, "have gone to extraordinary lengths to avoid the public relations disaster that plagued The Beach".

Before alighting on Monuriki, Cast Away's backers hired a local consultant to assess the possible environmental damage to the island and have followed his recommendations to the letter.

They also agreed to an environmental code of conduct with the island's landowners. Any tree removed will be replaced with at least three of the same species, while there will be no introduction of any alien flora or fauna (apart from the one fat-cat Hollywood star, of course).

Meanwhile, another casualty of The Beach is similarly patching up his tarnished reputation. Environmental groups protesting the alleged damage to Maya Beach on Phi Phi Island in Thailand invariably chose to focus on the film's star, Leonardo DiCaprio, even going so far as to burn an effigy of the actor outside the movie's premiere in Bangkok.

But now the baby-faced blond is hitting back. Last Friday, the 25-year-old actor paid a visit to the Oval Office to grill President Clinton on environmental issues. A White House spokesman confirmed that the pair discussed the current administration's policy on global warming and related issues. The interview was filmed for ABC and will air in America on April 22 as part of the network's coverage of Earth Day.

fields.headline: No drinks, sorry, you're ladies
fields.trailText: Cricket likes its dinners. Benefit dinners, club dinners, awards dinners; dinners held to raise money, launch books, mark anniversaries. Wisden has one every year in early April, to celebrate the Almanack's publication and thank its contributors. It had long been held at a prominent gentlemen's club in central London, until the club blotted its linen napkin quite spectacularly. Some female guests were refused a drink at the bar and directed upstairs where it was "nice and quiet". This was in 1999. The hitherto-stubborn barstaff quickly saw the error of their ways once a man complained - but not quickly enough. That man was the Almanack's editor, Matthew Engel, whose wife, Hilary, had been one of those barred.
fields.body:
Cricket likes its dinners. Benefit dinners, club dinners, awards dinners; dinners held to raise money, launch books, mark anniversaries. Wisden has one every year in early April, to celebrate the Almanack's publication and thank its contributors. It had long been held at a prominent gentlemen's club in central London, until the club blotted its linen napkin quite spectacularly. Some female guests were refused a drink at the bar and directed upstairs where it was "nice and quiet". This was in 1999. The hitherto-stubborn barstaff quickly saw the error of their ways once a man complained - but not quickly enough. That man was the Almanack's editor, Matthew Engel, whose wife, Hilary, had been one of those barred.

So this year guests will not be trotting along to clubland. The Almanack will be celebrating its 137th birthday tomorrow night at The Honourable Artillery Company, EC1. Hardly Damien Hirst's Pharmacy - uniformed pikemen will carve up the (British) beef - but quite a bold step for a book which dines out on tradition.

The dinner is a bit of a shock if you are not used to black-tie dos. Pre-prandial snifters are followed by a three-course meal plus cheese and port. A personalised bright yellow Almanack awaits each guest by their place at the table, there are toasts to the Queen and to cricket, plus a speech. The copious amounts of alcohol on offer and the jovial prep-school atmosphere lead to some unexpected situations. There was once an incident involving Steven Lynch (the mild-mannered managing editor of WCM), the then cricket correspondent of the Daily Star and a soda syphon. Another time, WCM's publisher had the pleasure of being continually winked at by a former Wisden Cricketer of the Year.

Men, unsurprisingly, outnumber women - of 120-odd guests last year, about 15 were female. But at least we were allowed in. Incredibly, up to 1990 women were invited for the aperitifs, but then told to toddle off down the road for a fish-and-chip dinner. The dispossessed included Christine Forrest and Harriet Monkhouse, numbers two and three at the Almanack. Handy with the editing and the stats they might have been, but they didn't quite cut the mustard with a knife and fork. Sultry serving-wenches, of course, were more than welcome. But that was then and this is now. Next week, I'll report back on how things went at the new venue.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.standfirst:
Destitute still going hungry as charities fight to use produce

What's wrong with our food? - special report
Live debate: John Vidal online at 1pm
fields.trailText: Julie is a waste of a teenager. She sits 20 yards from the front of Marks and Spencer's supermarket in Islington. Hands grimed with dirt, eyes dulled and body hunched, she lives rough. Tonight it's north London, tomorrow wherever. In a day's begging she expects to raise about £10, which she will spend on fags, bus rides and something round the corner from the burger bar. All she's eaten today is a milkshake and a cheese sandwich. She says she last had fruit and vegetables before Christmas.
fields.body:
Julie is a waste of a teenager. She sits 20 yards from the front of Marks and Spencer's supermarket in Islington. Hands grimed with dirt, eyes dulled and body hunched, she lives rough. Tonight it's north London, tomorrow wherever. In a day's begging she expects to raise about £10, which she will spend on fags, bus rides and something round the corner from the burger bar. All she's eaten today is a milkshake and a cheese sandwich. She says she last had fruit and vegetables before Christmas.

Round the back of M&S at closing time, Chris White, the food manager, has lined up seven trolley loads of today's waste food - food that has reached its sell-by date but is still edible for at least a few days. There's at least £500 of low-fat pastas, cocktail sausages, organic milk, cod in parsley sauce, veal escalopes, beefburgers, chicken in white wine, ham tagliatelle, sesame prawn toast, salmon steaks, barbecue ribs, potatoes, greens, leeks and roasted mushroom lasagne.

M&S Islington is just a neighbourhood store, but it sells £11m of food a year. However much Mr White and his colleagues would like to, they can't give the waste food away directly to Julie or anyone else because of strict hygiene laws.

Landfill

Mr White throws out almost £300,000 worth of food each year and the council lorries come round every day to cart it to landfill sites. But not all is dumped. A large chunk goes to Crisis FareShare, a scheme run by the charity Crisis which redistributes £500,000 of food a year to the homeless in several cities. Every day, about 15-20% of the store's food waste is picked up in the charity's small refrigerated van.

Andy Yuille, the driver, has already picked up hundreds of sandwiches from Pret a Manger sandwich shop chain, a load from Sainsbury's, mushroom pate and pizzas from a restaurant, and untold cartons of high-quality Covent Garden soup. He never knows what will be offered. Once he got three tons of energy bars, another time enough Italian Christmas cakes to feed an army.

"This is just the tip of the waste iceberg," says Mr Yuille. "The waste is phenomenal. Many places are good at giving away, but some of the biggest just don't want to know. They'd prefer to throw it away rather than give it."

"There'll always be some waste," says Mr White. "It's miss and hit. You never know if someone will come in to buy 10 loaves one week and nothing the next. Throwing food away is just pure wastage. It's no good to anyone." Giving the waste away, he says, is a community act.

The van winds through the rush hour back to the Crisis warehouse where a late shift of volunteers - students, nurses, the unemployed, office workers - unpack and grade it. More has been brought from other supermarkets, wholesalers and sandwich shops.

Meat and frozen foods are stored in the huge coldroom. Vegetables go into piles. There are 10ft-high stacks of Uncle Ben's stir fry rice. "We could use more. There used to be an active policy by many companies not to donate," says the manager, Lou White. "It's changing, but a lot of companies are just not there yet."

The next morning a new shift of volunteers arrives and the Crisis vans rush the food round to hostels for the homeless, night shelters, soup kitchens, old people's residential units, and the 30 or more other charities that Crisis FareShare serves.

By 11am donated food is bubbling away in Bernadette's and Bridgit's pots. The two women cook up to 1,500 meals a week at the Dello centre for the single homeless in Whitechapel, east London. Sandwiches are put out, but the culinary highlight is the 16 gallons of soup. Today's, says Bernadette, is typical. In go the waste vegetables, a load of ostrich, chicken, lentils, tins of dhal, mulligatawny soup, burgers, baked beans and some curry powder. It's Van Gogh yellow, and it tastes wonderful.

"It's really good nutritious food," says Bernadette. "They like the meat and spuds. We put out the sandwiches and use the fresh stuff immediately, the rest we stockpile." The 75,000 meals they prepare each year from donated food costs the centre less than 15p each.

Albert and George are waiting outside for their meal. They come every day as much for the company as the food itself. "I've worked all my life and get £51 a week," says George. "After I've paid the bills I have less than £20 a week for food and everything else. There are thousands of people in my situation all of whom would appreciate food of this quality."

Weighing up the handouts

The case for distribution

It feeds people in need at the same time as saving waste

It puts pressure on companies and governments to reduce waste

It boosts staff morale in shops and restaurants and gives companies kudos

The case against

It may perpetuate poverty rather than promote long-term solutions

People may become dependent on food redistribution schemes. It is far better to promote self-help schemes and community-based food initiatives

Private charitable schemes can unwittingly replace the safety net of public welfare, and play into the hands of governments which want to save money on welfare

Related stories
Scandal of the food Britain throws away
Stores need rethink as ban nears on landfill dumping

webTitle: Stores need rethink as ban nears on landfill dumping

fields.headline: Stores need rethink as ban nears on landfill dumping
fields.standfirst:
What's wrong with our food? - special report
Live debate: John Vidal online at 1pm
fields.trailText: In the US, where 27% of all food is thrown away, food retailers and processors get tax breaks to give surplus food away. More than 660,000 tonnes are given to charities who feed one in 10 of the population each year.
fields.body:
In the US, where 27% of all food is thrown away, food retailers and processors get tax breaks to give surplus food away. More than 660,000 tonnes are given to charities who feed one in 10 of the population each year.

But Britain, despite having millions of people experiencing "food poverty" and some of the worst balanced diets in the world, is one of the meanest of all countries when it comes to giving away food past its sell-by date but not its use-by date. Most companies find dumping the food in landfill sites the quickest, easiest and cheapest solution to the problem of waste. Many others are frustrated but do not have the means to arrange and coordinate its distribution to charity.

However, with the EU likely to ban food being dumped in landfill sites in the next few years, supermarkets and food processors are trying to work more closely with food charities and composting schemes.

A new report from Sustain, which represents more than 100 public interest groups including the Child Poverty Action group, the Health Education Trust and leading unions, environmental and health charities, has found that from almost nothing being donated in 1993, British food surplus donations now provide 8m meals a year at a cost of about £1m.

About 500 charities working with the deprived and vulnerable now benefit from food redistribution. They in turn distribute it to the homeless, elderly, women's refuges, disability groups, school breakfast clubs, rehabilitation centres, youth and community groups and local authorities, most of whom could take more of the surplus food.

"Surplus food has helped keep at bay hunger and malnutrition for millions of people and the food is very welcome", says Corinna Hawkes, the author of the Sustain report.

But, she says, there are many reasons why Britain should not take the US route and rush into giving surplus food away.

"Practical responses to emergency situations, such as providing food to people on the margins of society, are needed. But the question we should be asking is why is Britain's ability to provide all of its citizens with adequate means to obtain food declining?

"Short-term actions, even with the best of intentions, can cause problems in the long term. Food relief can deflect attention from why there is food poverty; the feeling that the problem is being solved removes the pressure for action."

The report calls for a wide debate about the implications of food handouts and an investigation into why so much food is wasted.

"Government says people should be given a hand-up not a handout, yet the problem of poor people's diets is increasingly being dealt with through hand-outs," says Jacqui Webster, food poverty officer at Sustain. "Evidence from other countries, particularly the US and Canada, suggests that surplus food redistribution has helped maintain the problems of food poverty."

Related stories
Scandal of the food Britain throws away
Waste food policy reaches sell-by date

webTitle: Scandal of the food Britain throws away

fields.headline: Scandal of the food Britain throws away
fields.standfirst:
What's wrong with our food? - special report
Live debate: John Vidal online at 1pm
fields.trailText: Britain is throwing away up to 500,000 tonnes of edible food each year - a scale of waste that has shocked charities working with the country's 13m people in poverty.
fields.body:
Britain is throwing away up to 500,000 tonnes of edible food each year - a scale of waste that has shocked charities working with the country's 13m people in poverty.

Only about 3,000 tonnes is given to charities and local authorities for redistribution, and all the charities licensed by the government to collect and store surplus food say that they could distribute much more, were it made available.

A spokeswoman for Grocery Aid, which collects 2,000 tonnes of food a year from retailers and distributes it to 374 charities, said last night: "We could handle a lot, lot more. We have a waiting list of more than 100 charities who would like to take food which we collect."

"This is craziness," said Corinna Hawkes of Sustain, an alliance of more than 100 food, environmental and other char ities and unions whose report on surplus food in Britain is published today. "It's want in the midst of plenty. The government must address the issues and make sure everyone can obtain food through the normal channels."

Figures obtained by the Guardian suggest that the value of the dumped food is at least £400m a year, and the cost of disposal about £50m a year and growing rapidly with the new landfill tax.

The scale of the wastage from supermarkets, food processors, wholesalers and restaurants is not known, because many companies refuse to make their data public, citing commercial confidentiality. But the environmental consultant Swap, which specialises in reducing food wastage from companies, says that roughly 20% of all food is thrown away.

In the past 10 months, the government's food interven tion board dumped almost 30,000 tonnes of fresh vegetables and fruit which had been withdrawn from the market to guarantee farm prices.

Tesco, the largest food retailer in Britain, said yesterday that it throws away £28m of food a year, a figure believed to be roughly equal to Sainsbury's.

One supermarket group, which asked not to be identified, admitted discarding up to 100,000 tonnes of food a year, of which "most" was edible.

Asda would give no figures but each store is thought on average to dump about 50 tonnes of food a year; Safeway dumps 20,000 tonnes.

Attitudes to charity differ widely. Tesco has no policy to donate food, but lowers prices when it approaches its sell-by date. "We have tried giving food away, but there are too many problems with food safety," a spokesman said.

Sainsbury's, which has reduced its food wastage from 23% to under 10% in the past six years, has pledged to give up to 1,000 tonnes of waste food a year to Crisis FareShare, a charity that feeds the homeless. Marks & Spencer gives large amounts to the Salvation Army and the charity Grocery Aid. Safeway donates only to zoos and animal sanctuaries.

"The scale of the waste problem is vast," said Pete Riley of Friends of the Earth. "A staggering amount of good food is landfilled each year, leading to environmental problems. Yet people on low incomes could be benefiting."

But some argue that giving food away risks maintaining the long-term problems of poverty. Tim Lang, of the food policy centre at Thames Valley University, said yesterday: "Food charity has never solved the problem of food poverty. It is a return to the medieval past, not a way forward for Britain."

Related stories
Stores need rethink as ban nears on landfill dumping
Waste food policy reaches sell-by date

fields.headline: Microsoft reacts to the judgment
fields.standfirst: Bill Gates and Steve Ballmer Statements on Conclusions of Law
fields.body:
Bill Gates: Good afternoon. I want to say a few words about today's ruling and how we look at these issues going forward. Today's ruling was not unexpected, given the Court's earlier findings. But there are several steps ahead in this case. While we did everything that we could to settle this case, and will continue to look for new opportunities to resolve it, we believe that we have a strong case on appeal. The Appeals Court has already affirmed Microsoft's right to build Internet capabilities into the Windows operating system to benefit consumers. This ruling turns on its head the reality that consumers know, that our software has helped make PC's more accessible and affordable to millions. We started with just a few simple ideas, and the results have helped bring lower prices, improve productivity and enormous benefits to consumers. As we look ahead to the appeals process, innovation will continue to be the number one priority at Microsoft. Microsoft's past success has been built on innovation and creativity, and our future success depends on that ability to keep innovating in the fastest changing market place on earth. We recognize we have a responsibility to provide positive leadership on behalf of consumers and our industry. We take this responsibility very seriously.

The high tech industry that Microsoft has helped to create has unleashed a wave of competition and innovation. We have constantly seen more powerful products for consumers at lower prices than ever before. This high tech explosion has dramatically increased business productivity. And our industry is an engine of the American economy and the global economy.

It's important to note how much the high technology industry has changed in just the two years since this case was filed. We are seeing amazing new technologies that build on the power of the PC to offer consumers everything from Web phones to smart kitchen appliances. There are record-breaking mergers, reshaping the competitive landscape. When you look at the incredible pace of technological change, it's clear that Microsoft, and every other company must compete and innovate in order to survive and prosper.

Above all, as this process moves forward, we will continue to innovate and deliver the best solutions for our customers. We are committed to continue to hire great people, to listen to our customers, to invest in the future and to create the next great generation of software. While our legal team works to resolve the case, we will put our energy and our focus on these new ideas, new innovations and new software that will improve people's lives. Thank you.

Steve Ballmer: Hello. When people ask me about this case, I tell them three things. I tell them that the right of appeal is a fundamental tenet of the American legal system and that until the appeal is over, nothing is settled. We have learned that from experience.

I tell them I couldn't be more proud of this great company, its incredible employees and its breakthrough products, and I tell them that I believe in this company more today than I ever have. I believe in our people, our technology, and our vision. We need to stay very focused in on that.

It's important for us to all think about what today's ruling means and about what it does not mean. The ruling does not change the challenges and opportunities before us. Windows 2000 is the foundation for a whole new generation of products and services that will make the dream of Next Generation Window Services on the Internet a powerful reality. The combined power of amazing software, the Internet, and wireless technologies will free our products from the desktop and server and take them into literally every corner and walk of life.

If you take a look at devices like pocket PC's, smart kitchen appliances, the MiPad that Bill had a chance to unveil last month, it's really quite amazing. And the boundaries of innovation are really being expanded as never before. And it's those incredible opportunities and challenges that will shape the destiny of Microsoft and our industry. At the same time, we do recognize that we have a special responsibility to set a positive example in our industry.

We spent the past 25 years thinking of ourselves as a small, aggressive company playing catch-up to industry giants, even though at some point along the way we became a large company. Our success has really come from the opportunities that Microsoft and Windows have created for consumers and for thousands and thousands of companies, even while we competed with the few of those companies. We have failed to adequately demonstrate all of that opportunity for consumers and business alike.

Our intense focus on moving forward has at times been threatening and our passion for this has been misinterpreted. We can do better, but that doesn't mean innovating any less or delivering any less value to consumers. It does mean that values we hold dear -- opportunity for everyone, integrity, innovation, customer focus and partnership -- have been called into question today. We continue to cherish those values as we always have.

In the coming weeks, I intend to speak directly with many of our key customers and partners to assure them that today's ruling will not cause us to slow our efforts to provide them with the products and services they need to run their businesses. I had an opportunity this morning to talk to a wonderful software developer building on our platform and the list and range of new things that they want to see in the basic platform was daunting, but we are dedicated to delivering on the kinds of things that folks like that want.

As Bill said, the reality the consumers know is different than one might think today. They see the wonders of what technology and competition has done for their lives. Microsoft has been focused in on that and will continue to be so. I thank you very much for this opportunity.

I had an opportunity this morning to talk to a wonderful software developer building on our platform and the list and range of new things that they want to see in the basic platform was daunting, but we are dedicated to delivering on the kinds of things that folks like that want. As Bill said, the reality the consumers know is different than one might think today. They see the wonders of what technology and competition has done for their lives. Microsoft has been focused in on that and will continue to be so. I thank you very much for this opportunity.

fields.headline: Getting personal with... John Shuttleworth
fields.trailText: Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? John Le Shuttle - Ken's idea - to help me break into the carvery circuit.
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? John Le Shuttle - Ken's idea - to help me break into the carvery circuit.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? I pretended to be a senior citizen once in order to qualify for a tea at the local hospice.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? I suppose I'd be "Lonely widower (favourite colour fawn) with fine command of vibrato seeks similar for regular trips to reservoir (to check level)."

What was the last illegal thing you did? I stole a packet of Polos when I was 11, but returned them the next day.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? Fixed Joan Chitty's security light.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? Patrick Moore.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with? E. I don't know her surname. She was the matron at a hospice in Dronfield who unplugged my organ during a number and said, "That's enough for today, thank you."

Has a critic ever made you cry? My wife, Mary, can be scathing about my new songs. I don't cry, but I do wince.

What would you advertise without a fee? The last one was "500 assorted wood screws - a bit rusty."

What would you never advertise? Bounty bars. Unless Mars reintroduce the cardboard strip.

What wakes you up screaming at 4 in the morning? Nothing - I watch the skiing on Eurosport before I retire.

What takes you to a "happy place"? My Austin Ambassador Y reg. It takes me to the reservoir to check the level.

 John Shuttleworth plays the Shepherd's Bush Empire on 7th April and Bristol Bierkeller on the 9th with Southampton Gantry in between

webTitle: At last, a chance to keep things simple

fields.headline: At last, a chance to keep things simple
fields.standfirst: Guardian online editor Victor Keegan welcomes the ruling
fields.trailText: There is one sure outcome of the ruling that Microsoft violated antitrust laws by abusing its monopoly. The Seattle giant will never be the same again. Whether it is broken up into competing 'Baby Bills' or forced to open up its source code or whatever, Microsoft will never have the same overweening power that it has wielded in the recent past.
fields.body:
There is one sure outcome of the ruling that Microsoft violated antitrust laws by abusing its monopoly. The Seattle giant will never be the same again. Whether it is broken up into competing 'Baby Bills' or forced to open up its source code or whatever, Microsoft will never have the same overweening power that it has wielded in the recent past.

This is partly because PC operating systems will become relatively less important as people increasingly use television and mobile phones to interact with the internet. In these areas, Microsoft is powerful but not the omnipotent force it is in the world of personal computers, where its market share exceeds 90% and it completely dominates key software such as spreadsheets (through Excel) and word processing (through Word). But the main reason it won't be the same is that it has been rumbled.

It has been guilty of hubris. Microsoft was never prepared to admit it was a monopoly, let alone that it abused its position. Yet look at the facts. It loses money on Hotmail, which it is forced to give away free because of all the alternatives on offer, yet makes a mouth-watering 40% net return on sales on its overall business. If there had been a number of successful alternative operating systems then the price would have come tumbling down. It is even possible that manufacturers would have given them away free in order to attract a captive audience. Of course, PC users benefit from having an operating system that is a world standard. But if you have such a dominant monopoly position you also have responsibilities. A monopoly operating system should be operated as a common carrier - allowing anyone that wants to sell products on to it at a 'fair' price. That's the only way to stimulate the maximum competition. Instead you get the ludicrous position where a twentieth century version of Gresham's law operates - expensive software drives out cheap alternatives. Why else did I have to give up a cheap and cheerful spreadsheet and buy Microsoft's Excel, except because the rest of the world uses it because it comes as part of the Microsoft package. I'm still holding out with a word processing package that came free with my Macintosh, but I wonder for how much longer.

Microsoft's armlock on operating systems is self-reinforcing because software firms write for Microsoft first and for Macs and other systems later on, if at all. The latest example is Autonomy of Cambridge whose intelligent search engine Kenjin - launched this week - will run on, surprise, surprise, Microsoft's operating system. When I tested one of the recent Mac operating systems I was surprised not only to find that Microsoft's browser was the default option but also that it would bounce back as the default in certain circumstances even when I had switched over to Netscape. Where's the competition in that?

Most users of personal computers simply don't want the ever more complicated versions of Excel and Word that Microsoft produces to keep the profits engine turning. They want something that does simple tasks quickly and reliably. Competition is the key - and we will see more of it once Microsoft's anti-competitive practices have been curbed. If Microsoft is tamed or broken up, it will be good for the consumer and ultimately good for Microsoft. Think what those thousands of brilliant programmers in Seattle could do if their creative and entrepreneurial talents were unleashed.

webTitle: Joining the dots loses its appeal

fields.headline: Joining the dots loses its appeal
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Things certainly move fast in the new economy. Not so long ago companies were falling over themselves to emphasise their links with the internet. Now net-savvynness is becoming a liability. Or so it seems from the announcement yesterday by Gameplay.com, the online games retailer, that it is dropping the "dot.com" from its name. The move is designed to underline the company's lack of reliance on the net for its revenues.
fields.body:
Things certainly move fast in the new economy. Not so long ago companies were falling over themselves to emphasise their links with the internet. Now net-savvynness is becoming a liability. Or so it seems from the announcement yesterday by Gameplay.com, the online games retailer, that it is dropping the "dot.com" from its name. The move is designed to underline the company's lack of reliance on the net for its revenues.

"Internet sales are only a small proportion of our total sales - we're actually selling more off the television than we are off the internet," said chief executive Mark Bernstein, before adding, unconvincingly, that the name change had nothing to do with recent sharp falls in business-to-consumer stock prices. "It was planned well in advance of whatever might or might not have happened to the stock market." He did concede that Techmark index losses had speeded up the rebranding process.

"I want to be able to demonstrate that we're not full of hot air. We've got very substantial revenues."

Mr Bernstein was speaking after Gameplay made an all-paper acquisition of Nordic Games Holdings, a Scandinavian computer games mail order retailer, for up to £5.96m.

The fact that vendors are prepared to take Gameplay's paper presumably means that they share Mr Bernstein's enthusiasm for his company. But he is sensible to distance himself from the hype over the net.

Investors are slowly waking up to the fact that it is not whether or not you are an internet business that counts. What matters is how good the business is, dot or no dot.com. Research from Credit Suisse First Boston shows some narrowing of the gap between medium term expectations for old and new economy companies. But the spread remains wide. Thirty-five old economy stocks still have implied medium term growth rates of 0% or less, while 23 new economy stocks are expected to grow at 20% plus in the medium term.

So there is still a long way to go before the market is back at anything like reality. At present, investors are only buying old economy stocks selectively. The same may be true of new economy stocks before long.

fields.headline: The road warriors
fields.trailText: Road Rages | Indian Journeys | Talking 'Bout A Revolution | Getting High - The History Of LSD
fields.body:
Womble delivered a kidney once. Cycle couriers travel 800 miles in a week, which is further than an albatross. A kidney doesn't weigh as much as a liver, so Womble was happy to slip the organ into his satchel. "When I started, I was a nut, cutting people up - specially thick ones", Womble reminisced, fondly. He got three months for punching a cabbie, but now limits his abuse to a vigorous V-sign.

Gary cuts people up for the other team, driving his black cab across "the 17th-century road plan of London", a deep puce of anger rising steadily through his large girth as the day progresses. "I see myself very much as a World War Two pilot, marking missions on the side of my door. When I've filled the door with cyclists, it'll be time to buy a new cab."

Road Rages (C5) needed a third party, Switzerland, to give some science. "Driving is a drug", a psychologist told us, making it a bit like chocolate... and drugs. Wisely, he stood well away from the curb as he spoke. "Like most addictions, it's progressive. So you need to do more and more extreme things to get the same buzz."

Womble's answer was to aim straight at pedestrians: "Out the way, prat!" he shouted furiously at a flock of people ("pigeons"). "I'd have done 'em a favour if I'd hit 'em. They looked thick as mince." Most couriers up the ante by retreating into a fantasy world, re-styling themselves Ninja Warriors (with a touch of the philosopher-prophet).

"Taxis are the aristocracy of the road," said a leather-clad, lane-cutting Sufi, "and we're the young surfers coming to town to take their crown." Leaning back on his Mad Max-mobile and stroking his petrol tank, the courier had the blasé hindsight of a true sociopath. "I did hit a child on Old Street roundabout... what can you do?" Stop had never occurred to him.

"Tell me about your motorbike", William Dalrymple asked Babagee, the naked star of Indian Journeys (BBC1), the only holy man in the subcontinent to own an Enfield Bullet.

"What do you want to know?"

"You have an on-board hi-fi. What music do you play?"

"Mostly religious."

Ask a stupid question.

Wearing nothing but diamonds and pearls over his dreadlocks, Babagee had a hard time explaining how swanning naked round India on a motorbike squared with his strict Hindu asceticism. "Is it important to suffer?" asked Dalrymple.

"Oh yes," said Babagee, revving-up.

Dalrymple followed in the footsteps of thousands of generations of BBC presenters, climbing with nothing but a film crew high up into the Himalayas, peering out of train windows and visiting the Equity-carded bathers at Hadwar ("God, not another documentary team!")

No doubt, the exoticism of a Palinesque journey must seem a far safer commissioning bet than a messy portrait of modern India, bristling with satellite dishes and Ford Lexuses. But Dalrymple's film acknowledged the clichés of its antecedents, and made shrewd, comedic mileage out of Lonely Planet mysticism and the Rolls Royce Bagwans.

Getting a little spiritual himself, Dalrymple stood before the source of the Ganges. Between heaven and earth, the stars and the fire, stood a pillar, engraved with three "instructions for Enlightenment":

1) Get up at 4am daily.

2) Do not overload the stomach.

3) Stick to your routine.

In Talking 'Bout A Revolution (BBC1) thousands of Koreans and Bosnians stood in a hall with their left hands raised, poised to pledge not dissimilar dictums in order to become American citizens. Jonathan Freedland asked anyone in a Florida diner if they could recite the first three words of the constitution. "We the People..." began a housewife rattling off Jefferson's first three pages.

In America, the drug is The People, a hallucinogen no less potent than road rage is for Womble on the 17th-century streets of London. One wondered, however, if the Koreans and Bosnians would have been so keen on America if they'd been shown Getting High - The History Of LSD (History Channel) first.

To the accompaniment of sitar music, this film explored the CIA's testing of LSD as a potential Cold War weapon.

More often than not, by agents lacing each other's tea at the Pentagon (I suppose it beat killing the afternoon by chewing a pencil). The japes had to stop when a scientist threw himself from a window. There's always one, isn't there? Boy, what a downer.

webTitle: Top Serb seized in Nato raid

fields.headline: Top Serb seized in Nato raid
fields.standfirst: Serbian hardliner's arrest raises hopes that war crimes tribunal may reach all those guilty of atrocities in Bosnia
fields.trailText: Momcilo Krajisnik, the most senior Bosnian Serb to be arrested for suspected war crimes, was seized at his home in Pale by French troops before dawn yesterday and sent to the International Criminal Tribunal for Former Yugoslavia in the Hague.
fields.body:
Momcilo Krajisnik, the most senior Bosnian Serb to be arrested for suspected war crimes, was seized at his home in Pale by French troops before dawn yesterday and sent to the International Criminal Tribunal for Former Yugoslavia in the Hague.

Mr Krajisnik, who was a member of Bosnia's collective presidency after the Bosnian war ended in 1995, was charged in a secret indictment with genocide and crimes against humanity for acts committed in 1991 and 1992, during which time he also served as the parliamentary speaker.

His indictment by the tribunal in February is bound to raise questions about timing and the implications it may have for other notable Bosnian Serbs.

Two of Mr Krajisnik's closest associates, Radovan Karadzic, the leader of the main Bosnian Serb political party, and General Ratko Mladic, were indicted several years ago, although they have never been arrested.

But Biljana Plavsic, who was one of the two Serb members of Bosnia's collective presidency before the war, and was later strongly supported by western leaders, has not been indicted - unless she too is covered by a secret charge.

The indictment of Mr Krajisnik is also important because it means that the prosecutors believe that the Bosnian Serb leadership had begun to prepare plans for genocide before the war began; the trials of Bosnians held so far have all dealt with atrocities during the fighting. Charging a top political leader in Bosnia for planning ethnic cleansing is thought to be a major step forward.

Witnesses of Mr Krajisnik's arrest said French troops with the Bosnian peacekeeping force detained him after blowing open a door of his home in Pale, about 15 miles south-east of Sarajevo, with explosives.

"They took my Dad away," his son Milos, 21, said. He managed to see seven or eight soldiers before he and his brother Njegos, 19, were tied up and their faces turned towards the floor. The state-run Yugoslav news agency Tanjug said Mr Krajisnik was led away still in pajamas and barefoot.

Paul Risley, the spokesman for the Hague tribunal, said Mr Krajisnik was one of the individuals who ran illegal operations that resulted in the deaths of thousands of Bosnians. He was present at every meeting where political and military actions that resulted in deportations, illegal arrests, ethnic cleansing and the deaths of thousands of Bosnians were decided.

A big businessman before the war, Mr Krajisnik wielded heavy influence on the Bosnian Serbs' wartime finances based on black-marketeering. When Mr Karadzic dropped from sight after the war to avoid arrest by Nato peacekeepers, Mr Krajisnik inherited his mantle as the Serbs' hardline nationalist leader, becoming the senior figure in Bosnia's semi-autonomous Serb republic.

He served in 1996-98 as the Serb member of Bosnia's first post-war multi-ethnic collective presidency.

webTitle: Champagne on hold until big fish served up

fields.headline: Champagne on hold until big fish served up
fields.trailText: No one was breaking out the champagne at the Hague war crimes tribunal yesterday, but Nato's capture of Momcilo Krajisnik is a real achievement that will raise hopes that the big fish of Bosnia's war may finally face justice.
fields.body:
No one was breaking out the champagne at the Hague war crimes tribunal yesterday, but Nato's capture of Momcilo Krajisnik is a real achievement that will raise hopes that the big fish of Bosnia's war may finally face justice.

Mr Krajisnik, the former right-hand man to Radovan Karadzic - who is still at large - is the most senior suspect to face the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia nearly seven years after it was set up.

But his arrest is only the latest in a string of successes which has focused attention on the former insurance company premises in a leafy suburb of the Dutch capital - and hugely bolstered the reputation of the UN court.

In courtroom number one, flanked by guards in blue UN uniform and facing judges from Portugal, Egypt and the US, the Bosnian Serb general Radislav Kirstic is in the fourth week of his trial.

Gen Kirstic, seized in December 1998, is accused of genocide for his part in the Srebrenica massacre, when 7,500 Bosnian Muslims were systematically killed in July 1995 - in a UN "safe area" - in Europe's worst atrocity since the Holocaust.

Two other generals held responsible for the brutal Serb siege of Sarajevo, Momir Talic and Stanislav Galic, are also in custody. But their commander, Ratko Mladic, was seen recently at a Yugoslavia-China soccer game in Belgrade.

Next door to Gen Kirstic, three low-ranking Serb soldiers from the once-idyllic Drina valley town of Foca are facing unprecedented charges of crimes against humanity for serial gang-rape, torture and sexual enslavement.

The prosecution says these men and their appalling personal brutality made possible the larger project of ethnic cleansing in Bosnia's three-and-a-half year war.

Not only Serbs are facing justice. Croatia, newly embarked on the path of democracy, has just handed over the ailing warlord Mladen Naletelic, accused of murder and torture in Mostar. A few days before the tribunal passed a 45-year sentence on another Bosnian Croat, General Tihomir Blaskic.

In all, 39 people are being held in the Dutch prison nearby at Scheveningen.

Yet if these are exciting times for the tribunal, too little happened for too long, largely because Balkan governments ignored their obligations under the Dayton peace accords and international law.

The recent successes are attributed to the practice of issuing sealed indictments, under which an investigation is mounted and evidence submitted to one of the court's 14 judges, who then accepts a prosecution request for non-disclosure.

fields.headline: I told you so
fields.standfirst:
As prime minister of Rhodesia, he led his country into war and international isolation. But he prefers not to dwell on the past. As political violence returns to Zimbabwe, Ian Smith tells Matthew Engel where Robert Mugabe went wrong
Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: As prime minister of Rhodesia, he led his country into war and international isolation. But he prefers not to dwell on the past. As political violence returns to Zimbabwe, Ian Smith tells  Matthew Engel  where Robert Mugabe went wrong
fields.body:
In Zimbabwe the past is another country. But the embodiment of that country is still with us. And he has had a pretty good weekend. After all, he told us it would happen, incessantly. Ian Smith, prime minister of Rhodesia from 1964 to 1979, took his country through treason and sanctions and war rather than submit to black rule.

In rough outline, he predicted Saturday's attack on the anti-government marchers 40 years ago. He was doing his best not to gloat. "We're pretty well in a state of anarchy, so I don't think it should surprise anyone who understands politics. It was a dreadful incident. People beaten with sticks and whips, including ladies . Par for the course, though. This is where we live. Dreadful."

It doesn't feel all that dreadful, though. He sits in a comfy armchair in his front room amid the over-fussy decoration beloved by colonialists of his generation. He is 80 now and a widower, a bit lonely I think (why else would he welcome the Guardian so readily?), but he is still fit, and has not lost a solitary marble.

He looks out on to a glorious lawn, fronting an avenue shaded by old jacaranda trees. He has less security than the average middle-ranked executive in Johannesburg. Only one thing jars: poking up behind his bougainvillea is a huge radio mast. Ian Smith's next-door neighbour is the Cuban embassy. He is not a humorous man, but this is probably the best joke in Harare. "They're very nice," says Smith. "I said in an interview that I preferred the Cubans to Mugabe, and the ambassador has waved cheerfully ever since."

There is a logical flaw here, since Smith's first allegation (of many) against Zimbabwe's current president, Robert Mugabe, is that he is a communist. This provided the only moment during our conversation when I was convinced I had him nailed.

"He is a communist," Smith was saying. "Still is. Absolutely dedicated. He stays in power so he can do what he wants to do."

"Some people might say that's what you did."

"THAT'S A LIE."

It was an unusually unsubtle get-out. Time and again I asked him during the interview, in different ways, if (1) he had made mistakes; (2) he blamed himself at all for his country's plight; and (3) he regretted what he had done. The answers were: yes (though he declined to specify any mistakes); no; and "I don't dwell on the past."

Funnily enough, the last bit was probably the biggest lie of all. The whole Rhodesian adventure was a piece of quixotry straight out of the past. A year after he took over, Smith made a unilateral declaration of independence (UDI) to prevent Britain forcing him to accept majority rule. There were fewer than a quarter of a million whites, and 5m blacks.

Harold Wilson considered invasion, then backed away, uncertain even of the British army's loyalty. White Rhodesia flourished, evading economic sanctions for more than a decade with a mix of 10% skill and ingenuity and 90% South African support. Britain looked pathetic. Then, as guerrilla warfare intensified, the South African president, the old soak and bully John Vorster, decided that this sideshow was jeopardising his own regime's survival, and forced Rhodesia to capitulate.

By Smith's armchair is his own book, The Great Betrayal, which refers to the South Africans' behaviour. He also has Reach for the Sky, the biography of the war hero Douglas Bader; The Abolition of Britain, a sort of past-dweller's handbook by the eccentric Daily Express writer Peter Hitchens; and a compilation of cartoons by Giles, another Express favourite. I didn't dare tell him the paper is now edited by a dope-smoking Labour supporter, and a woman - no, lady - at that.

He also has a huge painting of Spitfires over the Italian mountains, which is what he flew and where he flew them. He doesn't need much prompting to mention the war: that war, not the one he precipitated.

Otherwise, his conversation is mostly about long-ago negotiations with politicians, mostly dead, all of whom were evidently far trickier than he was. UDI was not illegal, he insisted, the lawyers said so: it was a response to a breach of contract by the British.

"We had majority rule," said Smith. "We had responsible majority rule. It was a system British ministers said to me time and again was a success. Harold Macmillan said so; Alec Home said so. On the day of UDI, Harold Wilson pleaded with me, 'Ian, please have a little more patience. You are our model for Africa.' Then he rushed to the House of Commons and said I was a traitor." Smith despises inconsistency in others but will never recognise it in himself. It is a very Rhodesian sort of trait.

But his greatest venom is reserved for Mugabe. "When you see what these communist gangsters have done to this country." He shakes his head. "They inherited a wonderful country. He told me so. The day the 1980 election results came out he rang and asked me to see him.

"Mugabe sat me down and said, 'I just want to tell you how lucky we are inheriting this jewel of Africa. We want to keep it that way.' He couldn't have been kinder or more polite. I couldn't believe what I heard. He talked like a sophisticated westerner, not like a communist. I said, 'You said it to me. Will you say it in public? And he did.

"I used to go and see him regularly for the first 18 months, and he couldn't have been more gracious. Then suddenly he had a rush of blood and decided to create a one-party Marxist state. I was never welcome after that and I've never seen him since. Now we have a dictatorship. It's totalitarianism. You're not allowed to disagree, you're allowed to agree."

It is a little hard to see how you can simultaneously have both totalitarianism and anarchy. And anyway, here we are in his sitting room, and he is disagreeing like crazy. "Mugabe never had such freedom in your day, did he?"

"He had complete freedom. He was only arrested because he practised subversion, unconstitutional methods." Mugabe spent years in jail; Smith is incensed because he has been briefly arrested three times.

"It doesn't feel like a communist country, does it?"

"In the last couple of years, yes, people have spoken out. They're very clever, these totalitarian people. They took over the communications media, they instituted the CIO [Central Intelligence Organisation], which is as good as any Gestapo on the face of the earth.

"You know, my friend, Africa is different. It's nothing like the free world. They believe in chiefs, in dictatorship."

And so you go round in circles. Never mind that Smith's constitution denied the majority anything but the most rudimentary say. Come to think of it, peaceful demonstrations against the government were not a major feature of life under the Smith government. I tried to find something on which he might agree with Mugabe: and it's true, he doesn't care for homosexuality either.

"I was brought up to believe it wasn't part of life. Sodomy was a crime. We were given this [he glances discreetly downwards] to procreate. I'm now told that there are inherent reasons for people being that way, that there's medical evidence. Well, all right, but you should keep it to yourself and not influence young people. I don't like it."

He is worried about the internet too: "I'm a bit worried from what I hear of it. I hear it's a bit unsavoury, a lot of smut." And he is concerned about the British young: "I don't think they have enough pride in Britain."

Here we have the very nub of Rhodesia. It was a country that embodied the values of the old Daily Express, where acceptable subversion might be safely contained in a Giles cartoon. Smith's Rhodesia ("Surrey with the lunatic fringe on top," as it was once characterised) had many old-fashioned Home Counties virtues: neighbourliness, civic pride, politeness, efficiency, practicality, discipline, reticence, pluck and a little light charity. For better or worse, women were always ladies (usually making the teas, not going on demos). It is as though the world was defied for a decade by some gigantic local bowls club.

Smith himself was an unpretentious and accessible leader, driving home for lunch in a little Peugeot. Good old Smithy! Nowadays, Avis give renters special instructions about how to behave when confronted by a presidential motorcade.

But the Rhodesians could not face up to the contradictions of their privilege and their position. There was no Great Betrayal. They were betrayed only by their own narrow-mindedness, selfishness and ignorance.

"We were not racialists," Smith insists. And it is true that Rhodesia had no Whites Only signs, like South Africa. The phrase was "Right of Admission Reserved". Most people did not have to be told what that meant.

Even now, Smith purports to believe that Mugabe has never won a fair election, and that he cheated more moderate leaders out of what was theirs - an assertion which everyone who understands anything of Zimbabwean politics thinks is nonsense.

Ian Smith understood everything about Rhodesia. But that was another country. Indeed, it wasn't even a country at all.

fields.headline: Cook defuses Mugabe row
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, last night attempted to defuse the row with President Robert Mugabe that has seen relations between London and Harare reach their lowest point since Zimbabwe became independent two decades ago.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill  and  Mona Eltahawy in Cairo
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, last night attempted to defuse the row with President Robert Mugabe that has seen relations between London and Harare reach their lowest point since Zimbabwe became independent two decades ago.

The meeting between the two men on the fringes of the EU-Africa summit in Cairo had threatened to be an explosive confrontation, given the level of insults flying back and forward in the last few weeks.

But the Foreign Office reported that the 45-minute meeting had been "interesting" and positive.

Mr Cook secured from Mr Mugabe an assurance that the Zimbabwe general election, postponed last month, will be held in May, though no date was set.

No apologies were given by Mr Cook or Mr Mugabe over the harsh words from both sides over the last two weeks. The foreign secretary told reporters that the meeting had been "worthwhile, but I stress it is only the beginning of a dialogue. The focus was on addressing concerns rather than parading the grievances of the last few weeks."

Mr Mugabe accepted an invitation to send a delegation to London to discuss land reform and other issues, though no date has been set for that either.

The row has ranged from the opening of the British diplomatic bag, the forceful annexation of white farms, an accusation that the British cabinet was run by a gay conspiracy and the violent break-up of last Saturday's peaceful demonstration in Harare against Mr Mugabe.

Mr Cook said that the real test would be whether Mr Mugabe ensured that the the rule of law was respected, whether the police upheld the law and whether the rights of white farmers were upheld.

Earlier in the day, Mr Mugabe had ignored Mr Cook when their paths crossed in a lobby. The president angrily denounced Britain in a television interview: "We are not a British colony any longer."

Countering British protests over the violent attacks by Mugabe supporters on the protest in Harare, he said: "Britain has no right, no right at all, to try and suggest to the rest of the world that we are a failure." He complained that Britain was "trying to teach us how to run our country."

Mr Cook has set as an overriding aim to ensure that international observers, preferably from the EU, attend the Zimbabwe general election.

The Tory foreign affairs spokesman, Francis Maude, said Labour's ethical foreign policy was a shambles. "Again, Labour are saying one thing and doing another. Their policies in Africa can be summed up as cover-up in Sierra Leone, cock-up in Zimbabwe."

Police in Zimbabwe yesterday released five activists who were arrested the weekend demonstration. "They said they are not dropping the charges but are letting us go," said Grace Kwinje of the Movement for Democratic Change.

fields.headline: Film confronts Spain's last taboo
fields.standfirst:
Terrorism is tackled at last in a biopic of an ETA leader

Bombs in Madrid: special report
fields.trailText: The murder of Yoyes, one of the most senior women in the Basque separatist group ETA, at the hands of a former comrade, shook Spanish society. Now, 14 years later, a film about her life threatens to reopen old wounds.
fields.body:
The murder of Yoyes, one of the most senior women in the Basque separatist group ETA, at the hands of a former comrade, shook Spanish society. Now, 14 years later, a film about her life threatens to reopen old wounds.

Yoyes was released in cinemas throughout Spain, including the Basque country, at the weekend. The film breaks a taboo on using the terrorist group, which has killed some 800 people in its 30-year campaign for an independent Basque state, as subject matter for the cinema.

"Compared to the American cinema, or the British, which has touched on the most painful aspects of its history, and made many films on Northern Ireland, the Spanish cinema has tiptoed around subjects like ETA terrorism despite their decisive influence on the country," said Guillermo Altares, film critic of the daily El Pais.

The film traces the life of Dolores Gonzalez Catarain - known by the codename Yoyes - from her early involvement with ETA in the Basque country and France, through her exile in Mexico from Paris and her eventual return to Spain.

It shows her going in 1973 to France, where most of the leadership were based, and taking over responsibility for ETA's political wing.

Yoyes is seen wielding a gun in target practice but not carrying out a terrorist attack.

The film includes real footage of the prime minister at the time announcing to a roomful of cheering Eta mem bers that Franco had died.

It then follows Yoyes's gradual disillusionment, after a particularly bloody bomb attack on a Madrid cafeteria, and her decision to break with the group and seek exile in Mexico.

"I have tried to tell the truth," said Helena Taberna, the director, whose treatment of Yoyes is broadly sympathetic.

The film focuses on Yoyes's love affairs and marriage to a philosophy professor, the birth of her son, and her agonising over whether to return to Spain in the early 80s when the country had become a democracy after Franco's death and former terrorists were offered an amnesty.

"Neither one side or the other will let me live in peace," Yoyes says in the film, which ends with her son witnessing her death in 1986 in a crowded market place, where she was shot at point-blank range by a member of ETA who considered her a traitor.

"This is one woman's story, based on her right to change and on the times she lived in," said Ms Taberna, who acknowledged that at first it was difficult to get funding for the film, an Italian, French and Spanish co-production, which received 20m pesetas (about £72,000) in subsidies from the Basque regional government run by the Basque Nationalist party.

"People haven't made films on ETA because they were scared," said Andres Vicente Gomez, a producer.

Yoyes was filmed last spring, virtually under cover, on location in the Spanish Basque country and in France during the truce declared by ETA when it looked as if peace might be possible.

Its release coincides with renewed conflict after ETA's decision to end the ceasefire in December.

So far this year there have been three deaths; threats against politicians, businessmen and journalists, one of whom received a bomb in a cigar box last week which failed to go off; and a sense that peace is further away than ever. At the weekend there was widespread street violence in the Basque country.

Ms Taberna has been praised for her courage in tackling the subject, but criticised for equating ETA with the self-proclaimed Anti-Liberation Groups, known as Gal, which waged a bungled dirty war against the terrorist group in the early 1980s.

Gal's links to the governments in Madrid at the time are still under investigation.

A minister shown in the film bears a strong resemblance to a minister who is currently on trial together with a top paramilitary civil guard general. They are accused of involve ment in the deaths of two ETA members.

"Of course the Gal should not have happened, but it [the dirty war] went on for only three years, not 30," said one Basque MP.

"We're starting to break the taboo," said Borja Hermoso of the daily El Mundo. "But there is still a sense that the subject needs to be handled carefully."

"It's still very much alive. I'm not surprised people don't dare tackle it," said Jose Sacristan, an actor involved in another film on ETA.

"Those who have done have been quite rigorous. It is better to have fewer films and that they should maintain that rigour."

The film traces the life of Dolores Gonzalez Catarain - known by the codename Yoyes - from her early involvement with ETA in the Basque country and France, through her exile in Mexico from Paris and her eventual return to Spain. It shows her going in 1973 to France, where most of the leadership were based, and taking over responsibility for ETA's political wing. Yoyes is seen wielding a gun in target practice but not carrying out a terrorist attack. The film includes real footage of the prime minister at the time announcing to a roomful of cheering Eta mem bers that Franco had died. It then follows Yoyes's gradual disillusionment, after a particularly bloody bomb attack on a Madrid cafeteria, and her decision to break with the group and seek exile in Mexico. "I have tried to tell the truth," said Helena Taberna, the director, whose treatment of Yoyes is broadly sympathetic. The film focuses on Yoyes's love affairs and marriage to a philosophy professor, the birth of her son, and her agonising over whether to return to Spain in the early 80s when the country had become a democracy after Franco's death and former terrorists were offered an amnesty. "Neither one side or the other will let me live in peace," Yoyes says in the film, which ends with her son witnessing her death in 1986 in a crowded market place, where she was shot at point-blank range by a member of ETA who considered her a traitor. "This is one woman's story, based on her right to change and on the times she lived in," said Ms Taberna, who acknowledged that at first it was difficult to get funding for the film, an Italian, French and Spanish co-production, which received 20m pesetas (about £72,000) in subsidies from the Basque regional government run by the Basque Nationalist party. "People haven't made films on ETA because they were scared," said Andres Vicente Gomez, a producer. Yoyes was filmed last spring, virtually under cover, on location in the Spanish Basque country and in France during the truce declared by ETA when it looked as if peace might be possible. Its release coincides with renewed conflict after ETA's decision to end the ceasefire in December. So far this year there have been three deaths; threats against politicians, businessmen and journalists, one of whom received a bomb in a cigar box last week which failed to go off; and a sense that peace is further away than ever. At the weekend there was widespread street violence in the Basque country. Ms Taberna has been praised for her courage in tackling the subject, but criticised for equating ETA with the self-proclaimed Anti-Liberation Groups, known as Gal, which waged a bungled dirty war against the terrorist group in the early 1980s. Gal's links to the governments in Madrid at the time are still under investigation. A minister shown in the film bears a strong resemblance to a minister who is currently on trial together with a top paramilitary civil guard general. They are accused of involve ment in the deaths of two ETA members. "Of course the Gal should not have happened, but it [the dirty war] went on for only three years, not 30," said one Basque MP. "We're starting to break the taboo," said Borja Hermoso of the daily El Mundo. "But there is still a sense that the subject needs to be handled carefully." "It's still very much alive. I'm not surprised people don't dare tackle it," said Jose Sacristan, an actor involved in another film on ETA. "Those who have done have been quite rigorous. It is better to have fewer films and that they should maintain that rigour."

fields.headline: Mugabe on the edge
fields.standfirst:
Elections, not sanctions, are the best hope

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Pressure is growing to "do something" about Robert Mugabe. But demands that Britain and others impose punitive sanctions are premature while there is still a chance of peaceful, democratic change in Zimbabwe. The diplomatic focus must be to convince Mr Mugabe to go ahead with general elections without further delay.
fields.body:
Pressure is growing to "do something" about Robert Mugabe. But demands that Britain and others impose punitive sanctions are premature while there is still a chance of peaceful, democratic change in Zimbabwe. The diplomatic focus must be to convince Mr Mugabe to go ahead with general elections without further delay. South Africa, the OAU, the Commonwealth, and the UN's Kofi Annan all have a role in persuading him that repression of his opponents, as in Harare last Saturday, is inimical to his own and his country's best interest. Robin Cook's suggestion that the EU send observers to ensure the polls are conducted fairly is reasonable. Such monitoring is established practice, after all; Zimbabwe's president can be assured he is not being singled out. The IMF, which suspended assistance last year, and NGOs can all help emphasise the positive benefits of keeping faith with democracy and following a better-regulated economic policy. The assurances given Mr Cook during his meeting with Mr Mugabe in Cairo last night may possibly take some of the heat out of a highly volatile situation.

For it is to everybody's advantage that Mr Mugabe calm down. February's referendum defeat seems to have badly unnerved him. As Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia says, Mr Mugabe is a man caught in a squeeze; he could do almost anything. Zimbabwe's crisis is not about land reform: that is necessary and overdue, as we said last week, but the farm invasions are a Zanu-PF stunt. Similarly, this crisis is not about skin colour. Zimbabwe since independence has enjoyed relatively good race relations and it speaks ill of Mr Mugabe that he tries to exploit the issue. Nor is it about Britain's "colonialist" attitude. That is another canard circulated for party political purposes, although few Zimbabweans seem taken in by it.

No, this crisis is about power. It is about the failing grip of the old guard; about the abuses inherent in one-party rule; about chronic mismanagement and corruption, particularly in previous land reform programmes; it is about a young, impoverished nation saying it is time for a change. Mr Mugabe's recent behaviour has been barely rational. If pushed too hard at this critical moment, he could well impose emergency rule and provoke far greater strife. This is a delicate balance to strike. But for now, persuasion, carrots, and free elections remain the best hope. Only if and when that fails should the sanctions hammer be raised.

webTitle: No candles for Kohl as new charges emerge

fields.headline: No candles for Kohl as new charges emerge
fields.standfirst: German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: With arrangements for the celebration of his 70th birthday in ruins, Helmut Kohl yesterday lamented that he had been turned into a "non-person" by the scandal of his acceptance of secret political donations.
fields.body:
With arrangements for the celebration of his 70th birthday in ruins, Helmut Kohl yesterday lamented that he had been turned into a "non-person" by the scandal of his acceptance of secret political donations.

Germany's longest-serving modern chancellor and the architect of its reunification spent what was to have been a day of triumphant festivities in ignominious hiding. He fled the town of Oggersheim, where his home is under siege by the media, and headed for an unknown destination, accompanied only by his wife Hannelore and a driver. Associates said he planned to mark his birthday at a quiet party with his family.

It was a far cry from the lavish reception in Berlin at which Mr Kohl was to have been feted by other leading statesman of his era. The reception and another celebration in his home town of Ludwigshafen he was put under criminal investigation for his role in the illicit funding of his party, the Christian Democrat Union.

In an interview published yesterday Mr Kohl said the present situation was "depressing for me, for my family, my friends and my associates".

He added: "For many, I have been turned overnight from a contemporary historical personality into a non-person and, for some, into a monster."

Nevertheless, he looks set to continue his role in Germany's increasingly sleaze-dominated politics.

The latest prospect is a constitutional row over the use of files on Mr Kohl and his party compiled by East Germany's secret service, the Stasi. The reports, which came to light last week, imply that Mr Kohl was aware of irregular party funding much earlier he has so far admitted, and they raise the question of whether senior figures in the CDU could have been blackmailed as a result.

The files are based on bugged telephone conversations, however, and there are doubts about the reliability of the information they contain.

In a radio interview, Mr Kohl said: "East Germany was . . . run by a criminal regime. I consider it completely unacceptable to take quotes out of these transcripts now."

He proposed that the constitutional court should rule on whether they could be published or used in either the criminal inquiry or a parallel investigation by a parliamentary commission.

Almost certainly, the documents cannot be admitted as evidence. But damaging extracts from the files have already leaked out, which the investigators can scarcely ignore.

One, referring to the mid-70s, has the CDU's former treasurer quoting Mr Kohl as asking: "Do we still have anything hidden anywhere?"

The Berliner Zeitung newspaper reported yesterday that, before German reunification, Mr Kohl's government ordered the destruction of the Stasi's transcripts of bugged telephone conversations. But Eckart Werthebach, a former head of West German counter-intelligence, which was said to have disposed of the documents, said he had no knowledge of any such operation.
