fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
 Is there no limit to the efforts Amazon.co.uk will make to protect its customers? Recently the on-line bookseller gave a place next to stuff about Harry Potter for the manual A Hand in the Bush: The Fine Art of Vaginal Fisting. Now the country's most visited commercial website enjoys another triumph. Without a word of warning, Amazon advertises The Protocols of the Learned Elders of Zion at £9.95 - the infamous anti-semitic propaganda forged by the Okhrane, Russia's Tsarist secret police, in the early 1900s, and the source ever since of so much rightwing dementia about international Jewish conspiracies to take over the world. Until recently the book was available only on the neo-fascist fringes, but now turns up - would you believe it - in Amazon's "religion and spirituality" section, as if it were a genuine text. Where the US site (Amazon.com) carries a disclaimer, a publisher's note and a message from the Anti-Defamation League stating the book is "plainly and simply a plagiarised forgery," the British site carries nothing. Amazon.co.uk say their management is currently considering what to do about the book. Meanwhile, bol.com (Amazon's main rival) doesn't sell the book.

 Energy minister Helen Liddell uses the Today programme to audition for Record Breakers. During an interview on Thursday about BNFL, Helen smashed the previous best when in a few minutes she used the phrase "to be frank" or variations a total of six times. It's always good for you sneerers to be reminded of how trustworthy the government is (you will recall Mr Tony's post-Ecclestone "Look, I'm a pretty straight kind of guy") but is it not pure bravado for an erstwhile Maxwell mouthpiece to raise her own credibility like this on national radio?

 Behold, Tom Robinson modelling the Oooh You Amaze Me! T-shirt. The garments are already selling fast in both Ken (L) and Frank (XL) sizes, and no wonder at just £7.50 (cheques payable to Guardian Media Group). Meanwhile, Guardian website footage of Frank's hilarious "Oooh, you amaze me!" interview on Zee TV has attracted heavy traffic. Equally worth a visit, meanwhile, is tomrobinson.com. And, even for us, that is quite enough plugging, I feel, for one day.

 In the latest Sunday Telegraph, Soraya Khashoggi expresses upset with Jonathan Aitken over the suggestion in his new book Mea Minima Culpa that their daughter Petrina was the product of a quick fling. "What he doesn't speak about is the fact that we shared a mews cottage in Belgravia and were making plans to marry," Soraya tells my so-called rival Mandrake. While Jonathan claims that she slept with him as "a kind of advance wedding present", Soraya insists they planned a large family together. Dear, dear, dear, just when we thought he had truly repented. One more whopper and I will have to delegate all praying for Jonathan duties to a professional, such as Diary vicar the Rev Steve Chalke.

 In Derbyshire, crime strikes a Tory parliamentary candidate. Heather Wheeler had various things stolen from her handbag, reports the Burton Mail, when a sneak thief walked into the Burton Conservative Association last Monday lunchtime. Mrs Wheeler reported the loss of cash, mobile phone, personal organiser, and a CD of William Hague speeches.

fields.headline: Microsoft shares plumb in panic
fields.trailText: More than £49bn was wiped from the value of Microsoft in just a few hours yesterday as the world's biggest software company prepared for a harsh legal ruling in its landmark anti-monopoly battle with the US government.
fields.body:
More than £49bn was wiped from the value of Microsoft in just a few hours yesterday as the world's biggest software company prepared for a harsh legal ruling in its landmark anti-monopoly battle with the US government.

Its shares in fell by 15% soon after Wall Street opened, following the breakdown of settlement talks between the Seattle-based company and the justice department at the weekend.

This failure opened the way for Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson to deliver his ruling on whether the company had broken US anti-trust laws designed to protect consumers.

Even Microsoft's lawyers expected him to rule against the company after his preliminary findings last November that it had harmed consumers and abused its monopoly position. Judge Jackson's ruling is expected to fuel more than 100 individual lawsuits already filed against Microsoft.

They allege that the company overcharged them in selling its Windows software, used on more than 90%of the world's computers. Damages from such lawsuits can be punitive and, amid continued uncertainty about future sanctions, terrified investors yesterday.

Microsoft's plunge dragged down other hi-tech companies. The Nasdaq index, the world's leading benchmark for the technology sector, fell by 5% in a morning. At one stage, the effect was such that the manufacturing company General Electric was larger in market value than Microsoft or Cisco, the company that supplies much of the internet's technology backbone.

Microsoft, founded by Bill Gates, the world's richest man, pledged to appeal against any negative ruling.

Settlement talks broke down over the failure to agree on an effective remedy. Several of the 19 US states that brought the landmark legal action against the company two years ago believe that a break-up may be the only way of preventing future abuses.

Microsoft chairman Bill Gates two weeks ago sent a detailed settlement proposal of almost a dozen pages to government lawyers. In it were several key concessions. Microsoft agreed to sell a version of Windows that does not have its web browser, Internet Explorer, bundled up its operating system; open its Windows code up to other programmers; and sell Windows at a standard price. But the government rejected the offer, deriding it as "inadequate".

Several Wall Street analysts sought to ease investor fears yesterday. Rick Sherlund, an influential company analyst at Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, warned investors that they would need to have a "thick skin" to deal with the fallout from yesterday's ruling and the break-down in talks.

webTitle: Tube trains to open a window on ads

fields.headline: Tube trains to open a window on ads
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: The tranquil darkness of Tube train windows may soon be transformed into mini cinema screens showing seven-second adverts between stations.
fields.body:
The tranquil darkness of Tube train windows may soon be transformed into mini cinema screens showing seven-second adverts between stations.

The ads would in reality be a series of 175 posters fixed to the tunnel wall, but, because the train is moving, passengers see a moving image, the size of a broadsheet newspaper, floating in the darkness 15 inches beyond the window.

The principle is that of the "what the butler saw" machine on Victorian piers. Instead of cranking a handle to move images past a viewing slot, the train moves the viewer past the images, though it has to be travelling in excess of 28mph. There would be no soundtrack.

The idea was given a trial on the Piccadilly Line in 1984, but the technology of the day was not sufficiently advanced or cheap. The firm behind its new incarnation, MotionPosters, has given demonstrations to potential customers on a private track in Leicestershire.

MotionPosters' chief executive, Michael Pelham, said it was in talks with TDI, which manages Tube ads, as well as with railways in Hong Kong and Germany. He claimed an advert on a prime stretch of line would bring in more than £8,000 a month.

The key is a microprocessor developed at Cranfield University which measures the train's speed and triggers strobe lights exactly so each image is lit, for two millionths of a second, as the window passes by.

"It's almost as if there was a screen outside, and you see a cinema-quality picture," said Mr Pelham. "It's amazing how it grabs attention." The seven-second slot was what the ad industry asked for; there was in principle no bar to a 20-minute documentary the length of the Channel tunnel.

He added: "No way are we stopping Tube passengers enjoying their newspaper. If they hold it up in front of them, they'll get the benefit of lower fares without ever watching our ads."

fields.headline: Website help for herpes sufferers
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A Birmingham company that wants to create a lonely hearts website for people with genital herpes is raising £3.5m in an Ofex flotation.
fields.body:
A Birmingham company that wants to create a lonely hearts website for people with genital herpes is raising £3.5m in an Ofex flotation.

The firm, Henderson Morley, is entirely focused on herpes. It is developing novel treatments for the disease, selling existing medicines and is planning an internet site of more than 3,000 pages for sufferers.

Chairman Andrew Knight described herpes as a "particularly distressing" problem which was often a barrier when people met for the first time.

He said that a lonely hearts service would help "remove the issue" and overcome any embarrassment.

As a whole, the company's website will be a "cross between a magazine, a reference book and a herpes-focused shop".

In time, Henderson Morley plans to sell medicines online.

The company is likely to be valued at £10m on joining the unregulated stock market. It believes it faces a huge market - one in five North Americans has genital herpes. The disease is thought to have similar prevalence in Europe, although screening is much less widespread.

A former property and nursing homes entrepreneur, Mr Knight established Henderson Morley four years ago with Ian Pardoe, a doctor researching herpes at the University of Birmingham.

The company is working on three treatments. They work by altering the electrical potential of the virus, preventing it from reproducing. Henderson Morley has two further drugs under development, which originate from plants.

Henderson Morley intends to charge browsers to enter its website, then channel the money towards drug development.

Mr Knight said people would be prepared to pay. "Some of these people are desperate," he said. "They've got symptoms which they are very worried about."

Many herpes carriers suffer from cold sores, ulcers, pain and depression with recurrences as often as every month. In more serious cases, the virus can cause blindness, shingles and cancer.

Once contracted, there is no way of getting rid of the disease. The virus is believed to be developing resistance to the most common existing treatments.

Henderson Morley's flotation is being handled by Griffiths and Lamb, the Birmingham stockbroker. The minimum subscription permitted is £1,000.

If successful, the placing will value Mr Knight's 37% stake in the company at £3.7m and Dr Pardoe's stake at £2m.

"Some of these people are desperate," he said. "They've got symptoms which they are very worried about." Many herpes carriers suffer from cold sores, ulcers, pain and depression with recurrences as often as every month. In more serious cases, the virus can cause blindness, shingles and cancer. Once contracted, there is no way of getting rid of the disease. The virus is believed to be developing resistance to the most common existing treatments. Henderson Morley's flotation is being handled by Griffiths and Lamb, the Birmingham stockbroker. The minimum subscription permitted is £1,000. If successful, the placing will value Mr Knight's 37% stake in the company at £3.7m and Dr Pardoe's stake at £2m.

webTitle: NHS running out of time, nurses warn

fields.headline: NHS running out of time, nurses warn
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Ministers have as little as six months to show they can save the NHS, Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, declared yesterday.
fields.body:
Ministers have as little as six months to show they can save the NHS, Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, declared yesterday.

The government needed to demonstrate before next winter that its record funding commitment was bringing tangible improvements, such as shorter waits in casualty and cleaner hospitals.

"The people who deliver and receive health services have got to feel the difference very soon," Ms Hancock told the college's annual congress in Bournemouth.

"Targets and headline figures are all well and good, but if we see a repeat of this winter's sorry tale of an NHS on its knees, people will lose faith."

Ms Hancock said later that while lasting advances in health care would depend on recruiting and training more nurses, simple improvements could be made almost immediately so that patients no longer face lengthy waits on trolleys in casualty units, people were not put on mixed sex wards and hospitals generally had a much-needed clean-up.

Many such improvements could be achieved by reordering priorities. "They are almost easy. The fact that they don't happen is a disgrace."

Nursing was at a defining moment. It had assumed a pivotal position in the government's drive to modernise the NHS, spearheading initiatives such as the NHS Direct telephone advice service, but it was expected to show a new leadership.

Many people articulated this by wanting to "bring back matron". But the job of matron had disappeared from the NHS 34 years ago, and the rigid attitudes it stood for had no place in today's health service.

"I am not saying 'Bring back matron'," Ms Hancock said. "I am saying 'Invest in nurse leadership', because what patients want is an experienced nurse with the authority to make things better."

Delegates called on the government to delay no longer in acting on the recommendations of the royal commission on long-term care which reported more than a year ago and proposed that all "personal care" of elderly people should be free.

June Clark, a former RCN president who served on the commission, said hundreds of elderly people and their carers had been "ruined" by having to pay for care while the government dallied.

The commission costed its proposals at £1.1bn a year. Chris Watson, the RCN president, said the recommendations should be a strong contender for use of the government's increased health funding.

Linda Nazarko, a nursing home proprietor from London, said: "We are the fourth richest country in the world. If we have the money to build the Dome, and luxurious offices for MPs, we have the money."

A Department of Health spokeswoman said the government was now consulting on its national plan for the Health Service, due to be published in July. Ms Hancock was centrally involved in the planning process.

 Nurses voted by more than three to one against relaxing restrictions on organ donation. They rejected a call to follow the British Medical Association, which last year urged a switch from the existing policy of "opting in" to donation to one of "opting out" from a presumption of consent.

More than 5,000 patients are awaiting a transplant and only 15%-20% of the population carry donor cards, giving consent to use of their organs after death.

webTitle: UN chief ends futile Chechnya trip

fields.headline: UN chief ends futile Chechnya trip
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The United Nations high commissioner for human rights, Mary Robinson, ended a much-delayed and frustrating visit to Chechnya yesterday, her attempts to assess alleged war crimes and atrocities by Russian troops stymied by her Russian escort.
fields.body:
The United Nations high commissioner for human rights, Mary Robinson, ended a much-delayed and frustrating visit to Chechnya yesterday, her attempts to assess alleged war crimes and atrocities by Russian troops stymied by her Russian escort.

She was prevented from travelling to three villages outside Grozny where international human rights monitors say Chechen civilians were massacred by Russian troops.

Her requests to inspect several detention centres where Russian troops were alleged to have tortured prisoners were also ignored.

Instead, she was taken to a jail in Grozny where the only inmates were two women held for theft.

Her Russian hosts added insult to injury by cancelling meetings with senior government officials in Moscow yesterday after her return from the north Caucasus was delayed by a day, officially because inclement weather kept her grounded in Dagestan, neighbouring Chechnya.

"The high commissioner had asked to visit a number of locations, none of which were satisfied. So there was some disappointment and frustration," said her spokesman, Jose Diaz, adding that he would describe the visit to the jail in Grozny as "ironic".

Vladimir Kalamanov, president-elect Vladimir Putin's special representative for human rights in Chechnya, dismissed the UN's complaints, insisting that "we have honoured our commitments".

"We were quite open, we showed her everything she wanted to see," he said.

Mrs Robinson has infuriated the Kremlin with her outspoken criticism of Russia's human rights record in Chechnya. Moscow denied her permission to visit the republic in February when she declared that war crimes could not be perpetrated there with impunity.

She repeated the criticism in Chechnya.

"I am hearing of very serious problems of human rights violations carried out by those in Russian military uniforms, special forces uniforms," she said.

"It is very important that these be fully investigated and that those responsible do not have impunity."

Elsewhere yesterday the International Federation of Human Rights Leagues (FIDH), which is based in Paris, also stepped up the pressure on Moscow to own up to its troops' human rights abuses in Chechnya.

Following a week-long mission to the region, the FIDH said: "The civilian population is the first target of the operations carried out by the Russians . . . who are responsible for the most serious violations of human rights and international law. These violations constitute war crimes and crimes against humanity."

The Russian hostility to Mrs Robinson was not unexpected since she had enraged the Kremlin with the requests she made before arriving in Moscow last Friday.

Her letter asked for "information on mass human rights violations by Russian troops or [Chechen] terrorists".

"That's an insult," Mr Kalamanov told the Guardian. "Ours is a modern, civilised European army. You can't put it together with terrorists in a war against religious extremism. That makes us angry."

During her trip to the Caucasus, Mrs Robinson also met some of the tens of thousands of refugees in Ingushetia.

Accompanying her, Oleg Mironov, Russia's human rights commissioner, belittled the catalogue of complaints from the homeless. "Conclusions cannot be drawn only from the words of excited people in refugee camps," he said.

Other officials said the lack of transparency on Mrs Robinson's tour was predictable.

"The Russians don't want to show Robinson the real face of what this war is all about," said Diederik Lohman, the Moscow director of the New York-based Human Rights Watch. "It's not surprising."

The FIDH said Russia should be banished from the Council of Europe for its conduct in Chechnya.

The council will decide whether to suspend Russian membership on Thursday.

A Russian delegation travelled to the council's headquarters in Strasbourg at the weekend, warning that there would be "radical reciprocal action" should the suspension threat be implemented.

fields.headline: Irvine's £23m for asylum cases
fields.standfirst:
Refugees in Britain: special report
The issue explained: How to claim asylum
fields.trailText: An extra £23m to provide more and better legal advice to asylum seekers was pledged by the lord chancellor yesterday, as he launched the new community legal service.
fields.body:
An extra £23m to provide more and better legal advice to asylum seekers was pledged by the lord chancellor yesterday, as he launched the new community legal service.

Another £23m will go to other areas of the law earmarked as priority - mental health, community care, education and other "public law" cases including claims against the police and government departments. A huge increase in such claims is expected once the Human Rights Act comes into force next October.

Lord Irvine said there were too many poor quality and even unscrupulous advisers providing immigration advice. The extra money would go towards improving advice and providing more advisers in areas to which asylum seekerswere being dispersed.

He said good advice would speed up decision-making because if claims were properly prepared cases could be processed much more quickly.

"In order for adjudicators to process cases faster it's much better that the paperwork comes to them in clear and proper order so they can quickly assess the case. That's where lawyers come in. Lawyers do some good and they're capable of doing good in this area," he said.

He announced a pay boost of 8% in London and 5% elsewhere for solicitors with contracts to provide legal help in the priority areas under the service, which replaces legal aid. Solicitors had been threatening to withdraw their services after a four-year pay freeze.

The launch of the new community legal service coincides with major changes in what used to be called legal aid. From this week, accident victims will no longer get public funding to fight for compensation, except for exceptional, high cost cases. They will have to find lawyers prepared to take their case on a no-win, no-fee basis.

A community legal service website, www.justask.org.uk, launched yesterday by Cherie Booth QC, gives details of 15,000 approved sources of legal advice and will provide answers to legal queries.

fields.headline: Our blind spot on Africa
fields.trailText: How should we expect African kids to get an education while their schools are being bombed to smithereens (Leader, April 3)? In Somalia in 1995, the UN's World Food Programme was feeding 1m school children in Mogadishu. Then came the pullout by UN peacekeepers. The WFP school programme was abandoned too, due to fears for the security of the foreign aid workers.
fields.body:
How should we expect African kids to get an education while their schools are being bombed to smithereens (Leader, April 3)? In Somalia in 1995, the UN's World Food Programme was feeding 1m school children in Mogadishu. Then came the pullout by UN peacekeepers. The WFP school programme was abandoned too, due to fears for the security of the foreign aid workers.

Today there are only a handful of schools across all of Somalia, since in the absence of a peace agreement the country still has neither state institutions nor funds for social services. Meanwhile, many kids have gone back to fighting.

Present and past wars are the single greatest reason why, for example, 12m are starving in the Horn of Africa today. By blaming Africa's crises primarily on nature - ecological collapse and Aids - you fall into the same trap as so many other observers of the continent. It is this same attitude which allows the west, perhaps not unintentionally, to wash its hands of helping to resolve Africa's conflicts.

In Sudan, the civil war has dragged on and off since the 1950s, yet the international community still has no coherent diplomatic policy other than to throw food aid at it, which many say serves to actually prolong the conflict.

Tony Blair's government may have done more for Africa than previous ones in aid budgets and the debt relief debate, but it has no real diplomatic policy on most African conflicts.

The people of the Horn did not die en masse centuries before there was ever a World Food Programme or AK-47s. But to take the example of Mozambique, the civil war, manipulated and fed with weapons by the Soviet Union, apartheid South Africa and Reagan's US, did much to weaken any potential response by local people for decades to come.

Before we pat our government on the back about debt relief, let's see some real efforts by Blair to tackle even one African conflict such as Sudan - or to prevent one in a country like Zimbabwe or Kenya.

Aidan Hartley
 London Mashur@cs.com

 Poor Africa, it seems we in the west do understand the reasons behind a continent's ongoing impoverishment and desperation: a "coincidence of crises" - ecological disasters, malnutrition, poverty, Aids and political corruption of resources?

So far, coverage of poverty in Africa is a successful record of self-deception. Today's Africa is the legacy of European historical plundering of a continent's resources, which in our contemporary world continues through a global free-market economic slave-trade, and monetary institutions which still proceed to extrapolate African finances through debt-interest repayment.

Africa's political corruption by its rich elites was a slice of the colonial cake we left behind, letting the west off the hook for its crimes of impoverishment, in light of Africa's own corruption.

Before we tell the world to educate its children, we might try to correctly inform ours, otherwise we proceed into the millennium as the new missionaries, bearing as much ignorance and responsibility for a continent's impoverishment as before.

Rachel Howes
Newcastle upon Tyne R.N.Howes@ncl.ac.uk

 Could Microsoft's excess profits (Leader, April 3) be used to supply many third world countries with computers to aid primary education? This, together with more radical debt relief, would revolutionise primary education across the world.

Helene R Perrin-Summers
Nailsworth, Glos

webTitle: Futile search for clues in ministerial gobbledygook

fields.headline: Futile search for clues in ministerial gobbledygook
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Mrs Angela Browning is the Tory spokesperson on industry. She was a puzzling choice. You look at the Tory backbenches these days, and you see folk like Peter Lilley, Michael Howard, Norman Fowler, Ken Clarke, John Redwood and David Davis - all right, many of them the scum of the earth - but compared to Mrs Browning, political titans every one.
fields.body:
Mrs Angela Browning is the Tory spokesperson on industry. She was a puzzling choice. You look at the Tory backbenches these days, and you see folk like Peter Lilley, Michael Howard, Norman Fowler, Ken Clarke, John Redwood and David Davis - all right, many of them the scum of the earth - but compared to Mrs Browning, political titans every one.

Yet they are reduced to collecting their own toe nails, hanging round chat rooms on the web, receiving thousands in consultancy fees from various merchants of death, or whatever it is people to do fill the long, lonely hours while Mrs Browning is trying and failing to get a handle on the Rover crisis.

Yesterday Martin O'Neill, the Labour chairman of the industry committee, got into trouble with the Speaker during another session on the Rover crisis. Mrs Browning has been attempting to prove that Stephen Byers, the industry secretary, knew Rover was in peril long before he told the House.

She has been shuffling newspaper reports, comparing Mr Byers's statements at one time with remarks made at another time, and generally snooping round. Curtain-twitching is an important part of an opposition's job.

So Mr O'Neill referred to "the paranoia of the second-rate Miss Marple across the way".

The Speaker was outraged. "This is not appropriate!" she barked.

Mr O'Neill said ingenuously that he thought a reference "to one of Agatha Christie's minor detectives was appropriate".

Betty continued to bristle. "It does cause me offence, actually," she said, though Mrs Browning, rather than looking affronted, merely simpered quietly to herself.

I was puzzled, though I suspect that Ms Boothroyd may have been more concerned to protect Miss Marple's reputation than Mrs Browning's.

After all, the fictional sleuth was intelligent, intuitive, well-informed, a mistress of detail, able to assimilate complex and often contradictory data, and generally an adornment to the place. Mrs Browning is not.

Nevertheless the existing list of unparliamentary terms, which includes "blackguard", "cheeky young pup", "Pecksniff", "jackass", "guttersnipe", "rat", "ruffian", "murderer", "swine" and "traitor" is now joined by "second-rate Miss Marple". Of such small moments is our unwritten constitution constructed through the ages.

Poor Mrs Browning had got off to an awful start. She was asking what's called a private notice question. These are usually about a subject on which the government would prefer to keep quiet, and so are a valuable way for the opposition to drag ministers into the chamber and account for themselves.

Mrs Browning seemed confused. Perhaps she thought she could save time by skipping Mr Byers' reply to her unasked question, and went straight into her riposte.

"The question of Rover is becoming a question of the survival of the secretary of state!" she announced, thus giving away her opening line.

(John Redwood, who believes he should have her job, could be seen trying not to smirk. Instead he took a series of short breaths, then stole a very quick look at the press gallery to make sure we had spotted the gaffe.)

Mr Byers was much better than he has been on this topic, which is not saying much. But his reply to Mr Redwood's call for him to resign was merely flaccid. "It is a delicious irony that so confirmed an anti-European should seek to make political capital out of the actions of a German car manufacturer," he said feebly, a sorry example of the higher gobbledy-gook in which this whole wretched debate has been conducted.

webTitle: Poodles or politicians? Now is the time to decide

fields.headline: Poodles or politicians? Now is the time to decide
fields.standfirst:
The freedom of information bill offers a defining moment for backbenchers

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Today will see a defining confrontation between the virtue and the vice of power. It poses the pretensions of New Labour as a party of reform against the instincts of no-longer-new Labour as a party of government.
fields.body:
Today will see a defining confrontation between the virtue and the vice of power. It poses the pretensions of New Labour as a party of reform against the instincts of no-longer-new Labour as a party of government.

Two decades of argument about citizens' right to be informed about the way they're governed have come down to a single moment in the Commons. The final stage of the freedom of information bill subsumes all that is familiar about the attitudes of executive regimes anywhere in the world, and all that is suspect about the Blair regime's claim to be different.

As readers of the Guardian, you know a bit about this, because we've been reporting developments for two years. You're more fortunate than you know. Most people face not only the grotesque betrayal of what this government once promised about free information but a level of ignorance which is the bequest of our wonderful free press.

Because FoI has become "a Guardian story", editorial honchos elsewhere say, it's a non-event for everyone else. They simply have not covered it. They tell me this quite blithely. A great reforming question is swallowed up in the circulation wars, even as these editors prate about the democratic vitality of the fourth estate.

The government has hitherto taken their lead. Marginalised to a Guardian ghetto, the question need not detain us, says Jack Straw. Extensive scrutiny by both select and standing committees yielded much criticism and removal of some especially blatant absurdities, but no change on the central issues. Now, however, there's an opportunity, and just possibly it will be taken.

For the first time, ministers are shaken. Their cunning evasions and damnable lies have enraged many senior parliamentarians enough to produce cross-party amendments for the report stage which, while not expunging every example of power mania, would make this the reforming act it was meant to be.

Consider one of them. It goes to the heart of the matter. The bill creates an information commissioner who, in the original white paper, was given the power to order disclosure, within categories of information otherwise covered by a blanket exemption, if she considered this in the public interest. A ministerial veto, said the white paper, "would undermine the authority of the information commissioner and erode public confidence in the act".

But when the white paper became the bill, the veto appeared. The prime minister took personal charge of installing it. He has also overseen, with his feline courtier-lawyer, Lord Falconer, a man who would never seek and never gain elective office, the pretty little subterfuge by which it has been retained. For the outpouring of ridicule over the bill was strenuous enough for the government to apparently change its mind and propose its own amendment. Now the commissioner would indeed, it seemed, be able to "require" disclosure.

But wait a moment. The words are there, but they're followed by other words which say that, having "required" disclosure, the commissioner may still have her ruling vetoed by the minister or local authority who doesn't like it.

A minister has offered reasons for this. Sharply revealing of the collective mind-set of the government, they were, in a word, scandalous. This commissioner was, he said, illegitimate. Her power would create "a democratic deficit". Letting her overrule ministers was "profoundly undemocratic".

"Democracy must mean something," he bleated. Besides, governing was specialised work. "Only a qualified person can have a full understanding of the issues involved in the decision-making processes of a public authority." The commissioner was not such a person. She was therefore incapable of determining what did and did not prejudice the public interest.

Mike O'Brien, the home office minister who uttered this neo-fascist garbage, has previously shown a special insensitivity to anti-authoritarian arguments, when dealing with the Tories' last police bill. Power, predictably, has fortified his arrogance. On the basis of what he said in committee, it would seem that no judge has a part to play in "democracy".

No one but an elected minister can say what is right and wrong, true or false. Every time a minister's word is successfully contested, democracy itself is assaulted. These are startling revisions of the constitution. Yet no higher minister intervened to correct the record.

Now, however, parliament has the chance to do so. O'Brien's case is presumably that a minister who misused his veto could always be called to account in the Commons. That's the way the democratic deficit is repaired. Some hope. The man is a fantasist as well as a wittering bully. Nothing like that could ever happen in the real world.

On the other hand, what must now happen in the real world does give parliament power. The bill has to be passed. Now is the moment we discover whether we live under government by, with and for the executive, or a version of power that says the people have their interest. Today and tomorrow offer the one opportunity available for Labour MPs to look themselves in the face and decide what they are for.

The Tories and Liberal Democrats will line up for the amendments. These all speak to the same big issue: shall the information regime be loaded for or against disclosure? On every tight call, the bill says emphatically against. The power of the commissioner - the judge, the disinterested party - is at the apex of the question. Labour backbenchers now have to decide whether they are crawlers-for-office whose reforming faculties have been lobotomised, or serious politicians prepared to acknowledge their discovery that ministers have for the last year been acting in bad faith.

They do not need to be the accomplices of these ministers. For this is not a party question. It's not about how to construct the best system of welfare reform. Nor is it one of those famous issues of conscience, in which different MPs summon their opinions from a variety of moral formations and are lauded or excoriated for their personal stand. There is nothing moral about this. It is a matter of democratic values and professional self-respect. Whose side are you on? The government's, which has betrayed Labour pledges stretching back two decades? Or the people's, who once expected FoI to be the peak not the nadir of Labour's constitutional reforms?

They might not win. But a decent turn-out for principled independence would send a signal to the other place. One hesitates to urge the illegitimate Lords to do anything at all. They live and breathe democratic deficit. But being there, by grace of Mr Blair, they need every encouragement to prove they're not his poodles.

webTitle: Rushing headlong into star wars and destabilisation

fields.headline: Rushing headlong into star wars and destabilisation
fields.trailText: Messrs Blair, Hain and the anonymous ministers quoted by Patrick Wintour (British role in US star wars shield, March 30) show the same blinkered, disingenuous subservience over the developmental stage of the British bits of the Space Based Infra Red System, to give it its more revealing official title, as HMG did when the bases were inaugurated in 1997.
fields.byline: Air Commodore Alastair Mackie   Norman Moss    DR Bell
fields.body:
Messrs Blair, Hain and the anonymous ministers quoted by Patrick Wintour (British role in US star wars shield, March 30) show the same blinkered, disingenuous subservience over the developmental stage of the British bits of the Space Based Infra Red System, to give it its more revealing official title, as HMG did when the bases were inaugurated in 1997.

SBIRS is only incidentally a defence against rogue states or a protection for Britain. Its purpose is to give the US a secure base for Global Reach, a strategy which, to quote its commander, General Ashy, in 1996, will use Space Command "to fight from space and... into space. That's why the US has developed programs in directed energy and hit-to-kill mechanisms".

Global Reach will destroy the west's precarious accommodation with Russia. It will antagonise China and terrify the other Pacific states. It will accelerate the nuclear arms race.

It will nullify UN efforts to ensure, as Kofi Annan put it, that outer space remains weapons free. And its predication of US impregnability is as flawed as was that of the embryonic predecessor with which Andre Maginot furnished France in the 1930s.

Air Commodore Alistair Mackie
London

 The so-called missile defence system is even more stupid than Martin Woollacott says (Nuclear weapons are a stupid risk, March 31). He says it might be easier for America and its allies to deal with a hostile country that had a handful of nuclear weapons if a defence was in place and there was little chance that those weapons would get through. But even a small chance that they would get through would be quite enough for them to serve as a deterrent to American action.

No American president would take even a small chance that one or two American cities would be destroyed and several million Americans killed because of a dispute with North Korea or Iraq. A missile defence system would only work- that is, negate a deterrent threat by another country - if it were known with certainty to be 100% effective. And it never will be.

Norman Moss
London normanmoss@aol.com

 When Germany sought to bury radioactive waste in the deserts of the newly- independent Namibia, the Namibian government said "No", in spite of the money offered by the Germans. So the Namib desert remains uncontaminated and its strange beauty, carefully maintained, one of the great tourist attractions of southern Africa.

Ours is not a poor country and we need neither the "stupid risk" nor monetary rewards (if any) for extending the US base at Fylingdales. "How can we turn down a request from our closest ally to change its computer software?" Just say "no", cabinet minister, or if that's too difficult, "no thank you".

DR Bell
Nottingham

fields.headline: A swap shop for vouchers
fields.trailText: Oxfam have quite rightly pulled out of accepting vouchers in their shops (Oxfam calls for asylum voucher boycott, April 3). But there must be some way of subverting this humiliating and iniquitous system. The obvious one would be for people with money to set up local exchange schemes and swap asylum seekers' vouchers for cash, if we could use the vouchers ourselves instead.
fields.body:
Oxfam have quite rightly pulled out of accepting vouchers in their shops (Oxfam calls for asylum voucher boycott, April 3). But there must be some way of subverting this humiliating and iniquitous system. The obvious one would be for people with money to set up local exchange schemes and swap asylum seekers' vouchers for cash, if we could use the vouchers ourselves instead.

If we can't do this (and I understand that the humiliation may be reinforced by asylum seekers having to show the cashier their papers at the same time), maybe we could link up with individual asylum seekers in a sort of buddy system, and go shopping together. They could use their vouchers for our shopping and we could give them cash.

If we can't thwart the government's nasty inten tions by opting out, can we do so by opting in?

Elinor Harris
Bristol

 Oxfam's David Bryer says "providing vouchers instead of cash already restricts where asylum seekers can shop". Quite so, but doesn't money itself also restrict where everyone can shop, and what they can obtain? Vouchers and money are instruments that obstruct needs because the means of producing food, goods and services belong to capitalists not workers. The fact that Oxfam would participate if asylum seekers merely received change - thereby maintaining their deprivation - shows why revolutionary politics should replace accommodative charity work.

Max Hess
Folkestone, Kent
max@truesocialism. freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: Dressing down
fields.trailText: I was intrigued by your piece about the allegedly new "office casual" dress style (Tie die, March 31), as we ancient Whitehall civil servants pioneered this fashion 50 years ago, when we worked on Saturday mornings.
fields.body:
I was intrigued by your piece about the allegedly new "office casual" dress style (Tie die, March 31), as we ancient Whitehall civil servants pioneered this fashion 50 years ago, when we worked on Saturday mornings.

It was the done thing not to wear suits on those mornings. We didn't need advice - we dressed in sports jackets and grey or brown trousers with coloured shirts, actually in preparation for our Saturday afternoon activities, often watching or playing football.

One daring lady always turned up in jodhpurs and two lads were famous for arriving in white shirts and shorts ready for tennis. Happy days!

Kenneth Clark
London

fields.headline: Wiser about work
fields.trailText: I retired three weeks ago at the age of 50 and found your article (BT ready to put up retirement age to over 70, April 3) of considerable interest.
fields.body:
I retired three weeks ago at the age of 50 and found your article (BT ready to put up retirement age to over 70, April 3) of considerable interest.

I am a literate, numerate and computer-literate engineer, but one of a large number of such people recently released on "voluntary" redundancy by the electricity industry. The carrot was an early (though not enhanced) pension; the stick no substantive job and the prospect of another 13 years with an increasingly family-hostile employer. With two school-age children and a working wife there was no real choice.

It is difficult to see how Mr Blair might tempt me back to work. I have never been unemployed before but have no wish to find a minimum-wage job just when I have broken free from long British working hours and finally have time to pursue my own interests. Perhaps he should be tackling the issues which make work so unattractive.

Mike Brown
Newcastle upon Tyne
family@brownz.fsnet.co.uk

 Margaret Hodge, minister for employment and equal opportunities, is quoted as saying, "the government believes that wasting talent by displaying age prejudice in the workplace is bad for the economy and unfair to the individual".

If this is what the government really believes it could make a start by practising what it preaches in the Lord Chancellor's department which is responsible for the lay magistracy and which compulsorily retires magistrates at 70. The government is therefore, in its own words, "displaying age prejudice".

Diane Munday Wheathampstead, Herts
dianemunday@care4free.net

fields.headline: Dyke's masterplan
fields.standfirst:
He's right to let creatives create

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke must be one of the few executives in the world who can announce up to a thousand redundancies - and hear his own staff cheer. Yet such is the goodwill the new director general enjoys, that was the reaction at the BBC yesterday to the first stage of his masterplan for the organisation. By promising to rip out an entire layer of bureaucracy he delighted an organisation that had grown sick of over-management in the John Birt era.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke must be one of the few executives in the world who can announce up to a thousand redundancies - and hear his own staff cheer. Yet such is the goodwill the new director general enjoys, that was the reaction at the BBC yesterday to the first stage of his masterplan for the organisation. By promising to rip out an entire layer of bureaucracy he delighted an organisation that had grown sick of over-management in the John Birt era. Programme makers have complained for years of creativity stifled by teams of paper-shufflers who write no scripts, record no interviews, shoot no pictures - yet draw large salaries and gain ever grander titles. His promise of a "flatter" structure where a few suits direct a large body of creative types strikes an immediate chord with those who think of the Beeb more as a cultural force than a glorified widget factory.

The details of the Dyke plan continue in the same, encouraging vein. He is slashing the number of "business units" that used to trade with each other in the BBC's artificial, internal market from 190 to 50. Hopefully this will end the ludicrous arrangement whereby one department would pay another £15 to borrow a record or £25 to look at a few newspaper clippings. An equal absurdity was the separation of the wing of the BBC that made programmes and the section that put them on the air: now the broadcast and production directorates created by John Birt are to become one. This should end the situation - maddening to programme-makers - which made the left hand a stranger to the right.

The BBC will also now "guarantee output" for several production departments: in the past, they could make no long-range plans because they were not sure a BBC channel would "buy" their work. This effectively turned units of the Beeb into independent producers, vulnerable to the chill wind of the market - except they could not offer their wares outside the BBC. They paid the price of competition, with none of the advantages. That contradiction will now end.

A last morsel of good news concerns Alan Yentob. A contender for Mr Dyke's job, he was faulted as an insufficiently robust administrator. But he is admired for his creativity and yesterday the DG gave him a large canvas on which to play. He will now head a super-department encompassing drama, entertainment and children's programmes - the broadcasting equivalent of John Prescott's mega-ministry. In addition, he is to oversee a BBC film unit modelled on Channel 4's highly-successful Film Four. This is just where the BBC should be, investing energy in the British film industry.

Two caveats remain. The first is that Mr Dyke must make sure his changes happen. The BBC can be like a mutant creature from a 1950s horror movie: you cut off its leg, only to see it regrow elsewhere. The DG should watch out for middle-managers who, officially sacked, simply resurface elsewhere with a new title: the head of radio sport reappearing as deputy head of radio (sport). If he wants to save money, he will have to sack actual people - not merely relabel their posts.

Second, as Channel 5's David Elstein helpfully argued in yesterday's Media Guardian, Mr Dyke will have to be vigilant that this revamp is not the first of many. Permanent revolution ate away at the Birt BBC; Greg Dyke would do well to avoid making the same mistake. He needs to make the structural changes begun yesterday and then leave his staff alone - allowing them to do what they do best. Not writing memos and strategy reviews but making radio we want to hear and television we want to watch.

fields.headline: Homer's latest epic
fields.trailText:
I note that BNFL has a facility called the Springfields plant (Nuclear flasks fail safety test, April 1). Is this the one managed by Montgomery Burns, with Homer J Simpson in charge of operations? Time for another BNFL name-change, perhaps?

Alan Dunbabin
Wrexham

Alan Dunbabin

 Why are there so many pictures in the Guardian of people with their mouths open? The other day I counted 10.

John JB Reade

fields.headline: A licence to print money
fields.standfirst: Now ask the people how to spend it
fields.trailText: The biggest online auction in the world is reaching its climax. It is being conducted not in the US by internet upstarts like ebay nor by any of the top auction houses - but here in London by Gordon Brown. He is auctioning licences for the next slices of spectrum for the third generation of mobile phones, powerful enough for two-way transmission of films and video.Last night 11 of the 13 consortia bidding for the five available licences were still in the race. None - yet - wants to face being the only big player without a licence for what could be one  of the biggest-selling consumer products in recent memory.
fields.body:
The biggest online auction in the world is reaching its climax. It is being conducted not in the US by internet upstarts like ebay nor by any of the top auction houses - but here in London by Gordon Brown. He is auctioning licences for the next slices of spectrum for the third generation of mobile phones, powerful enough for two-way transmission of films and video. It is already the biggest auction, the biggest single privatisation and one of the biggest creations of value-added. It arises from selling bits of paper giving the winners a licence to spend even more money building the infrastructure. By last night the potential proceeds had reached almost £11bn. This is more than three times what the chancellor had pencilled in in his Budget - and there is no sign that the bidding is about to stop. Last night 11 of the 13 consortia bidding for the five available licences were still in the race. None - yet - wants to face being the only big player without a licence for what could be one of the biggest-selling consumer products in recent memory.

There is another record. It is the biggest unexpected windfall any government has received in such a short period. The question is what should be done with the money? This could be a golden opportunity to have another kind of auction on the internet to see how people would like to see this money spent.

It could be used for a specifically digital purpose in keeping with its origin - like funding a speedy transition to digital television or bridging the "digital divide" between rich and poor. Or it could cure the ills of the London underground, build a fast rail link to the north from the channel tunnel, construct dozens of hospitals or improve our schools. If the government created a web site where people could vote for their preferences it would be in keeping with the way the money was raised and herald an experiment in digital democracy. Gordon should go for it.

fields.headline: Space school
fields.standfirst: Next week is the 30th anniversary of Apollo 13, the journey into space that almost came to grief. It was a lesson on a planetary scale, writes  Tim Radford
fields.trailText: Next week is the 30th anniversary of Apollo 13, the journey into space that almost came to grief. It was a lesson on a planetary scale, writes Tim Radford
fields.body:
On April 13, 1970, more than halfway to the moon, an exploding fuel-cell tank brought three men close to death 200,000 miles from home. How they escaped and got back to earth was a sublime lesson in engineering skills, coolness under pressure, and trust in the laws of physics.

There was a lesson in everything that happened aboard Apollo 13, and though it was mostly played out on radio, it unfolded as a kind of epic movie, on a screen a quarter of a million miles wide, and while it unfolded the entire world sat, and held its breath, and gasped at the awful starkness of it.

A spacecraft is a kind of tiny, free-range planet. It must have air, water, recycling systems, supplies, drainage, sanitation and heating and cooling mechanisms. On planet earth - unlike Mars or Venus - the air is made up in the right proportions of gases and there is enough water to go round and the power source is the sun. On planet Apollo 13, everything depended on fuel cells.

These fed oxygen with hydrogen to produce electricity and water in a reaction so precise you could write it on a blackboard. That was the first lesson: life is chemistry, quite literally. Inside the spacecraft were earth temperatures and pressures and it was the electricity that kept these up. Outside the spacecraft was the freezing vacuum of space, and at the first puncture of an oxygen tank, astronauts could actually see the ultracold liquid oxygen gas cascading out in the vast emptiness "swirling in the sunlight like cigarette smoke." There were two lessons there: in the laws of thermodynamics and the behaviour of gases.

There were lessons all the way for the next 300,000 miles. The force of the gas escaping wasn't very great, but Newton's laws of motion are unforgiving. The escaping oxygen acted like tiny rocket thrusters to destabilise the spacecraft and push it a little off course. The astronauts realised that the main spacecraft, Odyssey, was dying - a planet being stripped of its atmosphere - and scrambled into their "lifeboat": the lunar module Aquarius.

There they began to exploit some thing else the world had learned from Newton's laws of motion and gravitational force. They fired the engine to set a course that would bypass the moon and bend around it and use the moon's gravity to throw them back to earth a little faster, and they had to get it just right. They had to get their craft into a trajectory that would not only sling them back to earth, but also have them heading towards the home planet so that they would hit the atmosphere at just the right angle. If they came in too shallow, they would bounce off the atmosphere; if they came in too steep, they would burn up.

These things are tricky to calculate on earth, where all the sums are confounded by air resistance and friction and drag. But in the purity of space, the mathematics is true and the physics is like clockwork. A spacecraft heading round a planet in the right direction gains speed and the planet slows down proportionately. If the spacecraft is little, it gains a lot of speed and if the planet is huge, it slows down hardly at all.

Years later, when the Voyager spacecraft flew past Jupiter, it gained 37,500 mph and Jupiter slowed down by 12 inches in about a million million years. But to make sure they had calculated right, the Apollo astronauts did what all ancient mariners once did: they had to take star sightings. Then they discovered another problem. All the bits that had blown off the spacecraft in the original explosion were still riding along with them, with sunlight reflecting from them, "a swarm of false stars, indistinguishable from the real ones".

It was harder to calculate how to survive in a little lunar lander that only had very limited battery power. There was an even more pressing problem: carbon dioxide. Humans breathe in oxygen and breathe out carbon dioxide. With every exhalation, you create a problem of foul air. In a spaceship, you cannot open the windows. There were chemicals to "scrub" the carbon dioxide from the air but they were designed to cater for two men for two days, not three men for more than three days.

Carbon dioxide kills, slowly: first, there would be terrible headaches, then hearts would begin to pound, then the three astronauts would become drowsy, and then they would sleep, and quietly asphyxiate. The world held its breath while the astronauts, fatigued, cold and dehydrated, followed ground control instructions to turn two lithium hydroxide canisters from the mothership, some cardboard from a flightplan book, two plastic storage bags and some grey tape into a makeshift air purifier.

When the three men got back into the main ship as they approached earth, the vessel was at refrigerator temperature: so cold that all their breath had condensed in it, and even the instrument panel was dripping. When the spacecraft splashed down safely and gently, in the warmth of the South Pacific, Navy divers opened the doors and a great cloud of frosty air flew out into the tropical morning: inside the spacecraft, the chill of space lingered on. Every hour of the drama was a new demonstration in the stark, life-or-death, down-to-earth urgency of science.

Last week, the National Space Science Centre in Leicester conducted a survey of 1,026 children aged 10 to 13. Four out of five thought science at school was boring; 15% thought biology the only aspect of any interest, and 90% criticised the way they were taught. Only one child in 14 wanted to take up a career in science. However, there was a twist to all this: 43% of the children would like to be astronauts, compared with 23% who wanted to be a footballer and 20% who would prefer to be a fashion model. Some 65% wanted to see some form of space science introduced into the classroom. And 99% knew that the first man on the moon was Neil Armstrong.

The comments of the kids themselves were fairly withering. "The experiments are good but the teachers going on and on is dead boring," said one 12-year-old boy, and a 10-year-old said: "Science is really boring. It's equations, writing long words, body parts and bad smells. I don't mind experiments but I hate recording results."

A girl of 12 said "Complicated - all about atoms and everything. I don't know a lot about science. I sometimes like the experiments in science because you never know what is going to happen."

But a boy of 12 said: "Space is exciting. Later on I want to become an astronaut and at the moment I'd like to get all the knowledge I can. You need lots of qualifications. Being an astronaut is really cool."

Paul Murdin, of the British National Space Centre, which spends the government's money on space, wasn't in the least surprised by the Leicester research. "It confirms what we have known for a long time - that astronomy, space, cosmology, the origin of the universe and so on are the most important sciences when it comes to pulling young people into science and maintaining their interest as they make that terrible transition from GCSEs to A levels," Murdin said.

"The passion is maintained by enthusiastic teachers and by teachers who can point to modern things going on, and get away from the idea that science is frock-coated, bearded European males like Bunsen, the science of long past. It's about making it clear that science is about exploring frontiers - both intellectual frontiers and the real one, the planets."

webTitle: Lebanon chief moves to stem SLA exodus

fields.headline: Lebanon chief moves to stem SLA exodus
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: A South Lebanese Army general sentenced to death in Beirut for aiding the Israeli occupation of south Lebanon, yesterday vowed to fight to the bloody end when his paymasters withdraw in the weeks ahead.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg in Metulla, on the Israeli-Lebanese border
fields.body:
A South Lebanese Army general sentenced to death in Beirut for aiding the Israeli occupation of south Lebanon, yesterday vowed to fight to the bloody end when his paymasters withdraw in the weeks ahead.

With no sign of a wider peace deal with Syria, it is becoming increasingly likely that Israel's withdrawal from south Lebanon will be conducted under fire, a prospect that could destabilise the entire region and leave Israel's allies in the country open to reprisal attacks.

"I thought of leaving," General Antoine Lahad, commander of the South Lebanese Army (SLA), said from this Israeli border town. "But I am staying there no matter how bad it gets."

Although the general is believed to have secured his escape - to his residence in Paris - yesterday he put on an air of bravado for his men in the hopes of forestalling a wider exodus. However, it contradicted his appearance: a jacket hanging loose on his frail shoulders, his voice was at times barely audible.

As commander of the SLA, Israel's main ally in its self-styled security zone, Gen Lahad and his 2,600 men have much to consider when the 18-year occupation comes to an end. So too do the people of Metulla have much to fear.

Come early July, when the Israeli soldiers are scheduled to depart, the red-tiled roofs of this hamlet will once again be under the guns of whichever force rules - the Syrian-backed Hizbullah guerrillas, the Lebanese army, or most improbably, the SLA.

"Before 1982, it was a hell here," said Miriam Hod, who owns a guest house in Metulla. "I had two little children and almost all year we were in the shelters underground."

She points out the window, to the hill that rises beyond the peach and date trees at the bottom of her garden. "Do you see that road there? That is already in Lebanon. You can imagine what will happen to my living room."

And Ms Hod is not alone in her fear; many of Gen Lahad's troops are said to be expecting the worst, which is why he is trying to reassure them. "There we are described as collaborators, here we are described as collaborators," said Gen Lahad. "Just like you at Massada, we will fight to the last."

His invocation of the last, suicidal stand of the Zealots against the might of the Roman empire in the first century AD was deliberate and intended to impress on his Israeli hosts the danger of abandoning the SLA to its fate.

Israel has yet to announce the date of its pullout - or even to confirm whether it will abandon all its outposts inside Lebanon. Instead, officials say the timing of the operation will depend on the manner of its departure. "It depends on how we want to leave. We have equipment, we have soldiers, we have outposts, we have allies," said Brigadier General Benny Gantz, the chief liaison officer to the SLA.

The future of those allies is becoming a subject of increasing urgency. Yesterday, Gen Lahad demanded the Lebanese authorities grant an amnesty to the 2,600 SLA members and their families to ensure their safety.

"They must treat us like all Lebanese - better than the other Lebanese," said Mr Lahad. "It is the government of Lebanon that left the region and let it fall. If they come to our home they are welcome, but on our conditions."

But despite the general's defiance, there have been a flurry of reports about possible safe havens for his followers - including France, Turkey and the northern towns of Israel, where the authorities are believed to be scouting out flats for SLA officers.

At the so-called Good Fence border crossing, where some 1,500 Lebanese workers enter Metulla at dawn every day, few expect a valiant last stand for his SLA. "Who has the strength to make a war," said Jumana, returning home to her village in south Lebanon from her day job as a cleaner. "Half of our boys are dead and half have left. We have been fighting for so long. How can we go on this way?"

Almost all of the Lebanese workers here owe their jobs to their connections with SLA officers - an association that makes them hopelessly compromised when Israel departs. Some labourers, such as Riza, a metalworker who earns $25 (£16) a day inside Israel, are wanted men inside Lebanon.

Riza was sentenced to 15 years in absentia for his membership in the SLA. But he says he has no intention of fleeing his village, and he will not surrender either.

"We gave 500 martyrs from our village alone. We will not let the Hizbullah come so easily," he said. "If Israel doesn't help us, we will get [rockets] and fire them on Israel. And if Lahad does not defend south Lebanon, then we will throw him out."

fields.headline: The Guv'nor
fields.trailText: Target setting in schools is a meaty business. For me, it is at the heart of the governing body's role...
fields.body:
Target setting in schools is a meaty business. For me, it is at the heart of the governing body's role - it's the means of forward planning and giving direction for a school to achieve real improvement. And achieving real improvement is the key.

There are four basic steps:

1: Find out where your school is at the moment. There is a wealth of hard data out there. Ask your headteacher to provide this, and to explain it. And keep on asking questions until you are confident and clear about what it all means.

2: Ask the headteacher to prepare a series of improvement options. As a governing body, you are then in an informed position to examine each option carefully. The focus here is what are the gains - to whom - and at what cost?

3: Decide as a governing body, based on step two, what your targets will be. Apply the CARD formula:

 Costable

 Achievable

 Realistic

 Demanding

4: Inform your local education authority or inspector, whichever is appropriate in your area, of the targets you will be setting. Should they seek to challenge these, having followed steps 1, 2 and 3 you will be in a strong position to justify your decision, backed by the evidence.

A word of warning. Don't set targets that are overly ambitious. If you feel you are being "pushed" in this direction, ask the authority to say how, exactly, they would improve upon your targets, and perhaps more important, where the money will be coming from.

Target-setting should be about providing strategic goals by weighing up the ideals of progress and improvement against the cost, both in terms of finances and human resources. And remember: only a governing body that represents the school and the community at large can set targets that the school and community at large can respect.

 Fred Browning is senior governor development officer for Essex local education authority.

If you feel you are being "pushed" in this direction, ask the authority to say how, exactly, they would improve upon your targets, and perhaps more important, where the money will be coming from. Target-setting should be about providing strategic goals by weighing up the ideals of progress and improvement against the cost, both in terms of finances and human resources. And remember: only a governing body that represents the school and the community at large can set targets that the school and community at large can respect.  Fred Browning is senior governor development officer for Essex local education authority.

webTitle: Be a real scientist for a day

fields.headline: Be a real scientist for a day
fields.trailText: There is a stuffed fox, there are boxes of minerals, there are fossils, hand lenses, video microscopes, work stations... all you need to do some science
fields.body:
There is a stuffed fox in one case, a puma mounted in another - and the skeleton of a tortoise in its shell in a third. There are boxes of minerals, each with distinctive crystalline shapes and telltale colours. There are fossils, there are hand lenses, there are video microscopes, there are work stations. Outside, there is a tiny garden with a pond, and a stand for a wormery, or a woodlice collection, or somewhere to study newts in leaf litter. Around the gallery, the wall is lined with serious questions, light-heartedly bounced off the nation's favourite clichés.

How cold is a stone? How much does a feather weigh? How blind is a bat? How clear is a crystal? For anyone getting a bit long in the tooth - yes, that's a question as well - it doesn't look like education, it looks like fun. For Roy Walkey, head of education at the Natural History Museum, that's the point of his gleaming new basement resource centre. It is there to help children understand not what science is, but how they could do science.

The Clore Education Centre opens next week (April 12) with a display called Investigate. The display and the centre were made possibly by a £1m donation from the Vivien Duffield Foundation, not that its future customers will care about that. Walkey reckons it could be a workplace for up to 70 children at a time, and they will get a chance to do what the museum's 350 scientists do: they will touch specimens, weigh them, bounce light off them, turn them upside down and measure their vital statistics, and then they will try to solve some problems: what is it, where did it live, why is it that colour?

Schools and teachers can book, and Investigate has key stages 2 and 3 of the national curriculum in mind, but the centre is aimed at children of 7-14 and their families: it's there to provoke. Young minds can use a micrometer to measure a hair's breadth, or a balance to check a featherweight, handle ammonites to work out how they grow, why they are different, which bits have been fossilised.

They might never get around to finding out what an ammonite is called (although that information is there, too) because what it is called is not the point.

"The name of a natural object is not a property of the object and can never be deduced," Walkey says. "The great scientist Richard Feynman was fond of saying you can know the name of a bird in all the languages of the world, but it doesn't tell you anything about the bird, only about people and the kinds of things they know."

fields.headline: Stamp of approval
fields.standfirst: An old hobby is enjoying something of a revival thanks to pupils at Neyland County Primary School
fields.trailText: An old hobby is enjoying something of a revival thanks to pupils at Neyland County Primary School
fields.body:
"The only place that I would expect there to be stamps is in a museum, if I went forward 1,000 years," says Emily Rastall, a pupil at Spittal Junior School in Haverfordwest, in response to the question "Will stamps exist in the future?"

But perhaps the future is not so bleak for the humble stamp. Pupils at several schools across Pembrokeshire continue to collect and swap stamps thanks to the work of Erene Grieve, school liaison officer for the National Youth Stamp Group. Grieve believed that stamp collecting could still appeal to young people if it was presented in the right way. Since 1997, she has been using the resources of her local philatelic society to go into schools and encourage teachers and pupils to keep the pastime alive.

One such school is Neyland County Primary. Their stamp club regularly attracts 15-20 pupils to their Friday lunchtime meetings. Activities include displays, quizzes, demonstrations, competitions and, of course, stamps for sale and swap. There is plenty of scope for learning, too.

Jenny Seaton runs the club and says that many of the activities organised for the club are curriculum related. "The children have built up skills that are transferable to their classwork, particularly geography," she says.

Stamp collecting needn't be expensive. The British Philatelic Trust will supply items to give to young stamp collectors, the National Youth Stamp Group can provide services to help adults support young philatelists, and Stamp Active provides information on how to run a stamp club.

And for those who might doubt that stamp collecting could thrive in a more urban setting, Erene Grieve is keen to point out that this is not the case. Grieve spent two days in schools in Islington, north London, where the response from youngsters was as enthusiastic as it had been in Haverfordwest. All of which suggests that it's only a matter of time until more children agree with the sentiments of another pupil at Spittal Junior: "I think in about 2020 stamps will still be the same because they are interesting and fun to collect."

 The British Philatelic Trust, Stamp Active and the National Youth Stamp Group can all be contacted at the British Philatelic Centre, 107 Charterhouse Street, London, EC1M 6PT (tel: 020-7490 3112).

fields.headline: High hopes
fields.standfirst: Abbeydale Grange gives the chief inspector food for thought
fields.trailText: Abbeydale Grange gives the chief inspector food for thought
fields.body:
The chief inspector of schools went straight to the point as usual - but with one small, telling deviation as he paused in a corridor to sum up his impressions of Abbeydale Grange. Even the absolutely unsentimental Chris Woodhead was struck by the warmth of everyday routine at the Sheffield comprehensive - the world of Bleeper Man and children facing crushing poverty that riveted Guardian readers when Nick Davies described it last year.

Then - while the Grange's head, Jan Woodhead (no relation), was still savouring the word "warmth" which is central to the school's ethos - the VIP visitor was back on more familiar rails. In a clearly thought out and well managed structure, he said, he had spent the morning watching some very good teaching at work.

"That's what makes the difference," he said, giving the phrase "very good teaching" the same deliberate emphasis he had given "warmth". "It is a testament to dedication and hard work."

In under two hours, the head of Ofsted had absorbed - like his 12 colleagues who inspected the school in the week Nick Davies' articles were published last September - what many people in the neat but nervous suburbs round the comprehensive still fail to see.

Within minutes of his arrival, he was taking tea in the library with three pupils whose maths, and in one case French, GCSEs were under their belts either one or two years early. The only faux pas was a moment of teenage nerves that sent a couple of biscuits wobbling to the floor.

What did the children say about the school? asked the chief inspector. They liked it, they replied politely. They got a quick response when they raised anything with teachers. They would like more computers, books and everything else.

These were this year's successors to Hannah Gibson, who left last summer with 12 GCSEs, nine of them As or A*, and they had, of course, been hand-picked to meet Woodhead. That was not the case throughout the tour.

Studying modern and 19th-century leg amputations with schoolboy relish in a history class, a 14-year-old explained why a tranny was blaring out rock music as he and his friends explored the 1830s. "We've been quiet in the first half, so Miss's allowed us music for the second half."

Back in the corridor Jan Woodhead made another of many points drawn from her knowledge of the pupils' backgrounds. "We have children here who can't work in silence, because silence is something they hardly know." Later on the tour she refers to a girl whose home background makes her want to cry, and to a boy whose long spells in a quiet room, out of lessons, are understandable because "for him, school is the only sane part of his day."

Abbeydale Grange's lop-sided share of difficult children, far below their proper reading age or excluded from other Sheffield schools, has panicked most of the owners of neighbouring mock-Tudor semis into choosing more distant comprehensives - a version of what Davies called "selection by estate agents" - and a vicious circle. But Chris Woodhead learned that it also plays a part in the school's current revival. For parents like Sue Proctor, Cheryl Malcolmson and Debbie Gaunt, the mixture is a reason for trusting Abbeydale Grange with their children.

"I live next door to a Sheffield University lecturer," says Gaunt, a theology PhD student herself and chair of Abbeydale's governors, "and he's distressed at the number of students who drop out in the first year because the real world comes as such a shock. They were cocooned at school, growing up only with children like themselves. None of us wanted that."

The group of typical middle-class parents finds a wealth of useful experience in the school's rainbow racial mix, which is a strong though usually unspoken reason for the boycott by neighbours who haven't experienced it. They also don't pretend to be saints. They saw through the simplicity of the league tables, which have Abbeydale Grange bumping along in the low 20% of A-Cs at GCSE, and spotted the wealth of individual attention available.

Add to that, they explain to the chief inspector, the fact that Abbeydale Grange is honest; not a place that pretends for marketing purposes that everything is lovely. Jan Woodhead says: "We know the danger of celebrating mediocrity. We encourage and we write lots of positive letters to parents, but the point is to show students what is possible - to have high expectations of them and to give them a sense of aspiration."

A few grade Cs for a pupil may be hailed, rightly, as an Everest, but that's by no means it. On an individual basis, the students are shown that the rest of the world sees their summit as a foothill, honourably conquered but with more to come. Plenty decide to stop and Woodhead makes no bones about excluding pupils "when there's really no more we can do." But no one is deceived.

Chris Woodhead was manifestly pleased to be in a school run by a team that believes in what it is doing. After reading his inspectors' report, he first wrote to Abbeydale, then phoned, then called by for half-an-hour while in Sheffield on other business, before making his full-scale visit last week.

After endorsing both teaching and management, especially the calm, Bleeper Man approach to frequent indiscipline (the bleeper triggers instant staff intervention), he flagged up his own appeal to local parents to trust an exceptional team with their children. But how could you persuade them? He wryly repeated the question - the dilemma of so many comprehensives and middle-class homes - and came up with: "The proof of the pudding is in the eating."

Then he was off; with a raft of blunt Abbeydaleisms in his ears about "pathetic" computer provision and underfunding, but leaving behind that other true cliché, that nothing succeeds like success. Admissions are up again this year, there are all sorts of funding bids and Jan Woodhead finally expects a full, 150-strong intake in the autumn.

"I hope," she says, "that Chris has gone away feeling he's seen something at work here which could stimulate national debate about what sort of education system we can have if we really want it. How you can provide a first-class education for young people in very difficult circumstances, and how we can find the resources to make that happen."
