fields.headline: Mission: possible
fields.trailText: Has your class got what it takes to launch a probe to Mars? How would you and your classmates cope with a crisis that's out of this world? If you have always dreamt of becoming the next Neil Armstrong or Michael Foale, and want to discover more about life in space, enter our competition to win a realistic simulation of a space mission at the National Space Science Centre's Challenger Learning Centre.

If you have always dreamt of becoming the next Neil Armstrong or Michael Foale, and want to discover more about life in space, enter our competition to win a realistic simulation of a space mission at the National Space Science Centre's Challenger Learning Centre.

fields.headline: Finding the plot
fields.standfirst: Simon Midgley asks why academics like Richard Wiltshire are digging again
fields.trailText: Simon Midgley asks why academics like Richard Wiltshire are digging again
fields.body:
Just how do academics escape the pressures of contemporary university life? Well, a growing legion of new-age scholars are turning the clock back - and the sods over - down on their local allotments.

Take Dr Richard Wiltshire, a geography lecturer at London University's School of Oriental and African Studies. As a junior lecturer, he began working an allotment as a cheap way of producing food. Now he has two organic plots near his home in Dartford, where he grows yellow and red raspberries, asparagus, broccoli, brassica, carrots and grapes. Confucius, he observes, said: "Garden while the sun shines. Read while it does not."

A second reason for taking up the allotment was that he wanted links with his local community. Church was out, so an allotment was the next best thing.

Academic and allotment communities, he adds, have much in common. Neither gardeners nor academics do it for the money. Both plough their own furrows, academics being responsible for their own little plot within the broad body of knowledge. They share tolerance, diversity of expression and tend to be self-exploitative, working the hours required by the task. "Cultivation is very healthy for people who use their brains all the time and are trying to establish new knowledge," says Wiltshire. "To do something mechanical, repetitive, with birds singing in the background and bees buzzing past and the sun shining, is very relaxing."

Another benefit is that it "enables you to relate to people from all walks of life. It's a grounding in the broader reality. Part of having an allotment is to get a sense of perspective and to keep calm." Wiltshire has set up his own website, The Virtual Potting Shed, where allotment societies post news.

Dr Chris Pinney, a University College London anthropologist who lectures in material culture, has a local authority allotment where his partner grows leeks, potatoes, garlic, lettuces, broccoli, radicchio, raspberries and strawberries.

He is attracted by the charm of the vernacular. "It's the tumbledown bricolage that is utterly seductive. Bricolage is this sense of constructing from things that are ready to hand, used by Lévi-Strauss in The Savage Mind to describe a particular mode of thinking. One sees runner beans twining up old cast-iron bedsteads... little coldframes made of old windows propped up on bricks and stones."

While many people working on allotments do it out of necessity and love of the soil, Pinney thinks academics feel the joy of viewing an allotment's surreal conjunctions.

"There is also pleasure to be had from feeling the fine tilth of soil running through one's fingers. I periodically work in a village in central India, and I have taken photographs of my allotment to try to impress peasants. They are always singularly unimpressed by these pathetic rows of wilting onions.

"It's the organicity of it, I suppose - the earthy wholesomeness - contrasted with the near sterility of professional activity. It's the desire to escape the alienation of wage labour to temporarily inhabit this idyllic world where you control the lifecycle. It's wonderfully satisfying."

Simon Baddeley, an associate of Birmingham University's Institute of Local Government Studies, is fighting to save the city's Victoria Jubilee Allotments from housing development. He quotes the American psychologist Abraham Harold Maslow's hierarchy of human needs in relation to the importance of allotments in providing food to fulfil basic needs, and meeting a spiritual need through being in touch with where food comes from.

Alexander Kasterine, 34, is doing a PhD in environmental economics at London University's Wye College. On his allotment in Wye, Kent, he grows tomatoes, sweet corn, beans, potatoes and coriander.

"Allotments suffer from an image problem in that frequently you are digging away and someone shouts out, "Are you digging for victory?" and they expect you to be growing leeks and wearing a cloth cap. But it has moved on to being a focus for community development. It empowers the individual gardener and gives him a civic sense of belonging."

Dr Marcus Banks, an Oxford University reader in social and cultural anthropology, misses his old allotment. His college, Wolfson College, has its own allotments that can be taken up by staff or students. He grew Lollo rosso lettuces, salsify (a long black root vegetable with an asparagus flavour) and fir apples (like a knobbly pink potato).

"The satisfaction was being able to give friends home-produced vegetables or fruits that had come straight from the allotment that morning. I did not try to grow all the plants in Milton or Shakespeare or any of those other poncy academic ideas. I wanted good fresh food that I could not buy in the shops."

Dr Rachael Dwyer, a lecturer in Gujarati and Indian Studies at SOAS, shares an allotment in Brent with her husband Michael. "If you are a university teacher, your job is explaining or arguing with other people that you are right. In an allotment the truth is in the vegetables, and uneducated people can often do it much better than you. It keeps your feet on the ground."

Some even abandon academic life to work their allotments. Fiona Sanderson, 36, gave up her PhD to work her two allotments in Bristol. She even has a weekly allotmenting column in the Bristol Evening Post. "It is very much to do with self-sufficiency, living healthily and having a sustainable lifestyle. You feel more in touch with the planet."

Alexander Kasterine, 34, is doing a PhD in environmental economics at London University's Wye College. On his allotment in Wye, Kent, he grows tomatoes, sweet corn, beans, potatoes and coriander. "Allotments suffer from an image problem in that frequently you are digging away and someone shouts out, "Are you digging for victory?" and they expect you to be growing leeks and wearing a cloth cap. But it has moved on to being a focus for community development. It empowers the individual gardener and gives him a civic sense of belonging." Dr Marcus Banks, an Oxford University reader in social and cultural anthropology, misses his old allotment. His college, Wolfson College, has its own allotments that can be taken up by staff or students. He grew Lollo rosso lettuces, salsify (a long black root vegetable with an asparagus flavour) and fir apples (like a knobbly pink potato). "The satisfaction was being able to give friends home-produced vegetables or fruits that had come straight from the allotment that morning. I did not try to grow all the plants in Milton or Shakespeare or any of those other poncy academic ideas. I wanted good fresh food that I could not buy in the shops." Dr Rachael Dwyer, a lecturer in Gujarati and Indian Studies at SOAS, shares an allotment in Brent with her husband Michael. "If you are a university teacher, your job is explaining or arguing with other people that you are right. In an allotment the truth is in the vegetables, and uneducated people can often do it much better than you. It keeps your feet on the ground." Some even abandon academic life to work their allotments. Fiona Sanderson, 36, gave up her PhD to work her two allotments in Bristol. She even has a weekly allotmenting column in the Bristol Evening Post. "It is very much to do with self-sufficiency, living healthily and having a sustainable lifestyle. You feel more in touch with the planet."

fields.headline: A taste of real life
fields.standfirst: A project in Merseyside steers children away from exclusion
fields.trailText: A project in Merseyside steers children away from exclusion
fields.body:
For over a hundred Merseyside teenagers, their last year of schooling involves work-based training, taster courses at the local further education college, personal development courses - and one or two days a week at school. The preparation for work and training courses are offered to pupils at risk of exclusion in their final year. Some will be long-term absentees, others have behaviour problems and all are part of the rising tide of disaffection that has overtaken inner-city schools since the introduction of the national curriculum.

"They're a mixed bunch," says Dave Morgan, whose Knowsley Compact runs the course, "who don't like schools and don't like teachers."

Knowsley is one of the most deprived boroughs in the UK. If the experience of other inner-city areas is anything to go by, Knowsley exclusion rates ought to be sky-high.

"We haven't had a permanent exclusion for two years," says Brendan McLoughlin, headteacher at All Saints Roman Catholic School. And that goes for the other 11 comprehensives in the borough.

"Permanent exclusions are now down to zero," says the director of education, Peter Wylie. He believes the answer lies in early intervention. In Knowsley, that can take the form of educational support units, where pupils at risk of exclusion can be supported until they are ready to return to mainstream schooling, or a radically alternative diet of work, training and support.

Students on the programme are "disapplied" from the national curriculum, which involves dropping two of their eight subjects. Over 600 schools nationwide have applied to the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority to disapply some pupils. Last year, nearly 9,000 pupils followed such a slimmed-down curriculum.

Schools promise to squeeze the remaining six subjects into the one or two days that children are present. But the QCA doesn't police this and, for many, the reality is that normal schooling ends as soon as they are put onto the programme.

"These kids have the potential to take up a lot of the school's time," says Gerry Bedford at Knowsley High. "But that doesn't mean we should just abandon them." Bedford argues that it's about priorities, earmarking some money to keep the youngsters in touch with their education.

Eighteen-year-old Charlene is one of the project's successes, having gone on to college to do qualifications in hairdressing and beauty therapy. "I have strong ideas of what I want to do," she says. "Some of school was all right. I wanted qualifications, but they didn't have them in what I was interested in."

A local employer who offers work experience to young people from the project is positive about the scheme. "I'm the son of a docker and proud of it," says Eric Mahoney. "These kids are in the same position I was in when I left school at 15 with no qualifications. This project is really giving these lads a taste of life - what it's like to get up early and be dirty for a reason."

Dave Morgan claims a 70% success rate for the project, a claim backed by an evaluation which found that students on the project had "gained in self-confidence and improved in their attitude. They had developed work-related skills and been able to see a future outside school."

Research into children excluded from school has shown remarkable successes once they escape from academic pressures. The National Foundation for Educational Research in York has published several studies in this area and its principal researcher, Kay Kinder, says: "Having talked to a lot of practitioners, there's a strong view that the national curriculum is a disenfranchisement - it's academically orientated and underplays the fact that some children have a different orientation."

Professor John Andrews, the outgoing chief executive of the Further and Higher Education Funding Councils in Wales, agrees - arguing that anything up to 20% of pupils are failed by the current system.

Andrews argues that the curriculum has generated much of the disaffection in older schoolchildren, rather than any tidal wave of delinquency washing in through the school gates.

"With all their failings, the old secondary moderns had to provide a curriculum for those unable to cope with an academic diet." He emphasises his support both for the comprehensive ideal and for a national curriculum. "But you don't make a system comprehensive by putting everyone through the same process."

The existing disapplication process releases children from two subjects, which is not enough for an alternative curriculum to be viable, argues David Lang at Knowsley's Halewood School. "I urge the secretary of state," he says, "to extend disapplication in order to enable us to match students to more appropriate courses."

Criticism of the national curriculum generates a knee-jerk reaction from ministers who are unlikely to grant his request. Instead, there are initiatives to reduce exclusion and "support the pupil within the school". Funding is theoretically available, but Knowsley's project was financed with European money, which has now run out. Its future is by no means certain.

Sixteen-year-old Brian now works with a local builder instead of going to lessons in French and science. "I'm with the brickie," he says. "He's OK, makes you work though. I was always messing around at school. I didn't like it, hated the work. I'm learning more than I was in school. I've got a brickie's bum."

 The Knowsley Compact is a charity set up to promote education business partnerships in the area. It is looking for sponsors to help fund its community work. Contact Dave Morgan on 0151-477 0077.

 NFER research on provision for excluded pupils: Working Out Well. Contact NFER: 01753-747 199.

fields.headline: Mags behaving badly
fields.standfirst: Are rag mags infantile and deeply offensive, or just a bit of fun?
fields.trailText: Are rag mags infantile and deeply offensive, or just a bit of fun?
fields.body:
A call for academics to make a stand against offensive and sexist jokes written as part of the charity collecting antics of London medical students has sparked a row over the publication of rag-week magazines during the traditional fundraising activities of university students each year. The National Union of Students, which estimates that rag weeks raise as much as £5m a year for charity, has also condemned offensive and discriminatory material, and called on students not to publish it.

Angered by the material produced in the rag week magazine by students at the St Bartholomew and London School of Medicine and Dentistry, one of the school's lecturers last week used an email list to call on the university medical community to put a stop to the publications, which are sold by students to raise money for charities.

"It is filled with infantile, crude and deeply offensive humour, mostly of a sexist and anti-female variety and, in actual fact, degrading and disrespectful to all in the [academic] community," said Carolyn Roth, lecturer in midwifery at City University's St Bartholomew School of Nursing and Midwifery.

"It is surely time for institutions of medical education to take a principled stand against expressions of this kind in the 'tradition' of rag week.

"It is unacceptable behaviour and should no longer be condoned or tolerated within the university community."

Owain James, NUS National Secretary, said: "Rag provides the chance for a bit of fun while raising money for charity and good causes. But rag week is not an excuse for producing offensive material. NUS and its liberation campaigns work tirelessly all year round to fight discrimination and, as community outreach projects, rag projects should be leading this work, not undermining it."

But student leaders at St Barts, who have this year raised over £130,000 of charity funds during rag week alone, argue that the magazine is intended as light-hearted humour and includes explicit warnings of the adult nature of some jokes. It is also vetted by university wardens before being published.

Student union president at St Barts Ben Griffiths said that most of the magazine is made up of in-house jokes concerning nurses, physios, doctors and dentists, often focusing on competition between medical and dental schools, and rivalries between dentists and medics.

But there are also other jokes, which tend to be particularly adult in nature - intended for the general public buying them on the London underground. "It is a light-hearted way of looking at things," he said.

"It's intended to amuse a lot of different kinds of people and, because of that, certain groups may get offended in some ways. But the majority of the stuff is based on traditional things featured in rag mags for years." He also pointed out that the majority of this year's rag committee were female students.

The magazine was passed by a joint student and college editorial board, which removed any particularly sensitive topics. "If we applied true censorship there would be little of the magazine left," argued Dr Brian Colvin, assistant warden at the school.

"The warden's team remains committed to trying to find a balance between our desire to allow students self-expression and to maintain proper standards." The magazine, he stressed, is not endorsed by the medical school.

 Dr Lee Elliot Major is deputy editor of Research Fortnight.

fields.headline: Recovery for thousands
fields.standfirst: Rebecca Smithers on a reading scheme celebrating its 10th birthday
fields.trailText: Rebecca Smithers on a reading scheme celebrating its 10th birthday
fields.body:
Education experts gathered at a special conference in London at the weekend to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Reading Recovery programme, which is still very much alive and kicking in Britain's primary schools.

Schools using it say the intensive one-to-one programme for youngsters with serious reading and writing problems yields spectacular results. Yet thousands of children who would benefit from it are not being given the opportunity since government funding was switched to local education authorities in 1995.

The scheme has also suffered from appearing to be expensive - the initial costs amount to approximately £1,000 per pupil, which does not include the cost of training teachers. Yet headteachers who have used it believe it provides excellent value for money, as an early investment that pays off. It is also helping to raise standards generally, and is being imaginatively woven into the government's broader literacy strategy.

Reading Recovery selects pupils who are identified in the first year at primary school as having made the least progress in learning to read and write. They are then given a 20-week course of intensive daily individual lessons by specially trained teachers, which are tailored to their individual needs and existing knowledge. Once the programme is finished and the child is "successfully discontinued" according to the jargon - his or her progress within mainstream classroom teaching is closely monitored and further help given where needed.

New research shows a near 60% success rate in the national curriculum Sats tests taken by participants at the age of seven. Data collected on 1,400 children who have taken part shows that 57% achieved the national standard - level two or above - in reading and 58% in writing in 1999.

Julia Douetil, of the Reading Recovery National Network, based at London University's Institute of Education, explained how the scheme can help. "These children are failing, not just struggling. After a year of schooling, some still can't write their names, some can't tell the difference between a letter and a word, and some haven't realised that you read the black marks and not the white spaces," she explained. "At the end of that time, most have caught up with what the rest of the class has learnt over 18 to 24 months. They gain confidence, are able to keep up with the class and overcome the disadvantages of gender, poverty and second language learning."

Reading Recovery was founded by Dame Marie Clay, who brought it to this country from New Zealand, and has so far been used by more than 20,000 children over here. The number of participating schools has been static over the last couple of years, the scheme claims, largely because of the competing demands of school budgets and a swathe of new government initiatives. According to the latest figures, compiled last year, the programme is being offered by around 806 teachers in roughly the same number of schools, working in 55 local education authority areas in England, Northern Ireland, Scotland, Wales and Jersey. Last year 5,136 children took part in the scheme.

In many cases parents are encouraged to get involved and are invited to attend the teaching sessions. But in some cases, it may be the parents who helped to cause the problem in the first place.

Christine Sanders, who teaches Reading Recovery at Grassmere primary school in Hackney, east London, said that in her experience pupils went into the scheme with a positive attitude, which meant there was no question of them feeling stigmatised by being taken out of the classroom. "Quite the opposite," she says. "These are kids who know they can't read and write and who want to do something about it. They welcome the opportunity to be taken away from all the distractions of the classroom and given the help they need".

The school's headteacher, Penny Greenhaulgh, declared the scheme "brilliant". "We want to increase our resources in it," she said. "The results speak for themselves".

 Further information from the Reading Recovery Network, tel: 0207-612 6585. e-mail: readrec@ioe.ac.uk. Or details on the Institute of Education's website.

fields.headline: Grid lock
fields.standfirst: UK scientists are desperate to buy into research on a futuristic "grid" of knowledge
fields.trailText: UK scientists are desperate to buy into research on a futuristic "grid" of knowledge
fields.body:
Last week, an unprecedented scientific meeting took place at the Royal Society between particle physicists, biologists, environmental climatologists and computer scientists. The subject of the discussion: a computing "grid" that some predict will be the next generation of technology on the world wide web.

One day, they believe, the grid will offer scientists computing power 100 times the capacity of today's supercomputers. It will help decode the explosion of data emerging on a range of scientific fronts.

The grid will provide a common solution to the computing needs of different scientific problems: from the atom-smashing experiments at Cern, to the output of sequencing data from the human genome project, to the modelling of the world's weather systems. This is the vision, at least, at the heart of one of the bids for science funding in the Whitehall spending review. According to some government sources, the Office of Science and Technology has requested £100m over the next three years to support a concerted programme to help develop the grid, and improve the productivity of the country's science effort.

But many believe there is more at stake than improving the research tools of the scientific community. If the UK fails to participate in the international scientific information race, it may be excluded from future scientific developments altogether.

And despite the government's efforts to promote the UK as a hotbed for e-commerce and knowledge-driven companies, there are signs that UK industrialists will once more miss out on the technological innovations which will underpin the successful businesses of the future.

The key to the computing grid is software, or "middleware", which allows the computer user to extract information from a network of distributed computing resources. The concept of the grid is that you set a PC an intelligent task - an astronomer may request data on a galaxy, and current research - and the grid enables software tools to interrogate any relevant database.

"You don't know where the data is, you don't even necessarily need to worry about the CPU [central processing unit]. The grid will pull data from a variety of databases and formats, some of it live from satellites or telescopes, other bits from archives," says Jim Sadlier, who is coordinating the grid initiative for the Particle Physics and Astronomy Research Council. The director general of research councils, John Taylor, science minister David Sainsbury and e-commerce minister Patricia Hewitt have shown growing interest in this vision of "e-science".

But the problem for the UK science community is that it is several steps behind the US in the scientific information race. Up to now, the grid has been developed almost exclusively by US researchers. And since their atom-accelerator programme was cancelled, US particle physicists have been clear about how they intend to exploit their computing prowess: creaming off all the best physics from the experiments.

"If the UK does not buy into its part of the particle physics computational grid now, we will not even be in the game - and the only thing that we in the UK could do in the future is send our scientists abroad," says Paul Jeffreys, from the Council for the Central Laboratory of the Research Councils.

But it is not just leading edge science at stake. If the grid follows the precedent set by the world wide web, academics and businesses closest to the new technology now are those most likely to translate it into future commercial applications.

The success of the e-science bid is likely to rest on whether Treasury officials are convinced it can secure a brighter future for UK plc.

fields.headline: Cross currents
fields.standfirst: David Cohen on a three-month digital colloquium that made US and UK students rethink the slave trade
fields.trailText: David Cohen on a three-month digital colloquium that made US and UK students rethink the slave trade
fields.body:
Articles published in the Guardian over the years have created their share of ripples, from loquacious debate in the correspondence columns to ministerial resignations. One Guardian report, however, has been part of the basis for a remarkable internet exchange between students from both sides of the Atlantic. The article, published in February 1998, highlighted the legacy of the 18th-century merchant venturer Edward Colston, a benefactor who endowed many educational institutions, almshouses and hospitals in Bristol, and whose legend occupies a place of honour in that city.

The history of the sugar merchant and other traders of his time has come under scrutiny amid efforts to acknowledge how much of Bristol's wealth was built on the slave trade. How much culpability Bristol, and indeed all Britain, shared with the US was one of the key Anglo-American issues thrashed out by students at two institutions in a three-month-long transatlantic conference. Articles from the Guardian and The Washington Post were used to start the ball rolling, along with hyperlinks to numerous sites devoted to the study of slavery.

The colloquium was the brainchild of Peter Bardaglio and Richard Bradbury, who brought together a group of history students from Goucher College, a liberal arts institution in Baltimore, and a group of undergraduates doing African-American culture and politics at the University of Exeter.

Sixteen students took part in the 1998 conference, and a similar course will be held later this year or early in 2001. "I like to think of it as an example of technology with a human face - a very human face, really, given the subject," says Bardaglio, a history professor at Goucher who was at Exeter in 1997 on an exchange. It was there he met and worked alongside Bradbury, a lecturer in English and American studies at Exeter since 1990.

Both men developed the idea for the conference which, Bradbury says, "turned out to be an incredibly instructive one for both of us, as well as everyone else involved. It raised so many interesting questions, not only about slavery but about new technology and methods of teaching as well."

Ultimately, he points out, "all we really did was create a situation whereby students in America and Britain could simply communicate with each other - openly, honestly, intellectually. Our role, as we saw it, was simply to feed them."

And to shake them up a little bit too. While the theme of slavery was one all of the participants settled on happily enough, the perspectives of the two groups of students were often at odds. Yes, it was agreed, there had certainly been a mutual involvement of the Americans and British in the slave trade and slavery generally. But the American students were quick to argue that slavery was introduced by the British while the North American colonies were still part of the old empire, and that the British introduced slavery into their Caribbean colonies too.

On the other hand, the Exeter students pointed out that England abolished slavery in the empire in 1833 and without a civil war. "But more than anything," says Bardaglio, "as the debate unfolded, both the Goucher students and the Exeter students came to realise the complexity of the past and the ways in which people on both sides of the Atlantic blinded themselves to the wrongs that they were doing in the name of commerce and profit."

Bardaglio is no stranger to this kind of teaching. An earlier course he taught in America on the cold-war era required its students to add to their usual classroom activities by using the internet as a discussion medium. Students conducted web-board discussions and developed PowerPoint presentations of themes and personalities from an earlier generation - such as Billie Holiday and Bob Dylan.

But it wasn't until Bardaglio arrived in Britain that the two academics appreciated the potential in opening up one of their favourite scholarly subjects - slavery - to debate between young students from the two countries where, both educators believe, the topic has the greatest resonance.

"Slavery was never just about the American south," says Bardaglio, who has written widely on the subject - his latest book, Daily Life in the South During Reconstruction, is scheduled for publication next year: "The story of slavery belongs just as fully to the north, and ultimately, it's a British story too."

Bradbury laments British "mythologies" about American slavery, not only in its ignorance of the country's role in sustaining the American trade, "but in terms of the country's activities closer to home. There is this idea that only 13 port towns were involved, and pretty well everyone and everywhere else was exonerated. That's just historical nonsense."

Participants were encouraged to look at the ramifications of past injustices on contemporary culture. One question was why black Americans, having improved their representation in most fields, should have seen little statistical improvement in their collective lot since the early civil rights movement. It's a question for which not even Bardaglio or Bradbury have a ready-made answer.

"I don't know the full answer to why blacks in America continue to be as badly off as they were 40 years ago," says Bradbury. "But I do know it's worth talking about."

fields.headline: Still a write mess
fields.standfirst: Key skills were supposed to be the answer to employers' moans that school-leavers lacked basic capabilities, but signs are the new scheme will please no one
fields.trailText: Key skills were supposed to be the answer to employers' moans that school-leavers lacked basic capabilities, but signs are the new scheme will please no one
fields.body:
Even by Ofsted's usual standards, its joint report with the Further Education Funding Council (FEFC) and the Training Standards Council (TSC) on the pilot study of the key skills qualifications for 16- to 19-year-olds makes dismal reading.

It found a lack of agreement both in higher education and among employers about the purpose and benefits of the qualification, and serious problems in its implementation and teaching in the majority of GCE A-level and National Vocational Qualification centres, with only a small number of students completing units in any of the three skills.

Key skills were Sir Ron Dearing's big idea - his answer to the ever louder moans from employers that school-leavers were entering the workplace with few of the basic skills they needed to do the job. In 1996 Dearing proposed the introduction of six key skills - IT, communication, application of number, problem solving, team building and improving one's own learning and performance - with the first three being formally assessed - and a 3-year pilot scheme across 47 schools, 23 further education colleges and 13 training providers was duly set in motion the following year. With the results we have seen.

Ready or not, though, the key skills qualifications will go live nationally this September, though it will not become a statutory requirement until 2002. Which has prompted many educationalists to conclude that it will be widely ignored for the next two years.

"Schools that are confident about what they are doing, and have good A-level results will almost certainly ignore them," said one member of an examining body. "Those that are looking to pick up a few extra UCAS credits for marginal students may bother. The only institutions that will definitely offer key skills qualifications are the further education colleges because they are getting extra funding to do so. How popular the courses will be is another matter."

David Sherlock, chief executive and chief examiner of the Training Standards Council, sees the problems from a slightly different angle. "There has been a confusion between key skills and basic skills," he says. "What employers wanted was a work force that had a certain threshold level of ability in reading, writing and IT. In other words, the skills you might normally expect from those leaving school. So the answers properly belong there, rather than in post-16 education.

"The government has recognised this with the introduction of the literacy and numeracy hours, but it will take time for the effects to filter through, so in the meantime we have the ongoing problem of under-skilled current school leavers, to which the key skills qualification is the palliative solution. But the present system, with its four different levels of assessment for each skill, is not what employers want."

This last point is well illustrated by the fact that a number of employers dropped out of the pilot scheme in frustration at what they saw as the loss of many of the plus points of Modern Apprenticeships.

Instead of learning on the job, students were now sent off to colleges to study for their key skills, thereby undermining many of the benefits of integrating theory and practice. Moreover, the employers saw no reason for this enforced separation as they had been doing very nicely up till now, thank you, educating their work force to the standards required - up to and including degree level - for the particular job.

There is even some evidence to suggest that over and above the basic entry-level skills, it is the so-called softer, unassessed key skills of team building and problem-solving that industry values most, but Sherlock takes a pragmatic view of the current situation. "Something has to be done," he says ruefully. "The trouble is almost everything you do will be wrong in one way or another."

Other criticisms of the pilot scheme have focused on the emphasis placed on assessment by portfolio and exam. NVQs were specifically de signed for those who didn't perform well under exam conditions, and there are fears that even a partial reversion to the old system will alienate those for whom it was intended. The Qualifications and Curriculum Authority is at pains to call the timed assessment a "test" rather than an "exam" in a bid to appease its critics.

"It's not nearly as forbidding as an exam," says a spokesman. "After all we're testing the level of skill rather than the amount they know." Whether this explanation will satisfy students' in-built early-warning exam radar is not so clear.

Schools and colleges are far from clear themselves how best key skills should be taught. Indeed the pilot revealed that many teachers weren't even exactly clear what key skills were, let alone how to teach them, and that many institutions had hopelessly underestimated the resources to train their staff and implement their programmes.

The QCA has now fixed a syllabus for each level of assessment, but it hopes that much of the actual teaching will come from careful signposting of other parts of the current curriculum. This may work for A level and Advanced GNVQ; how it might work for Modern Apprenticeships where the teaching will have to take place in designated classroom time outside the workplace is, again, another matter.

The Further Education Funding Council takes a more upbeat view of the situation. "We have just spent £7m improving our delivery of the key skills programme," said a funding council spokesperson, without indicating precisely where and how the money had been spent.

The Qualifications and Curriculum Authority was similarly bullish about the prospects for the scheme. "The report on the pilot only dealt with the period to July '99," said a spokesman. "We've addressed most of the problems that were identified and everything is in place for this September."

Few people share this optimism. The best that most dare hope is that the scheme is not a total disaster - ignored by schools and poorly and haphazardly implemented by colleges - and changes are already widely predicted. Watch this space. This one will run and run.

fields.headline: Call the wedding off!
fields.standfirst: MP says merger couple are only doing it for the money
fields.trailText: MP says merger couple are only doing it for the money
fields.body:
Tory leader William Hague's former right hand man is accusing the Further Education Funding Council of forcing through a misguided merger between his local college and a bigger institution.

Alan Duncan launched a stinging attack in parliament on the proposed fusion of Rutland sixth-form college, which is in his constituency, and Tresham College in Northamptonshire, a bigger general further education institution 23 miles away. The deal was going ahead against massive popular opposition, he claimed.

Using Commons privilege, Hague's former parliamentary political secre tary named and berated the funding council's east-midlands official, Christine Frost, saying: "...her apparently unbending agenda amounts to questionable conduct."

The funding council completely rejected Duncan's accusations.

His attack was launched as the funding council published a report urging college heads and governors to think more about mergers.

According to the report, David Blunkett wants the funding council to be "proactive in encouraging mergers". And it admits that the council may make merger a condition of continuing funding for colleges in serious financial straits.

Rutland college was going ahead with its plan to merge with Tresham, simply to avoid a predicted £100,000 deficit next year, Duncan told the Commons.

There was no link between the two institutions and "no educational rationale for the merger". Last year only three students from Rutland went to Tresham college and there was "no natural link" between Rutland and Northants.

"The merger is ill-conceived, ill-timed and ill-considered," he said.

The "compelling" merger for the stricken sixth-form college, which has 400 full-time students, would be with Stamford College, 12 miles away in Lincolnshire, Duncan said. Two hundred full-time students already travel from Rutland to Stamford, and the two towns will come under the same local Learning and Skills Council.

"I am profoundly disturbed by the attitude of funding council officials, who are so bent on forcing the merger through that they have chosen to ignore all contrary points of view," he said.

"The truth is, I have never seen such a blatant case of bureaucratic bulldozing."

A funding council spokesman said: "The process has been carried out very thoroughly and quite properly.

"It's followed through the well-publicised and critical regime of presentation, consultation and assessment which has been tried and tested over a number of mergers."

John Glazier, Rutland college principal, said it would have to shed a quarter of its 32 full-time staff if it didn't merge - "not a sensible option".

Tresham was committed to developing the "sixth form college type education", he said.

He denied significant local opposition to the merger. Only one member of the public turned up to a meeting about the merger held by the local authority, he said.

Andrew Middleton, principal of Stamford College, said Duncan had made a "timely and impressive" speech on a matter deserving public scrutiny.

The final decision on the merger will be taken before June by the Secretary of State.

fields.headline: Weld done
fields.standfirst: John Crace talks to the fairground workers who are getting certificates
fields.trailText: John Crace talks to the fairground workers who are getting certificates
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead must be having a seizure. In his annual lecture, given at the end of last month, HM's Chief Inspector of Schools suggested that self-improvement was beyond the masses and that plumbers should just knuckle down and carry on plumbing. By the same token, fairground workers should presumably stay in their caravans. Except not all of them are. David Wynn, James Jones and Shaun Weightman, all of whom have been working the fairs since they were 14 and don't have a single academic qualification between them, are all studying for NVQs in fabrication and welding at Chesterfield College.

The story begins two years ago when Wynn, who, much to Woodhead's relief no doubt, can neither read nor write, reckoned that it was about time he had his skills certified. "I was born to the fairgrounds," he says, "so I've never known anything else. I learned welding both from my Dad and by helping out at the local blacksmith, and I used to muck in making candy-floss stalls and adapting lorries to accommodate the rides."

It was all low-risk stuff, but the jobs needed doing, and Wynn fell in love with welding. "I love the power of designing something and making it myself," he adds. In recent years, though, times have got a lot harder on the fairgrounds. The once lucrative summer season has become the slackest time of year, thanks to the big theme parks, such as Alton Towers, and to more people taking holidays abroad," says Wynn, with a half-smile.

In addition to all this, the Health and Safety regulations have quite rightly been tightened; each ride has to be rigorously tested to make sure it is safe. This does not come cheap: it can cost £250 to get a ride tested and if faults are found, a welder who has been certificated to work at a certain level must be brought in to do the repairs. This can run to £20-30 per hour.

With income falling and costs rising, you don't have to be a genius to see the attraction of getting qualifications. Initially, Wynn had no response when he enquired about welding courses at Mansfield College. But he got lucky when a teacher who visits the Selston caravan site to take classes for the fairground children, including Wynn's two sons, approached Chesterfield College on his behalf. Within a day Wynn had had a reply.

Dave Glossop is the course lecturer in fabrication and welding. "David was only going to be at his caravan site for 16 weeks of the year," he says, " and he wanted a course that would fit in to this time frame. Our normal courses last twice as long, but I reckoned that if he was prepared to do two full days a week, instead of the normal one, we could accommodate him."

Last year Wynn completed his Awarding Body Consortium (ABC) 165 scheme in flat welding. This year he has come back to take the more complex, horizontal welding and next year he intends to get his overhead qualification. Wynn has also come back mob handed, with Jones and Weightman who are taking the flat welding course.

"I've been working the fairs for 15 years and it's much harder to earn a living these days," Jones says candidly. Like Wynn, he is looking for the reassurance of a qualification. "There's a good chance that if you've got the paperwork to back up your welding, you can keep working all year long. You can do work for other showmen as well as looking after your own rides."

But even though Wynn and Jones say they know the stresses and strains of their rides better than any outsider, there are always going to be limits to how much repair work they will be able to do. "Some of the big computerised modern rides cost over £1m," says Wynn, "and if anything goes wrong the manufacturer guarantees to fix it. The rides are so safe these days, you've got more chance of being killed while setting them up than you have of being killed on them." Which presumably makes the computer course the logical next step for the men, Chris Woodhead permitting.

The rides are so safe these days, you've got more chance of being killed while setting them up than you have of being killed on them." Which presumably makes the computer course the logical next step for the men, Chris Woodhead permitting.

fields.headline: Recycled education
fields.standfirst: Janet Jones on monkey business and sucking eggs
fields.trailText: Janet Jones on monkey business and sucking eggs
fields.body:
Question: What does further education have in common with the house that Jack built and the Chinese calendar?

Answer: It builds on itself in cycles.

This is the year of the Learning Style. Forty or so of us grandmothers were summoned to suck eggs. We had to leave several hundred students behind for the day.

It was all very pleasant. Pleasant to see the other grandmothers. Pleasant to have a cup of coffee. Pleasant to have a biscuit. Pleasant to reminisce about our Learning Experiences. Pleasant to ponder Learning Styles.

But what was the point?

We all know we are all different. We all know we all learn in different ways. We must have done about eight hundred years of teaching between us. And near two thousand years of living.

We were told that, according to "research in Canada", there are four ways of learning. No more. No less. (And the world began in 4004BC, too, you know.)

But what was the point?

We all know that different students get on better with different kinds of teaching: "THIS IS VERY BORING," one student told me and the rest of the class last week. VERY LOUDLY.

"No, it isn't," another contradicted her. Students are real people who tell us real things day by day.

So what was the point?

We grandmothers had a fair idea of the point before we were gathered together. We have been gathered together before. We communicated our resignation to each other in the face of the inevitable: learning styles are flavour of the year. And we are go ing to be asked to "identify" (or maybe "diagnose") each of our student's learning styles next September.

Can you imagine?

Past experience is not encouraging. Remember The Year of The Action Plan? The Year of The Aim?

Then we had the Year of The Objective?

Then came the Year of The Progress Review?

And who remembers the Year of The Course Audit? The Year of The Appraisal? The Year of The Observation? The Year of The Inspection? The Year of The Annual Course Review?

Jack and his house enter the frame here. As each new line is added to each new verse, so each year is added to the year before and we grandmothers are left swimming in paperwork. But we are repeating the same things, with different words, again and again and again and again.

Of course, the Chinese cycle is more sensible: it calls a monkey a monkey every time it comes round. And Jack's house is more solid; the house of further education is built on sand. None of us grandmothers believe a word of it. But it was very pleasant to sit and suck eggs together.

fields.headline: Rangers
fields.trailText: Rangers
fields.body:
Hi-Yo! Beg pardon

Hi-Yo! If you're looking for the toilets, they're in the visitors centre.

No. Hi-Yo, Silver! It's your shout! Oh dear, sir, have we been eating the little mushrooms?

No, no. It's what the Lone Ranger used to shout. I'm not the Lone Ranger.

Are you sure? Utterly.

And you've no horse called Silver, or pal called Tonto? The only Cherokees here have four wheels.

So who are you? I'm a countryside ranger.

And what's that when it's at home? We're responsible for the maintenance and care of designated areas of countryside.

How do you do that? We increase public awareness about preserving natural heritage through projects and outreach work.

What else do you do? Where appropriate we train volunteers to help us.

Wow. What do you need to get the badge? Obviously you must love the countryside, and excellent communication skills are important. A specialist knowledge about the area you work in, eg about the plants and animals in specific habitats, is also very useful. There is strong competition for posts.

I can see that. What about qualifications? We require a good secondary education. A relevant NVQ is a bonus. There is the possibility of National Traineeships, but you'd need to check with your local TEC or careers service.

Are there any other sorts of rangers? I'm glad you asked, because it so happens there is one other - the forest ranger

What do they do? Mainly practical duties (sniff) involving upkeep of forest and woodland.

They get their hands dirty, you mean. I believe the work can involve using machinery such as chainsaws and tractors.

Is that all? No. They're very hot on fire prevention awareness, for obvious reasons. They also look after animals on their patch. And in some areas they can find themselves educating or supervising the public.

What are the requirements? You need to be fit and (sniff) good at manual work.

Are the jobs easy to find? For employment opportunities best find the Local Forest District Office number in your phone book.

 The Countryside Agency 01242 521381

 Lantra (Land based industries national training organisation) 0345 078007

 National Trust (for The NT Careership Scheme) 0171 222 9251

 Forestry and Aboriculture Safety and Training Council 0131 314 6247

 Forestry Commission 0131 314 6379

 learndirect 0800 100900 may be able to give further information and advice on courses.

fields.headline: Business champions
fields.standfirst: Veronica Laird, small business person, takes issue with the idea that she doesn't exist
fields.trailText: Veronica Laird, small business person, takes issue with the idea that she doesn't exist
fields.body:
Small businesses often have problems in making their voice heard, and we are often overlooked. But I can assure the principal of Weston College, Weston-super-Mare (Rostrum, March 28) that I am alive and well, and an active member of the Business Champions Group set up to promote business involvement in the new Learning and Skills Council.

Mr Williams claims that only the "top" people from Vauxhall, Jaguar, Coca-Cola and the Post Office are represented on the group. On the full list of members he will see - but probably not recognise - the names of Veronica Laird (Newbreed Freight), Clyde Williams (SHO-Net systems) and Roger Mills (Newsquest North London), among others.

We may not be household names, but we are typical of the vast majority of business in this country. And we share the view that we must not sit back and wait for things to happen to us, we must get off our (not so comfy) executive chairs and make things happen. And there has never been a better opportunity than right now for business of all kinds to influence the post-16 education and training agenda.

Today Nick Reilly of Vauxhall and I will be at the British Chambers of Commerce national conference urging business people to apply for board-level posts on the Learning and Skills Council and its 47 local arms. This is the point at which the post-16 vision becomes a reality. Now is the time for people to apply for those key posts, and put flesh on the bones of the new system.

Government can supply the funding and the clearer strategy, but we business people must supply the real know-how on the needs of the local economy, what skills gaps there are, and what type of effective training is required.

Forty per cent of the places on local Learning and Skills Councils are reserved for business. The Business Champions Group has been specially set up to make sure that those places are not taken up exclusively by big companies. In particular, I want to see people on the local councils who not only understand the importance of training to their company's competitiveness, but who will challenge discrimination and the barriers that exist for many people in taking up opportunities.

I am surprised that Mr Williams, as a college principal, thinks that the needs of small businesses are not being taken into account. Much good work has already been done in joint working between business and further education. I am a director of St Helens Chamber and also a governor of St Helens College. I have become a director of a joint venture company, Business Net Solutions, which was set up by the chamber and the college to deliver IT training for small companies. This company gives reliable advice and provides a valuable service to the business community.

Under the new Learning and Skills Council, this type of arrangement should flourish, because business people will be in a position to make post-16 education and training work for them.

I know that many people who head small companies have limited time or resources. But I prefer to see it as a matter of where my time and efforts can make the maximum impact. Many business people, especially from small firms, may say they can't afford to become involved with their local Learning and Skills Council.

I say they can't afford not to.

 Veronica Laird is managing director of Newbreed Freight, a St Helens company which employs seven people.

fields.headline: Urban mentors
fields.standfirst: Nick Tester  on the new mentors who will be going into schools to save the most difficult kids from exclusion
fields.trailText: Nick Tester on the new mentors who will be going into schools to save the most difficult kids from exclusion
fields.body:
Radlyn Booth says he once fleetingly played for Millwall FC, when the club was a Division One force to be reckoned with in the early 1980s.

Today he is a member of a new team trying to sidestep the obstacles that are holding back so many disadvantaged, inner-city youngsters from scoring with their learning.

He's one of the first 800 "education mentors" just appointed as part of the government's increasingly ambitious Excellence in Cities programme. The £33m mentoring section of this programme is now getting off the ground in secondary schools in six urban areas (Leeds/Bradford, London, Liverpool/Knowsley, Manchester/ Salford, Birmingham and Sheffield/ Rotherham).

Plans are afoot to extend the provision of mentors to other deprived urban areas, such as Leicester, cities in the north-east and Bristol. Minister of State Estelle Morris announced last week £25m of funding to pave the way for mentors in primary schools in the current areas.

Further education is playing the key role in equipping these mentors - few of whom have teaching or youth-work backgrounds - with the extra skills they'll certainly need to pass muster in a task that's emerging as one of the most difficult jobs in education. This is to seriously reduce the stubborn figure of 12,000 pupils excluded each year from school. Worse, a reckoned 170,000 youngsters leave school with no qualifications, and with no motivation and few incentives to contemplate a return to learning at any time during their adult lives.

Morris told an audience of these fledgling mentors that they were the start of a new education profession, "a hybrid of all sorts of other jobs". The intention was that by acting as "first-aider, or super probation officer", reducing classroom disruption, focusing on behavioural issues and generally encouraging more concentrated spells of learning, the mentors would relieve teachers of all the exhausting, non-teaching jobs they have to somehow pack into the day.

"Mentors," Morris went on, "will be a godsend for teachers, as well as for youngsters."

The potential for conflict between newly arrived mentors, disturbed kids, outside agencies and possibly cynical teachers is enormous, of course. This is new, mostly uncharted, territory and some sensitive professional toes may get trodden on.

The task of avoiding these flying late tackles, often from behind, is now down to Rotherham College of Arts and Technology and the Association of Colleges. Their joint bid, competing against powerful private-sector opponents, won the government training contract to ensure the mentors cope and really make a difference.

Many of the difficult youngsters will be in struggling schools with a culture of loathing and underachievement, points out Rotherham College's Mike Garnock-Jones. This means the training he's devised needs to be flexible enough to give the mentors various options for both their own survival and student success.

There's also a problem on the other side of the school-leaving age. "Too often," laments Garnock-Jones, "new recruits, or those on work experience, still get the mundane jobs because managers fear they can't cope with more demanding tasks.

"And so what happens? The youngster then gets bored and bunks off. Suddenly employers have a self-fulfilling prophesy to deal with."

The school mentors, who are being paid about £18,000 (slightly more in London) pro-rata, are each expected to have a case load of between 12 and 15 youngsters. After school and weekend work is par for the course.

Jacqueline Valin, head of Southfields Community College in Wandsworth, south London, has three learning mentors already in post. "I could do with 12." she says. "It's not that the youngsters can't learn, but that their behaviour stops them from doing so.

"That said, it is crucial the mentor is viewed positively, that they're not part of a disciplinary thing."

fields.headline: That sinking feeling
fields.trailText: Our son has failed to get into the secondary school of our choice. What can I do about it?
fields.body:
I have just found out that our son has failed to get into the secondary school of our choice. Instead, he has been given a place at the local "sink" school. I am very angry about this, and would like to know what I can do about it.

Christopher Kronda is headteacher at Cassiobury Junior School, Watford.

Remember that all parents and guardians have the right to state a preference for a school, and to appeal against the school which is allocated to them.

If you face this problem, firstly arrange an appointment to see the headteacher of your child's current school. Heads can be more objective than class teachers in these situations and can talk things through. It's natural to feel a range of emotions - hurt, anger, and even a sense of failure. Having another person acknowledge your feelings can be a comfort.

The next stage is to discuss the options. But think carefully about precisely what you want, and where - realistically - you go from here. You could "home educate", but as a professional educator, even I'd be loathe to opt for this route!

If your preference has been denied, you will receive information from the authority explaining what you can do to appeal. It is vital to keep to the published deadlines to take this course of action, and to follow the rules to the letter.

It's worth checking with the admission authority (ie the local education authority or the school itself) to find out if there is a "waiting list" for your preferred school.

If you go ahead with an appeal, it's worth reviewing your child's progress throughout their primary years, and putting together a portfolio of their work.

Are you certain this really is a "sink" school? Often a school's reputation can lag behind reality. Look at the school for yourself, and gauge if your child could actually be happy there.

And academic considerations are not the only ones. For example, if they have a particular aptitude for art that might be better served at a different school from your original choice.

Consider the social factors, too - are most of your child's peer group going to one school? Sometimes this is a good reason for your child also going there, but be as objective as possible.

Your child may have to go to the school where a place has been allocated. If this happens, their induction will not be easier if they have sensed your "negative vibes". Try to guard against criticising the school in front of your child.

It's perfectly understandable to feel aggrieved. Yet many children can - and do - make a happy transition to secondary school in such circumstances, despite their parents' or guardians' initial concerns.

Christopher Kronda's key points

You have the right to appeal to an independent appeal panel against the decision if you are unhappy with the school place allocated to your child - but before doing this, consider how strong your case is, and discuss the options with your child's current head.

The appeal panel will be three people, independent of the admission authority. First, someone from the authority will explain why the school cannot take more children. You will then have a chance to present your case. After that, the panel makes a "balancing judgement" and decides if the benefits to your child of going to the school you want outweigh the bad effects on the school and other children of having one more pupil in class.

If the panel decides your case is the stronger, it will uphold your appeal and the admission authority is then duty-bound to admit your child.

If you feel unhappy about how the appeal hearing was carried out, you can complain to the local government ombudsman for your area, who might recommend a new appeal.

For further information about appeals or how to contact your LGO, ring the Department for Education's School Admissions Team on 020-7925 5555.

Next week's query: At the secondary school where I teach, a wide range of soft drinks is on sale at break and lunch times. Yet fizzy drinks such as Pepsi and Coke seem to turn otherwise reasonable young people into pupils from hell. This causes much extra work and stress for all involved, and has a significant impact on their education and learning. I have tried repeatedly to get these drinks banned from school, but to no avail. Help!

But not everyone thinks web-based revision is a good thing. "If it means the kids will do some revision, that would be good," says David Jones, author of the Teach Yourself Revise GCSE Geography and a forthcoming A-level title.

"But the novelty would wear off pretty smartish. The problems you have in writing material for all syllabuses would make it incredibly difficult. I don't see it as a revision tool."

A-level learning, at least in the arts, is as much about constructing an argument and gathering evidence as learning facts - something which no interactive program has yet been able to test.

"What the web is good for is those times when you're going through your notes and find something's missing," says Jones. "A list of useful websites would be better than online revision at this level."

But revision starts much earlier now, and parents are worrying about their child's performance in SATs as well as GCSEs and A levels. Little wonder that they send anguished emails to the BBC's revision website fearing they are too strict, too lax or even too stupid to help.

These resources are among the most comprehensive and best written on the web. Commendably, the BBC is also urging 10- and 11-year-olds to join free revision clubs at weekends in April.

Other sites are trying hard to catch up. SAM Learning offers a limited, sometimes somewhat antiquated range of tests (Female jobs in French? How about secretary and waitress?) It is due to be updated soon.

Schoolsnet promises much but shows the influence of male programmers with its pouting Lara Croft clone, Minimax. Yes, girls, you can understand plant biology too!

Channel Four's Homework High invites pupils to email a teacher with homework queries. The team answers 250 questions a night and if you haven't got time to wait you can search previous queries. Teachers involved try not to spoon-feed and the accumulated knowledge is impressive.

fields.headline: Religious education
fields.trailText:
GCSE Religious Studies

***

Aimed at: everyone
fields.body:
GCSE Religious Studies

***

Aimed at: everyone

Concentrating on the NEAB 1342B RS syllabus, this site is a revision tool for the Christianity and Christian Perspectives elements of the course. It summarises the key points and then tests pupils systematically. Some elements, particularly conceptual and moral issues, could be taken further, but RS revision exercises are hard to find online and the site meets a need.

RE Curriculum Materials
**

Aimed at: teachers

Culham College also runs The RE Site and both stress Anglican Christianity. Most resources are suitable for collective worship. The RE Site does, however, have a searchable index of links to resources elsewhere.

RE Teachers' Cupboard
****

Aimed at: teachers

An invaluable collection of tips, advice and links for any RS teacher, the Teachers' Cupboard is run by Paul Hopkins (who is also responsible for the revision site listed above). Visitors are encouraged to contribute lesson plans and ideas.

Ship of Fools
***

Aimed at: everyone

While the Ship of Fools (subtitled the Magazine of Christian Unrest) is a Christian website, it also questions, mocks, satirises and pricks the bubbles of religious pomposity. The contents include serious reviews of church services, off-the-wall religious news, and excellent discussion boards.

Netclass

Aimed at: everyone

Our own Education Unlimited directory of RS links, ordered by religion.

Islamicity in Cyberspace
***
Aimed at: everyone

Although slow to download, this is probably the biggest Islamic portal online, with numerous potential classroom resources and information.

Judaism 101
****
Aimed at: everyone

An online encyclopaedia of Judaism, written by "a traditional, observant Jew". One useful feature is the grading of information for different levels of understanding or, as the author puts it: "Like the Passover seder, this site now includes information for the wise son, who wants to know the ritual details; the simple son, who asks simple questions; and the son who does not know what to ask." Bear in mind its American perspective.

Virtual Synagogue
***
Aimed at: everyone

Built by a rabbi, this site is not just a guided tour of a synagogue but also a glossary, history, photo gallery and guide to the structure of a service. You can pay a visit to Rabbi Amy Scheinerman's homepage, with still more information, and even email her.

Hindu Universe
****
Aimed at: everyone

A web directory, resembling Yahoo, which links to hundreds of potentially useful resources on Hinduism: gods, festivals, scriptures and even an English to Hindi dictionary.

Sikhism Homepage
****
Aimed at: everyone

These pages are compiled by a Sikh and, as well as setting out the tenets of the religion, bring together some interesting photographic resources and writing on, for example, the Gurus' teachings on women.

fields.headline: Freedom on paper
fields.standfirst: Jerome Monahan  asks whether journalists can work free from persecution, and explains why it matters
fields.trailText: Jerome Monahan asks whether journalists can work free from persecution, and explains why it matters
fields.body:
It may seem obvious that journalists should be allowed to investigate and report. But winning this right has taken centuries. Many still think there is a long way to go before true press freedom is achieved because powerful groups such as governments try to put certain information "off limits".

Others worry that too many newspapers and TV stations are owned by a few hugely powerful media corporations. They fear that truth and variety of opinion lose out when journalism becomes part of a global business.

Press freedom is an essential part of freedom of expression, which is protected by article 10 of the European Convention on Human Rights - soon to become law in the UK. A free press is a vital control on organisations and politicians. It provides the information we need to make sense of the world. It can champion important causes and generate public support at times of disaster.

Democracy is far more than having the right to vote. True "citizens" need to be knowledgeable and should be able to look to the press for information and ideas. Press freedom is one of the first things to suffer under dictators. In far too many countries, journalists still risk harassment, arrest and sometimes even torture or execution.

All freedoms need protecting and freedom of expression is no different. The press sometimes have to go through long and costly legal battles to hang onto documents or to keep secret the identity of people who leak sensitive stories to them. They also have to fight libel trials defending what they have said.

But not all the threats come from the outside. There are worries that sometimes the media themselves are responsible for eroding press freedom. Critics say newspapers and most TV stations are businesses and that business interests can interfere. For example, it can be difficult for a newspaper to run a story that criticises an important advertiser.

Some media can become so powerful that they have the power to influence elections. Here, politicians may try to keep the press sweet and avoid controversy. On the other hand, there is the worry that political parties are getting too skilled at manipulating the news through what is called "spin doctoring": presenting policies in an excessively good light or distracting attention away from things they do not want reported.

Much news comes from big business and governments, which have the money to employ teams of public relations specialists to present their views. Sometimes the press can be guilty of having a narrow idea of what is newsworthy, which may mean other issues are sidelined.

Journalists are expected to follow a strict code of conduct laid down by the Press Complaints Commission. Some newspapers go further. The Guardian has an internal and an external "ombudsman", both of whom are independent of editorial control and can insist that apologies and corrections are published.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Kissing the Queen | Budget for Babies
fields.body:
There are films that entertain, films that inspire, films that remain with the viewer long after the final frame. And then there is Dirty Dancing. The term "classic" barely conveys the eternal marvellousness of the 1987 spectacular featuring Jennifer Grey and god-in-wrinkly-jeans Patrick Swayze. Nobody puts Baby in a corner. So Sidelines was not unconcerned to discover plans for a remake. Rumoured contenders for the leads are - sit down for this, it's upsetting - Ricky Martin and Britney Spears. Johnny and the dance kids living la vida loca? Baby Houseman in pigtails and utility wear? Sidelines hereby calls upon all right-thinking citizens to take up the cause: write to your MP, start a petition, raise the issue wherever you can. Remember: this is my dance space, this is your dance space. Sigh.

 When Her Maj was snapped at the weekend receiving the second public kiss of her married life, her mouth screwed up like she was sucking on a particularly nippy sweetie. Phil planted the welcome-home smacker at an ungodly 5am, as his wife returned home from her tour of Australia. We're on Liz's side. Protocol be damned - she's just objecting to unnecessary early-morning personal space invasion.

 It might have been punted as a Budget for Babies, but it certainly wasn't put before a parliament for parents. Six women Labour MPs - most with kids - are reported to be planning to step down at the next election, mainly due to disillusionment at the pace of parliamentary reform. And 130 Labour members have signed a petition pressing for a more family-friendly approach in the Commons, where debates often continue into the wee hours. How can we expect businesses to take pro-family regulation seriously when those making the rules don't? While some argue that Tony's paternity leave dilemma is nought but a crypto-feminist storm in a nappy bin, it's beginning to look like one of the most important decisions of his term.

webTitle: Courage in the face of flab

fields.headline: Courage in the face of flab
fields.trailText: Ultrasoundings: "This morning I lost sight of my knickers."
fields.body:
Week 18

This morning I lost sight of my knickers. They have disappeared beneath the dome of my belly. This has never happened to me before, stout though I have been, and I find it alarming. After all, my body hasn't sprouted in the night since I was 15, and the consequences then were unspeakable.

I'd like to know when, exactly, it all intends to stop. This is the sort of question that sends me to the wall of pregnancy books in Waterstone's. The trouble is, there are so many answers. Dr Gordon Bourne, author of Pregnancy, the 20-year-old multi-selling bible on the subject, seems obsessed with weight gain, returning to it in nearly every chapter and providing strict and very slender tables.

Bourne quotes with approval the story of the woman who vomited so much through her pregnancy that she lost nearly 100 pounds ("she was still a little overweight!"). He provides diets that will allow every woman to look "just as nice in her bikini" three months after birth, but regrets the feminine ignorance that so often undermines his advice. "Most women on a diet tend to nibble between meals, especially cheese. It is not generally realised that cheese will cause an increase in weight. Its intake should be strictly limited." But then, Dr Bourne also calls nappies "napkins", and thinks episiotomies should be routine.

Miriam Stoppard Woman is much more progressive. She rises smoothly though a table of average weight gain, smiling Mona Lisa-like and keeping up her iron intake the while, and is even permitted a moment of body anxiety when she contemplates her stomach dubiously in a white dressing gown. Nothing about knickers, though.

Meanwhile, downmarket, Emma, author of the "Diary" issued free to every pregnant woman by the Royal College of General Practitioners, manages to record, "I can expect to gain anything from 9.6-19.2 kg (20-40lb)" - without panicking for an instant. Imagine Bridget Jones faced with such a prospect. But Emma is odd in many ways. She writes all weights down like that, in pounds and kilograms, says "pass water" instead of "pee", and has never noticed that her friend Paula is black. Emma also never reads the paper. You can tell because not once in her diary does she get upset by articles that advise you to "just buy a skirt a size larger than usual, and emphasise your slim arms with Agnes B tops".

Emma, therefore, has never had to wonder what to do if you always buy the largest size in the shop anyway and can only fit in the curtains in Agnes B. No, Emma just trots off to Mothercare and picks up a floral tent, for she is sweetly unaware of the rise of the pregnant media star.

If Emma had ever seen Carol Smillie, Posh Spice, or the two pregnant All Saints, she would realise that frocks are out and that tight tops and leggings with a pneumatic bulge in the middle are in. The look is not so much Ceres as python-that-has-recently-swallowed-a-sheep. On these women, you can tell what is python and what is sheep. Or rather, what is taut, personally trained muscle and what is soon to be caesareaned, clip-off baby.

These women, the python look tells us, will soon return to their sexual, available selves while the baby giggles elsewhere in a basket. They are laughing, prancing evidence that motherhood is no problem and certainly doesn't require a revolution in child care. No wonder Miriam Stoppard Woman - and I am she, undoubtedly, though in a dirtier dressing gown - looks so worried. She used to march for Wages for Housework.

T he thing is, I have never looked like a python, and I don't think my baby is clip-off, either. Already, I have pulled my pelvic bones out of alignment getting on my bicycle, and had to have them clicked back together by my osteopath, who, fortunately, is a genius. He told me gently that my pelvis was in sections, and that the ligaments stretch when you're pregnant. I didn't know.

It makes me think that birth may be more like splitting in two. I suspect, too,that I may not see my knickers again for many, many months, and may soon lose my toes. Fortunately, I have Emma as my heroine. Emma, busting in every diary entry out of bras, waistbands, jeans, oblivious to Dr Bourne and the Cheese Menace, to Miriam's relentless sensibleness, to the post-feminist python sirens. Emma with her straight forward delivery - just gas and air! - her years off work, her rapidly fading stretchmarks. Hurrah for Emma and baby Lucy-Kate. I think I'll skip Waterstone's. I'm off to buy a tent.
