fields.headline: Noye 'drove off calmly after stabbing'
fields.trailText: The man stabbed in an alleged road rage murder stared at his bloody hands, staggered backwards and collapsed as Kenneth Noye calmly got back into his car and drove away, a witness told the Old Bailey yesterday.
fields.body:
The man stabbed in an alleged road rage murder stared at his bloody hands, staggered backwards and collapsed as Kenneth Noye calmly got back into his car and drove away, a witness told the Old Bailey yesterday.

Heather Titley said she saw Stephen Cameron, 21, grab the collar of Noye's shirt and scuffle with him at the Swanley interchange of the M25 in May, 1996.

"They were struggling with each other. The next thing I can remember is the younger of the two men appeared to stagger. He looked at his hands and they were covered in blood. He put his hands out in front of him and looked shocked and confused ... the young man went to the front of the van and fell down."

Mrs Titley added: "It was apparent he had been severely wounded. The older man went back to his vehicle, got in and drove away. It did not screech away. It just drove away."

Mrs Titley was giving evidence yesterday on the third day of the trial of Noye, 52, of West Kingsdown, Kent. He denies murdering Mr Cameron, saying he stabbed him in self-defence.

The fight allegedly started when Noye confronted Mr Cameron, the passenger in a van driven by Danielle Cable, his fiancee.

Mrs Titley's husband Stephen said Mr Cameron seemed to pursue Noye when the "very violent" fight which followed broke up.

In a statement to police, Mr Titley said: "The younger man came up behind the older one and grabbed at his left shoulder with his right hand and then punched the older man with his left hand. I believe the punch landed on the jaw. They then exchanged a couple of blows in quick succession."

Two other witnesses gave different accounts of the fight which led to Mr Cameron being stabbed.

Helen Merral told the jury that Mr Cameron had thrown the first punch. "The first thing I saw, it is horrible to say, as the young boy is not here now, but the younger man hit the older one. But I don't know, it was a fight and it was not all on one side. I just saw the younger man hit the older man in the face. The older man broke away and began to walk away. I saw the younger man go up as if he was going to carry on."

Stephen Darling, however, said Noye landed the first blow, hitting Mr Cameron in the face with his right fist.

"That was definitely the first action of violence when they met. The younger fellow was then getting the better of the older one. I saw him throw punches and kicking. The older bloke was backing off. I thought the older fellow got out to give the young one a clout, then the young one got the better of it. I thought 'Fair enough, he deserves it'."

The trial continues today.

fields.headline: Sex and the sinful girl
fields.standfirst: When a Hollywood sex shop counts Liz Hurley among its customers and Ann Summers buys up high-street lingerie chain Knickerbox, are the days of red faces and brown paper bags numbered?  Caroline Sullivan  reports
fields.trailText: When a Hollywood sex shop counts Liz Hurley among its customers and Ann Summers buys up high-street lingerie chain Knickerbox, are the days of red faces and brown paper bags numbered?  Caroline Sullivan  reports
fields.body:
Just what did you buy at the sex shop, Liz?" asked a headline in last week's Mirror. The paper managed to concoct a full-page story out of a picture of Elizabeth Hurley walking out of a Hollywood adult emporium called Hustler, with a carrier bag full of... well, no one knew quite what, but something saucy, anyway. The paper claimed her attention was especially caught by a jar of pink liquid latex designed to be painted on to the skin, and a book called The Magic of Fetishism. An "onlooker" supposedly commented: "We were amazed, because you don't often get any women in places like this, let alone a famous British movie star."

Rubbish, actually. In fact, women now comprise a significant proportion of sex shop customers, and increasingly manage them and work behind the counter, too. Half of Hustler's 25 staff are female, and 75 per cent of the shop's trade is women and couples. "We get tons of resumes and applications from women," says manager Brett Drysdale. "Girls are very comfortable in our shop. We have glass frontage, hardwood floors and we're well lit."

It all sounds more like a department store (the term he prefers to "sex shop"), which isn't a coincidence. Erotic emporia are currently waking up to two facts: one, their average customer is as likely to be a woman as the classic dirty old man, and two, women like to shop in attractive surroundings. Consequently, shops that continue to peddle blow-up dolls in poorly lit premises with (as in one Soho dive) newspaper on the floor to catch drips from a leaky ceiling will miss out on the Girl Power pound. Those that make themselves female-friendly - perhaps following the lead of the 27-strong Ann Summers chain, which incorporates coffee shops and pram ramps in its newest stores - will find their efforts are repaid.

Ann Summers hopes to have 100 high-street sex shops by 2003. This increase will coincide with the 50-odd shops that German company Beate Uhse, the European sex shop market leader, plans to open in Britain by 2002. In June, Summers will be relaunching its flagship Soho outlets. "Our research has shown that they're looking dated," says publicity director Rebecca Cox.

"We want to give them a more luxurious feel with a clubby spin. We can foresee targeting trendy people who go to clubs and bars." The company is toying with several themes, including "ice queen", "classical" and the aspirationally titled "decadence". One corner of Cox's office at Summers' HQ in suburban Whyteleafe, Surrey, is occupied by architects' sketches of a space that looks more like a Notting Hill boutique than a sex shop. You can envisage groovesters in the right jeans in a place like that, perhaps casually popping the best-selling Heaven vibrator ("Soft jelly plastic in purple with a clitoral-stimulator attachment with rotating pearls in the shaft," explains the young head buyer, Tracey Bell) into their baskets as they chat.

The concept of women using an adult shop as a club-style hangout may exist only in the Summers people's imagination as yet, but in the Charing Cross Road outlet in central London on a Saturday afternoon, the female clientele are predominantly coolish twentysomethings. None of them seem self-conscious about being there - if anything, it's the male customers, congregating in the video section, who look uncomfortable. And it's the same story two doors down in a shop called Harmony, whose stylish logo and graphics give the impression of a hip clothes shop. Inside, it's as bright as a supermarket, women stroll casually and the female assistant wears rectangular glasses and black clubwear. Customers wander in pairs, examining PVC bras and leather goods (though they conspicuously avoid hardcore stuff like the indescribable Jenny's Vibrating Vag) with the glazed look women get when they're shopping seriously.

Everyone is so matter-of-fact that it's hard to accept the Mirror's claim that Hurley was "unable to hide her giggles" at Hustler. It's a safe bet that she managed not to giggle at all, unless she'd suddenly turned unto a 12-year-old boy. Much as the tabloids would love to paint women as hooting like Carry On characters at the sight of a vibrator, the fact is that the era of sex shops as preserves of seedy men and housewives trying to save ailing marriages is over.

Years of the women's media banging on about us taking control of our sexual pleasure, it seems, is actually having an effect, as witnessed by the sight of a middle-aged mother and teenage daughter browsing in Ann Summers. "I want to teach her not to be afraid of her body," says Susan, a 48-year-old teacher from Sheffield, of 18-year-old Suzi, who's busy buying a studded leather wristlet of the sort now found in every high street. "I was just explaining to her about the strap-ons. She asked me if it was just lesbians that used them and I said, 'No, men do, too.'" Rather than dying a million deaths, Suzi beams.

The ongoing feminisation of Ann Summers (which also sells its wares at female-only parties that are apparently much closer to the old-school image of girls giggling at "naughty" paraphernalia) has been encouraged by the success of fetishy lingerie shop Agent Provocateur (which also produces a popular range for Marks and Spencer), and Sh, an east London erotic boutique run by and for women.

"Sometimes women are very embarrassed," admits Sh owner Kathryn Hoyle. "It's not all 'Give me a vibrator and make it fast'. But people's attitudes toward sexuality became much more fluid in the late 90s. Things like fetish fashion and E culture came into the mainstream, and everyone was loved up, so people are less defining of sexuality now."

Her shop's organic feel - wooden floors, sheer white blinds - and policy of admitting only "accompanied men" encourages customers to linger. There's even seating and a pile of erotic magazines to read, though it seems these aren't as graphic as some clients would prefer. "There's a demand for hardcore porn, and explicit close-up penetrative shots. We get asked for videos every week, but we can't do anything to answer the need because the laws on what's obscene are a mish-mash," Hoyle says.

Which is interesting, because Ann Summers' Cox claims the opposite: "Women don't want hardcore pornography. It doesn't satisfy our fantasies, because it has no emotion. We still want to buy into fantasy and romance."

She could be right, since the top-selling items at both places - vibrators - are as inoffensively feminine as possible. Ann Summers' Heaven model comes in pastel colours that change every season, while Sh's most popular is called Jessica Rabbit, and has wiggly bunny ears.

Both businesses are benefiting, anyway, from the mainstreaming of what was once considered tartwear - when did we last see Posh Spice in anything that didn't show maximum leg and bosom? - and a concomitant openness about sex.

Dr Lorna Warren, lecturer in social policy at Sheffield University, has reservations, however, about how making direct correlations between women buying sex toys and their sexual liberation. "Does owning frilly underwear mean you have more liberal attitudes?" she asks. "It is the commercialisation of sexiness - women are coerced into buying. Ann Summers is there first and foremost as a business venture; it's not about what women really want."

But while the high street takes a step closer to Ann Summers territory by passing off ever tinier scraps of material as clothing, Summers takes a step closer to "respectability" this week by acquiring the high-street lingerie chain Knickerbox. Plans are vague, but, says Cox ambiguously, "We may be expanding their range." So will crotchless knickers be sold next to sensible cotton ones? We await developments.

As the boundaries between the sexual mainstream and the margins blur, one question remains un-answered: just what did Liz buy at the sex shop?

webTitle: Three feared dead after building falls

fields.headline: Three feared dead after building falls
fields.trailText: Three workmen were feared dead last night after a four storey building collapsed in Hull yesterday, trapping them under 50 tonnes of rubble.
fields.body:
Three workmen were feared dead last night after a four storey building collapsed in Hull yesterday, trapping them under 50 tonnes of rubble.

Of the four men who were in the building, one was found within minutes of the accident.

The 38-year-old, who had been on the top floor, was protected by a tunnel formed by falling masonry and escaped with cuts and bruises.

The remaining three had not been located after a second collapse, prompting health and safety officers to rule the area too unstable for the 45 firefighters involved.

Earlier rescue efforts at the site, in the city centre, were hampered when gale force winds affected the sensitivity of sound detection equipment.

Nick Granger, of Humberside fire service, said the search had been further complicated because of uncertainty about the workmen's location. "By the time we can restart the search effort they will have been under the debris for over 24-hours - you have to fear the worst," he said.

"What we are hoping is that they are trapped in the basement in a cavity somewhere and it is always possible they are relatively unharmed.

Mr Granger said the physical search by firefighters could be restarted if signs of life were detected.

A fifth builder, Shpend Lika, escaped injury because he had left to get some coffee for his colleagues. "They sent me off to get some drinks," he said last night.

"When I returned 20 minutes later the inside of the building had collapsed, trapping my mates."

webTitle: Museums give wary cheer to Smith's £1 adult fee plan

fields.headline: Museums give wary cheer to Smith's £1 adult fee plan
fields.trailText: National museums gave a cautious cheer yesterday to an announcement by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, that adult admission fees will be slashed from September 2001.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and Heritage correspondent
fields.body:
National museums gave a cautious cheer yesterday to an announcement by the culture secretary, Chris Smith, that adult admission fees will be slashed from September 2001.

Mr Smith astonished the museum sector by promising that, as long as their trustees agree, adults will pay £1 and people on benefit and the disabled will be admitted free. Children - and since last weekend pensioners - will continue to be admitted free.

The news that "near universal, very cheap admission" has been salvaged from the wreckage of Mr Smith's dream of "universal free admission" came as a complete surprise to many in the sector.

The £1 admission is a device to preserve the ability of museums and galleries to reclaim VAT. Those which do not charge - including the British Museum and the National Gallery - cannot reclaim VAT, because the customs and excise does not regard them as operating a business.

The independent arts charity, the National Art Collections Fund, said yesterday that Mr Smith's proposal ducked this crucial issue. It warned that the proposal might even force free museums and galleries to introduce a low admission charge.

"It seems like good news at first glance, but the more you study it the dodgier it looks," a spokeswoman said. "It is really messy."

While the political argument rages between the government and the museum directors, the effect could be dramatic for visitors. At the moment the Natural History Museum charges £7.50 per adult, the Science Museum £6.95 and the Victoria & Albert Museum £5. A family ticket for two adults and three children at the Science Museum, which cost £23.50 last year before children were admitted free, would fall to £2 a visit.

Mr Smith said that the measure was a big step in increasing access to the national collections.

"I want to see the best of our culture and heritage made available to the greatest possible number, regardless of their income," he said. "Free admission policies for children and the over-60s mean that from this year 23m people in England can enjoy our national collections without charge.

"Today's announcement takes this further. A typical family, for example, will be able to spend a day together enjoying the wonders on display at the Natural History Museum for less than the price of hiring a video. For the first time in 20 years affordable access to the best of our cultural heritage really will be available for the many, not the few."

"It's a surprise, but a very welcome one," Dr Alan Borg, director of the V&A, said. "Subject to two vital reassurances, we're delighted. It's very good news indeed. But we must know that the compensation for reducing admission charges will be adequate, maintained, and index linked, and we need absolute assurance that customs and excise is prepared to allow us to continue to reclaim VAT."

The same note of extreme caution was sounded by the Science Museum, the Natural History Museum and the National Maritime Museum. The latter warned that if the compensation was not ring-fenced, "inflation will inevitably reduce the value in future years, as has happened to our grant-in-aid, leaving us progressively poorer in real terms."

Last month's budget showed that Mr Smith had failed to persuade the Treasury to bankroll universal free admission, or to force a change in the VAT regulations. It is believed that the arguments between the Culture Department and the Treasury continued all last week and into the weekend, after Mr Smith cancelled a proposed announcement last Wednesday.

Maurice Davies, the deputy director of the Museums' Association, said: "I can see loads of problems - but if this works it would mean virtually free admission for most people. Well done Chris Smith."

The museums and galleries proposed for inclusion in yesterday's announcement are: the Science Museum, the Natural History Museum, the V&A, the Theatre Museum, the Wellington Museum, the National Maritime Museum and the Imperial War Museum in London.

Also included are HMS Belfast, the Cabinet War Rooms, Duxford airfield, the Royal Armouries at Fort Nelson, Portsmouth, the Tate St Ives, the Zoological Museum in Hertfordshire and the National Railway Museum, York.

fields.headline: Boy 'spiked by needle at surgery'
fields.trailText: A 13-month-old needed an anti-hepatitis B injection after spiking himself on a used needle that a doctor had thrown carelessly under paperwork on his desk, a General Medical Council professional conduct committee heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A 13-month-old needed an anti-hepatitis B injection after spiking himself on a used needle that a doctor had thrown carelessly under paperwork on his desk, a General Medical Council professional conduct committee heard yesterday.

Inspectors who went to the surgery after Adam Short's mother alerted hospital staff found a dirty surgery with paperwork scattered everywhere, the hearing in London was told.

Alok Kumar Ghosh, from Whitley Bay, Tyne and Wear, is accused of serious professional misconduct for failing to keep his surgery to a minimum acceptable standard, keep proper records and adequately treat several patients.

Adam, who was brought to the surgery on February 5 1997 with a chest infection, spiked his arm with a needle that had been used to vaccinate a previous patient.

His mother, Karen Short, told the hearing that Dr Ghosh had "squirted antiseptic on Adam's arm and applied a plaster. He made no suggestion of doing anything else. When I went home I telephoned the surgery. I told him [Dr Ghosh] that I wasn't happy and he denied that it had happened."

When Adam was admitted to hospital for his chest infection, Mrs Short told doctors about the needle incident, and he was given an injection against hepatitis B.

Ian Spencer, head of primary care and development at Newcastle and North Tyneside health authority, said the surgery "was very much a Heath Robinson arrangement".

The hearing continues.

fields.headline: Heart op girl slightly better
fields.trailText: Sally Slater, the six-year-old who had an emergency heart transplant after being given hours to live, was yesterday in intensive care but showing signs of slight improvement.
fields.body:
Sally Slater, the six-year-old who had an emergency heart transplant after being given hours to live, was yesterday in intensive care but showing signs of slight improvement.

A beacon is burning for her in the tower of St Michael's the Archangel in her village of Malham in North Yorkshire. Father Mark I'Anson said the light would continue to shine until the girl had made a full recovery and was back home: "It can be seen by all the village - we are a close-knit community, and are praying for all the family."

Three weeks ago the girl was struck down by a virus that weakened her heart muscles, leaving her in critical condition. After an appeal across Europe, an unnamed donor was found in the UK, and the girl was given her new heart in a seven-hour operation on Saturday night at the Freeman hospital, Newcastle upon Tyne.

She had undergone major surgery 10 days earlier to be fitted temporarily with a new type of artificial heart, only the sixth in the UK. Leslie Hamilton, the surgeon who fitted the £40,000 plastic heart, said it had never before been used to support someone in order for a donor heart to become available.

Jon and Bridget Slater, both 36, thanked the anonymous donor's family, and said they were taking their daughter's recovery "hour by hour" after being warned of the possibility of infection.

fields.headline: Colleges' £8,000 gender gap
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Universities are breaking the law by paying women lecturers and professors up to £8,000 less than men for doing the same jobs in the same subjects, the lecturers' union Natfhe said yesterday .
fields.body:
Universities are breaking the law by paying women lecturers and professors up to £8,000 less than men for doing the same jobs in the same subjects, the lecturers' union Natfhe said yesterday .

Even in nursing and paramedical studies - where 70% of lecturers are female - male lecturers earn £1,558 more on average, and senior male nursing lecturers earn £1,061 more than women in the equivalent posts. Only at professor level are women in nursing paid more.

Anatomy and physiology departments had an £8,000 difference while there was a £7,000 gap in veterinary science.

Howard Newby, president of the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals, conceded there could be no excuse for the situation and it would be tackled seriously.

Natfhe will present its figures next week to a joint working party of university employers and unions.

"The discrimination is even more widespread and deep-rooted than we thought," said Tom Wilson, head of the union's universities department.

Calling for the universities to tackle the issue, Mr Wilson said: "Either they get dragged in front of tribunals or they take action before they are forced to do so by the courts. The evidence is incontrovertible."

Research also revealed that there are no women professors among permanent staff in civil engineering or central computing.

fields.headline: Mother 'shook child to death'
fields.trailText: A 28-year-old mother who wanted her fifth child fostered killed the 16-month-old by shaking him and hitting his head on a hard surface, Bristol crown court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A 28-year-old mother who wanted her fifth child fostered killed the 16-month-old by shaking him and hitting his head on a hard surface, Bristol crown court was told yesterday.

Elaine Trego, of Weston-super-Mare, Somerset, denies murdering her son, Jacob Rowlands, in February 1999.

The child was taken to hospital after Trego's nine-year-old daughter Melissa alerted neighbours, but doctors could not save him, John Royce QC, prosecuting, said.

Trego told doctors and detectives that Jacob fell on to the floor from a settee, and had convulsions when she shook him to try to revive him.

But Mr Royce said a postmortem showed that Jacob had 12 areas of bruising to his head and face, and bruising on other parts of his body. There was also a build-up of blood around one of his optic nerves and further haemorrhaging under the skull.

"The degree of trauma was greater, according to the doctor, than would have been caused by falling off a settee and on to the floor," he said.

Trego had failed to bond with Jacob from birth and had him fostered until his father, Joe Rowlands, intervened.

"We have a situation here where a mother, who blatantly did not want this child in the first place, was content for it to be fostered after birth," Mr Royce said.

"She called it 'daddy's brat'. She appears to have caused him physical hurt before and for some reason on February 19 she used considerable violence towards him, violent shaking accompanied, it would appear, by a blow to the back of the head caused by an impact with a hard surface.

The case continues.

fields.headline: Snap judgments
fields.standfirst: Hockney photos to test market
fields.trailText: The art world is waiting to see if the market in peripheral products of well-known artists will finally collapse, when prints from a roll of film taken by David Hockney go on sale next week.
fields.body:
The art world is waiting to see if the market in peripheral products of well-known artists will finally collapse, when prints from a roll of film taken by David Hockney go on sale next week.

Everyday pictures of Bridlington, in Yorkshire's East Riding, and of a few of the painter's pals will be auctioned. Last year £11,000 was paid for a grimy set of faxed Hockney works.

The latest examples of peripheral works linked to Hockney met a similar reaction from the artist's family yesterday - though not for quotation, as relatives believe that any comment will only sustain a dubious market. Hockney himself has condemned the way that ephemeral material which he gave away is now being hyped as a potential investment.

When the faxes were auctioned last October he faxed out several similar sets in a vain attempt to undermine the proceedings. The purchaser, the Cumbrian Gallery owner Peter Nelson, said of the grumbles: "They say so much about this artist and his approach to his work."

The latest saleroom frisson centres on one print that shows two friends of the artist, with the image of Hockney and his camera caught in sunlight and reflected in a window. Advance publicity, suggesting bids of thousands of pounds, compares the group to Hockney's painting My Parents and Myself, showing a mirror reflecting the artist between his parents.

Hockney gave the prints to one of the two men in the picture, the art dealer Cavan O'Brian, in an album signed "For Cavan, love David." They will be sold for an unnamed client by the Scarborough auctioneers David Duggleby in a lot which includes digital pictures by the painter of the fashion designers Celia Burtwell and Ozzie Clark with their cat Percy, a trio who were also the subjects of a celebrated Hockney painting.

webTitle: Marquis St Leger 'was just a bloke called Keith'

fields.headline: Marquis St Leger 'was just a bloke called Keith'
fields.trailText: With a family tree apparently dating back to the Norman conquest, the doors to high society would always open to the Marquis St Leger, the 10th Viscount of Donarlie.
fields.body:
With a family tree apparently dating back to the Norman conquest, the doors to high society would always open to the Marquis St Leger, the 10th Viscount of Donarlie.

But, though he mingled in upper crust company by day, Bristol crown court was told how, by night, Marc Philip Justin Onslow Berkeley St Leger Curzon would return to a modest house in Swindon and to a mother who knew him only as Keith.

For 20 years St Leger used his aristocratic alter ego to weave a web of lies, even becoming a member of a committee of Irish peers, according to Don Tait, prosecuting. He was able to open a bank account with Coutts despite having no cash.

But, Mr Tait added, St Leger's pedigree masked a secondary school education in Kent, a humble abode and the humbler moniker of Keith Alfred Andrews.

Mr Tait said the defendant began leading a double life in about 1975, inventing a new family tree for the real St Leger family by taking advantage of a dispute in the line of succession.

He claimed his mother was Joy Chantal Helene de Burgoyne of Paris and Tours and that he had been married to Marie-Louise, daughter of the Duc de Brissac of Paris.

St Leger, who was arrested in 1996, denies a series of frauds, including obtaining jobs with Wiltshire county council and the Salvation Army using false CV details and attempting to secure a mortgage by deception.

He is also accused of trying to obtain by deception credit balances from the estate of the late Ethel St Leger. Further accusations include using his original name to falsely claim £19,405 in benefits.

Mr Tait said: "Twenty years ago not only did this man adopt a different name he also adopted a completely different personality and alter ego. Since that time these two personae have been running in tandem."

The case continues today.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: £5,000 reward for Enigma
fields.body:
£5,000 reward for Enigma

A £5,000 reward was offered yesterday for information leading to the return of a rare Enigma encoding machine used by the Germans to send top secret messages during the second world war. The machine, one of only three left in the world, was stolen from a glass cabinet in Bletchley Park in Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire.

Christine Large, director of the Bletchley Park Trust, said that the museum and police would declare an amnesty if the machine was stolen by amateurs who wanted to return it. "Our priority is get the machine back in good condition."

Man gets life for rape, murder

A man who raped and stabbed to death a former schoolfriend of his wife and then tried to cut up her body before dumping it in a wheelie bin was jailed for life at Teesside crown court yesterday. Graham Wilson, 25, of Grangetown, Middlesbrough, had admitted murdering Amanda Jane Fulcher, 21, a waitress, after persuading her to go to the house of a friend, Steven Staton, 20, who was jailed for six years for helping dispose of the body.

Teacher in lay-by row quits

A teacher who left a nine-year-old boy with learning difficulties in a lay-by three miles from his home after he had been misbehaving in a car while returning from an outing has resigned ahead of a disciplinary hearing, it was disclosed yesterday. Michael Roos, who left East Ayrshire council on Friday, had been recommended for dismissal.

Slight fall in dome visits

The number of visitors to the Millennium Dome fell slightly last month to 556,308 against 569,538 in February. It included 81,167 pupils on free school trips and contained the highest single one-day attendance so far, 27,224 on March 25.

Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, chief executive of the New Millennium Experience Company, said: "I am very satisfied with the figures for March. February's figures were boosted by huge numbers during half-term."

Inmate found in pool of blood

Police were last night investigating a murder after the body of an inmate was found in a pool of blood at his cell in Cardiff prison. His liver and an eyeball were found alongside his body.

Colin Bloomfield, 35, from Newport, south Wales, was jailed for six months this month for child neglect and was being kept on the vulnerable prisoner unit. A 28-year-old inmate was arrested.

fields.headline: Sir Robert Sainsbury dies at 93
fields.trailText: Sir Robert Sainsbury has died at 93 following a short illness. He joined J Sainsbury Ltd in 1930, and was made joint president of the supermarket chain in 1969.
fields.body:
Sir Robert Sainsbury has died at 93 following a short illness. He joined J Sainsbury Ltd in 1930, and was made joint president of the supermarket chain in 1969.

Devoted to the arts, he lived a life of quiet benefaction. He and his wife Lisa founded the Sainsbury centre for visual arts, designed by Norman Foster and opened in 1978, at the University of East Anglia, near Norwich. They donated their collection of works by Epstein, Moore, Picasso, Modigliani, Bonnard and Rouault to UEA in 1973. He served on the Arts Council and at the Courtauld Institute, and was a trustee of the Tate. He was knighted in 1967 for services to the arts.

He is survived by his wife and children David, Celia and Annabel. Last night the latter said: "He was a marvellous father and did an awful lot for other people. As well as help build up the chain as it is today, he helped young artists and did much for the arts generally."

webTitle: Rapist seen by CCTV jailed for life

fields.headline: Rapist seen by CCTV jailed for life
fields.trailText: A man was jailed for life yesterday for a rape which happened hours after he was released from jail where he had served a six-year sentence for rape.
fields.body:
A man was jailed for life yesterday for a rape which happened hours after he was released from jail where he had served a six-year sentence for rape.

Kevin Chambers, 36, was found guilty at Ipswich crown court of two counts of rape after his attack on a 19-year-old woman was caught on security cameras in Ipswich.

Judge Nicholas Beddard described the two attacks on the woman as "particularly brutal offences" and ordered Chambers, of Colchester, to serve at least 12 years.

Chambers attacked the woman on September 8 in an underpass in the town centre within sight of closed circuit television cameras. A CCTV operator monitoring the cameras immediately alerted police and tracked Chambers through the streets as he left the scene.

His victim picked him out in an identity parade, and evidence against him was given by a facial analysis expert who linked him to the man shown on the CCTV footage.

fields.headline: Strong feelings
fields.standfirst: Storm in a cowshed over 'Elizabethan' gardens
fields.trailText: The restored gardens of a centuries-old Welsh country house attracted tens of thousands of visitors in their first season and have been lauded by tourism and heritage bodies alike.
fields.body:
The restored gardens of a centuries-old Welsh country house attracted tens of thousands of visitors in their first season and have been lauded by tourism and heritage bodies alike.

But now they have become the subject of an archaeological row after being damned as "absolute rubbish" by Sir Roy Strong, the historian and a former director of the Victoria and Albert museum.

His public attack on the claims that Aberglasney gardens, in Towy valley, Carmarthenshire, contain the only surviving Elizabethan cloister garden in Britain has infuriated members of the restoration trust who accuse Sir Roy of "bad scholarship and worse speculation".

The former Victoria and Albert director, and the garden archaeologist Stephen Briggs, argue that what was discovered in the eight-acre grounds of the mansion was a series of cowsheds surrounding a former muckyard and vegetable patch from a later period.

"Anybody with any knowledge of garden archaeology has known for some time that the claims about Aberglasney are not true," Sir Roy said. "It was being billed as a kind of Welsh response to the most wonderful gardens of London in the early 17th century and it's absolute rubbish."

William Wilkins, the driving force behind the £3.5m restoration project, said Sir Roy had no serious basis for making such remarks. He had not talked to the project's archaeologist, Kevin Blockley, or looked at the archaeological evidence unearthed during excavations at Aberglasney.

"My assumption is that he is so London-based that he simply does not know what happened in west Wales in the 16th and 17th centuries. And of course he is not an archaeologist. All one can do is laugh at their suggestion."

Mr Blockely, who has dismissed Sir Roy's suggestions as "twaddle", said that the earliest features found during excavations of the garden were gullies containing 16th century pottery.

These, along with a 13th century penny and fragments of masonry elsewhere in the grounds, showed Aberglasney was occupied before the garden and parapet walks were constructed.

Aberglasney opened to the public last July and attracted more than 30,000 visitors in four months. It reopened this week.

Set on a west facing slope at Llangathen, the eight acre gardens consist of a series of rectilinear compartments separated by stone arcades or retaining walls and standing one above another on the hillside.

Their most celebrated surviving feature is a tunnel formed from a line of ancient yew trees (pictured above). The house to which the gardens belong dates back to around 1450.

The heritage lottery fund, which has contributed £750,000 in grants towards the restoration, declined to comment on Sir Roy's observations. "That is his opinion. We don't want to get into some kind of slanging match," said a spokeswoman. "We took very careful expert advice on this project."

The Welsh tourist board, which injected £50,000 into the scheme, said the gardens had been an important boost to tourism in west Wales.

webTitle: Exam boards 'must do better' on query delays

fields.headline: Exam boards 'must do better' on query delays
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Two of the top three exam boards were admonished yesterday for delay in handling appeals from schools and colleges querying students' GCSE and A-level results. Nick Tate, the government's chief exam regulator, said Edexcel and OCR "must substantially improve the service".
fields.body:
Two of the top three exam boards were admonished yesterday for delay in handling appeals from schools and colleges querying students' GCSE and A-level results. Nick Tate, the government's chief exam regulator, said Edexcel and OCR "must substantially improve the service".

His warning came after the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority published the first league tables of the boards' performance. It found that Edexcel failed to complete 35% of emergency requests for the remarking of A-level scripts within the agreed target of 30 days, and OCR failed on 46%.

The delays after publication of A-level results last summer could have disadvantaged students whose university places depended on disputed grades. "We will be monitoring closely to ensure measures are put in place to serve candidates better this year," said Dr Tate, the authority's chief executive.

His analysis followed complaints by heads of independent schools that the extent of exam board error was a national scandal. The Headmasters and Headmistresses Conference said 16% of independent school entries got results worse than expected and 4% were seriously worse.

The authority said the boards regraded 2,960 GCSE papers last summer after 10,300 inquiries out of more than 5m entries. At A-level, out of 790,000 entries, candidates made 22,983 inquiries; 3,476 received a grade change.

OCR commented: "Only 1% of our results were queried, down by one-third on 1998. We realise we have not handled this small number as rapidly as we could have, and we plan to improve this year."

webTitle: Briton held in South America drug swoop

fields.headline: Briton held in South America drug swoop
fields.standfirst: Grandmother accused over airport cocaine haul
fields.trailText: A British grandmother could be facing a jail term in South America after being arrested while allegedly carrying about £500,000 worth of cocaine at an airport on the holiday island of Margarita.
fields.body:
A British grandmother could be facing a jail term in South America after being arrested while allegedly carrying about £500,000 worth of cocaine at an airport on the holiday island of Margarita.

Irene Campbell, 53, a social worker from Glasgow, is being detained in prison on the Venezuelan island while authorities decide if they will prosecute her.

She was arrested last Wednesday, allegedly with 8kg of the drug, as she tried to board her flight home at the end of a two-week holiday.

Her family found out about the arrest when the Foreign Office contacted them.

A spokeswoman for the Foreign Office said Mrs Campbell had been visited by an honorary consul on the island and was doing as well as could be expected.

"We have given her a list of local lawyers, and the next stage will be bringing the case to trial, if the public prosecutor decides to prosecute," said the spokeswoman. "The process could take a few months, but it is very hard to tell at this early stage."

Mrs Campbell is divorced and has four daughters, a son, and eight grandchildren. Family members at her home on the Pollock estate in Glasgow refused to comment yesterday.

But friends have told a Scottish tabloid newspaper they are certain that Mrs Campbell must have been duped if she was found with drugs on her.

Neighbours said they were shocked by the news. One woman, who asked not to be named, said: "They have only just moved in really and seem very nice."

Mrs Campbell had been due to return to work at Glasgow city council's Shawbridge children project today. The council had not been contacted over her arrest, a spokesman said. None of her colleagues was prepared to comment.

Much of the cocaine grown in South America is exported through Venezuela, where the drug industry is reported to be the country's second largest after oil.

Stephen Jakobi, of the campaign group Fair Trials Abroad, criticised the justice system in Venezuela.

"We have seen 200 judges dismissed for corruption," he said. "It is a system that does not work properly. The situation on a judicial level is desperately bleak.

She was arrested last Wednesday, allegedly with 8kg of the drug, as she tried to board her flight home at the end of a two-week holiday. Her family found out about the arrest when the Foreign Office contacted them. "The process could take a few months, but it is very hard to tell at this early stage." Mrs Campbell is divorced and has four daughters, a son, and eight grandchildren. webTitle: I've never dabbled in drugs and drink, star chef tells libel jury

fields.headline: I've never dabbled in drugs and drink, star chef tells libel jury
fields.trailText: Millionaire chef Marco Pierre White yesterday told a high court libel jury that he had never taken drugs and rarely drank, despite claims in two American newspapers that he had had a "well-publicised bout with drugs and alcohol"
fields.body:
Millionaire chef Marco Pierre White yesterday told a high court libel jury that he had never taken drugs and rarely drank, despite claims in two American newspapers that he had had a "well-publicised bout with drugs and alcohol"

Mr White is claiming libel damages for an article published in both the New York Times and the International Herald Tribune, which are contesting the case and claim the article had caused no damage and had even "enchanced" the chef's reputation.

His counsel, George Carman QC, said the celebrity restaurateur was "shocked and very, very upset and angry" when he read the accusations two years ago and had been "distressed" by private investigators hired by the newspapers to "dig up dirt" on him.

Mr White, 38, waited to give evidence in the London court room with his Spanish fiancee, Mati Conejero, and fellow chef Gordon Ramsay, as Mr Carman outlined his case to the jury and Mr Justice Morland.

The court heard that the chef was a dyslexic school drop-out from a Leeds council estate who had arrived in London at the age of 19 with only £7.36 in his pocket but had worked up to 18 hours a day, six or seven days a week for many years to win his first Michelin star in 1988.

Mr Carman said: "He is probably the most outstanding and distinguished restaurateur and chef this country has produced in the last 25 years."

Although starting from "the most humble beginnings in life", the chef had had a "glittering career" through "a combination of immense talent, virtually unremitting hard work, ambition and complete passion", Mr Carman told the court. He said Mr White was the youngest chef to obtain three Michelin stars in 1995, and he was in addition the "only Englishman to be so honoured in the entire gastronomic world".

The court heard that the "bombshell" sentence in the otherwise favourable article published in May 1998 by American journalist, Florence Fabricant, claimed that "beneath Mr White's rock star veneer, including a well publicised bout with drugs and alcohol, lies a very savvy and rich businessman".

Mr Carman said: "That statement is not only untrue and totally false, but it is accepted by these two newspapers to be false and completely untrue."

Mr White said he had never taken drugs and "very, very rarely" drank an occasional glass of wine, but never spirits.

His mother had died when he was six, he said, and he believed that his father was an alcoholic, adding: "I saw the destruction it caused in the family."

The father of three also said he had concerns about his young children getting involved with drugs.

"I object to drugs. It's something that I totally disapprove of," he added.

Under cross-examination by George Robertson QC, for the defence, Mr White denied he was rich or lived "a rock star's life style".

Earlier, Mr Carman said that Ms Fabricant's reference to drink and drugs was based on an "ambigious passage" in Mr White's autobiography.

Despite immediate requests for a retraction and apology from Mr White's solicitors, the New York Times went on to syndicate the article to the International Herald Tribune.

He said the chef had felt harassed by the newspapers which, the court heard, had hired private investigators to "dig" into his background to get any "dirt" on him - any stories of "sex and drugs and rock and roll".

Shortly before the trial, the court heard, the newspapers withdrew their defence of justification and now relied on the argument that the article did not lower Mr White's reputation and was in fact "very positive" about him.

They had, Mr Carman said, accused Mr White of being "greedy" in seeking "large" damages.

The case continues.

webTitle: Mon dieu, Marianne accused of betrayal

fields.headline: Mon dieu, Marianne accused of betrayal
fields.trailText: Her father insisted it was a storm in a very British teacup. But it was a veritable tempest that shook France yesterday as the elected emblem of the republic, the 21 year old supermodel Laetitia Casta, was accused of taking up residence in London to escape French taxes.
fields.body:
Her father insisted it was a storm in a very British teacup. But it was a veritable tempest that shook France yesterday as the elected emblem of the republic, the 21 year old supermodel Laetitia Casta, was accused of taking up residence in London to escape French taxes.

So upset was the interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, that he went on national television to justify France's high tax levels by pointing out exactly what French citizens could expect to get for their money - and what British residents could not.

"Laetitia Casta will find out very fast that the price of property in London is very high, that you have to pay twice as much in rent," he said. "If she gets ill, the healthcare in a British hospital will be far short of French hospitals. And if she takes the metro she will realise that the London metro is nothing like the quality of the Paris Metro."

While politicians on the right seized on the departure of Ms Casta, who lends her body to the American lingerie firm Victoria's Secret and her face to the French cosmetics company L'Oreal, as "a magnificent symbol of the failure of socialism", those on the left accused her of betraying France.

"Laetitia Casta has stuck two fingers up at the republic," complained Noel Mamère, a Green MP. Philippe Séguin, a conservative grandee and leading candidate in the Paris mayoral race, said simply that "a Marianne who quits France, that's really very, very unfortunate. For fiscal reasons, it appears we're now living through a third great French exodus to England."

Ms Casta, who is estimated to earn £2m a year, would cut her tax bill by 30-40% by living in England. However her father, Dominique, insisted the whole story was a fabrication. "My daughter is French, proud to be French, and will stay French," he said. "I've never heard such rubbish. She has rented an apartment near Trafalgar Square for the past three years because she needs it for work there. She has bought the house of her dreams, and it's here in Corsica."

But there was no doubting the fury of the Association of French Mayors, which last October overwhelmingly chose Ms Casta as the model for the millennium Marianne, the bare-breasted symbol of republican virtues.

Succeeding Catherine Deneuve and Brigitte Bardot, a bust of Ms Casta will soon adorn town halls around the country.

The association's president, Jean-Paul Delevoye, said he was shocked by the defection. "All we can say is that we hope everyone who has been formed in France, supported by France, educated in France, will also decide to pay their taxes in France," he added.

But amid all the outrage, few bothered to note that Ms Casta is among an estimated 150,000 French people who have moved to Britain since 1995 - businessmen wooed by less red tape; or ambitious graduates drawn by Britain's headline rates of income tax which are the lowest in the EU after Spain and Portugal.

While opinion on the Paris streets was evenly divided between "good for her" and "spoilt brat", French commentators, including Pierre Georges in Le Monde, wondered why - apart from the money - any sensible French person would move. "The health system's a disaster, the trains are barely any better, the workers in the car industry despair of the Labour movement and the poor are paid peanuts," he said. "England is an exquisite paradise indeed."

Capital costs: A tale of two cities

London

Accommodation The average monthly rental for a one bedroom furnished flat is £950. The London Housing Federation says that to be able to buy an average priced property in the capital you would have to earn about £50,000pa.

Transport A one-day travelcard (zones 1-4) costs £4.10. Tube trains should run every 2 minutes at peak times but add on at least 15 minutes to your journey to allow for broken escalators and delays. Overcrowding and poor ventilation are two of the many problems.

Health care There are 58 NHS trusts in greater London and public health is still free. Maximum waiting time is 18 months, but 50% have their operation in three months and a further 44% in under 12 months. More than 75 per cent of out-patients are seen within three months. With a £6bn injection of cash, many London hospitals are being revamped.

Prices Loaf of bread 90p; cup of coffee £2.10 (large cappuccino); bottle of supermarket table wine £3.98; daily newspaper 45p; three-course dinner for four at top restaurant £240

Paris

Accommodation The average monthly rental for a one bedroom apartment in a residential area is 6,500 francs (£594.70), although most Parisians pay 100 francs per square metre per month. Roughly speaking a week in London costs the same as a month in Paris

Transport A one-day mobilis card for central Paris is 30 francs (£2.74) and a carnet of 10 tickets costs 55 francs (£5.03). The Paris Metro is generally regarded as one of Europe's cleanest, quickest and most reliable public transport services

Health care The French government refund up to 70% of medical costs but the French pay between 23% and 25% of their monthly salary in social security. There are 17 public hospitals in greater Paris plus numerous private clinics where patients will be reimbursed

Prices Loaf of bread £1.75; cup of coffee £2.07; bottle of table wine £2.94; daily newspaper 64p; three-course dinner for four at top restaurant £440

Sally James

webTitle: Shows get top billing in BBC revolution

fields.headline: Shows get top billing in BBC revolution
fields.standfirst:
Dyke's mission: Hundreds of jobs to go as director general begins mission to sweep away management culture

The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke, the director general of the BBC, began his mission to reinvigorate the corporation yesterday by sweeping away the hated management culture fostered by his predecessor, Lord Birt, and directing more cash to programme-makers instead.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke, the director general of the BBC, began his mission to reinvigorate the corporation yesterday by sweeping away the hated management culture fostered by his predecessor, Lord Birt, and directing more cash to programme-makers instead.

Executives will be stripped of their perks and the "internal market" will begin to fall away as Mr Dyke rolls back the Birtian era. Hundreds of staff whose jobs become redundant will be sacked, but Mr Dyke said he wanted those who remain to be inspired by their work and determined to do their best.

"If you want to get and keep the most talented people, then you want an organisation that is happy with itself," he explained.

Some staff were left bewildered at the rapid changes. Hundreds worried about their future while many more wondered for whom they now worked.

Speaking to senior staff in London, Mr Dyke said that the BBC would spend at least £100m more on programmes this year. Efficiency savings and the agreed increase in the licence fee will generate an extra £200m a year from 2001, and the money spent on bureaucracy would fall from 24% of the total income to 15% in five years.

Cash will be ploughed into drama and entertainment - currently areas of weakness - but there will be no more money for expensive sports events such as Premiership football. Neglected areas such as local radio will benefit from more investment.

There will be "more leadership and less management", Mr Dyke said. The number of "trading divisions" in the BBC's internal market, identified by Mr Dyke as a source of profound malaise, will fall from 190 to 50. "Our aim is to create one BBC, where people enjoy their job and are inspired and united behind the common purpose of making great programmes and delivering outstanding services."

Central to Mr Dyke's reforms is a determination to bring programme-makers closer to the decision-making process. He has abolished a layer of managers at the very top of the organisation, and positioned himself at the head of a new executive committee with 17 directors responsible for different areas of the BBC. Of these, nine will be responsible for programmes, four more than at present.

Alan Yentob, currently the director of television, becomes director of drama, entertainment and children's programmes. He will take charge of a new film unit modelled on the successful Film Four arm of Channel 4.

While Mr Yentob's new job appears to be a demotion, he stressed that it puts him at the heart of the BBC's creative process. Previously, his position was regarded as ill-defined and sometimes irrelevant. Mr Dyke said Mr Yentob would act as as his "creative director".

Mark Thompson, who currently oversees the BBC divisions in Scotland, Wales, Northern Ireland and the English regions, takes on the post of director of television. Although Mr Dyke said he had no plans to appoint a deputy, Mr Thompson effectively becomes his number two.

Mr Dyke also said he was looking for a director of sport who would consider whether to launch a commercial sports channel to compete with Sky for expensive sports rights such as Premiership football.

Mr Dyke stressed he would not waste money on terrestrial television rights that the corporation could not afford. "We cannot justify taking vast amounts of money from licence fee payers and giving it to footballers," he said.

The new structure took effect immediately, which left many staff reeling. "Lots of people in the production empire suddenly don't know who their boss is or what their job is," one said.

Others welcomed the reform of the internal market. Staff were also pleased with the announcement that different divisions of the BBC, such as drama and the regions would get guaranteed airtime "quotas".

Gerry Morrissey, of the technicians' union Bectu, said he welcomed the "broad thrust" of what Mr Dyke said. "More money is going into programmes, which can only be good."

A spokesman for the Department of Culture said: "The government challenged the BBC to increase its efficiency and effectiveness as part of the new funding settlement. It's good to see the BBC responding to that challenge. The government also welcomes the substantial shift proposed away from administration and into programming."

webTitle: Poultry bug still active, warns agency

fields.headline: Poultry bug still active, warns agency
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Up to 30% of chickens on supermarket shelves and in butchers may still carry the salmonella bug, the new food standards agency said yesterday.
fields.body:
Up to 30% of chickens on supermarket shelves and in butchers may still carry the salmonella bug, the new food standards agency said yesterday.

The chairman, Sir John Krebs, said contamination levels must be cut by half within five years as officials appeared to question some supermarkets' claims to have reduced salmonella to single figure levels.

He also said butchers faced compulsory licensing from the autumn and must pay annual inspection fees of £100 a year - a move likely to send shivers through the rest of the food industry, which has resisted paying extra hygiene costs.

Sir John wanted the whole industry to accept the need for better training in food handling. He would be prepared to "name and shame" companies which failed to meet new standards on hygiene and labelling.

There would be reviews of "confusing or even meaningless" food claims such as "country-style", and "85% fat free" as well as anti-BSE measures and further consideration of whether labelling of GM foods could be improved in ways that were "feasible and enforceable."

The continuing high levels of contamination were revealed by the agency's chief executive Geoffrey Podger who said salmonella appeared to remain in 20% to 30% of chicken on sale.

Britons eat nearly 800m chickens a year. Although reported salmonella poisoning cases from all types of the bug have dropped from a peak of 32,596 cases in 1997 to an estimated 17,251 last year, these are thought to represent the tip of the iceberg. But Sainsbury's and Tesco yesterday insisted their own checks revealed salmonella in less than 10% of their chickens.

About 7,400 of the country's 12,000 butchers have gained licences under a voluntary scheme.

The new charges represented a levy by the back door, said Graham Bidston, chief executive of the National Federation of Meat and Food Traders.

webTitle: Green peer 'blamed farmer for GM protest'

fields.headline: Green peer 'blamed farmer for GM protest'
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Melchett told a Norfolk farmer that he "only had himself to blame" when the hereditary peer and 27 fellow members of Greenpeace pulled up his field of genetically-modified maize, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Lord Melchett told a Norfolk farmer that he "only had himself to blame" when the hereditary peer and 27 fellow members of Greenpeace pulled up his field of genetically-modified maize, a court heard yesterday.

The Old Etonian and executive director of Greenpeace allegedly also told William Brigham that his £1,800 crop was being uprooted because he had failed to attend a meeting calling for its destruction 16 days earlier in the nearby village of Lyng.

Mr Brigham told the court that the peer had written to him after the meeting, claiming he was following local people's wishes, although the farmer could recognise no one from the village of 750 where he had lived all his life and where his family had farmed for 400 years.

The confrontation between the aristocrat and the arable and dairy farmer came shortly after 5am on July 26 last year. Mr Brigham, the chair of Lyng parish council, told the court he had learned that Green peace activists, accompanied by the media, had broken into the six-acre field at his 800-acre Walnut Tree farm and were beginning to rip up his just-flowering crop of GM maize. Driving down to the site, he saw the protesters in white overalls emblazoned with Greenpeace, rip out the crop, attack it with strimmers and a tractor, and place it, bagged up, in a truck.

After clambering over a gate they had locked and telling activists to stop, Mr Brigham approached Lord Melchett, 52.

"I said he should be ashamed of himself, and told him to stop and stop his fellow conspirators from carrying out what appeared to be a giant publicity stunt," the farmer told Norwich crown court.

"He said I only had myself to blame because I didn't attend the meeting in Lyng."

Lord Melchett and 27 others were accused of ripping up and stealing £750-worth of genetically-modified, herbicide-tolerant maize belonging to the biotechnology company AgrEvo, and planted at one of seven sites across the country in a four-year £3.3m trial.

The environmentalists, from as far afield as Edinburgh, Leeds and Aberdeen, and including a vicar and beauty therapist as well as Lord Melchett, a former Northern Ireland minister, all pleaded not guilty to theft and causing criminal damage.

They will argue their actions were justified because they acted to prevent serious damage to other crops and the environment by genetic pollution from the GM maize pollen.

The trial, at which the defendants were so numerous they flooded out of the dock, overspilling into the public gallery, is the first in Britain in which jurors will be asked to grapple with the controversial issue of genetically-modified crops.

But, before the case began, the judge warned them they were not there to deliver a moral or political verdict. Addressing the six men and six women, Judge Mellor said: "You may have guessed that this is the GM trial.

"Not the Archer's one [a reference to the similar trial of Tommy Archer in the long- running Radio 4 soap opera] but the real one. You can tell it it's the real one, because you won't be paid Equity rates."

He told them that, in an area as rural as Norwich, it would be surprising if none of the 12 was either an ardent supporter of the environment or involved in agriculture. But he warned them to put their prejudices aside: "It is not about whether GM crops are a good thing or a bad thing."

It was "a criminal trial ... neither a political debate nor a scientific debate," added John Farmer, prosecuting.

The court also heard from Judith Jordan, the AgrEvo manager responsible for the site, who admitted her company had carried out no checks for contamination on a control field of maize 200 metres away.

The case continues.

fields.headline: Life jail for 'motiveless' double killing
fields.trailText: A former salesman who claimed to be "the friendly face of home shopping" was yesterday given two life sentences for the murder of a dog breeder and her mother.
fields.body:
A former salesman who claimed to be "the friendly face of home shopping" was yesterday given two life sentences for the murder of a dog breeder and her mother.

Kevin Cotterell used the slogan while visiting homes across Norfolk and Cambridgeshire for a kitchenware firm, Kleeneze, before his apparently motiveless killing of the two women.

Janice Sheridan, 45, was found by neighbours stabbed once in the back, twice in the neck, and six times in the chest.

Her mother, Connie, 79, died on a sofa a few feet away with eight stab wounds to her chest, one to her stomach and one to her forearm.

At Norwich crown court yesterday, Cotterell, 33, switched his not guilty plea and admitted killing the pair at their cottage in Upwell, Norfolk. He refused to explain why he committed the murders.

Afterwards, Miss Sheridan's half-sister, Diana Penfold, who lives in Wisbech, Cambridgeshire, said she was "devastated" at Cotterell's guilty plea."We we just want to know why. We were hoping that we might get some answers during the trial but we still don't know."

Detectives suspect Cotterell killed the women and then spent the night with their bodies.

Detective Inspector Paul Chapman, who led the investigation, said: "He is clearly wicked and evil beyond belief."

Cotterell, of Pentney, Norfolk, had previous convictions for burglaries - one of which involved an indecent act - for which he was given 12 months probation in 1983.

Detectives were last night trying to establish whether he could be linked to other murders or sex crimes during the past two decades.

Det Insp Chapman said: "The view of the psychological profiler that we used is that it is very strange for anyone to progress from burglary to murder in the way that Cotterell has."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
If Romola Christopherson, once a top civil servant, aims to dispel the hoary old myths about The Whitehall Village (8.0pm, Radio 4) she had better get her act together in later instalments. This opening dissection of the modern civil service claims that Sir Humphrey babbles o' green fields, but her interviews hardly sustain the claim that his end is nigh. Instead they still portray a service highly efficient at plugging holes in the dyke but sluggish about designing a better dam.

Science correspondent Sue Nelson, who expects her first child in September, gets a splendid opportunity to quiz experts about its likely development. Baby Brain (9.0pm, Radio 4) asks how the 100 bil lion neurons its brain has acquired in the womb will hook up to one another in its first year of life. Can a pregnant woman improve a child's prospects through planned sensory stimuli before birth, as some claim, or will nature just carry on as ever?

fields.headline: The real Mohamed
fields.standfirst:
Charles Wardle The Tory MP who rejected Fayed's passport application explains why he now works for him


Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Last summer when Mohamed Al Fayed suggested I join the board of Harrods as a non-executive director to help develop some of his international businesses, I liked the challenge immediately. I told the parliamentary commissioner for standards of Fayed's approach and she asked me to report again if a firm offer was accepted.
fields.body:
Last summer when Mohamed Al Fayed suggested I join the board of Harrods as a non-executive director to help develop some of his international businesses, I liked the challenge immediately. I told the parliamentary commissioner for standards of Fayed's approach and she asked me to report again if a firm offer was accepted.

Fayed deals with top lawyers, bankers and accountants, many of the world's glitterati, even heads of state. But I asked myself what the reaction would be to his appointment to the board of Harrods of an MP after the cash for questions controversy. In 17 years in the house, I can safely say I have never asked parliamentary questions at anyone's behest. Why should I be put off by the shoddy behaviour of a few shameless parliamentary colleagues who asked for, received and then failed to register the cash for questions they had assured Fayed was legitimate lobbying?

Our negotiations proceeded and, on March 1, I signed an agreement to work for Harrods at Knightsbridge as well as in five areas of overseas business - oil and gas and mining in Asia, e-commerce and satellite mapping in the United States and international banking. On March 2, I gave the parliamentary commissioner for standards a copy of my contract, which stipulates among other things that I will not be required or requested to promote, ask questions, make speeches, lobby or represent in parliament in any way Mohamed Al Fayed's private or business interests or those of his family.

I know the Fayeds' background better than most people. In 1993 when I was at the Home Office, I turned down a Fayed application for British citizenship on the basis of a DTI report labelling the Fayeds scoundrels. After that, Mohamed Al Fayed insulted me at every opportunity for the next two years and with the benefit of hindsight I can hardly blame him. I was later to discover from my own research, which Fayed and his lawyers knew absolutely nothing about, that the DTI report was the result of a ruthlessly vindictive smear campaign by the late Tiny Rowland. I told parliament about the distortions and inconsistencies in the DTI report, but the press continued to quote it whenever they needed anti-Fayed ammunition, knowing they were safe from libel.

Only last week I came across a typical example of media myth. Two newspapers have previously reported at some length, and in sensational terms, allegations that Fayed improperly influenced police officers to either arrest or at least interview former employees with whom he had had disagreements. These allegations in the press also formed the basis of much of the cross-examination of Fayed during the Hamilton trial. That cross-examination was itself widely reported in the press. I have now seen a letter from the complaints investigation bureau which says that after thorough investigation there is no evidence whatsoever to support the newspaper allega tions. Equally shocking is the revelation that the police had reached this conclusion before the Hamilton trial began but did not communicate that decision until after it had finished.

In spite of the war-zone atmosphere, I like what I have seen. The management of the Knightsbridge store is first class. And in the executive suite, Mohamed Al Fayed works closely with a small trusted in-house team capable of saying no as well as yes. Having run businesses myself for over 30 years and being an unapologetically managerial politician who prefers to speak out to try to change things rather than to play the tediously ambitious role of political chameleon, I find the challenges at Harrods stimulating.

To doubters I offer these observations: the Fayeds' private business empire is much more substantial and extensive than is generally reported in the UK's financial pages, colour supplements and gossip columns. The facts are to be found in audited accounts, due diligence reports and professional valuations.

The infamous DTI report which Tiny Rowland's men stole and Rowland published in the Sunday newspaper he then owned was a stitch-up. Al Fayed's relationship with the British government in the mid-1980s slid from that of favoured investor welcomed at Number 10 to hounded suspect because Rowland, enraged at losing the House of Fraser to the Fayeds, threatened to expose Mark Thatcher's activities in the Middle East ahead of the 1987 general election. Thus the DTI inquiry was launched on spurious grounds, took false evidence and drew misleading conclusions.

So obvious had the falsehoods of the DTI report become by the mid-1990s that the Home Office eventually decided to set the report aside from their deliberations about the Fayeds' renewed claim for citizenship. That did not deter malicious voices in the media from continuing to quote from the report to fuel their hatred of the Fayeds.

I n August 1997 the terrible car crash in Paris pitched Mohamed Al Fayed into a bitter conflict with the British establishment that will not be resolved until there is a comprehensive account of many still unexplained aspects of the tragedy. One does not have to subscribe to conspiracy theories about the death of the mother of the future king of England to appreciate that the Paris inquiry left many vital questions unanswered. I shall mention just a few.

How could the blood test that was so discredited by serious medical commentators in the US, Britain and elsewhere in Europe be taken seriously as evidence that the driver was drunk? CCTV showed him sober. Why did the ambulance take one hour and 43 minutes to travel 3.8 miles to a small hospital run by nuns, passing at least three major hospitals with functioning accident and emergency units on the way? Why did the French police drop their search for a Fiat Uno proven by paint samples to have col lided in the tunnel with the Mercedes? Did British officials intervene at the autopsy as the respected American investigative journalist Gerald Posner claims they did? Why did the British security service deny their own presence in Paris when two of their senior officers answered telephone calls in the British embassy at the time? If parliament refuses to inquire into these and other key questions and damaging factual evidence trickles out later, we shall be seen to have failed in our responsibilities.

Most people in this country have made up their minds about Mohamed Al Fayed, Dodi and Diana, and the fatal car crash. Anti-Fayed media onslaughts do not seem to budge their scepticism about what happened. Yet a few very senior journalists, a handful of Metropolitan police officers with known links to the security service and a motley band of political ankle-biters together form the immovable object opposed to Mohamed Al Fayed's unstoppable force.

Two newspaper editors dining in early 1997 swore they would have Fayed out of the country by the end of that year. How wrong they were. What do they fear? I am not a betting man, but if I were, I should say that ultimately salaried editors, an increasingly ragged security service and today's soft-centred establishment will prove no match for the determination of a very angry, rich man, who will leave no stone unturned to get at the truth and has not the slightest interest in middle-class pretensions. I like him.

Charles Wardle is the Conservative MP for Bexhill and Battle

webTitle: Tory MP accepts £120,000 contract from Fayed

fields.headline: Tory MP accepts £120,000 contract from Fayed
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: A former minister last night shocked fellow Conservative MPs by revealing that he had accepted a £120,000-a-year directorship from Mohamed Al Fayed, the man whose allegations of political sleaze helped destroy the government of John Major.
fields.body:
A former minister last night shocked fellow Conservative MPs by revealing that he had accepted a £120,000-a-year directorship from Mohamed Al Fayed, the man whose allegations of political sleaze helped destroy the government of John Major.

Charles Wardle, the 60-year-old MP for Bexhill and Battle, admitted that some of his party colleagues "loathe" Mr Fayed and "are furious with him for exposing the wrongdoing of corrupt cronies".

But the offence Mr Wardle may give Tory supporters of the disgraced former MPs, Jonathan Aitken and Neil Hamilton, is today compounded by his defence of the Harrods proprietor in an article in the Guardian.

Ironically, Mr Wardle, a Harvard Business School graduate involved in many companies over the years, was the junior Home Office minister who rejected Mr Fayed's requests for a British passport in 1993 - on the basis of a Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) report, which subsequently he declared flawed and unfair.

The move, which will see the MP almost triple his parliamentary salary for two days work a week, as a non-executive director of the Harrods board, has been cleared with the Tory whips office, with Mr Wardle's local party activists, and with Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards.

But today's Guardian article is certain to raise hackles, mainly on the right wing of the Conservative party where members still believe their colleagues were the victims of a vindictive conspiracy between the media and the Harrods boss, who has since been denied a UK passport by the home secretary.

Not only does Mr Wardle insist Mr Fayed's private business activities are both more extensive than supposed and free of taint, he says: "In spite of the war zone atmosphere, I like what I have seen."

The MP even says that the French inquiry into the deaths of Princess Diana and Mr Fayed's son, Dodi, "left many vital questions unanswered". He writes - describing himself as a "diehard monarchist" - that the Duke of Edinburgh's description of Mr Fayed senior as "the son of a Bedouin camel driver" prompted the Harrods proprietor to make his celebrated outburst against the duke, blaming him for the princess's death.

"In America, Asia, even France where he holds the Legion d'Honneur, al Fayed does not suffer the media prejudice which exists here. Ordinary public opinion in this country is sympathetic to him. It reflects genuine doubts about the Paris tragedy, understands his anguish and likes his irrepressible anti-establishment edge. But our broadsheets and tabloids obviously hate his guts," the MP claims.

In the contract Mr Wardle has lodged with Mrs Filkin for scrutiny he says he will not be required "to promote, ask questions, make speeches, lobby or represent in any way" Mr Fayed's interests at Westminster. As for the size of his remuneration, which could eventually include share options, the MP, who describes himself as "a rightwinger in a dull sort of way", tells friends he has been paid more in previous jobs. He will help the Egyptian-born tycoon expand his international interests.

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Horizon 9pm, BBC2

For the Markways, cancer is a way of life. The American family carry the gene that causes Xeroderma Pigmentosum (XP) and even the smallest amount of sunlight on their skin can cause tumours to grow. But this sensitivity to ultraviolet, tragic as it is for the rare few who suffer from XP, has given scientists unique insights into the way cancer develops. Sadly, this research has been of little practical use to XP victims so far, but that may be about to change as doctors discover drugs that stop cancerous cells from re-growing after treatment. A journey through cutting-edge scientific research that, as the Markways reveal how little feedback they were given after being assiduously studied, should make the scientific community pause to consider its attitudes towards those who cooperate with research.

Bad Girls 9pm, ITV

Students of kitsch culture may want to have their notebooks ready for this second series of the women's prison-set drama. It's not so much that Bad Girls is any worse than a lot of mainstream TV, it's just that the way it melds soap-opera clich*s with big-budget production values is decidedly jarring. Baddie prison warder Fenner, for instance, is one of the most one-dimensional characters currently gracing British TV; while it's difficult to tell if a line like "Get in the car and keep your legs together", directed by a warden at a prisoner being carted off to hospital to give birth, is unintentionally or intentionally funny. Prisoner Cell Block H with pommy accents.
