fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
Tales Of The FBI: Bureau v The Klan 7pm, History

A cheery advert for Mississippi explains "our town is thoroughly segregated", over shots of a little black girl taking water from a pump marked "coloureds only". When the lynchings increase in 1964 J Edgar Hoover intones: "The protection of individual citizens is a matter for the local authorities." Lawrence Guyot, a black civil rights activist, recalls, "The sheriffs who were arresting us, spying on us, those were the people we had to go to when there were violations of law? Yes." (CR)

Breathless (Jim McBride, 1983) 9.30pm, Carlton Cinema

Given Jean-Luc Godard's fascination with Hollywood there's a certain irony in this US updating of his 1959 classic. Richard Gere takes the Jean-Paul Belmondo role as the car thief who accidentally kills a cop and, with events spiralling out of control, heads for the border with girlfriend (Valerie Kaprisky). Unlike the original it's no ground-breaker, but pretty gripping, in its own way.

Midnight In The Garden Of Good And Evil (Clint Eastwood, 1997) 11.55pm, Sky Premier

At a Christmas party in Savannah, Georgia, the host (Kevin Spacey, pictured) shoots dead his lover (Jude Law): visiting journalist John Cusack is left gawping at the bizarre reality beneath the town's genteel veneer. Eastwood's version of John Berendt's book is full of vivid characters and though the drama loses its way, it's a fascinating portrait of time and place.

Deep Crimson (Arturo Ripstein, 1996) 12.20am, FilmFour

Ripstein, who started out as assistant to Bunuel on The Exterminating Angel, creates here a savagely comic account of the Lonely Hearts Killers, who preyed on rich widows in 40s Mexico. Regina Orozco is Coral, who gives up her children to be with the man of her dreams: the Charles Boyer-like - if you ignore the wig - Nicolas (Daniel Gimenez Cacho). The film's colours contrast with the banality of the crimes: and you can almost hear Bunuel laughing at the sad, screwed-up couple's motive: love.

fields.headline: Summer specials
fields.standfirst: It's summer (well, nearly) and the nation's schedulers are lining up the usual cycle of repeats to see us through until autumn. But there are some nuggets of gold amongst the dross.  Richard Vine digs them out
fields.trailText: It's summer (well, nearly) and the nation's schedulers are lining up the usual cycle of repeats to see us through until autumn. But there are some nuggets of gold amongst the dross. Richard Vine digs them out
fields.body:
Here we are again. The season of the TV year known as déjà-view, where programmes repeat faster than a bad meal at sea. This year, however, there are one or two shows that may leave you feeling like you're not being forced out into the sun for lack of anything to watch. Here's what we'll be staying in for_

Best potential fiasco

Frank Skinner and David Baddiel, are launching a very brave new show in which they will be filmed live, sitting on a sofa chatting about anything the studio audience suggests, with the promised exception of football. This has no doubt been designed to have viewers sitting at home on their sofas bitterly thinking: "I could do that." This is the avant garde of the ordinary, and probably the most experimental thing you'll ever see on ITV.

Best This Life clone

If it's a hit, remake it. And everybody is. Hearts And Bones (BBC1), Metropolis (ITV) and Coupling (BBC2) are all running the Maddy/Anna/Egg race, and in a cunning twist, C4 are roping in a bunch of real-life people to perform in Flat-Mate. Oh, and so are the BBC with The Horror Of_ Flatshare. But of course, the best version of This Life over the next few months will be, er, This Life, which BBC2 is reshowing in its 32-episode entirety.

Best spinoff from a film about young East End gangsters

Fighting off the warnings from anyone who's ever endured Clueless: The TV Show, Ferris Bueller: The Series or Honey I Shrunk The Kids: The TV Show, Lock, Stock And Two Smoking Barrels comes ram-raiding onto C4's schedules with a whole new set of upwardly mobile phone users (ie no one from the film) scamming, ducking and diving, weaving and bobbing etc, etc...

Best use of security cameras

Channel 4 are offering you the chance to feel like a security guard, with a version of the Dutch surveillance game-show phenomenon which pitches a house full of strangers against each other for 90 days without telephones, newspapers, radio, or even television. Watch as they disintegrate into a savage community of chess-players, torturing each other with ingenious 24-hour mind-games, nominating fellow inmates to be evicted every week. Then the viewers vote and someone is chucked out.

Best disabled show

With features on the American Stunt School For The Disabled, Howard Stern's 3ft 6inch-tall sidekick Hank The Angry Dwarf, a deaf comedian signing jokes (with interpretation from Bernard Manning) and a section where the able-bodied will get a chance to "let off steam about the disabled", Freak Out (Channel 4), from the people that brought you Eurotrash, promises to get the most Shocked From Suburbs mail.

Best rehash of a standard formula

Sooner or later all those ideas you thought would never return will. So we've got an impressionist and a variety show on the horizon (Alistair McGowan's Big Impression on the BBC, and Tonight At The London Palladium on ITV). And the return of 70s revivals, just in case you didn't get enough in the 90s, with a 10-week run of I * 1970s, with the usual laugh-at-flares shenanigans.

Most gratuitously graphic science documentary

The grinning brain specialist the BBC have found to present Brain Story at the end of the summer Professor Susan Greenfield, promises to find out if humans are really just big-brained chimps, which sounds like a promising sort of endeavour. To do so she's going to be cutting open skulls and then reviving patients while they're under the knife.

Most pointless gimmick

We all use them, but only architects really care about them. In one of those not-so-freaky coincidences of TV scheduling, two new series are hoping to get more people thinking about buildings. With Shock Of The Old in August on Channel 4 Piers Gough takes the easy option of looking at old buildings and talking about them, while BBC2 looks set to inject a lot more tension into the proceedings in May by taking a presenter with a fear of heights (Kevin McCloud) and forcing him to climb up six famous structures in a programme called - wait for it - Don't Look Down.

Best reason to stay up all night

Continuing 4 Later's mission to turn us into sleep-deprived wrecks, 4 Music is promising 31 weeks of whatever's passing for rock and roll among the kids these days (Merz, Shack, Super Furry Animals, Flaming Lips, Angie Stone, The Beta Band etc.) And Jo Whiley, continuing her militant campaign against socks.

Best Carol Vorderman vehicle

Yes, she's a star, and we love her. And in case you'd forgotten that there was life outside daytime, ITV are boosting Carol's smiley profile with a wide selection of formats. Soon, for anyone with the foresight to go digital, ITV: Carol will be booming into your living rooms, but until then the terrestrial population will have to make do with her upcoming appearances on Stars And Their Lives, Carol Vorderman's Better Homes, The Pride Of Britain Awards, Time Travellers and Find A Fortune. Oh, and Countdown.

webTitle: Ramblers want right to walk in the woods

fields.headline: Ramblers want right to walk in the woods
fields.trailText: Ramblers would gain the right to walk in the woods and wander along river banks under proposals launched today to extend right to roam legislation.
fields.body:
Ramblers would gain the right to walk in the woods and wander along river banks under proposals launched today to extend right to roam legislation.

In a move which will be resisted by landowners, pro-rambling Labour MPs are backing a change to the countryside and rights of way bill which would see woodland and riverside added to the list of moorland, mountains, heath, downs and commons land which will be opened up under the new law.

A poll conducted by ICM for the Ramblers' Association found that 79% of people supported the extension of the freedom to roam.

The amendment to the bill, which is today in its committee stage in the Commons, has been tabled by David Lepper, Labour MP for Brighton Pavilion.

He said last night: "It's not surprising that woodland ar eas are some of the most popular features of the countryside.

"My amendment would extend the scope of the right to roam to some of the most attractive woodland areas in the country, subject to commonsense restrictions."

Gordon Prentice, Labour MP for Pendle and one of the staunchest Commons campaigners on the right to roam, also backed the change last night.

He said: "In Germany they have had forest laws since 1975 so Germans have the right to traipse through the woods." Ministers had indicated that there might be scope for including woodland in the legislation at a later stage, he said, but Mr Prentice called for it to be "yoked into the bill" now.

Any attempt to extend the controversial right to roam legislation will be opposed by landowners and the Conservatives, who last week faced accusations of trying to wreck the bill after tabling 138 amend ments limiting its provisions. Privately, ministers are warning campaigners that the bill has always been a "project of negotiations and compromises".

The government is deeply wary of alienating the countryside lobby and is likely to resist attempts at amend ments, though there may be some flexibility later.

Countryside campaigners have already lost a battle over compensation for access in Oxfordshire, after the Lands Tribunal decided against awarding the 3rd Baron Rotherwick the £1m compensation he sought after being forced to let ramblers use a footpath through his private forest.

The hereditary peer had claimed that public access would hit income from forestry and game shooting.

Tory amendments to the bill sought to ban access to the countryside at night, greatly restrict walkers' entry to private estates and criminalise those who broke new rules on ramblers' behaviour.

Countryside campaigners claimed that many of the proposed changes would render almost meaningless the new freedoms promised by ministers. But opposition MPs insist they are trying to make the access rights workable, safer and less tempting to thieves.

fields.headline: Widdecombe doubt on tough policing
fields.trailText: Rudolf Guiliani, New York's fearsome republican mayor who is credited with reducing the city's crime rate, will meet his match later this week when Ann Widdecombe storms into town to study his "zero tolerance" initiative.
fields.body:
Rudolf Guiliani, New York's fearsome republican mayor who is credited with reducing the city's crime rate, will meet his match later this week when Ann Widdecombe storms into town to study his "zero tolerance" initiative.

The shadow home secretary, whose public profile has slipped in recent months, will tomorrow visit the New York police's "Model Block" project which has successfully reduced crime rates by refusing to tolerate the slightest of misdemeanours. Championed by Mr Giuliani, the project has become known as "broken windows" because police have found that serious crimes have fallen when officers concentrate on apparently trivial crimes such as broken windows.

Miss Widdecombe will kick off her trip in Washington today when she goes out on patrol with the DC Metro Police just outside the centre of the city. Before she flew to New York last night, the shadow home secretary was forced to admit that she would struggle to copy Mayor Giuliani's "zero tolerance" policy because even she would be unable to muster the necessary numbers of police. New York has seen its police numbers increase by 11,000 in recent years.

Asked whether zero tolerance would work in Britain, she told the BBC's Westminster Hour: "It would be very difficult indeed just to come up with a pledge for that level of policing. I am going to see if there is anything we can learn, but I do not go there with a presumption that we can copy what Mayor Giuliani has done." Miss Widdecombe hopes to use Mayor Giuliani's success to step up the pressure on the home secretary over police numbers. Jack Straw has faced embarrassment after police numbers dropped.

Miss Widdecombe is following a path that has been well-trodden by Tories in recent years. Jeffrey Archer visited Mayor Giuliani during his ill-fated campaign to become London mayor. William Hague also travelled to the US last year to try and find inspiration from George W Bush.

fields.headline: Dobson call to 'shop' suspicious drivers
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson yesterday added a twist to his mayoral manifesto, urging Londoners to join his crusade against drugs by "shopping" suspicious Mercedes and BMW drivers to the police.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson yesterday added a twist to his mayoral manifesto, urging Londoners to join his crusade against drugs by "shopping" suspicious Mercedes and BMW drivers to the police.

Even supporters of his campaign were baffled when Mr Dobson suggested that a "tougher attitude" was needed towards drivers of expensive cars who had "no visible means of support". He also suggested that some police officers turned a blind eye to drug crime, including crack dealing.

The police should provide protection for people who reported suspicious characters, the Labour candidate argued in an interview with the black weekly paper New Nation.

"I think law-abiding people should shop anybody they see. We often hear about role models in terms of good role models, but if you're working and you are trying to get your children to work for a living in difficult circumstances, then seeing someone riding round in the lap of luxury pushing drugs is clearly the wrong model."

His call came on the last day for nominations to become London's first elected mayor. The candidates, Mr Dobson, Ken Livingstone - running as an independent and officially suspended from the Labour party yesterday - the Conservative Steve Norris, the Liberal Democrat Susan Kramer and the Greens' Darren Johnson, are preparing their manifestos as the contest gathers pace before the May 4 poll.

Battlegrounds include the future of the London Underground, road congestion charging, crime and policing, but Mr Livingstone - commanding 61% support in the latest poll - is so far in front that policy issues are slipping into the background.

Mr Norris, lying third in the polls and battling under the slogan Action not Politics for London, will today unveil his package of measures, including using little-noticed mayoral powers to press for improved services from overground train companies in London.

While the mayor will not have the scope to amend existing contracts between rail companies and the government, he or she will be able to issue "binding guidance" which the companies are obliged to note.

While they would not be required to address mayoral demands over issues such as delays or cancelled services, the guidance would influence the terms of future government contracts, Mr Norris's strategists say.

Staying well to the left of his party in an uphill struggle in a Labour city, he will also promise today to press the government for higher London weighting, from an average of £3,000 to £6,000, on the salaries of public sector workers. Nurses, teachers and police have felt the squeeze of rising house prices most strongly, he will argue.

Mr Dobson yesterday launched a five-point plan to improve the tube, proposing public access to performance information and performance related pay for managers.

Some in the Labour party are questioning the wisdom of his campaign strategy, amid signs that he is seeking to woo natural Tory voters with policies such as his proposed drugs crackdown.

By apparently seeking the second preference votes of Conservatives backing Mr Norris, he gives the impression of having conceded that he cannot beat Mr Livingstone in the first round.

Speaking to New Nation, which noted his liberal use of four-letter swearwords, Mr Dobson - whose new slogan is Frank and to the Point - expressed concern that the police were too soft on drugs.

He said: "There are people in the police force who want a lower priority given to it [drug crime], but as hard drugs ruin lives I think a lot of attention should be given to it.

"I'm never very impressed when I hear the police on any given topic saying that it shouldn't be an offence any more."

Asked if he was seriously saying that some officers ignored crack dealing, he replied: "It's round and about that with a few of them. That's my impression. They think it's futile.

"I'm sure that isn't most police, but there are some who drift into these attitudes."

Mr Dobson also claimed that the Macpherson report on the murder of Stephen Lawrence had uncovered corruption, despite the report's statement that it found no evidence of it.

As for his rival Ken Livingstone, Mr Dobson said: "I think he has a paternalistic, neo-colonialist attitude. He likes the idea of organisations being dependent."

fields.headline: Labour throws out Livingstone
fields.standfirst:
MP hopes that expulsion will only be 'trial separation'

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone was yesterday expelled from the Labour party after 31 years as a member and 13 as a Labour MP. He was thrown out for standing against the party's official London mayoral candidate the moment nominations closed at noon for the mayoral and Greater London assembly elections.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone was yesterday expelled from the Labour party after 31 years as a member and 13 as a Labour MP. He was thrown out for standing against the party's official London mayoral candidate the moment nominations closed at noon for the mayoral and Greater London assembly elections.

As Labour's Frank Dobson launched a "Frank and to the point" advertising campaign, and his running mate Trevor Phillips raised the prospect of an "accommodation" between the party and the independent frontrunner if Livingstone won, the former Greater London council leader said he hoped it would only be a "trial separation".

But there was no sign of any let up in the onslaught from Labour's Millbank headquarters, which yesterday launched a renewed attempt to damage Mr Livingstone by highlighting his use of a company, called Localaction, to maximise his income from journalism and public speaking.

The Brent East MP yesterday dismissed claims by Labour sources that he had wrongly used director's loans from the company to buy a holiday home in Brighton.

"This is absolute rubbish and comes from the same people who brought Peter Mandelson back into government after he failed to declare a £373,000 loan," Mr Livingstone said last night. "Perhaps I'll be the next Northern Ireland secretary because of my accountancy skills."

The loans, which were first made public more than five years ago, had either been repaid or converted into a dividend, on advice from his accountant. The Brighton house, bought last summer for £168,000 with his partner Kate Allen, had been financed with the dividend and a £120,000 mortgage.

Mr Livingstone was suspended from the Labour party last month when he said that he would stand against Mr Dobson as an independent, leaving open the possibility that he might nevertheless withdraw at the last minute.

Margaret McDonagh, Labour's general secretary, finalised his excommunication yesterday in a personal letter. "By your actions you have excluded yourself from Labour party membership and you are therefore no longer a member," she wrote.

Mr Livingstone responded by saying he expected to "be back soon". He added: "Once we have had the election and put all of this behind us, the party will want to work together to make sure London government functions properly." He said he hoped to be shown the "same tolerance" as those who had left Labour in the 1980s to join the Social Democratic party and who now worked in Downing Street.

But Labour's spokesman said Mr Livingstone's chances of being allowed back had been "obliterated by this". Simon Fletcher, his political adviser who is also acting as his agent in the mayoral campaign, can now also expect to be expelled from the party, along with others who have signed his nomination papers.

But there are also indications that the party hierarchy is keeping its options open on how to deal with Mr Livingstone as mayor if he wins the contest on 4 May. Mr Phillips, who heads the Labour list for the assembly elections and is standing as Mr Dobson's deputy, said that although Mr Livingstone would face an initially hostile reception from the Labour group, "we would have to work out an accommodation" and that he would "have to work with us".

The full list of mayoral candidates will be announced tomorrow, but is expected to include Mr Livingstone, Mr Dobson, the Tories' Steven Norris, the Liberal Democrat's Susan Kramer, the Greens' Darren Johnson, and Ram Gidoomal of the Christian People's Alliance, Damien Hockney of the UK Independence party and Geoffrey Clements of the Natural Law party.

Malcolm McLaren, former manager of the punk band, Sex Pistols, who had been planning to stand as an independent, announced yesterday he was pulling out of the race in favour of Mr Livingstone.

fields.headline: Yesterday day
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Pigs. Winnie the pig has joined the race for London mayor. The porker had her nomination papers handed in yesterday and according to minders will be drawing attention to the crisis in the UK pig industry.

Old boy's day

Tony Benn yesterday marked his 75th birthday by doing what he does best nowadays - angrily denouncing the government's policies. The firebrand has condemned Labour's failure to do more for fellow pensioners. He was expected to join a Labour backbenchers' revolt last night to try and restore the link between pensions and earnings.

Bad day

Ann Widdecombe. Her first novel The Clematis Tree has taken a panning. One critic's reaction: "This book is one long course in misery, perked up only by a little crucifix waving ... it is completely devoid of plausible contemporary reference."

Today

Commons: Freedom of information bill, report. Lords: Care standards bill, third reading. Insolvency bill, second reading

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: Alan Wallis writes: In the late 1970s, I made a film about the novelist Anthony Powell (Obituary, March 30) at his Somerset home. He was, as might have been expected, a charming and witty host, and accepted the presence of my crew wandering all over the place with great good humour. In interviews he gave little away, and did not accept my suggestion that he was not at his best when writing about "the lower classes".
fields.body:
Alan Wallis writes: In the late 1970s, I made a film about the novelist Anthony Powell (Obituary, March 30) at his Somerset home. He was, as might have been expected, a charming and witty host, and accepted the presence of my crew wandering all over the place with great good humour. In interviews he gave little away, and did not accept my suggestion that he was not at his best when writing about "the lower classes".

However, my enduring memory of the experience is my host's insistence that I include a sequence featuring his cat in the film. The animal had recently broken a leg, and was wearing a splint. Powell found this highly amusing, and in the com pleted programme there appeared a totally meaningless, even surreal, shot of the unfortunate cat, limping comically across the dining table.

A few months after shooting, I showed the finished product to Anthony Powell in London. As the lights came up in the viewing theatre, he turned to me and remarked, "I thought the cat was particularly good."

Anthony Sampson writes: Your obituary of Lord Dunrossil, the British diplomat in South Africa (March 31), describes his secret feat of sending books to Nelson Mandela after he was jailed in 1962. In fact, both the British and South African archives show clearly that the books were sent at the request of David Astor, then editor of the Observer, through his friend Sir John Maud, the British high commissioner, with the approval of the prison authorities. The feat was not secret, nor was it Dunrossil's.

Sheila Himsworth writes: I was incensed by the description as a "tyrannical father" of my dear friend and former boss, John Harvey, who was the father of the astrologer Charles Harvey (Obituary, March 2). I cannot believe that the kind and courteous scholar, who led me into countless avenues of the world's cultural heritage, from whom I learned so much, could ever have been a tyrant.

fields.headline: Father Brocard Sewell
fields.standfirst: As priest and printer, he nurtured literary talent and sparked a continuous series of intellectual and theological debates

fields.body:
Father Brocard Sewell, the Carmelite friar who has died aged 87, was a scholar, theologian, printer and brilliant connoisseur of 1890s decadence. He will be fondly remembered as the friend and patron of young poets, whom he published in the Aylesford Review. A small, owlish man in his brown habit, with a quizzical but imperturbable expression, he was an unforgettable figure on the fringes of English literary life - he had the strange mix of innocence and sharp intelligence that seems to flourish more creatively in a religious order than in the outside world.

It was characteristic that Brocard experienced monastic life in three religious orders, having tried out the Dominicans and Austin Canons before settling down with the Carmelites at Aylesford in Kent. His friendships were similarly adventurous. He would speak affectionately of Diana Mosley and Henry Williamson, Christine Keeler and Colin Wilson. The level of his tolerance of human oddity was part of his extraordinary charm.

Surprisingly, he was born into the Anglican hierarchy in Bangkok, where his father was a teacher. His mother died soon after his birth and he was sent back to Cornwall, where his maternal grandparents took him into their care. He was baptised by his paternal grandfather, who came from a long line of Anglican clergy connected with the Oxford Movement.

Brocard, then known as Michael Sewell, was a descendant of William Sewell, the Tractarian divine who founded Radley College. He was sent to Weymouth College, a minor public school in Dorset, run on low church lines. In his memoirs, The Habit Of A Lifetime, he described it as a hell of rain-drenched rugby pitches and swishing canes.

Leaving at 16, with a surely record-breaking nil out of 300 in school certificate maths, he found a niche as general factotum in the London office of GK's Weekly, the paper founded by GK Chesterton, which was the official organ of the Distributist League. One of Sewell's weekly tasks was to collect copies of the new edition from the train at Euston, and bring them back by taxi. As he later wrote: "Since all the bundles of copies could be got into one taxi, it will be surmised that the paper's circulation was not large."

Working at GK's Weekly must have given Brocard his first taste of the joys of the small specialist enterprise - the little magazines and the private presses with which he has been so much associated. Surely, too, it was an early training in intransigence.

Chesterton was the supreme fighting journalist of his age. Brocard recalled vividly that groaning, wheezing figure ascending the staircase, squashing his girth into the editor's swivel chair, and regaling the staff with conversation even better than Oscar Wilde's at his most scintillating. But it was typical of Brocard that when he came to write a book about a Chesterton, he selected not GK but his younger brother, Cecil, a political journalist, editor of the New Witness, and a fascinating but relatively obscure figure.

So much of Brocard's writing was rescue operation, reflecting his own sharp appreciation of unobviousness. Like Black Swans was a good title for his collected studies because it was the black swans, not the white ones, that attracted him - his achievement was to show people that black swans could be interesting, too.

Brocard's connection with Hilary Pepler, Eric Gill and the Guild of St Joseph and St Dominic dated back to his late schooldays, when he answered an advertisement in GK's Weekly for the workshops at Ditchling Common, Sussex. Arriving at St Dominic's Press, with its iron hand presses and frames containing cases of type, he felt he was entering a congenial new world. Within minutes, Pepler had handed him a setting stick and begun teaching him how to set up type by hand. After he left GK's, by now a Roman Catholic convert, he went back to Ditch ling as a compositor, and stayed for five years.

In that Catholic community so alluringly combining the doggedly practical and fervently religious, the risqué and the rugged, intellectual and folksy, Brocard found an emotional haven and professional direction. All his life he continued his involvement with the printing crafts, working later as a compositor with Edward Walters, at Primrose Hill, and then as printer and editorial controller of St Albert's Press, at the Carmelite priory, Aylesford, from 1955. He paid a final debt to Pepler with his last great work of scholarship, the St Dominic's Press bibliography, magnificently printed at the Whittington Press in 1995.

Brocard took me on my first visit to Ditchling, having rung me out of the blue at the Guardian offices. I still have the book he sent me after that memorable day - a copy of Two Friends, his study of John Gray and Andre Raffalovich, inscribed "In spe novae amicitiae." We did indeed become friends, and 15 years later I began the biography of Eric Gill.

Brocard was a tower of strength in the furore that followed publication. Though some of his confreres were shocked at the apparent sang froid with which he referred, in a television documentary, to Gill's "peccadilloes" - which included adultery, incest and experimental conjunction with his dog - Brocard refused to be budged from his conviction that Gill was fundamentally a holy man.

In the 1950s at Aylesford, Father Brocard, whose religious name memorialised the 13th-century prior of the her mits of Mount Carmel, initiated the magazine that burgeoned to become one of the leading literary-intellectual journals of its period. The Aylesford Review, which has been seen as a successor to TS Eliot's Criterion, lasted from 1955 to 1968, and many of those early issues are now collectors' items.

I particularly remember the special number on Aubrey Beardsley and the 1890s (published in 1966), surely the first serious reconsideration of Beardsley to emanate from a religious house, with a resplendent psychedelic cover, and the issue entitled Homage To EH Visiak (1967). Visiak, an almost forgotten writer and thinker in his late 80s, had been tracked down by Brocard to his retreat in Hove.

The list of contributors to the Aylesford Review is remarkably eclectic, including Thomas Merton, John Gawsworth, Stevie Smith, Sylvia Townsend Warner and Henry Williamson. Even more impressive is the list of young writers the review published before they became well-known: DM Thomas, Angela Carter, Penelope Shuttle, and Frances and Michael Horowitz. Brocard's wide contacts and warm friendships gave the review its special flavour; it was the point at which the beat generation met the Roman Catholic church in England, an unlikely convergence only he could have achieved.

I wrote my first book review for Brocard, and one of my lasting regrets is that I never went to one of the Aylesford priory weekends. These were literary gatherings at which writers, known and unknown, leftwing and very rightwing, would stay in the priory guesthouse, united in affection and respect for Father Brocard and a belief in the seriousness of writing.

In the early 1960s, the Aylesford Review entered a more combative, overtly political phase, publishing articles on the Official Secrets Act, police corruption and the Profumo scandal. It was at this stage that Brocard first befriended Christine Keeler, described in his memoirs as "a beautiful and well-mannered young woman". When asked how it was that these incendiarist issues drew no comment from his superiors, Brocard suggested that neither the prior nor the prior-general ever read the magazine.

They did, however, respond firmly to the letter he wrote to the Times in 1968 protesting at the papal report on birth control. His first sentence had an obviously Chestertonian ring: "Sir, The publication of the encyclical letter Humanae Vitae shows, if nothing else, that the Orthodox and other eastern churches are fully justified in their mistrust of the papal office as it has developed over the centuries since the great schism."

Father Brocard was suspended from preaching and hearing confessions in his diocese, and expelled from the priory at Aylesford. He went into exile in Canada, teaching courses on the pre-Raphaelites and fin-de-siecle writers at St Francis Xavier University in Antigonish, Nova Scotia. He then moved to Mount Carmel College, where, among other things, he taught young seminarists to make Christmas puddings - to a recipe by the poet Frances Horowitz, who became a close and valued friend.

In his final years, the authorities relented and he came back to the Carmelite houses at Faversham and, most recently, East Finchley. Though the inmates were kind to him, he moaned about East Finchley, finding the suburban sameness at odds with his distinctively Firbankian tastes.

Brocard was a stalwart companion, with the celibate's antennae for the sexual and emotional upheavals of his friends. Tetes-a-tetes in out-of-the-way tearooms were his speciality and he amazed my teenage son by demanding two double vermouths in a pub. He once made the comment that "perhaps most of us have, at least potentially, something of the decadent in us."

Father Brocard's reclamation of forgotten, esoteric writers of the 1890s was his major literary life's work. Gray and Raffalovich; Arthur Machen; Frederick Rolfe, Baron Corvo; Olive Custance, the poet, Lord Alfred Douglas's wife; the dubious demonologist, the Rev Montague Summers. It has been a weird and marvellous pursuit.

Fiona MacCarthy

fields.headline: Sir Robert Sainsbury
fields.standfirst: Public benefactor who channelled the wealth of a grocery empire into the arts
fields.trailText: The Sainsburys are renowned for their skill in food retailing and their munificent patronage of the arts. Sir Robert Sainsbury, who has died aged 93, was the member of the family known better for buying Bacons than selling bacon.
fields.body:
The Sainsburys are renowned for their skill in food retailing and their munificent patronage of the arts. Sir Robert Sainsbury, who has died aged 93, was the member of the family known better for buying Bacons than selling bacon.

Though, in 1930, he dutifully joined the family grocery business founded by his grandfather, and became joint president almost 40 years later, it was as an art collector and benefactor that he was better known. He gave his priceless collection to the University of East Anglia, and was awarded a knighthood in 1969 for services to the arts.

However, Sainsbury was always an advocate of better conditions for the retail chain's employees. Pensions and sickness benefits for all staff came in 1935; overtime payments were introduced in 1941; and, from 1962, the five-day week was standard - all improvements that transformed Sainsbury's from a benign but paternalistic employer into a modern one.

Robert Sainsbury was educated at Haileybury College (which he didn't enjoy) and Cambridge (which he did), before qualifying as an accountant. Eight years after he joined the family firm, his father, John, retired due to ill-health, and Robert and his elder brother became joint general managers. While Alan took charge of trading matters, Robert specialised in administration, finance and personnel. It was a happy partnership, lasting more than 30 years.

The second world war broke out a year after Robert's promotion, and his logistical skill at distributing rationed supplies to the 250 Sainsbury shops - with official regulations, sudden shortages and occasional windfalls - was seen as a model by government departments and other retailers.

This public service ethic was a thread in the philosophy and practice that Sainsbury's continued postwar. Their sense of social justice ensured that Robert and Alan were strong supporters of the Beveridge report, which cradled the welfare state into being. By the end of the war, Robert had cut the long hours which under-18s had necessarily put in - with men conscripted and women on war work - anticipating that the Labour government would want youngsters to complete their education.

These concerns, along with safeguarding the career prospects of employees who wished to return after completing war service, were brought in at a complicated time. Trading conditions were difficult post-1945; the firm wanted to expand, but wasn't sure how quickly this could be accomplished. Robert was aware, too, that in a period of full employment, the retail sector had a lot of catching up to do in the competition for well-motivated staff.

The 1950s brought further challenge and change with the rise of supermarkets. The Sainsburys realised that the new new world of aisles, checkouts - and big profits, of course - would be expensive to bring to a family undertaking. Robert presided over much of this transformation. Over the period of his joint general management, deputy chairmanship and chairmanship (he became deputy chairman when his father died in 1956, and succeeded his brother as chairman in 1967), the company's turnover increased from £45m to £166m, and the number of employees rose fourfold.

By the time he quit as chairman in 1969, Sainsbury could bask, albeit quietly, in the knowledge that he had been a principal architect of the supergrocer's fortunes, which would see it sail towards the end of the century.

What awaited Robert was the culmination of his secondary career as a collector and benefactor. In 1973, he made a gift to the University of East Anglia of several hundred paintings, drawings and sculptures from around the world, which he had bought over the decades.

Designed by Norman Foster, a talented British architect who, up to then, had enjoyed more success with commissions on the continent than in Britain, and with an endowment of £3m from his son, David, to house the works, the awe-inspiring Sainsbury Centre for Visual Arts opened in spring 1978.

Almost 40 years earlier, Sainsbury's shrewd eye had alighted on a piece by a young sculptor he was anxious to help. In 1933, he bought a carving, Mother and Child, from a sculptor who was not having great success: Henry Moore. The £160 he paid was half Moore's income in that year.

Sir Robert and his wife, Lisa, who survives him, along with their two daughters, Celia and Annabel, and son, David, was also an early patron and friend of Francis Bacon. They bought the first of nine paintings by Bacon in 1953; later, Lady Sainsbury asked the artist to do a portrait of her husband. To those who said - unsurprisingly - that Bacon had hardly produced a likeness, Sainsbury replied: "It's not the business of portraits to look like people, but to be exciting arrangements of form and colour."

A recipe, if you think about it, that works also for enticing shoppers into supermarkets.

John Cunningham

Robert Sainsbury, businessman and philanthropist, born October 24 1906; died April 2 2000

fields.headline: Claire Duchen
fields.standfirst: Chronicler of the struggle of French women
fields.trailText: The university teacher Claire Duchen, who has died of cancer aged 45, wrote lucidly and sympathetically on modern French feminism, and was central to a global network of feminist scholars, as a writer, translator, research co-ordinator and regional editor for the Women's Studies International Forum.
fields.body:
The university teacher Claire Duchen, who has died of cancer aged 45, wrote lucidly and sympathetically on modern French feminism, and was central to a global network of feminist scholars, as a writer, translator, research co-ordinator and regional editor for the Women's Studies International Forum.

Her book Feminism In France From May 68 To Mitterrand (1986), written as a "participant observer", continues to inspire students because it so successfully links what might seem fancy theory and the everyday lives of ordinary women. French Connections (1987), her brilliant little book of translated texts, showed the full range of French feminist thought.

Claire was born in London to South African parents, Myra and Leo Duchen. When she was five, her father became professor of neuro-pathology at the institute of neurology, Queen Square, and the family moved permanently to England. She was educated at North London Collegiate School and read French at Sussex University. Her 1983 doctoral thesis, on contemporary feminist thought, was the first granted by the institute of French studies at New York University. She came to think the thesis subject had chosen her, it was her own way of making the personal political.

After teaching briefly at Aston University and Oxford Polytechnic (now Oxford Brookes University), Claire took a post at Bath University, where she wrote another book, Women's Rights, Women's Lives In France 1944-1968 (published in 1994), and helped set up a research centre for women's studies. In 1993, she took a senior post at Sussex University, but her years there were clouded, first by the illness and death of her parents, and then by being diagnosed herself with advanced ovarian cancer in 1996.

Claire confronted her illness with honesty and determination. Cancer was, she said, "like being on a wobbly bicycle", and she undertook high-dose chemotherapy in order to stay on the road as long as possible. During the last four years, she continued to work, and co-edited When The War Was Over, a book on women in postwar Europe, which reached proof stage just before her death.

Claire never lost her feminism; she thought it should be rooted both in rigorous thinking and human solidarity, but recently wrote an article in which she explained that her interests had gone beyond French culture and she was drawn to people "on the margins", wrestling with conflict, hardship and taboos. Her last article was about women who had their heads shaved after the liberation of France for being wartime collaborators.

Claire loved it when students spoofed her strongly-held views, but she also inspired many of them to work in her field, She liked having fun. She travelled widely, wove wool on the loom in the spare room, and through her partner, the musician Ben Mandelson, knew other musicians and performers, to whom she introduced her international circle of friends. You never knew who you might meet in the house in Finsbury Park, north London.

She insisted that her funeral should not be too sombre and should be conducted by a woman rabbi. Ben, and her brother and sister, survive her.

Sin Reynolds

Claire Frances Duchen, academic, born May 15 1954; died March 15 2000

webTitle: Error led to bombing of Monte Cassino

fields.headline: Error led to bombing of Monte Cassino
fields.standfirst: Monastery destroyed after translation slip by British intelligence officer
fields.trailText: The world's most glorious monastery, at Monte Cassino in Italy, was destroyed during the second world war because of a mistake by a British junior officer, according to new evidence in a book due out this week.
fields.body:
The world's most glorious monastery, at Monte Cassino in Italy, was destroyed during the second world war because of a mistake by a British junior officer, according to new evidence in a book due out this week.

The officer - translating an intercepted radio message - mistook the German word for abbot for a similar word meaning battalion. His version convinced his superiors this meant a German military unit was using the monastery as its command post, in breach of a Vatican agreement which treated it as neutral.

Allied generals ordered a huge bombing attack. Only when the planes were in the air did a British intelligence officer, Colonel David Hunt, recheck the full radio intercept. He found that what it actually said was: "The abbot is with the monks in the monastery".

"Tragically, this was discovered too late," the book says. "The bombers were already approaching."

Monte Cassino - founded in 526 by St Benedict, numbering St Thomas Aquinas among its early monks - was blitzed in what is mourned as probably the greatest single aesthetic disaster of the war. Some 250 men, women and children died.

The ruins created a superb German defensive position which cost thousands of allied soldiers' lives before the monastery fell after a further three months of fighting. Controversy continues over whether it was German-occupied before the bombing.

Hunt's account of the intercept is told for the first time in With Alex at War, the autobiography of Sir Rupert Clarke, aide -de-camp to Field Marshal Lord Alexander of Tunis, deputy supreme allied commander in Europe and the leading British general in the liberation of Italy.

'Awful tragedy'

Last night Brigadier Bryan Watkins, who collaborated with Sir Rupert on the book, said: "It was an awful tragedy. It was idleness by the man who read the intercept. I don't find the story at all hard to believe. War is a balls-up." The book does not name the intelligence officer.

Field Marshal Lord Carver, former chief of general staff, who is writing the Imperial War Museum's official history War in Italy, 1943-45, said he had not previously heard of the intercept.

Col Hunt - Alexander's personal intelligence officer - later became Sir David Hunt, diplomat, author and private secretary to the post-war prime ministers Clement Attlee and Winston Churchill.

In February 1944, when Monte Cassino was bombed, he was general staff officer in charge of intelligence in a unit with Sir Rupert. German strongpoints in the mountains around Cassino were imperilling the allied advance towards Rome.

Fighting in conditions almost as severe as the trenches of the first world war, allied units on exposed slopes were under heavy artillery fire which they were convinced was being directed by spotters in the 1,600ft high monastery. But Sir Rupert's book says Hunt told him after the war that the monastery was not occupied by the German parachutists who were holding the Cassino feature.

"However, a radio intercept of the German command net reported that a parachute commander had been heard to ask 'Ist Abt in Kloster?' and was answered, 'Ja in Kloster mit Monchen'.

"The intelligence officer who received the intercept only recorded the answer 'Yes from the enemy'. The translation then produced was 'Is the HQ in the abbey?' - the word 'abt' being taken as an abbreviation for 'Abteilung' (a battalion) rather than abbot. It was only when Col Hunt questioned the translation and the whole intercept that it transpired that the correct reply to the question was, in fact, 'Ja, Abt is mit Monchem in Kloster'. ie: 'Yes. The abbot is with the monks in the monastery'."

Sir Rupert adds: "Rather than saving lives, that bombing would lead to savage losses".

From his own study of the papers of British, American and Commonwealth generals in the Imperial War Museum, Lord Carver said he did not think the reportedly misread intercept was likely to have influenced the decision to bomb.

"What they were arguing about with each other was not whether the monastery was occupied but whether, if the attack was going to be successful, the top of the hill should be obliterated."

He added: "I don't think the bombing was necessary or could be justified."

But Brigadier Watkins said: "Both the allied and German sides had given undertakings to the Pope that they would not destroy the monastery. We know from records that Alexander was very conscious of allied responsibilities under this agreement.The intercept, in its mistranslated form, implied the Germans had broken their word. That exonerated the allies and served as a green light for the bombing."

In public, allied leaders exploited the belief that Monte Cassino was occupied to prepare opinion for aerial attacks on it. On February 11 - four days before the bombing - the Daily Mail ran an army-inspired lead story, Nazis Turn Cassino Monastery into Fort.

On February 14 allied guns fired leaflets over the area warning that, in view of the German occupation, "with very heavy hearts we are going to have to turn our weapons on the abbey".

The abbot, who survived the bombing, said: "I swear there were never any German soldiers in the area of the monastery."

Panzer corps messages quoted by German historians after the war speak of a 300-metre military no-go area around the abbey. But details about the timing of these messages are not clear enough to rule out the possibility that they were transmitted as propaganda after the bombing.

Monte Cassino, restored in the 1950s, is a shrine for relatives of the estimated 183,000 soldiers on all sides who lost their lives in the battles around it.

From Lombards to Second World War

529 St Benedict founds the monastery, with a routine of prayer and farming, on a pagan temple site 87 miles south-east of Rome. There he writes the Rule of St Benedict, which becomes a guide for celibate asceticism. Monte Cassino becomes the font of western monasticism

547 St Benedict dies

580s Lombard forces storm the monastery. Its copy of the Rule is taken to Rome for safety

884 Saracen forces storm the monastery

1030 Norman forces storm the monastery

1066 New bronze doors for the abbey are cast in Constantinople (now Istanbul) for the abbot Desiderius

1087 A scholarly monk, Constantine the African, dies after giving western civilisation its first systematic account of classical Greek medicine through translations

1230 Thomas Aquino joins Monte Cassino for spiritual instruction. He becomes theologian St Thomas Aquinas

1349 Earthquake damages buildings

1500 - 1600 Buildings repaired and extended

Late 1943 - early 1944 The town of Cassino becomes a key German defence point against the allied advance on Rome

February 14 1944 Allied artillery fire leaflets alleging German occupation of the monastery and warning of bombing

February 15 Allied bombers obliterate the monastery

1950 -1960 Monte Cassino is rebuilt after an international appeal. Virtually all its decorative detail had been destroyed; but the bronze doors were found and restored to their place

webTitle: Tiger threat: India's touted conservation victory shown to be hollow

fields.headline: Tiger threat: India's touted conservation victory shown to be hollow
fields.trailText: India is to be shamed by the UN for its failure to save the tiger, its national emblem, while corruptly pocketing conservation money and taking no action against poaching.
fields.body:
India is to be shamed by the UN for its failure to save the tiger, its national emblem, while corruptly pocketing conservation money and taking no action against poaching.

A UN official on tiger conservation advises potential donors to stop directing new funds into tiger conservation in India because they do not reach the projects.

The UN fact-finding mission to India, chaired by Robert Hepworth, a British civil servant, found that tiger numbers were below the official estimate of 5,000 and put the number at between 2,000 and 3,000. Some reserves which claimed to have tigers had none, despite the fact that tourists were regularly taken there on sightseeing trips in the expectation of seeing one. In 1900 there were an estimated 100,000 tigers in the wild - now the number is less than 5,000.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, said yesterday that the findings of the report were grave. "If trends go on as they are we will have no tigers in the wild in five to 10 years."

Delegates for the UN Con vention on International Trade in Endangered Species visited India, China and Japan to persuade the governments to stop the trade in tiger parts. Japan responded by passing a law making the trade illegal, and China has also responded. Poachers in China face the death penalty - but in India they are rarely caught and never convicted.

The report says of India: "There is very little evidence of a coordinated, modern professional approach to law enforcement, either in anti-poaching operations or in the investigation of wildlife crime and illicit trading."

It calls for a central agency in India with sweeping powers and political backing to enforce anti-poaching laws and clamp down on the organised gangs which are systematically killing the tigers.

The UN mission was "not convinced that tigers outside designated areas, or indeed those inside other than showcase reserves, are being properly protected or valued".

The mission was given a lukewarm reception by India's environment and forests ministry. .

webTitle: Japanese PM Obuchi in a coma

fields.headline: Japanese PM Obuchi in a coma
fields.trailText: The Japanese prime minister, Keizo Obuchi, was in a coma last night after a severe stroke. Government officials, who had earlier played down the seriousness of his condition, said Mr Obuchi, 62, was on an artificial respirator in the intensive care unit of Juntendo hospital in Tokyo.

"We have heard that there is bleeding in part of his brain," said the acting prime minister, Mikio Aoki. "His blood pressure has been maintained, but we have to watch the situation very closely."

Mr Obuchi, who has brought political and economic stability to Japan since taking office in July 1998, was taken to hospital at 1am on Sunday after he complained of feeling unwell.

Prompting criticism of a Kremlinesque cover-up, the government did not confirm this until 22 hours later.

Even then, officials would only say that the leader of the world's second largest economy was undergoing tests because he was suffering from exhaustion.

Mr Obuchi, who has a pacemaker, suffered the stroke after a taxing week in which he had to deal with the eruption of Mount Usu, the breakaway of prominent members of his coalition and a visit to the southern island of Kyushu to check on arrangements for this summer's G8 summit.

Whether or not he recovers, analysts say Japan will soon have a new prime minister. "A resignation is inevitable," said the Nihon Keizai business newspaper.

The process of appointing a replacement may prove difficult, since Japanese law makes no provision for a situation in which the prime minister is unable to utter his intention to stand down.

"Since he is in a coma, it is impossible for the prime minister himself to make his own decision about his resignation," said Mr Aoki, who was chosen by Mr Obuchi as a stand-in leader.

He said he would consider disbanding the cabinet if the prime minister's condition did not improve.

"It is natural for the government to start thinking about the post-Obuchi era," Yoshimi Watanabe, an MP of the ruling Liberal Democratic party, told reporters.

Heading the list of most likely successors is Yoshiro Mori, secretary general of the LDP, who is seen as being very much in the Obuchi mould. Other candidates include the foreign minister, Yohei Kono, one of the progressive members of the cabinet; Shizuka Kamei, head of the LDP's policy unit and the most vocal proponent of the government's huge public spending programme; and Koichi Kato, head of the party's second biggest faction and an advocate of fiscal restraint.

Mr Obuchi's shoes would not be easy to fill. Despite his low-key style - he once described himself as a "little noodle shop between two skyscrapers" - the prime minister has pushed through a raft of important legislation and used his knack for consensus-building to create the biggest coalition Japan has seen in decades.

The next general election must be called by October.

webTitle: Sonia stoops to win the masses

fields.headline: Sonia stoops to win the masses
fields.standfirst: Gandhi acts to silence critics in Congress party
fields.trailText: Sonia Gandhi tried to end the crisis surrounding her leadership of India's demoralised Congress party yesterday by announcing plans to stage a national tour.
fields.body:
Sonia Gandhi tried to end the crisis surrounding her leadership of India's demoralised Congress party yesterday by announcing plans to stage a national tour.

Her announcement follows accusations that she spends too much time closeted with a tiny coterie of senior advisors, and a humiliating mutiny by her own MPs last week.

Six months after her general election defeat by the nationalist Bharatiya Janata party (BJP) and its allies, the Italian-born widow of the former prime minister Rajiv Gandhi faces a growing rebellion from Congress members who believe the party is unlikely to revive itself with her in charge.

Although the rebellion is not yet decisive, it could mark the beginning of the end of the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty and its association with the Congress party, which has governed India for 45 of the last 52 years, but lost power in 1996.

Last week Congress MPs in two key states, West Bengal and Uttar Pradesh, refused to endorse Mrs Gandhi's nominees to the upper house, the Rajya Sabha, and voted for candidates from rival parties. The snub left Mrs Gandhi badly weakened.

"The Congress party is facing a terminal problem. You can't keep running the Congress as a family firm," Professor Zoya Hassan, of the Centre for Political Studies, said.

"Mrs Gandhi doesn't seem to have a grip on what the Congress should be doing."

Most analysts agree that Mrs Gandhi is unlikely to be toppled in the immediate future, because there is no alternative candidate who is acceptable to all of Congress's competing factions.

"They are like lobsters in a pot. As soon as someone else comes up, the others pull him down," a Congress source said.

But even previously loyal Congress members are calling for a debate on the party's dwindling fortunes.

"The time has come for every right-thinking Congressman to sit up and ask himself the reason for the present situation," Kapil Sabil, a former party spokesman, said last week.

Mrs Gandhi's critics accuse her of failing to build strategic alliances with the newly powerful regional parties, many of which now serve in the BJP's coalition government. They complain that she imitates the authoritarian style of her late mother-in-law, Indira Gandhi, refusing press interviews and rarely venturing out of her Delhi residence.

"She really behaves like an empress, because it's the only thing she knows. Very senior Congress leaders have to sit outside her room for three or four hours waiting to see her," a dissident said.

Loyalists point out that the Congress party still runs more of India's states than the BJP coalition. They also point out that Mrs Gandhi, who took over two years ago, has enjoyed some successes. These include persuading the government last month to back down from a contentious ruling which would have allowed local civil servants to join the RSS, India's most influential militant Hindu organisation.

Many Congress members are already looking to Mrs Gandhi's daughter Priyanka Vadra to lead the party out of its current mess.

Ms Vadra took a discreet step further into Congress politics at the weekend, when she opened her own office in Delhi.

webTitle: Prodi opens way to west for Gadafy

fields.headline: Prodi opens way to west for Gadafy
fields.trailText: The Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy, took a further step towards ending his pariah status in the west yesterday when he met the European Commission president, Romano Prodi.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, and  Mona Eltahawy in Cairo
fields.body:
The Libyan leader, Muammar Gadafy, took a further step towards ending his pariah status in the west yesterday when he met the European Commission president, Romano Prodi.

The two met in Cairo, where Colonel Gadafy is attending the first European Union-Africa summit.

"This is not the final step, it's not the opening of all gates, [but] I think it's fair to say that it's improving," Riccardo Levi, Mr Prodi's press spokesman, said.

The meeting was seen by Mr Prodi as vindicating his policy of helping to bring Col Gadafy back into the wider international community. Mr Prodi was criticised by European leaders in December when he invited the Libyan leader to Brussels, a meeting that did not take place.

The meeting yesterday was the most important development of the first day of the EU-Africa summit.

Another positive development was an offer by the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, of £200m in debt relief to 30 African countries as "a special sign of solidarity".

During his meeting with Mr Prodi, Col Gadafy was in a cooperative mood. Fear had been expressed by the conference organisers that he might disrupt proceedings by expressing his hostility towards Israel, or call for an apology for the crusades.

A communique said Col Gadafy affirmed during a long and friendly meeting with Mr Prodi that Libya accepted that the terms of the so-called Barcelona process of cooperation between the EU and Mediterranean states were not negotiable.

The EU wants Libya to accept officially that Israel and the Palestinian Authority are entitled to participate fully in the Euro-Med dialogue, and to undertake not to block the Middle East peace process.

Mr Prodi said the Cairo meeting was no substitute for an eventual invitation to Brussels.

Commenting on the US restoration of relations a fortnight ago, Col Gadafy said: "The Americans made a smart move. They sent this delegation after long years of boycott and the rise of oil prices."

The UN suspended sanctions against Libya almost a year ago, after it handed over for trial in the Netherlands two men indicted for the 1988 bombing of a PanAm airliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, in which 270 people were killed.

Britain restored full diplomatic relations with Tripoli after it agreed to pay compensation for the killing of a British police officer by gunfire from the Libyan mission in London in 1984.

In the conference hall, African and EU leaders came together with warm words of cooperation at their inaugural summit, which is seen as a major effort to bring the heavily indebted African countries into the global economic and political mainstream. Debt remains the overriding issue and Germany's offer makes only a small dent in it.

fields.headline: In Brief
fields.trailText: Suharto grilled at home
fields.body:
Suharto grilled at home

The former Indonesian dictator Suharto was questioned at his home yesterday about alleged massive corruption after twice defying summonses to appear at the attorney general's office. Doctors halted the examination after 90 minutes when Mr Suharto's blood pressure soared. John Aglionby, Jakarta

20,000 miners riot in China

Up to 20,000 redundant miners rioted in north-eastern China against low unemployment benefits, smashing windows and blocking roads, officials said yesterday.

The government sent in soldiers when the police were unable to stop the violence, which erupted in late February in Yangjiazhangzi, about 200 miles east of Beijing, after the town's mine was closed. AP, Beijing

Haitian radio journalist killed

Two gunmen shot and killed Haiti's most prominent radio journalist, Jean Dominique, outside Radio Haiti Inter, which he owned and directed. A station worker also was killed in the attack. AP, Port-au-Prince

webTitle: Earl 'had to die' - but not on US radio

fields.headline: Earl 'had to die' - but not on US radio
fields.trailText: Why are some radio stations in the United States not playing the latest single by one of country music's most famous groups?
fields.body:
Why are some radio stations in the United States not playing the latest single by one of country music's most famous groups?

Because it celebrates the killing of a violent husband and appears to have touched a raw nerve among male DJs and radio producers.

The song, Goodbye Earl, features on Fly, the latest album from the Dixie Chicks, which won a Grammy award and has sold more than 4m copies.

The bouncy tune tells the story of two friends, Maryanne and Wanda, who decide to poison Wanda's violent husband. They decide it is poetic justice to use black-eyed peas, as Earl gave his wife so many black eyes.

After disposing of the body, the two women set up a roadside stand where they sell Tennessee ham and jam and "don't lose any sleep at night".

The video which accompanies the song shows the band gleefully dumping the tarpaulin-wrapped body of the abusive Earl and includes the line: "Earl had to die".

The song has been such a success that it is number eight in the Billboard pop charts and holds the number two spot in the country charts.

But while such a hit would normally be heard across the airwaves with enormous frequency, the song is experiencing problems getting airplay.

Although the Dixie Chicks have said that the song is meant to be "tongue-in-cheek", some radio stations believe that it sends the wrong message.

One radio programme director in Pennsylvania said that a line had to be drawn. "What do we do a song about next - school shootings?" A number of stations have decided not to play the song.

Initially the band's record company was reluctant to release the song as a single but changed its mind when it became clear that it was the most popular song on the album.

Some of those radio stations that are playing the song are suggesting that there are other ways of dealing with domestic violence. They supply the telephone numbers of local and national organisations that can offer help and refuge to abused victims.

The National Coalition Against Domestic Violence said that while it does not condone the action taken in the song, it welcomes the fact that it has raised the issue of wife abuse.

"Many battered women feel trapped and feel that violence is their only option to get away from the abuser," said Rita Smith, the coalition's executive director. "We don't want them feeling that way. We want them to know there are resources available to them.

"We want stations who play the record to tell their listeners that there is a hotline number they can call if they've been a victim of violence."

The writer of the song, Dennis Linde - who wrote Elvis Presley's 1972 hit Burning Love - says he considers it "a little story with lots of attitude. No message . . . I thought I was writing a black comedy like Arsenic and Old Lace or The Trouble with Harry."

fields.headline: Annan sets out UN targets
fields.standfirst: Secretary general calls for overhaul of 'antiquated' security council
fields.trailText: The secretary general of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, set targets for the organisation for the 21st century yesterday in a wide-ranging speech in which he also called for the reform of the antiquated security council, on which Britain has a permanent seat.
fields.body:
The secretary general of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, set targets for the organisation for the 21st century yesterday in a wide-ranging speech in which he also called for the reform of the antiquated security council, on which Britain has a permanent seat.

His 56-page speech, described by UN officials as the most important he has made, was to prepare the ground for a special UN millennium conference in New York from September 6 to 8 which he hopes will provide a platform for fundamental reforms.

He said the composition of the security council, on which Britain, France, the United States, Russia and China have permanent seats and vetoes, was based on the distribution of power and alignments in 1945 and "does not fully represent ei ther the character or the needs of our globalised world".

He said: "The council must work effectively, but it must also enjoy unquestioned legitimacy. Those two criteria define the space within which a solution must be found. I urge member states to tackle this challenge without delay."

The Foreign Office position is that it is prepared to accept reform but the problem is complex, with questions such as whether the European Union should have a seat and which countries would be chosen to represent Africa and Latin America. It is also to be decided whether the permanent members should retain a veto.

The UN millennium meeting could turn out to be the biggest ever meeting of government leaders: between 130 and 150 are expected to attend.

One of the main themes of Mr Annan's speech was to achieve a target of lifting 1bn people out of extreme poverty by 2015.

Education was a key element in achieving this. He said: "I urge the millennium summit to endorse the objectives of demonstrably narrowing the gender gap in primary and secondary education by 2005 and of ensuring that by 2015 all children complete a full course of primary education."

He hoped that by the same date the HIV/Aids epidemic would be halted, and the percentage of people without access to safe water would be cut in half.

With the world being transformed by a global economy and instant communications, Mr Annan said, "the central challenge we face today is to ensure that globalisation becomes a positive force for all the world's people, instead of leaving billions of them behind in squalor".

Calling extreme poverty "an affront to our common humanity", he said that nearly half the world's 6bn people were now living on less than $2 a day, and about 1.2bn were struggling on less than $1 a day - including 500m in south Asia and 300m in Africa.

He announced four new UN initiatives: to provide 10,000 hospitals and clinics in developing countries with access to up-to-date medical information; to have hi-tech volunteers give computer training to groups in developing countries; to provide mobile and satellite telephones for relief workers in disaster areas; and to explore new approaches to the problem of youth unemployment.

fields.headline: No: 1608 Guarana
fields.body:
Description: Brazil's favourite homegrown soft drink.

Appearance: golden.

Taste: sugary and fizzy, like a tropical Irn Bru.

Vital ingredient: extract of berries of guarana, an Amazonian plant with alleged aphrodisiac, medicinal and energy-giving properties.

Says who? Indians. They've been drinking it for generations.

Any proof? Legend has it that the first bush sprouted where a bolt of lightning hit lovers from rival tribes.

Corroborative evidence? "The drink is so powerful that while hunting, the Indians do not feel hunger from one day to the next," according to adventurer John Philip Bettendorf in the 17th-century.

How about some proper science? Guarana berries contain guaranine, which has similar effects to caffeine.

Sounds interesting. Where can I get some? It's coming soon to a bar near you. PepsiCo has done a deal in Brazil to distribute it worldwide.

How come? The tipple sells almost 1bn litres a year in Brazil, and ranks 15th among the world's top-selling soft drinks. PepsiCo hopes it will become a core side brand to Pepsi cola and eventually win 1% of the world soft drink market.

Any chance of that? Guarana extracts are already popular in many New Age products, which claim to give a natural high.

So is it a sure-fire success? Not certain. Pepsi has tried before. In 1996 it launched the guarana-infused Josta in the US, using rainforest imagery and an appeal to the drink's "primal power". But Josta proved impotent and was withdrawn last year.

Spurious guarana fact: Brazilians regard the drink as a symbol of national pride. One Brazilian president was such a fan that he had it shipped 800 miles to the national palace.

Do say: "Would Mr President be wanting some cigars with his guarana tonight?"

Don't say: "If it's from the Amazon, it'll be cheaper than Waterstones."

Not to be confused with: Guacamole, Guangzhou, the Guardian.
