fields.headline: Working late
fields.standfirst: Today most of us can expect 10 years of leisure between giving up work and death - but that may soon change. As BT plans to raise its retirement age beyond 70,  Richard Reeves  investigates the pros and cons of growing old at the office. While below,  Peregrine Worsthorne, who was forced to retire from the Sunday Telegraph, explains why he believes he should have had the right to stay on
fields.trailText: Today most of us can expect 10 years of leisure between giving up work and death - but that may soon change. As BT plans to raise its retirement age beyond 70,  Richard Reeves  investigates the pros and cons of growing old at the office. While below,  Peregrine Worsthorne, who was forced to retire from the Sunday Telegraph, explains why he believes he should have had the right to stay on
fields.body:
Wilma Smith has views on the value of employment for senior citizens that would warm even Gordon Brown's work-obsessed soul. "I know people who don't work, who sit and get fed up, and before you know it they are not around anymore. I'm not saying that the lack of work kills people, exactly, they just seem to fade away a bit."

Wilma is coy about her exact age - "I've been 39 for years," she insists - but will admit that she was born in 1922, which however you do your maths means she is well above retirement age. Yet she spends three days a week as an energetic and efficient assistant to a company secretary. Younger staff rate her: "She is fantastic," says one 26-year-old colleague.

"It is crazy to tell people they have to stop working at a certain age," she says. "I'd get so bored just sitting around."

Wilma and thousands like her were heartened by the news that BT is considering raising its retirement age to 70, challenging a long-term trend for workers to leave companies earlier. For campaigners against age discrimination, the shift represented by the BT move - mirrored elsewhere - is long overdue.

"The key issue is choice," says Helen Garner, campaign director of the Employers Forum on Age, which lobbies against ageism. "For too long people have been stereotyped as being useless once they hit 50, so any move against that is welcome."

There are signs elsewhere of a changing approach to older workers, as the pendulum swings back from the downsizing agenda of the 80s and early 90s, during which there was an implicit assumption that it was fairer to dump older workers. Supermarkets and bigger stores - most famously B&Q - are hiring older staff and introducing pension schemes that allow greater flexibility than traditional schemes. The BBC is increasingly using staff over retirement age on associate contracts. Midland Bank had to bring back older managers after a restructuring because of a lack of skills and knowledge. Shell is using senior managers to mentor small businesses. It's good to be grey.

"Most of the movement so far has been among people who are in receipt of a pension, but want to top it up with some contract or part-time work," says Garner. "Very often, companies keep quiet about it because there can be tax implications, but it is definitely happening."

At first sight, the case for companies, and indeed Governments, raising retirement ages seems a no-brainer. People are living longer and more healthily, meaning that they are productive for longer; the structure of the population means that without reform we face a demographic time bomb as tomorrow's workers struggle to pay the pensions of the retired baby-boomers; the nature of work has changed so that raw physical strength is less important than intellectual skills, experience and knowledge - all of which older workers have in abundance.

In 1960, most people could expect a gap of between two to three years between their last day at work and their last rites. Today, the gap is over 10 years, and many workers can look forward to decades of retirement. A recent report by JP Morgan estimates that without a change in policies by both firms and governments, living standards could drop by 15% as huge pension bills hit the doormats of the shrinking working population.

And for many, of course, work brings social advantages, a social circle, a sense of belonging. "I work partly because I like the company," says Wilma, who works at the Industrial Society. The dispersal of families increases this need. "Maybe if you have lots of family around you it's OK," she says. "But most of my family are in Italy, and some in Australia." Later retirement could also help to rebalance working lives in a more family-friendly direction, rather than cramming all the work into the decades when children are most likely to be on the scene.

Against this backdrop, early retirement seems crazy - but out dated attitudes to the value of older workers have been pushing companies in that direction. "More than two thirds of retirements take place before official retirement age," says Garner. "The growth in early retirement has been fastest on the grounds of efficiency or redundancy, not ill health." Negative attitudes about age are hard to shake off.

Economic and social trends all seem to point to a loosening-up of the retirement age. Nonetheless, the debate remains a thorny one. Charities representing older people see an increase in retirement ages as eroding our right to a long and enjoyable post-work life, and worry that workers in less skilled jobs will lose out.

"It might be satisfactory for professional, skilled people," says a spokesman for Age Concern. "But what about people who are not well-paid, who are not as skilled? Simply moving up the retirement age is prejudiced against them."

She also said that moving the retirement age risked breaking a moral contract with workers who have been paying into their pension fund. "If you have been paying in with an expectation that you can draw out at a certain age then it is deeply unfair to change that," she said.

But for the moment, employment trends mean that firms are working harder to retain older workers. Skills shortages - especially in manage ment, which appears to be the biggest headache - and low unemployment mean that firms in the south are courting the older worker. "I'd like to think there had been a change in attitudes," says Garner. "But I think the truth is that the condition of the job market is what is really concentrating minds. Employers need the skills, it is as simple as that."

But any moves that challenge ageist assumptions are to be welcomed, she said, not least because of the effects on workers lower down the age distribution. "Once we started seeing 50 as a retirement age, it didn't seem worth training 45-year-olds." Research shows that people believe that age discrimination starts as early as 42.

There is also good evidence that older workers might be better value for money; they are less likely to leave, more likely to turn up to work - B&Q found absenteeism rates were 39% lower among older workers - and, according to Wilma, more committed to the job at hand. "With older workers you know they are working because they really want to rather than because they have to," she points out.

She certainly intends to keep going. For her, the prospect of working until the end is exciting. "I think I'll just keep going," she says. "I don't see why I should stop. I'll keep going."

In praise of gerontocracy: it's time the pendulum swung back
By Peregrine Worsthorne
O ne person's delayed retirement is another person's delayed promotion, as the middle-aged Prince Charles would be the first to recognise. Indeed, that is how I used to look at the question during my own very many years as a deputy editor of the Sunday Telegraph. But of course it wasn't how I looked at the matter when I, in my turn, was eventually chucked out aged 65 to make way for a younger man whose abilities I rated no higher than my own. So like most others who are compulsorily retired from jobs they are enjoying and, in their own opinion, doing well, I felt hard done by and frustrated. Which, in a way, I still do.

Whether 65, let alone 60, is the right age for compulsory retirement, however, is another matter, bearing in mind the prospect of all of us living for so much longer - in many cases to 100. Given this prospect, surely it is time we did start moving back to the old retirement age of 70 or 75, which would be fair to all.

Take myself, for example. Now that I am 76, I do feel both physically and mentally ready for retirement, which I most certainly did not 10 years ago. Concentration is indeed fading, as is memory and also interest and curiosity. If retirement had been delayed until now, it would have come as a blessed relief rather than a cursed deprivation.

Likewise, looking at it from the other end of the spectrum, if retirement was postponed to 70 or 75 - as is now being proposed - 50 year olds, with another quarter of a century of active life to look forward to, would be feeling in less of an urgent hurry for promotion.

Of course there is no ideal age for retirement, and never can be, since some of us are born longing for retirement almost as soon as we put our shoulders to the wheel and others cannot face the prospect of idleness until they have both feet in the grave; nor does age always bring with it wisdom and experience any more than youth always guarantees energy and enterprise. Sometimes you have young heads on old shoulders, and just as often - as in the case of the young William Rees-Mogg - you have very old heads on very young shoulders. In other words, maximum flexibility and minimum uniformity must be the right approach to the retirement age. As for so much else.

But the result will never really satisfy everyone. For if the old are left in charge they will tend to favour their contemporaries for the plum jobs - the old-boy network - which is unfair to the young and if the young come to the top early, they in turn will practice the same kind of favouritism. In short, the choice is between gerontocracy - which used to be the order of the day when I was young - or youthocracy, which has been the order of the day in my old age, condemning me to the worst of both worlds.

A lthough the swing back of the pendulum to gerontocracy will be too late for me and many others, it is a good thing if it happens, since the young have been having it all their own way, in most walks of life, for far too long, with results that scarcely inspire confidence, judging by the reduction of standards in the increasingly youth-led institutions, from the prime ministership down to the media, where the average age of editors has never been lower. So it is no accident that the most revered figure of our time - indeed the only revered figure of our times - is an octogenarian pope.

B ut what about the benefits of early retirement for those who cannot wait to escape the harness - won't they be the losers if the retirement age is put back to where it was in the bad old days? Indeed they will, which is why it certainly should not be put back for those who have dull jobs from which no satisfaction can be drawn. For them, escape with a decent pension should come as early as the economy will allow for. But for managing directors and their like - top dogs - who long to carry on with all the perks, it should come as late as possible, since there is no more off-putting and demoralising spectacle than of them guzzling and boozing away fat pensions and redundancy payments in mid-week, post-golf lunches in expensive pubs and clubs throughout the home counties.

On balance I think Dr Johnson (or was it Adam Smith?) was right when he said that man is never so innocently employed as when he is earning money, to which I would add, and never so frustratingly employed as when spending it, which is all that early retirement leaves the erstwhile high-earners to do. Workers of the world unite, you have nothing to gain by losing your chains. So in thy mercy, oh Lord, keep us at it until we drop.

 Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society.

fields.trailText: A business story, page 26, March 29, said that Sainsbury's was donating 100,000 tonnes of unsold food to charity, in part to reduce food dumped in landfill sites which create gases harmful to the ozone layer. In fact, Sainsbury's is giving about 1,000 tonnes. And while methane from dumps adds to the greenhouse effect, it does not damage the ozone (CFCs do).

A business story, page 26, March 29, said that Sainsbury's was donating 100,000 tonnes of unsold food to charity, in part to reduce food dumped in landfill sites which create gases harmful to the ozone layer. In fact, Sainsbury's is giving about 1,000 tonnes. And while methane from dumps adds to the greenhouse effect, it does not damage the ozone (CFCs do).

The scenic photograph, page 12, April 2, showed the Isle of Rum but was captioned as being the Isle of Skye. The photographer apologises for the unintentional island swapping - he slipped in selecting that frame from a series.

Numbers from the April 1 lottery were misprinted on page 8, April 3. The correct sequence is 3 11 19 25 29 30. Bonus 16.

The exhibitions preview yesterday on page 19 in G2, London edition only, said that the Romantic Landscape exhibition at the Tate would run until March 17. It runs until September 17.

No.

fields.headline: Focus: Associated British Foods
fields.trailText: Associated British Foods is selling its ice-cream operations to Richmond Foods for £18.8m after deciding it was no longer a core business. That follows a board review of ABF's activities to identify businesses that were failing to return shareholder value.
fields.body:
Associated British Foods is selling its ice-cream operations to Richmond Foods for £18.8m after deciding it was no longer a core business. That follows a board review of ABF's activities to identify businesses that were failing to return shareholder value.

The ice-cream business, Allied Frozen Foods, makes about 300 products, 95% of which are sold under own-label brands. The remaining 5% is sold under the Jeffrey's name. Last year the business had an operating profit of £300,000 on sales of £48.4m.

ABF has been out of favour for some time - its share price was 640p two years ago. The market failed to get excited about yesterday's deal and knocked a further 7.5p off the price to 408p.

The move will double the size of Richmond Foods, which is based in Northallerton, Yorkshire. A spokesman said it would help it become "a full line supplier" of ice-cream to supermarkets.

"It will also give us a foothold in the fast-growing food service market, and will allow us to manufacture some of the products we currently purchase overseas for the Treats brand business in the impulse market," he said.

Under the deal, Allied's four plants in Kent and the West Country will be transferred to Richmond's frozen confectionery subsidiary, along with a workforce of around 500. The sale is dependent upon not being referred to the competition commission.

Peter Jackson, ABF"s chief executive, said: "We signalled at the time of our results last year that we would be focusing our activities in markets where we are well positioned to maximise shareholder value and this action is a part of that process."

webTitle: Asia pays the social price of boom and bust

fields.headline: Asia pays the social price of boom and bust
fields.standfirst: News Analysis: Tigers turn Tigger to bounce out of crisis -but it's a long way from business as usua
fields.trailText: Asian policymakers moved closer over the weekend towards accepting the need for improved social safety nets in the wake of a financial crisis that has worsened regional inequality and shaken the long-standing belief that economic development alone can alleviate poverty.
fields.body:
Asian policymakers moved closer over the weekend towards accepting the need for improved social safety nets in the wake of a financial crisis that has worsened regional inequality and shaken the long-standing belief that economic development alone can alleviate poverty.

At a forum in Seoul, finance ministers and leading economists from Apec - the world's largest regional economic grouping - patted themselves on the back for Asia's stunning turnaround, but there was a widespread recognition that the post-crisis climate will not allow business as usual. "We in Asia must spend more time on social reform. We have spent a little too much time on the economy," said Supachai Panitchpakdi, deputy prime minister of Thailand.

The Apec gathering was initiated by South Korean president Kim Dae-jung to discuss the lessons of the 1997-98 financial crisis and how to minimise the impact of a recurrence.

South Korea has led the way in Asia's recovery. Last year, its economy jumped out of recession with growth of 10.7%, compared to minus 5.8% in 1998. The Seoul stock market recently hit record highs and the country's foreign exchange reserves are now at $80bn, compared to $3.9bn when the crisis hit.

The other Tiger economies - Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore and, to a lesser extent, Indonesia - have also turned Tigger by bouncing back quicker than expected, but many economists at the forum warned that the "Asian miracle" of uninterrupted growth has been superceded by a more painful era of conventional boom-and-bust capitalism.

"The next crisis is inevitable," said Stephen Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "The time to act is now." However, delegates were divided on both the causes of and the best remedies for the crisis.

The prevailing view in Asia is that the instability was sparked by ruthless international speculators and exacerbated by the clumsy response of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. To tackle this, Asian nations have proposed the establishment of a regional monetary fund - a call that was supported in Seoul by last year's Nobel economic laureate Robert Mundell. But this is unlikely to be realised because the United States has repeatedly shot down possible challenges to the influence of the IMF.

The momentum for reform of Asia's economies has also slowed as the sense of crisis has ebbed. Banks remain saddled with huge non-performing loans and the restructuring of unprofitable conglomerates, such as Daewoo in South Korea, has slowed.

Daewoo, the country's second biggest car manufacturer, was the focus of a march through Seoul on Saturday to protest against a possible foreign takeover. "Foreign companies kill jobs," chanted the demonstrators in a crowd estimated by participants at 15,000 people. Four foreign companies, including General Motors, Ford, Fiat and Daimler Chrysler are in the bidding along with Hyundai Motor, leader in the domestic industry. The protesters said they wanted the South Korean government to take the company over and save jobs. One senior financial official said the workers reaction illustrated how "Asia has not even gone 30% of the way towards the reforms it needs to avoid another crisis".

But there was more agreement on the importance of minimising the social impact of economic downturns. Although Asia is out of crisis, unemployment remains high in most countries, and the gap between the region's rich and poor is growing faster than ever.

Earlier this year, president Kim introduced South Korea's most advanced wel fare policy with legal guarantees on basic living conditions, education and medical care, as well as increased state resources for the re-training and re-employment of the workforce. He proposed the regional adoption of this "productive welfare" system which emphasises the development of human resources - a departure from Asia's long-standing focus on infrastructure projects and European-style support of living standards for the needy.

He also suggested the creation of an Apec social safety net that would help countries hit by earthquakes, floods and other natural disasters with a pool of funds from governments and private companies.

Given the sprawling nature of the Apec group, which includes powers such as the United States and minnows such as Papua New Guinea, such a proposal may be tough to realise, but it is not the only sign that Asia's policymakers are starting to look beyond the economy.

fields.bodyText: Asian policymakers moved closer over the weekend towards accepting the need for improved social safety nets in the wake of a financial crisis that has worsened regional inequality and shaken the long-standing belief that economic development alone can alleviate poverty. At a forum in Seoul, finance ministers and leading economists from Apec - the world's largest regional economic grouping - patted themselves on the back for Asia's stunning turnaround, but there was a widespread recognition that the post-crisis climate will not allow business as usual. "We in Asia must spend more time on social reform. We have spent a little too much time on the economy," said Supachai Panitchpakdi, deputy prime minister of Thailand. The Apec gathering was initiated by South Korean president Kim Dae-jung to discuss the lessons of the 1997-98 financial crisis and how to minimise the impact of a recurrence. South Korea has led the way in Asia's recovery. Last year, its economy jumped out of recession with growth of 10.7%, compared to minus 5.8% in 1998. The Seoul stock market recently hit record highs and the country's foreign exchange reserves are now at $80bn, compared to $3.9bn when the crisis hit. The other Tiger economies - Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore and, to a lesser extent, Indonesia - have also turned Tigger by bouncing back quicker than expected, but many economists at the forum warned that the "Asian miracle" of uninterrupted growth has been superceded by a more painful era of conventional boom-and-bust capitalism. "The next crisis is inevitable," said Stephen Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "The time to act is now." However, delegates were divided on both the causes of and the best remedies for the crisis. The prevailing view in Asia is that the instability was sparked by ruthless international speculators and exacerbated by the clumsy response of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. To tackle this, Asian nations have proposed the establishment of a regional monetary fund - a call that was supported in Seoul by last year's Nobel economic laureate Robert Mundell. But this is unlikely to be realised because the United States has repeatedly shot down possible challenges to the influence of the IMF. The momentum for reform of Asia's economies has also slowed as the sense of crisis has ebbed. Banks remain saddled with huge non-performing loans and the restructuring of unprofitable conglomerates, such as Daewoo in South Korea, has slowed. Daewoo, the country's second biggest car manufacturer, was the focus of a march through Seoul on Saturday to protest against a possible foreign takeover. "Foreign companies kill jobs," chanted the demonstrators in a crowd estimated by participants at 15,000 people. Four foreign companies, including General Motors, Ford, Fiat and Daimler Chrysler are in the bidding along with Hyundai Motor, leader in the domestic industry. The protesters said they wanted the South Korean government to take the company over and save jobs. One senior financial official said the workers reaction illustrated how "Asia has not even gone 30% of the way towards the reforms it needs to avoid another crisis". But there was more agreement on the importance of minimising the social impact of economic downturns. Although Asia is out of crisis, unemployment remains high in most countries, and the gap between the region's rich and poor is growing faster than ever. Earlier this year, president Kim introduced South Korea's most advanced wel fare policy with legal guarantees on basic living conditions, education and medical care, as well as increased state resources for the re-training and re-employment of the workforce. He proposed the regional adoption of this "productive welfare" system which emphasises the development of human resources - a departure from Asia's long-standing focus on infrastructure projects and European-style support of living standards for the needy. "As a result we have switched to policy of poverty reduction rather than economic development."

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: It was not an easy day for the London market.
fields.body:
It was not an easy day for the London market.

Aside from the fact that most market participants did not know what was going on for the first half of the day, due to technical problems, it quickly became clear that last week's savage bout of techno-jitters had not blown away over the weekend.

Both the FTSE 100 and the Techmark 100 index were heading south before news of the impending Microsoft judgement broke. That was good for 15% off the price of Microsoft in the US even before details emerged.

In the event, the top 100 closed at 6462.1, down 78.1, while the tech 100 slumped a full 5.7%, off 2147.5 points at 4083.3.

The heavy damage came from the telecoms sector, where Vodafone slid from 348p to 334p and British Telecom gave up 33p to £11.42. Several of the big American investment banks were reported to have cut their recommendations on European telecom stocks.

Media stocks in for a thumping included advertising group WPP , which ran back from £11.02 to 988p, while Reuters fell from £12.72 to £11.52. Its Tibco networking associate, listed on Nasdaq, shed 8% during early US trading.

In the oil sector the post-Opec honeymoon came to an end with a 16p fall in BP Amoco to 557p and a 6p slip in Shell to 514p.

Lower down the corporate scale, shares in ladieswear manufacturer Slimma suddenly put on 10p to 34p. The stock is very thinly traded and dealers attributed the surge to buying by private client speculators.

Car dealer DC Cook jumped from 12p to 18p after news that it plans to launch an online insurance service, while patent licensing specialist Scipher surged from 602 to 720p after a weekend stock tip.

But it was not a good first day for sports website Teamtalk.com . Against a placing price of 145p, the market price quickly fell to 82p.

There was further evidence as to why "old economy" companies should fear the "new economy" and hope that dot.com punting fever has come to an end.

An outfit called surfCONTROL, which says it is a specialist in "corporate filtering" and internet access management, has published a survey claiming that the average employee spending one hour of work time surfing the net for personal reasons - cyberskiving - costs a company £20,000.

Online stock trading at work, meanwhile, costs companies £10 for every £6 trade, according to the consultancy.

webTitle: UK firm to test breast cancer 'tumour killer'

fields.headline: UK firm to test breast cancer 'tumour killer'
fields.trailText: Drug development company Antisoma believes it could have found the "holy grail" in treating breast cancer by identifying a protein that makes tumours commit suicide.
fields.body:
Drug development company Antisoma believes it could have found the "holy grail" in treating breast cancer by identifying a protein that makes tumours commit suicide.

When injected into the blood, the protein triggers enzymes called DNase which live inside cancer cells. It makes DNase chew up the cells' DNA, causing them to die naturally.

This approach contrasts with most anti-cancer treatments, which contain a toxic substance aimed at delivering a killer blow to tumours. Because of their toxicity, they often cause damaging side-effects. Antisoma's chief executive Glyn Edwards said: "We know what the holy grail is. This could be it." News of the development sent Antisoma's shares up 24p to 192p.

Mr Edwards said the treatment was "potentially side effect-free", although he cautioned that it had only been tested on cells in the laboratory. "This is an idea which has been in development for some time. It's still at an early stage, but we are extremely excited about its potential." Antisoma plans to begin clinical trials using human volunteers and animals by next year. Mr Edwards said: "We're confident enough to go for large-scale trials." Trials and regulatory review of the compound could take up to five years.

Antisoma's chief scientific officer, Agamemnon Epenetos, began working on the protein in the mid-1990s, while affiliated to the Imperial Cancer Research Fund.

Antisoma was spun out of the fund some years later, but the charity still has a 7.9% stake.Work on the compound has continued at Antisoma's laboratories at St George's Hospital, Tooting, and at Imperial College. The development team has only recently managed to get the protein into a form in which it can be delivered effectively to breast cancer cells.

The results were announced yesterday at a meeting of the American Association for Cancer Research in San Francisco.

Professor Epenetos said: "We believe we have developed a way to push the cancer cell towards choosing to commit suicide. In this case, the cell breaks down naturally and the body's natural mechanism sweeps up the debris."

Production of the compound is set to be contracted out to a third party. If successful, Antisoma said the same process could be used to target other variants of the disease, including lung, pancreatic, prostate and gastric cancer.

Originally listed on the European market Easdaq, Antisoma joined the main stock market in December. The company has a treatment for ovarian cancer, Theragyn, in phase three clinical trials.

Drugs company Cambridge Antibody Technology has scaled back its fundraising from £100m to £90m because of market conditions. The company said investors were "nervous", pointing out that the Nasdaq biotech index had fallen by 31% since it announced its placing of shares.

fields.headline: Founder courts controversy
fields.trailText: Brian Souter has acquired a reputation as a colourful and controversial entrepreneur. He is under attack by gay and lesbian groups for leading the campaign, in which he has invested thousands of pounds, against the abolition of Clause 28 .
fields.body:
Brian Souter has acquired a reputation as a colourful and controversial entrepreneur. He is under attack by gay and lesbian groups for leading the campaign, in which he has invested thousands of pounds, against the abolition of Clause 28 .

With sister Ann Gloag, he founded their company in 1980 with two second hand coaches on a single route from Dundee to London.

They financed their acquisitions through family capital and bank facilities. Large doubledeck coaches were introduced and new express coach services offered between Scottish cities.

After years of growth boosted the founders' personal fortune to £600m, the share price has flagged and critics say that it has overstretched itself too in the US bus market.

webTitle: Factory output up despite oil and sterling pressures

fields.headline: Factory output up despite oil and sterling pressures
fields.trailText: Manufacturers increased output for the eleventh month in a row last month despite being squeezed by sterling's renewed strength on one side and and rising oil prices on the other, new figures showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Manufacturers increased output for the eleventh month in a row last month despite being squeezed by sterling's renewed strength on one side and and rising oil prices on the other, new figures showed yesterday.

Fierce competition is making it impossible for firms to raise prices at the factory gate, despite absorbing the sharpest jump in fuel and raw material costs for more than four and half years, according to the latest snapshot of the sector from the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply.

The institute's activity index stood at 51.4 in March, a fraction above the 51.1 figure recorded in February but below the levels seen in the last half of 1999. A reading above 50 indicates expansion: below 50 marks a contraction.

Post-millennium hiccups are still troubling the sector, according to the institute.

"The effects of Y2K stockpiling are still curtailing growth in the manufacturing economy," the report warned. "The running down of Y2K safety stocks was cited as a factor behind a fall in the rate of growth of orders for the third month running in March."

Analysts warned that with order books filling at a slower rate, growth is likely to stall later in the year.

Richard Iley, UK economist at ABN Amro, said: "With the pound once again touching DM3.25 and the remnants of the UK car industry struggling to survive, worse is likely to come."

Firms are continuing to shed workers as they have done for most of the last two years, according to the institute. "Natural wastage and redundancies arising from the need to cut costs and improve productivity were again widely reported in March," it said.

Analysts said that despite the sharp jump in input prices, there was nothing in the survey to worry the Bank of England's monetary policy committee which starts its monthly interest rate meeting later this week.

"Even the most paranoid interest-rate hawk would be hard pressed to argue there is currently a genuine inflationary threat from the manufacturing sector," said Mr Iley.

While British industry is wilting under the pressure of sterling's rise, separate figures also released yesterday showed that the plummeting euro is boosting European manufacturing.

The Eurozone purchasing managers' index stood at 59.4 last month. This is more than two points higher than in February.

Audrey Childe-Freeman, economist at CIBC World Markets, said: "Conditions are now well above the recovery stage, with the sharp surge in the main activity index pointing at a strong acceleration in the industrial sector activity.

"Looking further ahead, it would appear that the outlook is even better, as the forward looking new orders index showed another sharp monthly increase last month."

fields.headline: Stagecoach profits alert
fields.standfirst: £300m wiped off value of transport operator
fields.trailText: Stagecoach, Britain's largest bus and train operator, yesterday issued its first profits warning, sending its shares crashing by nearly a fifth and wiping £300m off the company's value.
fields.body:
Stagecoach, Britain's largest bus and train operator, yesterday issued its first profits warning, sending its shares crashing by nearly a fifth and wiping £300m off the company's value.

The company, run by Brian Souter, blamed rising fuel prices and problems in recruiting bus drivers. It said they were pushing up costs in Britain and at its recently acquired US subsidiary, Coach USA. It is also writing down the value of Prestwick airport by £30m following the loss of its principal freight customer, Federal Express.

The company, whose financial year concludes at the end of April, gave no detailed reason for the warning. Profits from the core British buses operation would be "about the same as last year", it said.

It boosted its financial position by selling its train leasing company, Porterbrook, to Abbey National for £1.44 bn. This will result in a net inflow of cash of £773m, some of which will be used to fund a £250m share buyout.

Stagecoach has been searching for a buyer for some time. Although Porterbrook has been strengthening its position since it was acquired by Mr Souter four years ago, Stagecoach wants to develop other commercial interests on which it says greater returns can be achieved.

The company's new chief executive, Keith Cochrane, who has just replaced Mike Kinsky, said it was "important to give a realistic overview" of Stagecoach's prospects, but said that the long-term outlook for the company looked rosy.

Within minutes of the announcement, Stagecoach shares fell 20.5p to 101p, having been as low as 90p at one stage.

webTitle: Two drop out of phone auction here

fields.headline: Two drop out of phone auction here
fields.trailText: Crescent Wireless and Eircom yesterday became the first to withdraw from the poker-style bidding in the government's auction of third generation mobile phone licences as the stakes were raised to almost £11bn.
fields.body:
Crescent Wireless and Eircom yesterday became the first to withdraw from the poker-style bidding in the government's auction of third generation mobile phone licences as the stakes were raised to almost £11bn.

Nomura subsidiary Epsilon is likely to be next to pull out of the race for one of the five licences on offer because it stood down from one of the auction rounds.

A bidder is excluded from competing once it has waived bidding in three auction rounds.

The exit of Crescent Wireless, a vehicle of Global Crossing, and Eircom leaves at 11 the number of bidders competing for a licence.

However, Eircom is pinning its hopes on buying some spectrum from one of the five successful bidders. "At the current bidding levels it becomes almost an economic requirement for the winning bidders," an Eircom spokesman said. "Our strategy is now focused on becoming a mobile virtual network operator."

Eircom chief executive Alfie Kane added: "We believe that the business case, especially for a new entrant, is too uncertain beyond Ir£2.5 (£2bn)."

Vodafone remained in the lead on licence B, the biggest licence available to the four existing operators, with a bid of £2.5bn. Spain's Telefonica was next with an offer of £2.2bn for licence A, reserved for new entrants. Top bids on the other licences were made by Canada's TIW at £2.1bn, WorldCom at £2.12bn and Orange at £2.1bn.

Winners will be able to hold the licences for a 20-year period which expires in 2021.

fields.headline: Departures leave gap at Kleinwort's
fields.trailText: A top-ranking team of analysts resigned from Dresdner Kleinwort Benson yesterday, prompting fears of a mass exodus from the City investment bank, which has an uncertain future.
fields.body:
A top-ranking team of analysts resigned from Dresdner Kleinwort Benson yesterday, prompting fears of a mass exodus from the City investment bank, which has an uncertain future.

The defection by the seven-strong team of equity analysts to Salomon Smith Barney came despite the promise of "golden handcuffs" from Kleinwort's, whose German parent company, Dresdner Bank, is merging with its closest rival, Deutsche Bank.

While Deutsche initially insisted Kleinwort's was a "jewel" which would not be a casualty of the groundbreaking deal, it is now expected to announce this week that the equities operation of the business will be sold to a rival.

Yesterday Kleinwort's refused to comment on the departure of part of the utilities team, led by Tony White who is being appointed a managing director at Salomon Smith Barney. The team is ranked second for its research of European utility firms.

The defection came days after the investment bank paid annual bonuses to its staff - long-established as a period of musical chairs between City firms - and asked for their patience for one more week during which time it hoped to resolve the issues about its future.

While Kleinwort's promised to pay staff half of their bonuses again provided they stay until July, insiders and rivals believe this does not go far enough to act as a deterrent to prevent top staff leaving.

"July is too far away and you can just factor that into any talks with another firm," one banker said.

Speculation was mounting yesterday that an announcement about the future of Kleiwort's would be made later this week, when Deutsche Bank and Dresdner are due to publish their annual results.

A number of suitors have been named for the bank, including Chase Manhattan which is already in talks about buying Robert Fleming, the privately-owned British investment bank.

fields.headline: Stuck in the woods
fields.standfirst: You have to admire the craft of the Greenhouse Effect artists at the Serpentine. But, asks  Adrian Searle, do they have anything new to say about our relationship with nature?
fields.trailText: You have to admire the craft of the Greenhouse Effect artists at the Serpentine. But, asks Adrian Searle, do they have anything new to say about our relationship with nature?
fields.body:
Walking through Kensington Gardens in central London on a spring afternoon, things are poking through the soil, there's blossom on the ornamental cherry trees and obscene, sticky sci-fi buds bursting on the boughs of the chestnuts. Nature's at it again.

But it isn't natural, is it? The squirrels the kids coo over are American imports that have killed off our native species. The cormorants perched on the posts in the lake shouldn't be inland, but have nothing left to eat in the North Sea. There's almost nothing natural about the park - not the artfully placed stands of trees, the acres of greensward, or the carefully managed stands of bankside reeds.

The Greenhouse Effect, an international exhibition about nature and artifice at the gardens' Serpentine Gallery, made me think about all this. The guest curator, Ralph Rugoff, has filled the galleries with a simulated riot of nature. Walking into the climate-controlled, gravity-defying upside- down rainforest of exotic greenery that grows from the ceiling and fills one of the Serpentine's spaces, I conclude, reluctantly, that Kew Gardens has more to offer. Bringing the outside inside is one of contemporary art's more persistent cliches.

It is difficult to see The Greenhouse Effect as anything other than a sampling of the many artists whose work is in some way concerned with our relationship to nature. The hard part, of course, is to say anything meaningful about the relationship, rather than indulging in a lot of hand-wringing about despoliation and mystic clap-trap about our being part of, rather than apart from, the natural world. Mark Dion's catalogue manifesto, consisting of notes on the ethical relationship between the artist and the environment, try to map out a territory of action, but like all manifestos, it veers between the goody-goody and the apopleptic.

Many of the artists here - too many, in fact - simply copy nature, not to show how close we are to it, but to point up the schism between the natural world and human artifice. To be cynical, the generation that read Jean Baudrillard so avidly in the 80s must have found all the controversy over genetic engineering and cloning, and the advent of virtual reality, a confirmation of the belief that the world is becoming a simulacrum of itself, and that what is left of nature now is only a theme park.

The artists here demonstrate great skill and amazing technical resourcefulness in their trompe-l'oeil re-creations, just as 18th and 19th century ornithological and botanical painters so faithfully recorded the curl of every feather, the form of every stamen. Tim Hawkinson has made a tiny, fragile and entirely believable skeleton of a baby bird from his own nail clippings, and a feather from the hairs on the back of his neck. It is all done with a magnifying glass and superglue. His huge root ball, a great gnarled, tuberous tree stump, is made, appropriately enough, from paper, while his perfectly lifelike spider's web is, again, knotted from his own hair. Tom Friedman has made life-size insects from the most modern materials (Play-Doh, fishing line, plastic and something called fuzz). His dragonfly - a perfect double-take - perches on the edge of a white minimal cuboid.

His Daddy Long Legs waits on the wall, although it isn't what we would call a daddy long legs (the adult crane fly), but one of those long-legged autumnal spiders with a body like a dun-coloured pea. Yoshiro Suda's flowering ivy, its long tendril sprouting from the wall, has been hand-carved from wood, while Roxy Paine's Psilocybe Cubensis Field covers the floor with 2,200 polymer hallucinogenic mushrooms. It goes on: seaweed and lichen tabletop forests, plastic weeds, man-made tree fungus and rice-glue mould.

This is all very well, but taken together these works all suffer a distinct lack of artistic biodiversity. The artist Vincent Shine, for one, was doing much the same thing a decade ago. The desire to recreate nature, to turn it into a symbol and to possess it in some way, has a pedigree that goes back to the cave. It made me think of Albrecht Durer's wonderful early 16th-century drawing of a patch of turf, and how his attention to a tiny unregarded patch of fertile sod fills the viewer's imagination with an entire natural world. At its best, all this stuff should lead you back to the world rather than away from it.

Nina Katchadourian tries to trick spiders with her patches of "lightly starched Mölnlycke red sewing thread reinforced with polyvinyl glue", with which she repairs their torn webs. The spiders aren't fooled, and reject her patched repairs. Maybe they don't like red. Katchadourian goes to inordinate lengths to record the spiders' reaction to her efforts, in what can only be a spoof of arachnid research. That said, back in the 60s researchers really did drug spiders with LSD, booze and coffee to see how their web building technique was affected. Spaced-out and pissed, the spiders managed somehow, even if they lost concentration for a bit; jazzed-up on caffeine, however, they really made a botch of things. The research was more bizarre and fascinating than this.

And that's the trouble. Real entomology, botany and zoology reveal far more interesting aspects of the natural world than anything here. But then again, hard science also begets monsters, like Dolly the sheep and Monsanto. The argument is, of course, that man has been genetically engineering plants and mucking about with Darwin's order since the first crop was planted, the first wild dog was tamed. If this exhibition is trying to talk about the loss of nature, it should go beyond the sentimental and nostalgic yearning for a golden age that cannot be reclaimed, because it never existed.

The truth is, though, the decline of the natural world is probably irreversible. Yet there is a place for wonder, even if it is tinged with loss. Anya Gallachio has replanted a grubbed-up old apple tree from an orchard, and it is bursting into leaf on the gallery floor. Michel Blazy's artificial rain, drooled from threads of hot glue suspended from the ceiling, has a wonderful sparkling, ephemeral quality. There's a much harder edge to Olafur Eliasson's artificial rain room, Your Strange Certainty Still Kept.

A curtain of water rains down into a trough, in a darkened room lit by a bank of strobe lights. The rain freeze-frames in the flashes, appearing to dance, and even fall upwards towards the ceiling. The effect is magical, but so is watching rain fall through car headlights, or watching bats hawking for insects around a street light - an experience at once natural and unnatural.

This is not a show of great art, but it is perfect for the Serpentine. Perhaps the most telling work is Rachel Berwick's May-por-e'. Berwick has installed an octagonal, translucent-walled aviary in a low-lit space. It is a shadow-show of foliage, and contains two live parrots. We hear the insect-loud forest, the call of the parrots, whose real voices mingle with recordings of themselves. A text on the wall tells of the demise of the Maypure people of Amazonia, who died out following inter-tribal warfare a couple of hundred years ago.

The parrots, it is said, have retained the last traces of the tribal language, like living tape recordings. This, of course, is a fiction, although the parrots have been trained to utter strange cries that echo an unknown human speech. It is a wonderfully elegiac work. Huge efforts, too, have been made to ensure the well-being and comfort of these two reared-in-captivity birds, and the fact that we cannot see them adds to whatever sense of wonder we might have left in us.

Meanwhile, in a linked artwork at the Natural History Museum, Swedish artist Henrik Hakansson - who gave us the upside down forest - has dotted cameras around the museum's wildlife garden. Underwater cameras spy tadpoles and newts in the murky water. A camera is trained on a blue tit's nest, still being built. There are cameras everywhere, relaying live action to a screen among the taxidermological dioramas inside. Not great art, if art at all, and you wonder why the museum staff never thought to do this themselves.

 The Greenhouse Effect is at the Serpentine Gallery, London W2 (0171-298 1515), till May 21.

fields.headline: Northern exposure
fields.standfirst: 'Jobs for all' is Labour's new ethos. But unless the infrastructures of the most deprived regions are improved, employers will not relocate
fields.trailText: One of Labour's "unifying themes" for next time round - so the Guardian reported on Saturday - is employment opportunities for all. To that end, the chancellor published a paper just before the Budget boldly entitled The Goal of Full Employment. Its purpose was to downgrade the importance of regional differences - the proverbial north-south divide. Reference is made instead to "pockets of high unemployment".
fields.body:
One of Labour's "unifying themes" for next time round - so the Guardian reported on Saturday - is employment opportunities for all. To that end, the chancellor published a paper just before the Budget boldly entitled The Goal of Full Employment. Its purpose was to downgrade the importance of regional differences - the proverbial north-south divide. Reference is made instead to "pockets of high unemployment".

In these "small areas" people with particular problems in finding work are con centrated but (the document says) they are almost all "within travelling distance of labour markets with high levels of vacancies". The government concludes that, in addition to welfare-to-work and skill enhancement programmes, "further measures" may be needed, "specifically targeted at helping people in the most deprived areas to be able to compete more effectively for jobs".

At first sight the unemployment figures for the English regions are encouraging. Differences between them are rather small by the standards of the past 20 years. Official unemployment measured as a proportion of all men and women aged 16-64 is higher in Merseyside but not by much. Yet there is a shortage of jobs in the regions and it is worse than the official figures suggest.

Many of those without jobs are counted as "inactive" in official surveys rather than unemployed. Large numbers of women never enter the labour force if work is not available whilst many men who lose their jobs end up on incapacity benefit. Differences between regions in such "inactivity" are far greater than in unemployment. On this measure the spread between Merseyside, again the worst region, and the south-east is bigger.

Of course, many people are out of the labour force because they have children or relatives to care for, because they are in school or college or suffer from ill health - reasons which may be unconnected with lack of work. But such reasons for inactivity will not differ much between the regions. They cannot account for huge differences in their employment rates.

To bring employment as a proportion of the population of working age up to the average of the south (the south-east outside London, East Anglia and the south-west) would require 1.75m more jobs than exist at present. This "jobs deficit" is a measure of the specifically regional or north-south employment problem which needs to be distinguished from the problem of localised concentrations of deprivation which can be found in the south as well.

Unemployment and inactivity are highly concentrated amongst the less qualified. The chart shows the very high level of their non- employment - unemployment plus "inactivity" - and the great spread between the regions. In the south, 68% of the least-qualified quarter of the labour force (that is, those without school certificates or only modest vocational qualifications) have jobs. But in Merseyside only 40% of the least qualified have jobs. The regions doing badly in these terms include the West Midlands. Big job losses at Longbridge and in factories supplying motor manufacturing located in this area will make the situation much worse.

Lack of work in the regions is not confined to older workers who lost their jobs in the early 80s and 90s. The pattern of differences across regions shown in the chart is repeated across all age groups. In the south more than 71% of the worst educated 25-34 year olds have jobs. In Merseyside, however, the proportion is 43%. The figure is below 50% in Tyne and Wear. Chronic joblessness for the less qualified is being reproduced in the younger sections of the labour force. Again the phenomenon is not confined to small, concentrated areas - it is evident across England's old industrial regions and afflicts up to a million or more people of working age.

Chancellor Brown's paper says that there are now more vacancies in the regions than 10 years ago. But grave doubts need to be registered about the reliability of these regional vacancy statistics - as the Trades Union Congress has emphasised. There is also no evidence that the vacancies are suited to the skills of those without work. In any case they represent far fewer jobs in the regions than the number required to bring employment rates up to those in the more prosperous areas.

There has been a national recovery in jobs but it has failed to bring employment elsewhere closer to the southern level. The regional jobs deficit for the least qualified is more than 100,000 higher than in 1993, all the increase being for women. It would now take more than 800,000 additional jobs for the least-qualified quarter of the labour force to bring their employment rates across the country up to the level reached in the south.

Helping or persuading the long-term unemployed and inactive to search more effectively for work - the thrust of the government's policies - will not bring a proportionate rise in employment. Some vacancies might be filled more quickly if job seekers were more assiduous. But Say's Law (supply creates its own demand) does not apply to the less qualified in local labour markets. More jobs do not flow into depressed areas just because there are more people looking for them. The alternative of large-scale migration to the south is not feasible for the less qualified, even if it was desirable.

Spending more on physical infrastructure and education and training; relocating public-sector activities and procurement; making maximum use of regional assistance within the European Union's framework to persuade firms to locate in the regions; greater differentiation of council tax ... these are on the list of measures which might help raise regional employment. The point, however, is that the existence of a regional jobs problem should be honestly recognised by the government. There may be no easy solutions but that does not justify the pretence that regional joblessness is not a persisting problem.

Esra Erdem and Andrew Glyn are in the department of economics at Oxford University

fields.headline: The chart busters
fields.standfirst: First Britpop, then drum'n'bass, now UK garage: behind every popular band are the A&R scouts, hunting for acts who might repeat that success.  Adam Sweeting reports
fields.trailText: First Britpop, then drum'n'bass, now UK garage: behind every popular band are the A&R scouts, hunting for acts who might repeat that success. Adam Sweeting reports
fields.body:
We're not signing them...
The Bidding War is one of the hardy perennials of the record industry. In Britain, where musical activity is concentrated around a cluster of London-based record companies, everybody quickly finds out exactly what everyone else is doing, and which acts are being eyed up by whom. Every successful act, whether it's Oasis, the Spice Girls or Take That, instantly breeds its own school of imitators as the A&R scouts - the artist and repertoire scouts, almost always men, who decide which acts their company should sign - try to make lightning strike twice, or 25 times. With swarms of talent-spotters trying to sign up the same handful of artists, the asking price rapidly balloons to lunatic proportions.

Partly this is human nature. "It is a hothouse," confirms Steve Allen, who runs the pop and dance label Eternal under the sprawling multinational umbrella of WEA. "With something like garage music, which is happening at the moment, there's always the fear factor of missing out. It was like Britpop or drum'n'bass acts - every company had to have one. Most successful A&R guys are specialists in some area, but if they start dabbling elsewhere just because they're terrified of missing something that everybody else has got, it helps to stoke it up."

The boom in garage records has prodded the feeding-frenzy issue into the spotlight once again. In this case, "garage" doesn't mean rock'n'roll scruffs playing ancient Ramones riffs alongside the lawn mower and the Black & Decker Workmate. Instead it's the latest incarnation of ultimate dance cool, epitomised by discs like Artful Dodger's Rewind and Movin' Too Fast and DJ Luck & MC Neat's A Little Bit of Luck. The industry journal Music Week recently noted how garage's emergence from the underground "is leading to expensive bidding wars from major labels keen to capitalise on the trend."

Christian Tattersfield, managing director of East West records, obligingly owns up to the fact that "me and every joker" are"fighting away, paying too much". But never mind - even if these records turn out to have all the upward mobility of a lead-lined breezeblock, they can always be bundled together onto a compilation album, which will sell on the strength of a couple of headlining hits.

In the long run, however, putting the emphasis on cash over creativity doesn't do anybody any favours. Tony Portelli, managing director of cutting-edge garage label 4 Liberty, is exasperated by the tactics of the major companies. "Ninety per cent of the time the major labels get it wrong," he fumes. "They'll pay 150 grand for a single that sounds like it's from our scene, but then they'll spend as much as that marketing it to make it a hit because they have to chase that money. When it gets to number one, you've got the whole country singing along to a record that's awful, and it's seen as coming out of the UK garage scene. That's what we're worried about."

Portelli espouses the classic indie-with-integrity ethos for his label - "forward thinking A&R and long term artist development by independents will always match or better the majors and their cherry-picking tactics," he reasons - and he eulogises the potential of garage music like a man who has not only seen the promised land, but has already bought himself some real estate. "I think for the first time since Soul II Soul 10 years ago, Britain has really got something to shout about," he claims. "There's already a lot of club play of this music in America. If it's song-led and artist-led, it'll come through positively."

Portelli happens to be talking about garage music, but his attitude is an echo of many independent music-makers down the decades. From classic independent labels like Island or Atlantic to Rough Trade or Factory, the idea has always been to put the music first and let the artists develop at their own organic pace.

Most current A&R men aren't like the cocaine-addled buffoon with the bottomless expense account waving the corporate chequebook of popular mythology. The business will no longer tolerate the financial excesses of the 70s, when even journalists were showered with endless record company largesse. "The industry's much more businesslike," reckons Steve Allen. "We're run by accountants, aren't we? But I still think you need a little bit of arrogance and self-confidence, otherwise you couldn't do the job."

Nor, however, do they fit the image of the pioneering years of the record business, when the A&R man was a sympathetic character who made sure musicians were looked after financially and encouraged to do their best artistically.

And, despite Tony Portelli's optimism, finding artists who will be able to sustain a 10-year career looks increasingly like a game of pin-the-tail-on-the-donkey. It's every A&R man's dream to find an act like Radiohead, that will evolve over several albums, but they all accept that the industry's ever-shorter attention span and bias towards instant gratification make it decreasingly likely. "This year's Brit awards was sad, but it was a fair reflection of the year we had," says Steve Allen brutally. "We've got too many micro-celebrities and manufactured acts with not enough talent. What I find really disturbing and unhealthy is the way we pick up soap stars and make records with them."

Mark Fox, A&R consultant at RCA, notes the ways the A&R man's role has changed since he abandoned the musician's life (he used to be in Haircut 100, 80s champions of the cheesy grin and the chunky sweater.) He's well aware of the dance-records-and-compilations syndrome, but also stresses that the airbrushing and pre-packaging of pop acts has reached epidemic proportions.

"You find artists like Westlife or B*witched appearing more consistently, the auditioning, the honing down, the finding a marketing opportunity. You could say 'well that used to happen with Motown or the Monkees', but back then it used to be an aberration. Now it's a mainstay of the music industry."

Fox admits that his personal tastes in music run to "obscure Brazilian music and wild and reckless Norwegian free-form jazz", but he hopes that this kind of uneasy listening helps him bring "something left of centre to projects I'm working on. If I go home and listen to Five or Westlife, then I don't know what benefit I am to the process."

The online revolution which is starting to shake up the music business threatens to put increasing pressure on the big record companies, because it may offer independent labels a means to discover and develop artists without the need for the marketing and distribution facilities the majors can offer. Yet, simultaneously, the internet could offer the business a route back to the disenfranchised older listeners it has increasingly lost touch with.

"If there's a Q magazine website or a clickmusic.com that's suggesting musical possibilities, then that's quite invigorating, because it empowers those people to make decisions about music without suffering the embarrassment of going to a record shop," Fox believes. "I'm 41, and if somebody says to me 'you're old, therefore you'll like Leonard Cohen', they've completely misunderstood me. Now the whole online marketing strategy of harvesting data and getting people reacquainted with music is no bad thing."

It's a larcenous concept - older listeners seeking artists who offer artistic maturity and continuity gallop to the rescue of the ailing, infantile pop biz. A&R might even become a job for a grown man.

Great Moments in A&R:

1962: Decca's Dick Rowe turns down The Beatles, though he later denies making the much-quoted comment, "groups with guitars are on the way out."

1963: Decca's Dick Rowe signs The Rolling Stones, largely at the instigation of Beatle George Harrison.

1968: CBS president Clive Davis signs San Francisco band, Santana, and they release a string of bestselling albums.

1970: In a Los Angeles nightclub, Mick Jagger tells Ahmet Ertegun of Atlantic Records that the Stones want to be on Atlantic. Ertegun is so drunk that he falls asleep while Jagger is speaking. Nevertheless Atlantic pact with the Stones in 1971.

1972: Bruce Springsteen is signed to CBS records by mythic talent-spotter John Hammond, who had signed Billie Holiday, Bessie Smith, Aretha Franklin and Bob Dylan. Hammond is blown away by Springsteen's solo song-recital at his office piano. "I couldn't believe it," said Hammond. "I knew at once that he would last a generation."

1973: "We may have run to the end of our days with Bruce Springsteen. This is not an album we are going to put out." - CBS A&R chief Charlie Koppelman on Springsteen's second album, The Wild, the Innocent and the E Street Shuffle.

October 1976: EMI sign the Sex Pistols with a £40,000 advance.

January 1977: EMI drops the Sex Pistols. March 10 1977 - A&M sign Sex Pistols on a trestle table outside Buckingham Palace at 7am. March 16 1977 - A&M sack Sex Pistols with £75,000 pay-off. May 1977 - Virgin signs Sex Pistols for £15,000.

1982: to resolve an A&R wrangle over the signing of Matt Johnson (alias The The), CBS chairman Maurice Oberstein inks a deal with Johnson's manager, Stevo, while sitting on a stone lion in Trafalgar Square at midnight in pouring rain.

1990: Nirvana abandon hip Seattle label Sub Pop and sign to Geffen Records, who will release their seminal album Nevermind in 1991. A vintage turning-rebellion-into-money moment.

1992: Creation boss Alan McGee sees then-unknown Oasis play in Glasgow's King Tut's. Presciently, he reaches for his cheque book.

1995: Clive Davis, now chairman of Arista, signs Carlos Santana, and reignites the guitarist's stalled career with the multi-Grammy-winning Supernatural.
fields.bodyText: We're not signing them... The Bidding War is one of the hardy perennials of the record industry. In Britain, where musical activity is concentrated around a cluster of London-based record companies, everybody quickly finds out exactly what everyone else is doing, and which acts are being eyed up by whom. Every successful act, whether it's Oasis, the Spice Girls or Take That, instantly breeds its own school of imitators as the A&R scouts - the artist and repertoire scouts, almost always men, who decide which acts their company should sign - try to make lightning strike twice, or 25 times. With swarms of talent-spotters trying to sign up the same handful of artists, the asking price rapidly balloons to lunatic proportions. Partly this is human nature. "It is a hothouse," confirms Steve Allen, who runs the pop and dance label Eternal under the sprawling multinational umbrella of WEA. "With something like garage music, which is happening at the moment, there's always the fear factor of missing out. It was like Britpop or drum'n'bass acts - every company had to have one. Most successful A&R guys are specialists in some area, but if they start dabbling elsewhere just because they're terrified of missing something that everybody else has got, it helps to stoke it up." The boom in garage records has prodded the feeding-frenzy issue into the spotlight once again. In this case, "garage" doesn't mean rock'n'roll scruffs playing ancient Ramones riffs alongside the lawn mower and the Black & Decker Workmate. Instead it's the latest incarnation of ultimate dance cool, epitomised by discs like Artful Dodger's Rewind and Movin' Too Fast and DJ Luck & MC Neat's A Little Bit of Luck. The industry journal Music Week recently noted how garage's emergence from the underground "is leading to expensive bidding wars from major labels keen to capitalise on the trend." Christian Tattersfield, managing director of East West records, obligingly owns up to the fact that "me and every joker" are"fighting away, paying too much". But never mind - even if these records turn out to have all the upward mobility of a lead-lined breezeblock, they can always be bundled together onto a compilation album, which will sell on the strength of a couple of headlining hits. In the long run, however, putting the emphasis on cash over creativity doesn't do anybody any favours. Tony Portelli, managing director of cutting-edge garage label 4 Liberty, is exasperated by the tactics of the major companies. "Ninety per cent of the time the major labels get it wrong," he fumes. "They'll pay 150 grand for a single that sounds like it's from our scene, but then they'll spend as much as that marketing it to make it a hit because they have to chase that money. When it gets to number one, you've got the whole country singing along to a record that's awful, and it's seen as coming out of the UK garage scene. That's what we're worried about." Portelli espouses the classic indie-with-integrity ethos for his label - "forward thinking A&R and long term artist development by independents will always match or better the majors and their cherry-picking tactics," he reasons - and he eulogises the potential of garage music like a man who has not only seen the promised land, but has already bought himself some real estate. "I think for the first time since Soul II Soul 10 years ago, Britain has really got something to shout about," he claims. "There's already a lot of club play of this music in America. If it's song-led and artist-led, it'll come through positively." Portelli happens to be talking about garage music, but his attitude is an echo of many independent music-makers down the decades. From classic independent labels like Island or Atlantic to Rough Trade or Factory, the idea has always been to put the music first and let the artists develop at their own organic pace. Most current A&R men aren't like the cocaine-addled buffoon with the bottomless expense account waving the corporate chequebook of popular mythology. The business will no longer tolerate the financial excesses of the 70s, when even journalists were showered with endless record company largesse. "The industry's much more businesslike," reckons Steve Allen. "We're run by accountants, aren't we? But I still think you need a little bit of arrogance and self-confidence, otherwise you couldn't do the job." Nor, however, do they fit the image of the pioneering years of the record business, when the A&R man was a sympathetic character who made sure musicians were looked after financially and encouraged to do their best artistically. And, despite Tony Portelli's optimism, finding artists who will be able to sustain a 10-year career looks increasingly like a game of pin-the-tail-on-the-donkey. It's every A&R man's dream to find an act like Radiohead, that will evolve over several albums, but they all accept that the industry's ever-shorter attention span and bias towards instant gratification make it decreasingly likely. "This year's Brit awards was sad, but it was a fair reflection of the year we had," says Steve Allen brutally. "We've got too many micro-celebrities and manufactured acts with not enough talent. What I find really disturbing and unhealthy is the way we pick up soap stars and make records with them." Mark Fox, A&R consultant at RCA, notes the ways the A&R man's role has changed since he abandoned the musician's life (he used to be in Haircut 100, 80s champions of the cheesy grin and the chunky sweater.) He's well aware of the dance-records-and-compilations syndrome, but also stresses that the airbrushing and pre-packaging of pop acts has reached epidemic proportions. "You find artists like Westlife or B*witched appearing more consistently, the auditioning, the honing down, the finding a marketing opportunity. You could say 'well that used to happen with Motown or the Monkees', but back then it used to be an aberration. Now it's a mainstay of the music industry." Fox admits that his personal tastes in music run to "obscure Brazilian music and wild and reckless Norwegian free-form jazz", but he hopes that this kind of uneasy listening helps him bring "something left of centre to projects I'm working on. If I go home and listen to Five or Westlife, then I don't know what benefit I am to the process."
